HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Listening for A Scary Word: Depression

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
War and peace caught traders' attention last week, but the growing evidence of a deteriorating economy may yet have a bigger impact on securities prices.
"People have basically not concentrated on the domestic problems," said Stanley Shopkorn, a vice chairman and chief equity trader at Salomon Brothers. "They should." He is bearish, and thinks even a short and successful war would produce only a brief rally in stocks. 
 There are signs that the government officials with the most responsibility for dealing with financial problems are getting scared. Last week, L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said that while there are problems, the banking industry "is not, however, in a situation like the Great Depression, or anything like that magnitude."
Sometimes, more can be learned about what is going on from what officials choose to deny than from what they affirm. Not long ago, a statement that the difference between the 1930's and now was only one of "magnitude" would have been unthinkable.
Then on Friday, The New York Times reported that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, really would have liked the Fed to ease credit more quickly, but had allowed other Fed policy makers to keep policy tighter for too long. It is unusual, to say the least, for word to leak that a Fed chairman has not controlled monetary policy, and sounds suspiciously like a man seeking to avoid blame for a situation that is deteriorating far more rapidly than he ever expected.
The big question this time around is not whether the Fed should have started to ease a month or two sooner than it did, but whether the easing will work at all. "A depression is not a more severe case of a recession," says Ray Dalio, an economist who runs the Bridgewater Group, a money management firm. "It is an entirely different phenomenon."
In a depression, says Mr. Dalio, Fed easing does no good. The Fed can bring down interest rates and with them the cost of servicing debt, but incomes fall even faster and "you have self-reinforcing credit problems."
Mr. Dalio thinks this is a depression, but concedes he could be wrong. It is certainly a minority view among economists. The signs to watch, he says, will be whether the economy shows signs of responding to the Fed easing, and whether the savings rate starts to pick up. In the past, savings rates have risen in recessions and fallen in depressions.
Short-term interest rates tend to fall in both recessions and depressions, and are doing so now. with Treasury bill rates nearing 6 percent. The drop was accelerated last week by a flight to safety, which also sent the Dow Jones industrial average down 64.60 points, to 2,501.49.
This week, with Tuesday's deadline for an Iraqi pullout looming, the Mideast news may again dominate the market. But eventually traders will again focus on the economy, and its implications for corporate profits. They may not like what they see.

HEADLINE: Aquino's New Chief of Staff Is Raising Hopes in Manila

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA

 BODY:
The young and energetic Oscar Orbos, newly appointed executive secretary to President Corazon C. Aquino, is expected to work varying miracles on behalf of a faltering administration facing severe economic difficulties.
In his new job, which is sometimes called "the deputy presidency," he is Mrs. Aquino's John H. Sununu, in charge of coordinating the entire range of Government policy. 
 Mr. Orbos, a 39-year-old lawyer and former Congressman from Pangasinan Province in central Luzon, first came to general attention after a coup attempt in December 1989, which nearly succeeded. He was brought into the Cabinet, its youngest member, as Transportation Secretary, where he gained a quick reputation for action by displacing some vendors and getting traffic to flow a bit better on Manila's main streets.
Such an achievement was so unusual that some of Manila's multitude of columnists, always in search of something fresh, however diaphanous, started promoting him for the presidency.
 
Advice From Columnists
 In December 1990, after a confusing and badly coordinated effort to raise the prices of petroleum products held Mrs. Aquino up to further ridicule, she dismissed her longtime executive secretary, the drab Catalino Macaraig, and installed Mr. Orbos.
Columnists immediately started giving him advice. They suggested that his 7 A.M.-to-2 A.M. workdays would lead to burnout in a job that is impossible anyway.
In conversation, Mr. Orbos, universally known as Oca, has a better grasp of what is possible. Mrs. Aquino became President in 1986 saying she was only a housewife and could offer sincerity, honesty and her best efforts. Mr. Orbos promises little more.
But besides integrity and a "leaner, more efficient government," he does promise decisiveness, a quality that critics of Mrs. Aquino say she lacks.
"People say we need more leadership, and I agree," Mr. Orbos said. "But I don't think our problems will be resolved by 1992," when Mrs. Aquino's term ends and nationwide elections are to take place. "We're getting into rough seas. We're there already."
 
Urgency Called Lacking
 With a recession coming, a battle with the International Monetary Fund over deficits and economic restructuring, a possible war in the Persian Gulf and a consistently uneasy military, Mr. Orbos said, "the whole country needs to feel a sense of urgency we don't frankly feel."
Filipinos spend too much time "blaming others," whether the United States, the International Monetary Fund or someone else, he said, "or they look to the same forces to move the heavens and save us."
"We don't look to ourselves sufficiently," he said over a late dinner, with two more appointments yet to keep. "We have to realize we have only ourselves to depend on primarily. But I firmly believe we can pull it together and share the sacrifice in these rough seas."
It will be difficult, he admits, with only 16 months before the May 1992 elections, which Mrs. Aquino says she will not contest. At the moment, every office in the land will be at stake on the same day, and about half those in the 23-member Senate have talked about running for President. Potential candidates include the Senate President, Jovito Salonga, and the Speaker of the House, Ramon Mitra Jr.
So statesmanship is not likely to prevail in Congress, Mr. Orbos conceded. "But I told my colleagues in the House: 'Let's not belittle what we have. Let's not throw the onus all on the executive. Let's have more help from everyone.' "
 
Buying Time for Aquino
 Did they listen? Mr. Orbos smiled and shrugged. "Well, if they're looking for old patterns of politics here, they'll be sadly mistaken," he said. "Many ordinary people hate all this posturing for the presidency in the midst of this crisis. If Congress won't help, we'll go around them and rally the people."
Yet some diplomats suggest that Filipinos' expectations of this Government's being able to make a difference in their lives has fallen so low that it would be difficult to rally them now in great numbers for anything.
At this point, a senior Asian diplomat said, "the perception of movement is almost as important as movement itself."
"Orbos," he said, "buys her more time."
A senior Western diplomat said: "This is a Government that lives day to day, week to week. Orbos is very bright, with good political instincts. He comes in very late. But he can help her, and everyone basically wants him to succeed."
 
'Let's Do It Now'
 If Mr. Orbos, who does not lack ambition, can find some success, it will help his reputation, he acknowledges. And if he fails, it may not hurt him much, since many think that no real transformation is possible at this stage when Mrs. Aquino is perceived as a lame duck.
That is a view he strongly rejects. "Let's do it now," he said. "Why wait until '92?"
More is at stake than Mrs. Aquino's reputation, Mr. Orbos said. "I want to give her a boost, so that she will be judged by history in a kinder way, rather than go out sinking, causing us to sink downward, too."

HEADLINE: Trade Talks With Japan Face Stormy Reopening

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Trade negotiations between Japan and the United States, which resume here Thursday, are headed for rough weather.
At the talks in Tokyo, the agenda includes a review of an accord reached last summer to reduce the so-called structural impediments to trade. 
 Japan agreed to revise business practices to encourage competition and to increase spending on public works to stimulate demand for imports. The United States, for its part, promised to reduce the Federal budget deficit, deregulate certain industries and improve the quality of American education, all steps aimed at bolstering American competitiveness and producing goods that foreigners would want to buy.
While American negotiators have reported a growing peevishness within the Bush Administration about Japan's stance on various trade matters, a senior Japanese negotiator said this week that Japan was perplexed by the American failure to keep its promises of last summer.
 
'More Confrontations'
 "I very much anticipate more confrontations with the United States," a Japanese negotiator said. "We are very satisfied with our own responses to the United States, but we are not satisfied with the American replies."
In the next few weeks, in several "working group" sessions, the United States intends to take up what it regards as Japanese barriers to American exports of computers, semiconductors and paper products.
The Administration is also pressing Tokyo to ease restrictions on American lawyers and law firms in Japan, and to move faster to allow foreign banks and securities firms to compete on equal terms in Japanese financial markets.
There will also be another round of talks reviewing a 1988 Japanese pledge to open up 14 big Japanese construction projects to bidding by foreign companies. The Bush Administration charges that Japan has been slow to carry out the accord, and that it should open up more projects to foreign bids.
 
Teams of Negotiators
 The American negotiators at the structural impediment talks will be led by Richard T. McCormack, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs; S. Linn Williams, the deputy United States trade representative; J. Michael Farren, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade; and Charles Dallara, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs.
The Japan team includes Koji Watanabe, Deputy Minister for Foreign Affairs; Makoto Utsumi, Vice Minister for International Affairs at the Finance Ministry, and Naomichi Suzuki, Vice Minister for International Affairs at the Ministry for International Trade and Industry.
The following weekend the American delegates will go to Hakone, a resort near Mount Fuji, for talks on general issues of trade and economics. The Japanese side will again be led by Mr. Watanabe.
 
Frustration Over the Middle East
 American impatience over Japan's failure to send personnel to the Middle East after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has also increased frustrations.
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has committed $2 billion in assistance for the military buildup against Iraq and another $2 billion in economic aid for Jordan, Egypt and Turkey. But less than half of the money has actually been disbursed.
The United States is also unhappy with Japan over its tactics at the global trade talks in Geneva that collapsed last month. President Bush criticized Tokyo for blocking the Administration's efforts to reduce trade barriers and subsidies for farm products, including rice in Japan.
Mr. Bush said the opposition of Japan and the European Community was "all the more disappointing" because the world's poorest countries had offered to reduce import barriers in return for being able to sell their farm products to Europe and Japan.
 
Big Transit Project
 In the dispute over construction projects, Washington contends that the choice of a Japanese group to provide a transit system at the Kansai International Airport, outside Osaka in western Japan, was a slap at AEG Westinghouse Transportation Systems Inc., an American-German joint venture that has built several such systems.
After the American protest, the airport authorities awarded contracts to a group of American, Japanese and German companies to install a baggage-handling system. A Japanese official said he viewed the dispute as resolved. But American officials in Japan said they remained concerned about the bidding procedures used in awarding various airport contracts.
In the structural impediment talks, American officials said Japan's pledge to spend more than $3 trillion on public works in the next 10 years is on its way to being carried out. Such spending is being sought to spur consumer demand generally, and demand for imports specifically.
 
Bid-Rigging Charges
 But the United States contends that Tokyo is not going far enough in its proposal to punish companies guilty of bid-rigging and other anti-competitive practices, and Washington is also pressing the Japanese to introduce the concept of the rights of stockholders in Japanese companies.
The United States also wants Japan to make it easier for Japanese citizens to sue to punish companies guilty of antitrust behavior.
The Bush Administration is joining many critics of the Government in Japan in saying that Prime Minsiter Kaifu's proposal to increase the tax on land holdings, aimed at encouraging increased sales and development of land, is not sufficient to have any impact.
Japan, in addition to resisting these steps, has its own agenda of demands on the the United States, most notably a reduction in the Federal deficit. The budget deficit is regarded as hampering the American savings rate and undercutting industrial productivity.
Although President Bush accepted a deficit-reduction package last year that included tax increases, the Japanese seem unimpressed. "We appreciate the effort, but the result was nonsense," a Tokyo official said.
Japan also seeks greater American steps to ease antitrust laws and other business regulations, including abrogation of the ban on selling oil from the Alaskan pipeline to foreign countries. Japan also wants the Bush Administration to promise to block Congressional legislation that Tokyo considers adverse to foreign investment.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Crowds in European Cities Protest a War in Gulf Area

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Mobilized by leftist, environmental, pacifist and trade union groups, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched through the streets of major West European cities today to demand that force not be used against Iraq in Kuwait.
As part of an international day of action coordinated with antiwar groups in the United States and Japan, protests against the military buildup in the gulf were organized in Britain and France, which have sent troops to Saudi Arabia, as well as in Germany, Italy, Switzerland, Sweden and Norway. 
 The demonstrations appeared to reflect a surge of anxiety in Europe about a possible gulf war as the Jan. 15 deadline fixed by the United Nations for an Iraqi withdrawal approaches. Until now, protests against Western policy in the crisis have drawn minimal crowds.
 
Big March in Paris
 In France, where the Government is leading European efforts to find a diplomatic solution to the crisis, the largest turnout was in Paris, with more than 50,000 demonstrators marching from the Place de la Bastille to the St.-Augustin Church near President Francois Mitterrand's Elysee Palace.
A letter delivered to a Presidential aide by the protest organizers demanded that more time be allowed for economic sanctions to force Iraq to leave Kuwait. Max Gallo, a prominent member of Mr. Mitterrand's Socialist Party, said, "France has everything to lose in this absurd war."
At Chambery, in southeastern France, 100 protesters blocked a train with American military supplies destined for the gulf region. The train was delayed for 90 minutes.
Antiwar demonstrations were also held in Lyons, Marseilles, Bordeaux and dozens of smaller French cities.
In Britain, polls show considerable public support for the West's tough stance against Saddam Hussein. But the police in London estimated that 40,000 protesters marched from Hyde Park Corner to Trafalgar Square, where they were addressed by antiwar and antinuclear veterans like Tony Benn, a prominent leftist in the opposition Labor Party.
"Hundreds of thousands of innocent men, women and children could well be slaughtered by the most modern weapons, often manufactured by the same arms companies and supplied to both sides," he said. "The oil wells may well be set alight, causing a major environmental disaster for the whole region and beyond."
Smaller demonstrations were held in other British cities, including Glasgow, where the city's Roman Catholic Archbishop, Thomas Winning, said that war was not a legitimate option. "There may be a thief in Baghdad," he said, "but war is not the way to get him to surrender his booty."
 
Protests in Germany
 In Germany, 200,000 joined antiwar demonstrations organized by the Peace Cooperative Network in more than a dozen cities, including Berlin, Cologne, Stuttgart, Hamburg and Munich. In Bonn, small groups of protesters held a candle-light vigil outside the United States and Iraqi Embassies. In Frankfurt, one march ended outside the headquarters of the United States Army's Fifth Corps.
In Rome, the Italian Communist Party was the main organizer of an antiwar rally that drew a crowd of 30,000. "For oil, they want a massacre, this is the goal of the United States and NATO," some demonstrators shouted.
A few hours before this demonstration, Pope John Paul II told Rome-based diplomats accredited to the Vatican that "the time is more than ever for dialogue, negotiation, the pre-eminence of international law" because even a limited war, he said, would be "specially murderous, without taking into account the ecological, political, economic and strategic consequences."
 
Other Expressions
 Suggesting that such consequences were out of proportion to the results a gulf war could achieve, the Pope said that "by leaving intact the deep causes of violence in this part of the world, peace obtained by arms could only lead to new violence."
In Oslo, about 1,000 people carrying banners saying, "Iraq, Out of Kuwait" and "No Blood for Oil," marched past the United States Embassy. In Stockholm, a protest outside the American Embassy drew only about 200 people, the police said.
In Switzerland, where antiwar groups have urged the public to hang white sheets or cloths outside windows and doors to protest a possible gulf conflict, the bells of Protestant and Catholic churches are to ring together for peace on Sunday afternoon. Antiwar demonstrations have also been scheduled in other countries, including Spain, for Sunday.

HEADLINE: No Malaise, Please;
Reports by Dinkins and 3 Governors Focus on Silver Linings, Not Money

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
In major speeches in recent days, the Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and the Mayor of New York City assessed the generally grim state of their respective domains, looked into a future tempered by a souring economy and gaping holes in their budgets and tried to sound at least a little optimistic.
 Typically, their annual reports to constituents and inaugurals are laden with new goals and new programs, and all four officials, in their own way, seemed reluctant to disappoint their audiences. The speeches, which reflected on silver linings as well as dark clouds, opportunities as well as disappointments, were doubtless intended to shore up confidence in a region shaken by the loss of more than 100,000 jobs last year, plunging real-estate prices, growing social problems and no sign of a quick turnaround. But at a time when spending on vital programs will be cut -- sometimes deeply -- the leaders may have risked raising expectations to a level that cannot be fulfilled, and missed a chance to prepare constituents for the worst. 
 "You have a very bewildered electorate," said George Sternlieb, professor emeritus of urban and regional planning at Rutgers University, who found the speeches often at odds with the deteriorating economic and fiscal climate. "It was a lost opportunity."
The four speeches formed a kind of political continuum. On one end, in the view of Mr. Sternlieb and others, was Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York City, who arguably has the biggest problem -- a budget deficit estimated at up to $2.1 billion in the coming fiscal year and the need to combat rising violence and a sense of foreboding that shrouds his city -- but seemed the most optimistic.
 
'A Rebound Is Coming'
 The Mayor acknowledged he would have to cut the budget "to the bone," but insisted: "This is no time for despair."
"Though our prospects may seem dim at the moment, a rebound is coming," he said, "and it will be based on the wealth of resources that we sometimes, in our gloom, overlook."
Mr. Dinkins asked for tougher laws on juvenile crime and talked of a march on Washington for gun controls. But he did not mention probable changes among his senior aides, or dwell on labor agreements that had been criticized by the city's fiscal monitors. At several points, he sought to see positives in negatives, like falling real-estate prices that he said would make New York City a cheaper place in which to do business.
Mr. Dinkins, Mr. Sternlieb said, "basically seems to be under a misapprehension that this is 1988. He's sort of frozen in past grandeur."
 
'No Broken-Field Running'
 Elected Governor last fall, Lowell P. Weicker Jr. was not around as Connecticut's deficit widened alarmingly. It is now projected to be a bigger percentage of spending than the gap Mr. Dinkins must close. Yet in his short inaugural the former Senator declared: "So let's get this deficit business done -- and fast. No broken-field running, ladies and gentlemen, straight into the line. We take our licks so that we can restore the caring and quality of life that is Connecticut."
And while he was at it, Mr. Weicker said he stood by his commitment "to rekindle business in Connecticut, to save and expand jobs, to generate the revenues to turn this state around."
He did not say exactly how he intended to do all this, but his language suggested that Connecticut might not long be among the 10 states without an income tax.
"This is a wonderful year for raw truth," said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in an address combed for signs of a Presidential bid. "We don't have any money."
He talked about goals not now affordable, like a longer school year; programs others would pay for, like an expansion of child-care services to be financed largely with Federal money; initiatives for which financing was not specified, like new funds for transportation and environmental projects, and laws that would require little or no new money, like a ban on assault weapons.
"Basically, he became a born-again conservative with a heart," said Mitchell L. Moss, head of the Urban Research Center at New York University, who declared the Governor's speech his best since his address to the 1982 Democratic national convention.
Social-service advocates, however, worried about the declining purchasing power of welfare grants and Albany's commitment to AIDS programs.
Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, for his part, acknowledged that he may have moved too fast in raising taxes by $2.8 billion. But having made their investment, taxpayers would now reap dividends, he said, on auto-insurance and property-tax bills.
He also spoke of creating 7,000 new jobs through an increase in state highway and other construction, reduced-cost mortgages for first-time home buyers, health-care programs for uninsured hospital patients and a doubling of resources for child care, though he was not specific about how some of this would be financed.
 
Florio Calls Taxes Farsighted
 Mr. Florio maintained that last year's rise in the sales tax and income-tax rates for the wealthy had been necessary and farsighted, but acknowledged that New Jersey could not "tax its way out of a troubled economy."
In what came to be called his "national malaise" speech of 1979, Jimmy Carter proved how dangerous it can be for a politician to traffic in gloom. Then again, Mr. Cuomo's predecessor, Hugh L. Carey, took office declaring that the "days of wine and roses are over."
"I understand the impulse to remain optimistic," said Richard Ravitch, the former head of the Metropolitan Transportaton Authority who ran for mayor last year. "You've got to give people some sense of confidence that the world is not going to end."
Pessimism can also unsettle nervoous credit markets. Still, Mr. Ravitch and Mr. Sternlieb both said the politicians should have been sounding fiscal alarms earlier.
"The longer you tell them happy stories," Mr. Sternlieb said, "the greater the shock of landing."
For all four politicians, though, days of reckoning are approaching. They must soon submit budgets in which bad news will be inescapable.

HEADLINE: Hopeful E.P.A. Report Fans a Debate as Talks on Warming Near

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency says that at a time when most other countries have only pledged to take action, the United States has already taken steps that will keep emissions of heat-trapping atmospheric gases at current levels for the next two decades.
The conclusions are playing a crucial role in the United States' preparations for an international conference in Washington next month to negotiate a treaty to control emissions of the gases, which scientists say could cause a catastrophic warming of the Earth in the 21st century. 
 More than 20 industrialized countries have committed themselves to stabilizing or reducing emissions of carbon dioxide, the gas that would play the largest role in the warming. The Bush Administration has opposed such a target for carbon dioxide, arguing that the extent of the problem is too uncertain.
 
Reliability Is Questioned
 The E.P.A. study is already generating argument. Some critics question its reliability and assail it as a ploy to justify what they see as the Administration's go-slow policy on global warming. They say that even if the findings are reliable, enough of the gases are already in the atmosphere to require stronger action. Scientists say, further, that a substantial reduction in emissions will be required if the global concentration of the gases is to be stabilized at current levels.
But William K. Reilly, the E.P.A. Administrator, said in an interview that the study showed that the United States had already acted to stabilize its overall contribution to warming. Mr. Reilly has long advocated emissions targets, provided they encompass all the implicated gases, not just carbon dioxide.
Atmospheric concentrations of the gases are steadily rising as a result of human activity. Scientists say that because they trap heat much as a greenhouse does, they could cause drastic climatic changes in the next century.
Some experts on the international politics of global warming say the findings of the agency's report could prompt the United States to drop its objection to targets. In this view, Washington might recapture leadership on the issue of global warming if it proposed an overall target that included all the gases implicated in global warming -- a target that the E.P.A. study suggests it could meet.
 
Sununu Opposes Targets
 "If they don't do it, they're going to have a very hard time getting back in the game seriously, in terms of playing a leading role in shaping an international approach," said William Nitze, a former State Department official who was responsible for coordinating Government policy on global warming and who represented the United States in international meetings on the subject. He left the Administration last September to become president of the nonprofit Alliance to Save Energy, based in Washington.
Whether the Administration will now embrace targets in light of the report's finding remains to be seen. The idea has considerable support among officials of Government agencies who are discussing what the United States' stance should be, Administration officials say. But higher officials, including John H. Sununu, the President's chief of staff, have successfully opposed any targets in the past. Mr. Sununu said through an aide that he was aware of the report but would not comment on it.
Mr. Reilly says that while the study is not yet "fully researched" or scientifically reviewed, "it's the best we have."
Recently adopted measures that the E.P.A. study says will limit the United States contribution to the greenhouse effect include these measures:
*Provisions of the new Clean Air Act amendments that will slow carbon dioxide emissions.
*Recent energy-saving measures mandated by the Department of Energy, including efficiency standards for appliances, the development of energy-saving building codes, and initiatives to expand hydroelectric power, promote solar energy and stimulate greater efficiency by the electric-power industry.
*The phasing out of chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's. These chemicals, used as refrigerants, solvents and propellants, are being abandoned primarily because they destroy the ozone layer that protects living things from ultraviolet radiation. But they also are even more powerful and long-lived heat-trappers than carbon dioxide.
According to a report on the study by Alex Cristofaro, director of the agency's air and energy policy division, researchers calculated the effect of the recent Government measures on emissions of the various greenhouse gases. It converted all the gases to carbon-dioxide equivalents, in terms of heat-trapping capacity.
It found that the United States contribution to the greenhouse effect, expressed in carbon-dioxide equivalents, would be about the same in 2000 as in 1987, and that it would either drop slightly or show an increase of about 4 percent by 2010. This could change, the study said, if the new Government measures do not materialize as expected or if the economy grows faster than expected.
 
Can It Be Painless?
 One Government official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, said that the study's conclusion means that "the problem is possibly less intractable than it might appear at first glance." He said it suggests that "we could quite painlessly" take further action to limit greenhouse emissions over the next few years.
Environmental skeptics doubt that a United States pledge to stabilize its overall greenhouse emissions by the year 2000 would be a sufficient response. "It would still be a considerably weaker position than that adopted by the Europeans," said Michael Oppenheimer, a senior scientist and expert on global warming at the Environmental Defense Fund, an environmental research and advocacy group.
He said the Europeans have committed themselves to capping or reducing carbon dioxide emissions. "In addition," he said, "they will do the same as we're doing with CFC's, namely, eliminate them." Most of the world's nations have agreed to halt production of CFC's by the end of this decade.
The E.P.A. study shows that carbon dioxide emissions in the United States would continue to grow over the next two decades, even though this nation's overall contribution to the greenhouse effect would stabilize.
Moreover, Dr. Oppenheimer said, overall greenhouse emissions by the United States would resume their growth after CFC's have been eliminated if no further action is taken. "In my opinion," said Dr. Oppenheimer, "the U.S. is trying to pull the wool over everyone's eyes under the guise of stabilizing greenhouse emissions."
Mr. Reilly, a career environmentalist before he joined the Bush Administration, has consistently advocated targets to stabilize or reduce overall greenhouse emissions. By setting overall targets, he argues, individual countries are afforded more flexibility.

HEADLINE: Rising Personal and Public Toll In New England Economic Plunge

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARDNER, Mass., Jan. 11

 BODY:
For decades, Gardner has called itself "Chair City," for the furniture factories that dominated its economy.
But that was before Conant Ball shut down with a loss of 105 jobs, before Gem Industries closed its rambling old red brick mill, laying off 110 workers, before Temple Stuart went out of business, idling 400 workers, and before Collier-Keyworth closed its factory, eliminating 450 jobs -- all in the past two years. 
 "It's scary; it's like unemployed people are coming out of the sky, there are so many of them," said Arlene Morin, who had been a furniture assembler at Temple Stuart for 17 years in this city of 20,000 people in north-central Massachusetts.
 
A Regional Calamity
 In the past year unemployment in Gardner has more than doubled, to 11.4 percent, the fastest loss of jobs for any area of the country, according to the United States Department of Labor. So widespread has been the effect of the downturn that not long ago a banker in his 50's and his son, a public school teacher in his mid-20's, were laid off at the same time.
Although Gardner's job losses are extreme, its situation reflects the economic freefall throughout the six states of New England: Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Vermont. While the rest of the nation has just entered what many economists believe will be a mild recession, New England has been in an economic slump for nearly two years and has now plummeted into what regional economists say is a severe recession.
The economic calamity has made a mockery of what had been called the Massachusetts Miracle, the extraordinary growth in the 1980's that had served as former Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's platform in his 1988 Presidential campaign.
"It wasn't a miracle, but an apparition," said Richard F. Syron, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston.
In the past two years, New England has lost 254,000 jobs, a decline of 4 percent, and currently accounts for one fifth of all the jobs being lost in the United States, though the region accounts for only 5.5 percent of the country's population, said Wayne Ayers, chief economist for the Bank of Boston.
Housing prices in Boston, which had been the highest in the country three years ago, have dropped 20 percent to 30 percent, real estate agents say. Commercial real estate values have fallen as much as 50 percent. And business failures increased 193 percent in New England last year, as against 14.5 percent nationwide, according to the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation.
In recent days the area's misery was symbolized by the failure of the Bank of New England, once the area's second-largest bank, which was taken over by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation after it was forced into insolvency by bad real estate loans.
In Rhode Island, 15 banks and credit unions that were part of the state's private insurance fund that failed two weeks ago remain closed. Despite a program to set up a new fund, Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun, a Democrat, estimated that one quarter of the depositors may never regain their money.
 
Coping With Anxiety
 The reversal in the region's fortunes, coming so swiftly and sharply, has had an intense psychological effect. Last fall the Consumer Confidence Index in New England, measured by the Conference Board in New York, plunged to the lowest level ever recorded for any area of the country.
William Roiter, a psychologist and vice president of Hurst Associates, which offers counseling to businesses in the Boston area, said that since last summer he has seen an abrupt shift in the main concern of white-collar workers. In the 1980's they worried about coping with stress, he said, but now their concern is coping with depression and anxiety.
"The difference is that with stress, people come in and say they have too much to do and not enough time to do it in," Dr. Roiter said. "Now people feel like they are losing things -- losing status, or jobs and homes. That's very frightening for people."
The economic downturn has caused a sharp drop in tax revenues, contributing to budget crises in all six states. The situation is most critical in Massachusetts and Rhode Island, where the shortfall between revenues and spending is at least 12 percent of their total budgets. Connecticut ranks third, with a shortfall of about 9.5 percent.
In Massachusetts, the crisis has already led to cuts of 20 percent in spending for the state's colleges and universities. "The mood is one of discouragement," said Joseph Duffey, chancellor of the University of Massachusetts, where the faculty has been reduced by 160 positions since 1988 and several senior administrators have resigned in the past two weeks to accept other jobs.
In Maine, the battle over the budget is so intense that Gov. John R. McKernan Jr., a Republican, has threatened to "engage in one-man rule," unilaterally cutting all state spending by 15 percent. State Representative Joseph May, the House majority whip and a Democrat, has denounced the plan as "financial martial law."
 
'A Very Strange Recession'
 In examining New England's troubles, some economists are particularly troubled by the nature of the recession. "The real issue is that it's a very strange recession because it involves a shrinkage of non-cyclical parts of the economy that are usually resistant to recession," said Gary Ciminero, chief economist for Fleet/ Norstar Financial Group, the large banking holding company in Providence, R.I.
Mr. Ciminero said he believes that the recession began in the region's overexpanded real estate and construction business and spread quickly to other, usually more stable sectors like services, retail trade and public employment. "This is bad news indeed," he said, "because after they've shrunk, they don't plant the seeds for their own recovery, as usually happens in a recession when jobs contract and wages drop. It's like a sweater that has shrunk."
In Gardner, Dick Batt had worked for 30 years as an engineer in the now-shuttered Collier-Keyworth plant. As the town grew in recent years, spurred by the addition of families who commute to the high-technology industries nearer Boston, Mr. Batt, 60 years old, had grown accustomed to a middle-class life, including ski trips with his children and regular dinners out with his wife and friends.
"Now we find ourselves avoiding going out in groups, because we don't want to be in the situation where we have to buy cocktails," said Mr. Batt, who is still looking for work. "We can't afford them any more."
Mr. Batt is fortunate that he owns his house, with only a small mortgage, but he is fast using up his retirement savings to pay for medical insurance.
Lisa Pepper, a 21-year-old resident of nearby Winchendon, had managed a store that sold overhead doors until it was closed last January as the construction business dried up. Her husband, a carpenter, was laid off for much of the year. She has been busy sending out resumes, but has found that often there are 300 applicants for any job opening.
"It's discouraging to be caught up in this turmoil, competing with all these other people for that one job," she said.
 
$8.50 an Hour at McDonald's
 Karl E. Case, a professor of economics at Wellesley College in Wellesley, Mass., said he believed that the real estate boom of 1984 to 1986, when New England's economy was growing fastest, "did serious damage to our economy." Most of the new jobs added in Massachusetts in those years came in construction and among people rushing to become real estate brokers, he said That helped to drive the state's unemployment rate down to 2.4 percent and to push wages up.
"Labor was so scarce that McDonald's had to pay $8.50 an hour to get workers," Professor Case said. At the same time manufacturing was shrinking, though with little public notice, "so we had the fiction of a boom, but it was not about our core economy"
The labor shortage pushed wages in Massachusetts well above the national average, which along with the high cost of housing led companies to stop investing in the area. While housing costs have fallen sharply since their peak in 1988, New England remains "the least affordable area" of the country, said Sara Johnson, managing economist at DRI/McGraw Hill in Lexington, Mass.
Several economists project that the region's recession will continue through the end of this year, with the loss of another 100,000 jobs. Then, assuming that the national economy recovers from its recession and that the Persian Gulf crisis does not produce a prolonged war, New England would see "a very gradual recovery" starting in 1992, Mr. Ayers said.
But Ms. Johnson of DRI cautioned that because "New England got a head start on the recession and because it has been in recession longer, so it will be longer and deeper here." And the national recovery must come first, she said, because the orders and investment to stimulate New England's economy must come from outside the region. She estimated that in the first half of the 1990's New England would grow slower than the rest of the country, with growth returning to the national average around 1995 as its wage and housing costs come more into line with those elsewhere.
But Mr. Syron, of the Federal Reserve Bank, cautioned against writing the region off, saying, "There is an extraordinary lack of perspective about the New England economy."
In December, unemployment in Massachusetts rose to 7.4 percent, according to the United States Labor Department, the highest of any of the major industrial states and almost double the 4 percent figure at the end of 1989. But, Mr. Syron noted, in the recession of 1973-74, unemployment in the state reached nearly 12 percent.
 
Question of Perceptions
 In the earlier recession, he said, "everyone was sure New England would end up as the world's biggest bird sanctuary," as the region's traditional industries like leather, shoes and textiles shriveled. Then in the mid-1980's, with the computer business along Route 128 outside Boston and the jet engine and submarine factories in Connecticut booming, "everyone was sure New England would go on forever being a perpetual prosperity machine."
Now, everyone is again convinced that New England is finished, he said, although it is still the wealthiest in the country in per capita income. In addition, he said, "we still have an edge in the basic research infrastructure, the universities, that will contribute to the revival of the region."
Largely as an outgrowth of research in schools like the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, New England has 15 percent of the nation's 22,000 emerging high-technology companies, Mr. Ayers said. Some of those companies, in fields like biotechnology, computer software and environmental control systems, could do for the area in the 1990's what makers of minicomputers did in the 80's.
But, he added, biotechnology companies in Massachusetts now employ only 7,000 people. So these new companies are likely to be smaller than the computer giants and will take time to grow.

HEADLINE: Design Your Own Games, Monopoly Rivals Told

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
In what could be characterized as an anti-antitrust action, the makers of Monopoly, the board game, have filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan, seeking to maintain their monopoly on their famous game board.
"They should go directly to jail," said Arthur Greenbaum, a lawyer representing Parker Brothers, conceding that the quip was a bit obvious. Mr. Greenbaum was referring to a California-based company that is marketing Big Appleopoly, as well as 70 other municipalopolies, including Bostonopoly, San Diegoopoly, San Franciscoopoly, Torontoopoly and even Berlinopoly. 
 "This is crazy," said Arthur Mitchell, vice president of Cityopoly, the company in El Cajon, Calif., that manufactures the rival games. In them, players do not buy the real estate in Monopoly, but with a roll of the dice and for a few fake dollars, acquire such enterprises as the Plaza Hotel ($400), the Four Seasons restaurant ($300) or New York Telephone ($200).
"What is the difference if we're making this game," Mr. Mitchell said, "when other companies have marketed Farmopoly, Medical Monopoly, Legal Monopoly, Anti-Monopoly?" -- not to mention Worldopoly, Europopoly, Condoopoly and even Rockopoly.
 
Streets of Dreams
 "The answer," Mr. Greenbaum said, "is we don't object to anyone using 'opoly.' There are other games out there that we do not object to. But this company takes all of the Monopoly indicia -- the things that are synonyms, in a sense, for the Monopoly game -- and they've copied our game."
Parker Brothers, based in Beverly, Mass., has sold more than 100 million Monopoly sets since it bought the game from an unemployed heating engineer, Charles B. Darrow, in 1935. Mr. Darrow used Atlantic City's thoroughfares as his Depression-era streets of dreams.
Mr. Mitchell said Cityopoly has sold "a few hundreds of thousands" of its games in the last two years.
From the word "Go," Mr. Greenbaum insisted, similarities between the two are striking. In Big Appleopoly, "Go," becomes "Start," with the underline reading, "$200 Reward As You Pass."
 
The Same Colors
 "They've taken the same colors for the properties," Mr. Greenbaum added. "We have Boardwalk as the blue property; they have the Plaza as their blue property. The price for the properties is the same. The money is in the same denominations and the same colors.
"We have 'Go to Jail.' They have 'Go to Sing Sing.' We have 'In Jail' and 'Just Visiting.' They have 'In Sing Sing' and 'Just Visiting.' They even use our famous green houses and red hotels."
Mr. Mitchell cited some of the same examples to insist that the games were different. "I don't see how they're the same," he said. "They have 'Go.' We have 'Start.' We don't 'Go to Jail.' You 'Go to Sing Sing.'
"The rules aren't even the same," he continued. "With us, you build high-rises and buildings, you buy and trade businesses, not real estate. This is an entrepreneur's game."
 
Suing for an Injunction
 Mr. Greenbaum, of the law firm of Cowan, Liebowitz & Latman, said the suit was filed on Tuesday. "We don't know what their sales have been," he said.
"We're certainly suing for an injunction to make them stop, and for an accounting," Mr. Greenbaum said. "We want them, as we lawyers say, to disgorge their unjust enrichment."
Mr. Mitchell said there was precedent for like-designed games on the market. "Pictionary is a game where you draw a picture and people try to figure out what it is," he said. "Win, Lose or Draw is a game where you draw a picture and people try to figure out what it is. And they both sell in the same stores, side by side."
Pointing out one significant difference, Mr. Mitchell said, "Our game is even more expensive -- $24.95 retail." Monopoly costs between $10 and $15.
The Mayor of Atlantic City, James A. Whelan, assumed a posture of parochial pride in his city's "good symbiosis" with the Parker Brothers product. "There's only one Atlantic City and only one Monopoly," the Mayor said. "Boardwalk is Boardwalk and Park Place is Park Place. We've got 'em. Monopoly's got 'em. And nobody else is ever going to have 'em."

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
CONGRESS ACTS TO AUTHORIZE WAR IN GULF; MARGINS ARE 5 VOTES IN SENATE, 67 IN HOUSE

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
After three days of solemn, often eloquent debate, Congress today voted to give President Bush the authority to go to war against Iraq.
The Senate approved the use of military force by a vote of 52 to 47. The majority included 42 Republicans and 10 Democrats, mostly Southerners who were convinced that economic sanctions would not force Iraq from Kuwait or who were unwilling to vote against the President. Two Republicans joined 45 Democrats in opposing force. 
 In the House, the vote was a more comfortable 250 to 183, as 164 Republicans and 86 Democrats voted for force, while 179 Democrats, 3 Republicans and 1 independent were opposed.
 
'All Necessary Means'
 The measure, the Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Iraq Resolution, said Mr. Bush was authorized "to use United States armed forces pursuant to United Nations Security Council Resolution 678," which authorized member nations to use "all necessary means" against Iraq if did not withdraw from Kuwait by midnight Tuesday, Eastern standard time.
Mr. Bush asked Congress for this declaration last Tuesday, and its passage removed the last political obstacle to an attack by United States-led forces against Iraqi troops occupying Kuwait.
Under the terms of the resoluton, before force may be used Mr. Bush must send a message to Congressional leaders saying that diplomacy and sanctions will not be effective in geting Iraq out of Kuwait. [Excerpts from the debate and roll-calls of the votes, page 10; excerpts from the debated resolutions, page 11.]
 
'Last Best Chance for Peace'
 At a news conference immediately after the votes, President Bush said the action by Congress "unmistakably demonstrates the United States's commitment to enforce a complete Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait."
The President added that he was inclined to order military action against Iraq "sooner rather than later," but suggested that he might hold back if President Saddam Hussein began a large-scale withdrawal from occupied Kuwait before Tuesday. [Page 8.]
Just before the Senate voted, Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, said the time to authorize the use of force had come. "Let's not pull the rug out from under the President when the pressure is building on Saddam Hussein by the minute," he said. "Let's don't give him any relief."
 
Foley Favored Sanctions
 The losing argument for continued reliance on sanctions was voiced by Speaker Thomas S. Foley in a rare speech to the House. He said all members owed Mr. Bush their "informed and reasoned judgment." And he said, "If you believe that more can be done, if you believe that Saddam Hussein is growing weaker every day, if you believe that the coalition will hold," then members should vote to continue reliance on sanctions and not support force now.
Their comments were just two examples of a remarkably full, thoughtful debate by more than 268 Representatives and 93 Senators, many of whom waited until the early hours this morning for a chance to go on the record. And today, both chambers usually had majorities of the members sitting and listening as the final arguments were offered.
Today's action was the first time since Aug. 7, 1964, when the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution was adopted, that Congress had voted directly for offensive military action. But today's votes were far closer than the 88-2 Senate margin or the 414-0 result in the House for the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, which was cited for years afterward by foes and supporters of the war effort as Congress's critical move.
The last time Congress was comparably divided in deciding to go to war was with its votes to launch the War of 1812; the House voted 79 to 49 in favor and the Senate followed, 19 to 13.
 
Sanctions Lost in First Votes
 Before voting for force, each House foreshadowed its crucial decision by defeating resolutions urging continued reliance on sanctions.
In the Senate, the vote was 53 to 46, with only 1 Republican, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, joining 45 Democrats in the losing effort. In the House, the vote was 250 to 183, with 179 Democrats, 3 Republicans and 1 independent in favor and 164 Republicans and 86 Democrats opposed.
The House also passed, 302-131, a measure reasserting Congress's exclusive constitutional authority to declare war.
But whatever resolution was formally before the House or the Senate, the arguments seemed interchangeable, whether for force or for sanctions, for support of the President or the United Nations, or warning of the costs in lives or dollars, or complaining of the level of support from other nations.
 
'How Can We Turn Our Backs?'
 Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the minority leader, said: "President Bush has openly and forthrightly asked for our help. How can we turn our backs on him?"
Representative David E. Bonior, Democrat of Michigan, urged members to "pause before you cast your vote."
"Ask the same question that thousands of Americans are asking their families today," he said. "Is this the cause for which you would ask your son or daughter to risk their life?"
Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, who got his political start running a campaign based on opposition to the Vietnam War, said the circumstances were fundamentally different today.
 
'Economic Jugular of the World'
 He urged support for the use-of-force resolution that he took the leading role in writing and said, "If we prevail, we will have prevented a brutal dictator from getting his hands on the economic jugular of the world."
Mr. Foley and Dante B. Fascell, the chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, who supported the authorization to use force, each warned members not to think of the vote as anything less than the equivalent of a declaration of war.
But William H. Broomfield of Michigan, the senior Republican on the Foreign Affairs Committee, argued that today's vote was a vital diplomatic bargaining chip that might persuade Iraq to quit Kuwait.
In the Senate, Mr. Dole predicted that today's votes would be the last chance to persuade Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Iraq. He said it was the time "to send the mesage that we want a peaceful world."
 
'Defining Moment in Our History'
 Representative Jim Slattery, Democrat of Kansas, said "Saddam Hussein will not see our threat as real" until Congress votes to authorize force. Predicting victory for the resolution authorizing force, he said "today is a defining moment in our history."
Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the chairman of the Armed Services Committee, argued that with sanctions weakening Iraq: "We are playing a winning hand. I see no compelling reason to rush to military action."
Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, said that the greatest risk in supporting force is the loss of human life. "How many people will die? How many young Americans will die? And for the families of those young Americans who die, for every one of us, the truly haunting question will be, did they die unnecessarily?"
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, scorned the other members of the anti-Iraq coalition, "a coalition that has allowed us to take on 95 percent of the sacrifice across the board."
 
$2 Billion a Day for War
 Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, called Japan's $4 billion contribution "paltry" and said that if war came it would cost $2 billion a day at a time when scarce tax dollars "are needed to solve problems at home, to rebuild the strength of this country, to get American ready to compete as a world leader in the next century."
"We can't even get countries like Japan to pay their pledged share," said Representative Mary Rose Oakar of Ohio.
Before voting on the competing issues of war and sanctions, the House adopted the resolution asserting the exclusive authority of Congress to declare war and insisting that Congressional authorization was required for any offensive actions against Iraq.
The resolution won the support of 260 Democrats, 41 Republicans, and one independent, and was opposed by 126 Republicans and 5 Democrats.
 
Significance for the Future
 One of its sponsors, Representative Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, said the resolution was important, not perhaps for the moment, but for the future. "Over the long term," he said in an interview after the vote, "it was a major statement by the House about its relationship with the White House."
Throughout the day, Senators and Congressmen spoke of their votes as the most important they would cast in their careers, and compared them to others. Representative Charles E. Bennett, Democrat of Florida and a Silver Star veteran of World War II, said that "Out of the 17,000 votes I have cast, the only one I really regret was the one I cast for the Bay of Tonkin Resolution."
Today the 80-year-old lawmaker urged opposition to war, but told his younger colleagues "a vote ought to be cast on the basis of what you think is best for our country, not best for the Republican or the Democratic Party, not best for the President, not best for you, but what's best for our country and what's best for the world."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
The Road to Bank Reform May Be Bumpy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AMERICA'S banking system is in serious trouble, and a consensus has developed in the White House, in the Capitol, on Wall Street and on Main Streets across the land that something must be done in Washington to change the laws that govern the banks. The laws, written during the Great Depression, are obsolete.
Congress was told last week that the fund that insures deposits is barely solvent. And the top regulators said that many more large banks would surely fail, as the Bank of New England did last weekend, if the flagging economy does not rebound within a few months. 
 While most authorities do not think a disaster like the one that hit the savings and loan industry is in the offing, the prevailing view is that the banks will never thrive again unless the 60-year-old rules that sharply limit how and where they can operate are overhauled. But there is no consensus on exactly what to do. There is also serious doubt whether the political leadership to bring change to such an entrenched system exists in the White House, in the Treasury and on two key Congressional committees, where one chairman, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., is tied up in an ethics investigation and another, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, is unusually unpopular; a third of his Democratic colleagues voted to remove him from his chairmanship.
With the country on the brink of war, no one would expect President Bush or Congress to be focusing on banking issues, as important as they are. But this is a matter politicians have failed to address for years, ever since Richard M. Nixon tried unsuccessfully and half-heartedly more than 20 years ago to lift some of the restraints on bank operations.
Insurance companies, investment firms, brokerage houses and even credit unions are also weakened. In those industries and in banks as well, bad management caused some of the problem, and market forces like declining real estate prices much of the rest. But outmoded Government rules are contributing factors and Mr. Bush has promised that legislation to restructure the financial system will be his top domestic priority in 1991. A year ago, he instructed the Treasury Department to develop the policy. Now, barely two weeks before the President is to outline the legislative proposal in his State of the Union message, the Treasury still has not finished many of the details.
But the basic principles are clear: The package will include measures to shore up the deposit insurance fund, which is expected to lose $5 billion this year, entering 1992 with just $4 billion in assets; in one form or another, these measures will probably be enacted, and individual deposits of $100,000 or less will continue to be protected completely against loss. Other provisions of the legislation would break down the 60-year-old barriers that now keep commercial banks, investment houses and securities companies out of each other's businesses and prevent banks from opening branches nationwide; these measures are less certain to be approved. Finally, the Administration wants to consolidate overlapping Federal supervision that is now divided among several agencies; if the regulators can agree among themselves on consolidation, Congress may go along.
All that is a large mouthful for Congress to swallow. Dozens of different groups will have to be mollified. Regional divisions will have to be bridged. Many lawmakers fear that letting banks get into new lines of business would repeat the mistake that led to the savings and loan mess. (Administration officials deny this, saying banks are better capitalized and better regulated.) Overcoming these obstacles will require enormous political skills.
Congress is rarely confronted with legislation of this scope. The last time was in the mid-1980's when Ronald Reagan proposed revamping the entire income tax system. Mr. Reagan threw his personal popularity and the full weight of his Administration behind the effort. The drive was led by James A. Baker 3d, then Treasury Secretary, and Richard G. Darman, then his deputy, both masterful political tacticians. In Congress, two powerful committee chairmen, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, and Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, were basically on the Administration's side.
The principle figures on the banking issue do not seem to have equivalent political skills or authority. Even before the Persian Gulf crisis, Mr. Bush paid less attention to domestic matters, and had less influence on them, than Mr. Reagan did.
 
Brady Too Diffident?
 Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who will command the Administration's troops in the fight for the banking legislation, is viewed in Congress as too diffident to be an accomplished legislative power-broker. His chief aide, Under Secretary Robert R. Glauber, is a specialist in finance who has little political experience.
The Administration official in the banking area who has the most influence with Congress is L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. But as an independent regulator he must avoid political activities like lobbying. Moreover, Mr. Seidman's habit of straight-talking, which has made him popular in the Capitol, has lessened his authority within the Administration, where he is seen as unpredictable and unreliable.
The chairmen of the Banking Committees, Senator Riegle of Michigan and Representative Gonzalez of Texas, both Democrats, may not, say some of their colleagues, have the stature or the capacity to handle monumental legislation. Mr. Riegle is one of the five senators whose dealings with Charles H. Keating Jr., a symbol of the savings and loan debacle, are under investigation by the Ethics Committee. The inquiry has sapped Mr. Riegle's political strength, other senators say.
 
A 'Leaden Autocrat'
 The word on Mr. Gonzalez, said a senior aide who takes soundings for the Democratic leadership, is that the chairman "has been autocratic in that he doesn't permit flowers beneath him to bloom, and leaden in that he has not been an activist."
House committee chairmen are normally re-elected by the Democratic caucus unanimously or with only token opposition, but more than a third of the party's Congressmen voted last month to oust Mr. Gonzalez. Six Democrats on the banking panel quit and took a different committee assignment this year, in part because they did not like serving under him.
Many lawmakers who favor sweeping changes in the financial system fear that the drive to enact such changes may fail because of weak political leadership. But others say that could paradoxically work to the Administration's advantage. Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat, said that lawmakers might accept the President's proposals without the scrutiny they deserve.
In the end, said Representative Jim Leach, an Iowa Republican, the fate of the legislation may hinge on events in the Persian Gulf. "If the gulf goes well," he said, "you'll have a stronger Administration. That could make all the difference."

HEADLINE: The Region;
Sounding Notes of Fiscal Stability, Austerity and Pain

 BODY:
THEY are as much a January ritual as the department-store white sales: the State of the State speeches in Albany and Hartford and the State of the City address in New York. But last week the customarily upbeat rhetoric was overshadowed by the reality of recession and its consequences: declining revenues, skyrocketing deficits and -- perhaps most frustrating to elected officials not accustomed to having expensive initiatives scuttled for lack of cash -- scaled-down dreams.
The new goals and hoped-for new programs were tempered by the realization that the new programs may never be and that existing ones may have to be cut drastically. The region's economy is, according to most experts, getting worse, not better. The prospects for a quick turnaround are considered remote. 
 Following are some of the unhappy details, and excerpts from the speeches of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Mayor David N. Dinkins.
 
GOV. MARIO M. CUOMO -- ALBANY

 
 
 
The Problems
 Mr. Cuomo, beginning his third term as Governor of New York, said the times demanded a new austerity. Although the Governor and the Legislature closed a $1 billion budget gap only last month in a $29 billion budget, state fiscal analysts say the shortfall in the next fiscal year could approach $4 billion. Mr. Cuomo said that money was not available for goals he has outlined in past years, like universal health insurance.
 
The Speech
 "The immediate goal is to live within our means, closing the gap between what we would have proposed to spend and our diminished resources. It is essential that we do this, because if we do not maintain fiscal integrity by taking this bitter medicine, then we lose the capacity to pursue the mission.
"Then, having done that, the ultimate challenge is -- while balancing the budget -- to keep alive our vision of America here in New York, giving our people the chance to thrive by helping them become participants and shareholders in a strong New York State economy.
"Everywhere in that message, and in that budget, you will see a candid recognition that our fiscal emergency will require great sacrifice . . . even wrenching readjustment.
"And throughout both those documents, you will also see that I have taken pains to assure that the sacrifices are distributed fairly among all people of this state -- with no elite exempt class protected by political power, and no easy victims offered up because they lack political influence.
"There will be no sacred cows . . . and there will be no sacrificial lambs either."
 
GOV. LOWELL P. WEICKER JR. -- HARTFORD

 
 
 
The Problems
 Mr. Weicker took office as Connecticut's first independent chief executive in more than a century. Some lawmakers speculated that to solve budgetary problems, Mr. Weicker might propose a state income tax when he presents his budget next month. Connecticut is one of 10 states that do not tax regular income. If current spending is maintained, the shortfall the Governor will confront is expected to approach $1.5 billion in the fiscal year beginning July 1. This is in a budget of slightly more than $7 billion.
 
The Speech
 "You in this chamber and those who sent me here expect nothing short of total candor in dealing with the problems and opportunities of our state.
"So let the message of this day be simple -- and bold. No more sacrifices postponed. No more decisions ducked. No more lowest-common-denominator solutions.
"A deficit has taken control of our lives, coloring all else as it climbs beyond comprehension, sapping our confidence and humbling our visions.
"The past is not worth the best of our courage and creativity. That belongs to the future. So let's get this deficit business done -- and fast.
"No broken-field running, ladies and gentlemen. Straight into the line. We take our licks so that we can restore the caring and quality of life that is Connecticut, unmatched anywhere, hard to define, but a treasure worth every moment of our commitment and spirit during this session.
"What I seek is your grit and ingenuity; your resolve to accept sacrifices long postponed to gain achievements long denied."
 
MAYOR DAVID N. DINKINS -- NEW YORK CITY

 
 
 
The Problems
 At a time when financial experts say New York City may be facing the most difficult problems in the region, Mr. Dinkins gave the most upbeat speech. As for a budget gap that could reach $2.5 billion over the next 18 months, the Mayor said the budget would have to be cut to preserve fiscal stability. He said he wanted to make sure that the State's Financial Control Board, which monitors city finances, did not have to intercede. Governor Cuomo, who last year seemed to be growing exasperated with Mr. Dinkins's handling of fiscal matters, has already indicated that such a step might be unavoidable.
 
The Speech
 "Our economy has contracted at a breathtaking pace, and it shows no sign yet of recovery. Thousands of city employees will lose their jobs in the coming months because the size of our government must fit the size of our rapidly declining economy. However, before we eliminate any essential service, we must first cut out the fat -- and we have already begun.
 "In the future, ours will be a smaller government, but a stronger one, more creative, more productive and more responsive, one able to cope with the rapid changes the rest of this decade will surely bring. And, more importantly, it will be our government. By spending no more than we take in, we will maintain our fiscal integrity -- and will avoid losing control to outside monitors. The people of our city elected us to make the difficult choices, enlightened by our sensitivity to their needs. We will not seek to escape that responsibility. And until our economy rebounds, we will rely on our resourcefulness to protect those who need help the most."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Are the Pentagon's Cuts Leaving Defense Thin?

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
THE Navy promised a technological marvel when it persuaded Congress to begin paying for the A-12 Avenger attack plane in 1988. The carrier-based aircraft would be able to fly deep into enemy territory without being detected by radar and drop bombs with pinpoint precision. But even before a single plane was built, the program's costs soared at least $1.6 billion over budget.
Angry over the mismanagement of the program and unwilling to go back to Congress for more money, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney canceled the A-12 last week, shocking the Navy and the arms industry and making clear that a harsh new economic reality has settled over the Pentagon. But if this and other recent cancellations left some applauding the Pentagon's decisive action to trim waste, others wondered if the Administration's lack of a comprehensive plan for defense cutbacks might lead to decisions that will later be regretted. 
 The cancellation left the Navy scrambling to find an alternative to the A-12, which was to replace the 25-year-old A-6 Intruder starting in the mid-90's. It was also a major blow to the nation's two largest military contractors, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the General Dynamics Corporation. The companies were equal partners in the A-12 project, and had counted on selling 620 of the planes in coming years for a total of $57 billion.
Within hours of Mr. Cheney's announcement on Monday, the companies began laying off 9,000 workers, mostly in St. Louis and Fort Worth, and began storing away their work on radar-evading technology and state-of-the-art aircraft design. Thousands of workers at subcontractors and suppliers around the nation could also lose their jobs.
The timing of the decision to kill the A-12, the largest program ever to be canceled by the Pentagon, seemed incongruous, coming as the nation appeared headed toward war in the Persian Gulf. But it was just the most visible of a string of weapons projects that have recently fallen victim to rising costs, hard bargaining by the Government and mismanagement by the industry. Last summer the Navy killed a new submarine-hunting plane, the P-7A, being developed by the Lockheed Corporation, and last month the Army terminated a missile program known as FOG-M being developed by the Hughes Aircraft Company and the Boeing Company. On Thursday, the Air Force canceled a Boeing contract for an air defense system for Saudi Arabia.
The cancellations have given new impetus to questions that Government officials, arms industry executives and analysts have been pondering since it became clear that the need for expensive new high-technology weapons would decline sharply in a post-cold war world. It appears to them that the Pentagon does not have any clear plan for dealing with the shrinkage of the defense industrial base, and some experts say that the Government could come to regret some of the decisions it is making as problems crop up with one weapons system after another.
"It's decide as you go and not decide in accordance with a coherent policy," said Gordon Adams, the director of the Defense Budget Project, a non-partisan research group in Washington. "There has been no fundamental attempt made to decide what current programs we need, and there has not even been much thinking about the next generation of weapons needs and the industrial capability necessary to support them."
The problem is particularly acute because the armed services have been cutting back purchases of existing weapons systems to help pay for newer, more exotic and more expensive systems, leaving contractors dependent on the payoff from future programs.
The new weapons, in turn, have been plagued in many cases by cost overruns and other financial troubles even as the military need for them has diminished. More than any other single factor, Government officials and industry executives agree, the financial problems with the programs stemmed from the fixed-price contracts that the Reagan Administration imposed in an attempt to cut costs. Both the Government and the industry learned that there is almost no way to predict the cost of developing a new technology. The industry has absorbed billions of dollars in cost overruns and the armed forces have been forced to kill weapons that they still consider essential.
As big new programs are cut, experts think some of the large prime contractors will be forced to merge and that more and more of the small and medium-sized companies will be forced out of the business or will shift to commercial work.
"As we narrow our technological base, we face the real question of whether we will be able to maintain our superiority across a broad range of weapons systems," said Ethan B. Kapstein, head of the Economics and National Security program at Harvard University.
Industry executives see little chance that the Bush Administration will adopt any formal policy to deal with the shrinking of the industry. Such an approach would fly in the face of the Administration's commitment to free-market ideology, and advocating an industrial policy within the Pentagon can be professional suicide. The former head of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, Craig I. Fields, lost his job last year when he pushed for limited Government support for companies developing new technologies.
But while many industry executives clearly wish that the Pentagon would step in to alleviate the financial pain they are beginning to feel, they don't expect it to.
"I'm not optimistic in the short term at all," said Malcom R. Currie, the chairman of Hughes Aircraft. "The Defense Department is likely to say the problem is so large, how can we the Government make choices? How can we help the industry over this hump without being accused of favoritism or of engaging in industrial policy? They'll say we have a free-market society, let the chips fall where they may."
