PUB-DATE: January 13, 1991

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 3220 words

HEADLINE: For Glasnost in the Arts, Blues in the Night

BYLINE: By HILARY DE VRIES; Hilary de Vries writes about the arts for The Los
Angeles Times and other publications.

 BODY:
While Mikhail Gorbachev battles a sagging economy in the Soviet Union, glasnost has become one of the hottest trends of the American arts scene. Since the restoration of cultural relations between the two superpowers six years ago, the flow of artists from East to West has achieved near flood-tide proportions. In concert halls, regional theaters and museums around the country, the number of Soviet artists is at an all-time high: glasnost can also mean boffo box office.
 Long fascinated by such glamorous emigres as the dancer Mikhail Baryshnikov, Americans have more recently been entranced by Mr. Gorbachev's media triumphs involving the changes in Soviet society. It might be said that after the recent wave of Gorbymania, Soviet artists, long exiled to Siberia at the world's cultural parties, are now seated at the main table. 
Yet a number of American producers and directors believe that the quantity of Soviet culture being exported is beginning to outstrip demand, that the unprecedented influx of Soviet arts groups into the United States has brought a decline in quality, and that work by less than top-rank artists has resulted in lackluster commercial and critical response. The so-called glasnost industry, these arts leaders say, may have peaked and the shaking out begun.
 "That old cultural bugaboo that foreign-language arts don't play well here is still true," said Harvey Lichtenstein, president and executive producer of the Brooklyn Academy of Music in New York. "Just because Soviet companies are feeling the pinch at home doesn't mean that Soviet culture is necessarily interesting or good. Many people have been sold a bill of goods by promoters and much of the hype has been misleading."
 Until a few years ago, American audiences were accustomed to infrequent and carefully regulated foreign tours by Soviet performers. Today, Soviet dance companies, theater ensembles and even circus troupes appear not only in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles but in Rochester, Houston, Minneapolis and Atlanta, as well as at numerous city-sponsored arts festivals. Individual Soviet artists now work directly with American arts groups, either as permanent company members or as guest performers.
 While extensive tours by major Soviet cultural troupes -- like the recent appearances by the Bolshoi Ballet -- may still play well with audiences and critics, smaller, less well-known groups are meeting with diminished success. And a handful of contemporary Soviet art exhibits, like the show "Between Spring and Summer: Soviet Conceptual Art in the Era of Late Communism," now on a tour of American cities, have received serious, though not rapturous, critical attention.
 Mixed reviews and less than enthusiastic audience response have greeted a number of productions at regional theaters during the last few years. These have involved either Soviet companies performing in Russian or Soviet directors working with American actors in English-language works. Among the recent collaborative efforts have been "Ivanov" at the Yale Repertory Theater, "Brothers and Sisters" at the Old Globe Theater in San Diego, "Crime and Punishment" at the Arena Stage in Washington, "Phaedra" at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., and "Zoya's Apartment" at Circle in the Square in New York.
 "Russian companies are a tough sell," said Thomas Hall, managing director of the Old Globe, which was the host for the Maly Theater of Leningrad in 1989. The Maly production of "Brothers and Sisters" was part of the San Diego festival "Treasures of the Soviet Union." "Frankly," Mr. Hall said, "if we hadn't had the festival packaging around us, we would have been in terrible trouble."
 
Quality vs. Quantity

 Is It Russian Roulette?
 Many American arts leaders cite the benefits of such cultural exchanges, whether they channel much-needed hard currency to struggling Soviet artists and their institutions, help forge esthetic ties between the two nations or simply serve as windows through which to examine recent Soviet events.
 Yet do Americans, after all, clamor to see Soviet cultural presentations? Some critics and artistic directors suggest that the quantity of offerings may have as much to do with cultural hucksterism as with any real American appetitefor all things Russian.
 "I don't know if there is a hunger on the part of American audiences for Soviet culture," said Michael Kahn, artistic director of the Shakespeare Theater at the Folger in Washington, which was a recent host to the Georgian Film Actors' Studio, an experimental theater troupe of stage and film artists. "These appearances have more to do with awakening American audiences, who've been very insular."
 Robert Arsenault, a Washington-based Soviet arts consultant who worked on the New York International Festival of the Arts in 1988, said, "The bloom is not quite off the rose in terms of audience demand. But there is a lot of schlock coming in now, and a lot of producers think that just because it's Russian they can make a buck off it."
 According to Martha Coigny, president of the International Theater Institute, which has sponsored exchanges of Soviet and American artistic directors, "A lot of people have mounted Soviet productions because it's chic. It will be interesting to see what will go beyond the 'flavor of the month' syndrome. Now we are seeing interest being paid to African and Latin American groups as well as to those in Hungary and Czechoslovakia. The Soviet fashion may die down a bit."
 
Dollar Diplomacy

 Which Came First, Art or Rubles?
 The origins of the glasnost industry may, in fact, have been based more on the capitalistic needs of the Soviet Union than on any fascination by Americans for Soviet culture.
 Traditionally, Soviet-American cultural exchanges were a few choice events presented as the highly visible handmaid of diplomacy. In the mid-1970's, appearances by Soviet artists who performed in the United States were carefully controlled by the powerful Soviet Ministry of Culture and a handful of experienced presenters, such as the late Sol Hurok, who produced the Bolshoi and Kirov Ballet tours and exercised a virtual monopoly over Soviet performances in the United States.
 But the breakdown of diplomatic barriers, notably the signing of a new General Exchanges agreement in 1985, cutbacks in government subsidies and the restructuring of the Soviet economy -- including bureaucratic changes within cultural agencies -- changed everything. Soviet arts groups eager for hard currency discovered the lucrative foreign tour, especially to the United States. The image of this country among Soviet cultural representatives is that it is "still the land of milk and honey," according to Steve Boulay, vice president of the Space Agency, a Salt Lake City concert presenter that produced a recent tour of the Red Army Chorus.
 The result is that more and more Soviet performing-arts companies are bypassing their own government bureaucracy to sign individual contracts with cultural institutions and commercial producers here.
 "Why are we seeing so many arts groups in the United States?" asked Mr. Boulay. "The answer is simple -- greed. They want dollars, dollars, dollars."
 
Visa Fever

 But Once Here, Tours Can Fizzle
 Whether it is increasingly frequent appearances by such leading groups as the Bolshoi Ballet, first-ever exhibitions of Russian Conceptualist painters or debut performances by little-known groups, like the native tribes in "Siberian Music and Dance From the Island of Sakhalin, the Soviet Far East" at the Asia Society in New York, more Soviet artists are arriving in the United States. State Department officials report that the number of visas annually granted to Soviet visitors, including arts groups, has climbed from 10,000 to nearly 100,000 in the last five years, with no leveling off foreseen.
 "In all disciplines -- visual arts, music, dance, theater -- Soviet companies are coming here at a time when their own country is in a great deal of chaos," said Lee Lamont, president of I.C.M. Artists, which produces the American tours of the Leningrad Philharmonic and the Moiseyev Dance Company. "They are coming here in order to function, to perform their work and to get paid for it."
 According to Yuri Grigorovich, artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet, "The arts are no longer at the top of the priority list in terms of state subsidy. Any arts group that can get over to the States does get over. And recently there has been a flood of not very high quality groups."
 For some Soviet artists the American dream ends in cold reality: half-filled auditoriums and galleries, shortened tours and occasional strandings of performers when ticket sales fail to materialize. For every sold-out performance by the Red Army Chorus at the Kennedy Center in Washington, or by the Moiseyev Dance Company at Radio City Music Hall in New York or even by the Sovremennik theater troupe, which performed in Seattle last summer, there are dozens of partly filled houses for major company tours.
 For second-tier arts groups the consequences can be disastrous: empty arenas, bounced checks, hotel evictions. In the last two years, several groups -- notably the Great Circus Bim Bom and the Ukrainian Donetsk Ballet -- were all but abandoned by their American producers.
 
A Tighter Borscht Belt

 As Fees Rise, So Do Jitters
 Some producers say much of the current problem has its origins in longstanding and well-publicized difficulties with Goskontsert. The concert agency, which traditionally pocketed some 80 percent of the fees from foreign tours of Soviet groups, has shown a growing willingness to approve agreements with the highest bidder, whether they have sufficient financial backing or not. Arts presenters and museum and theater directors say they must pay Soviet artists increasingly high performance and exhibition loan fees -- fees that can run from $10,000 to more than $1 million for a single exhibition or tour.
 "These companies are at least twice as expensive as they used to be," said Jane Sahlins, producer of the International Theater Festival of Chicago, which presented the State Theater of Lithuania there in 1988. "They get fewer government subsidies, so you have to pay them more, and there are always special arrangements that have to be made."
 The subsequent financial risks are often too much for small producers working with lesser-known groups. But even more established deep-pocket organizations, such as I.C.M. Artists, are voicing caution.
 The Nederlander theater organization in New York, which co-produced the most recent Bolshoi tour last year, is not currently involved in the Soviet arts scene. "You don't really make any money on those tours," said Arthur Rubin, the company's vice president and general manager. "It's more of a cultural thing. As long as you don't lose money, that's about it."
 
The Art Market

 If It's Novel, It Must Be Soviet
 In the area of fine arts, some museum directors and gallery owners say that despite first-ever exhibitions of contemporary Russian paintings, the market for such works is driven more by novelty than real collector interest. Few American galleries regularly sell contemporary Soviet paintings and those that do, such as the Feldman Gallery in New York, are finding buyers largely for the work of such established Soviet emigre artists as Vitaly Komar and Alexander Melamid.
 Few American art institutions have purchased works by living Soviet artists, or sponsored major contemporary Soviet art shows. Today only a handful of critically acclaimed smaller exhibits have been mounted, including "Art Into Life," an exhibition of Soviet Constructivism that opened at the Henry Gallery in Seattle last summer, and "Between Spring and Summer," that began at the Tacoma Art Museum.
 "We've had this big bad enemy for so long that our interest has been piqued, but this is not a hot trend," said Ronald Feldman, owner of the Feldman Gallery. "European interest in Soviet work is way ahead of ours, and no one really knows how long it is going to last."
 According to Martin Friedman, the former director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, which co-sponsored the "Art Into Life" exhibit last year, "The answer is not blockbuster exhibits but more collaborative and specialized exhibits that build critical relationships between museum staffs." Unless these foundations are laid, Mr. Friedman said, "there will be a fading of interest here in Soviet art."
 
Theater of Difficulty

 A Risky Stunt And a Hard Sell
 Although regional theaters had been at the forefront of institutions seeking cultural ties with the Soviets, many directors now say that contemporary Soviet theater, with its parochial political themes and translation difficulties, is a box-office risk and a logistical and financial headache. Sponsoring a Soviet theater company usually means transporting, housing and paying fees to large ensembles; the costs can run to hundreds of thousands of dollars, significantly higher than for most domestic productions.
 "The word in the industry is that Soviet theater just doesn't sell," said Norman Langell, producer of the Goodwill Arts Festival in Seattle last summer. Daniel Sullivan, artistic director of the Seattle Repertory Theater and one of the city's few arts leaders who declined to sponsor a Soviet troupe during the festival, concurs. "There is a certain amount of bandwagoning that is going on," said Mr. Sullivan, who described most of the theater he saw during a recent Moscow trip as "more of a political thing," adding, "Soviet theater may not be as rich a trove as we thought."
 In some cases, hiring a Soviet director to mount a production with American actors has become a less expensive, less risky yet still trendy means of bringing Soviet stagecraft to the United States. Although some directors say that such joint productions make for legitimate cross-fertilization, others maintain that language difficulties and differences in rehearsal practices make the arrangements little more than theatrical stunts.
In a review of last fall's production of "Ivanov" at the Yale Rep, with American actors directed by Oleg Yefremov of the Moscow Art Theater, Frank Rich wrote in The New York Times that "it suffers from the mistaken conviction that a brilliant Soviet director can drop in to a foreign theater and . . . re-create a celebrated Moscow production." The result, Mr. Rich said, "failed to fulfill the play at hand and the highest standards of either the Soviet or American artists involved."
 During the residency of the Georgian Film Actors' Studio at the Folger Theater, Keti Dolidze, a Georgian director, said, "We have much to learn from American actors. But a three- to six-week rehearsal period? It is impossible for us to work in such a short time."
 
International Strains

 Who Will Win At the Arts Game?
 A number of arts leaders caution that few long-term links between Soviet and American arts groups have been forged and that American audiences have not developed an educated appreciation of Soviet culture.
 "More and more the United States is becoming responsive to the international arts scene," said Mr. Lichtenstein of BAM. "The Soviet Union is only part of the mix. Africa, Asia, Eastern Europe -- it's all part of our growing cultural diversification. But the idea of being interested in something Russian just because it's Russian, that's not interesting."
 Everyone, said Mr. Boulay of the Space Agency, "is looking for a quick buck with Soviet artists. When the demand stops, the supply will stop. The level playing field will prove to be a harsh reality for the Soviets."
 
MOSCOW NIGHTS HAVE DWINDLED
 When the United States and the Soviet Union signed the new General Exchanges agreement in 1985, the first artists over the fence included the Russian pianist Vladimir Horowitz in a celebrated return to Moscow and the pop singer Billy Joel in the first Soviet tour by a major American rock star. Since then, the flow of artists has all but reversed direction.
 While several dozen Soviet arts groups annually visit the United States, less than half a dozen major American groups perform in the Soviet Union, according to American officials who monitor such exchanges. Those that have visited recently include the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, the Acting Company of New York and the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.
 The reasons, say American arts representatives, are largely financial. While Soviet artists anticipate a profit on their United States tours, most American groups must cover their own expenses -- or obtain corporate or government grants -- and usually receive only a modest honorarium.
 The Chicago Symphony Orchestra's tour in November, for example, which included four performances in the Soviet Union plus stops in Hungary and Austria, cost the orchestra more than $1 million.
 A recent trend among American organizations is to send a single artistic director to help a comparable Soviet arts group. "They have an incredible thirst for American management techniques," said Robert Orchard, managing director of the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., who made the trip last year.
 "The Soviets are very depressed about their own theaters -- they can't fire anybody. Their subsidies are being reduced. They don't know how to write contracts. And so far they have only had the Broadway commercial theater as a model."
 
WHAT DO AUDIENCES IN AMERICA WANT?
 Measuring audience demand for Soviet cultural imports is difficult, in part because many commercial producers who sponsor such events do not release profit-and-loss statements.
 Certainly some Soviet productions sell well. Recent tours by the Bolshoi Ballet and the Red Army Chorus, for example, were considered critical and box-office successes.
 The popularity of some other imports, however, has hinged on non-Russian factors. "Ivanov," at the Yale Repertory Theater last year, was thought to have sold out not because of Oleg Yefremov (in photograph), its Soviet director, but because of its star-studded American cast, which included William Hurt.
 The well-received performances by the State Theater of Lithuania at the Chicago Theater Festival in 1988 had as much to do with enthusiastic critical notices as Chicago's extensive Lithuanian population, which, according to Jane Sahlins, the festival's producer, made up a large percentage of the audience.
 And still other Soviet productions and exhibits simply do not perform as expected. Part of the problem, according to producers, is that auditoriums are too large, tours too frequent and ticket prices too steep. The top ticket price for some events has been up to $100 a seat, double what comparable companies here charge, and dicey in a recession economy.
 "The glory days are past in terms of making a profit," said John Ballard, president of the Space Agency, a concert presenter in Salt Lake City that has handled the tours of a few prestigious Soviet arts groups. "These are incredibly expensive tours, and there are just too many of them."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1096 words

HEADLINE: Now That the Recession Is Official ... Three Experts Predict the
Recovery

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
Amid a great deal of publicity -- and several false calls -- the recession has finally arrived. But by all accounts it is not a typical recession, nor was it pronounced in the typical way. The seven-member Dating Committee of the National Bureau of Economic Research normally makes its dour recession confirmation only after two quarters of a downturn in the gross national product have been observed.
 This time, by traditional standards, the committee's call was early. The Commerce Department's figures, which are complete only through the end of the third quarter of 1990, still show growth. 
Even so, it was the right call," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University in Atlanta. "The recession began in the fourth quarter of last year. That's the consensus forecast. Who says we economists can't agree?"
According to Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities, most recessions start after prices begin to rise and the Federal Reserve Board raises interest rates to dampen inflation. "Then the Fed opens the floodgates, which ends the recession but reignites inflation," he said. But this time, according to Mr. Levy, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, has been far more prudent. In the midst of a slowdown, monetary policy remains fairly tight.
 This recession is also different in the way it is inflicting its pain on thecountry. Typically, recessions begin in the manufacturing sector and later spread to the services. But this time, one of the few bright spots in the economy has been export-oriented manufacturing. Services -- especially financial and retail services -- have been the hardest hit.
 Banks, savings and loans, Wall Street firms and even law firms are hurting. Layoffs from the financial and retail sectors are rising. Sears, Roebuck and Citicorp, the nation's largest retailer and bank, have both been thinning their ranks. "There is a tremendous restructuring going on in the service-producing industries," said Mr. Levy.
 As a result, the healthiest regions of the country are those with heavy concentrations of export-oriented industries -- the Midwest and Northwest. At the other extreme, the weakest region is the Northeast. This is exactly the opposite of the pattern observed during the last recession in 1982.
 Inventory accumulation is another indicator that is behaving differently from the past. Generally, inventories rise significantly when times are tough and goods remain unsold. But so far in this downturn, inventories have remained remarkably flat. New methods, like just-in-time inventory management, more outsourcing and ordering goods closer to the time of sale, have enabled companies to operate in a leaner fashion.
Housing starts, on the other hand, are doing the traditional thing -- falling. In the Northeast and West, housing starts and sales are already down to levels not seen since the last recession, in 1982.
 Then there was Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The subsequent oil price jump added to inflation and took more money from consumers' pockets. This slowed a weakened economy even more. And if there is a war -- long or short -- its effects on the economy are too uncertain to predict.

 
MICKEY D. LEVY

 Chief economist at CRT Government Securities in New York City.
 The current recession is merely a correction that will wring out a decade of excesses from the economy, according to Mr. Levy. As this happens, inflation will fall and prices will adjust downward. Real estate prices will continue to fall as unsold inventories of commercial property are cleared. But the recession will not be deep. Instead, there will be the long-sought "soft landing" in the first half of the year. The second half will begin a slow but steady recovery. While the service sector will be hurt by the downturn, the manufacturing sector will be helped by continued growth in exports. Because of its export orientation, the Midwest and Northwest will outperform the rest of the economy. Even though the Federal Reserve has eased somewhat on interest rates and on the reserve requirements for certain types of bank deposits, Mr. Levy believes it will continue to follow a relatively restrictive policy. "Mr. Greenspan has done an excellent job managing the economy," Mr. Levy said.

 
DONALD RATAJCZAK

 Director of the Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University in Atlanta.
 Mr. Ratajczak thinks the recession will be a little deeper, but shorter than average. "The recession started in the forth quarter of 1990," he said. "It will have a duration of 8 to 10 months." In the first half of the year, unemployment is likely to rise to 7 percent and then drift upward to 7.25 percent before coming down in 1992. The fear of war and the reluctance of consumers to spend has put the brakes on the economy. These two factors particularly hurt the housing and construction sectors. Exports have also been affected because much of Europe has been slowed by the fear of war and of a subsequent disruption of its oil supply. But if war does come, Mr. Ratajczak believes, it will be short and do little damage to the oil delivery system outside of Kuwait. "If this is what happens, oil prices will come down and inflation will virtually vanish," he said. With inflation gone, consumers will have more money to spend, confidence will return and the growth of exports will resume.
 
A. GARY SHILLING

 President of an economic consulting firm in Springfield, N.J., that bears his name.
 Mr. Shilling has been predicting a recession for a long time. Now, he is finding his worst fears confirmed. In the Shilling view, the recession is likely to be deep and last at least through the end of this year. After that, growth is likely to be sluggish, "no more than 2 or 3 percent." And even though growth will become positive in early 1992, unemployment will continue to rise -- to a level above 9 percent, where it will stay until the end of 1993. "The factors that normally put the bounce in the economy are absent," Mr. Shilling said. At the same time, the Federal Government is constrained in its ability to help the economy. In 1991,the Federal deficit could swell to as much as $500 billion, which would prevent Congress from taking action to stimulate growth. At the same time, the Federal Reserve, even if it "dumps money into the system" will not see an end to the credit crunch. The value of tangible assets -- even investments like coins, antiques and precious metals -- will decline.

HEADLINE: Northeast Notebook: Burlington, Vt.;
Developing The Waterfront

BYLINE: By KENT SHAW

 BODY:
AFTER years of haggling, voters here approved the first phase of a plan to develop extensive holdings of public and private land on the city's long-neglected waterfront. City planners say development of a 70-acre area could total $100 million to $140 million in 5 to 10 years.
Two major private developers, who own a total of about 15 acres of sparsely developed land, say they will wait for an economic upturn before proceeding. But with the approval of the voters last November, city planners can now move ahead on an 11-acre waterfront park. Bids on the $2 million project, which includes the purchase of the parcel, should be completed this month and the park could be open in time for fireworks on the Fourth of July. 
 Some critics question whether a park will provide the anchor they say is needed to attract large numbers of visitors. They are calling instead for mixed development, including housing and retail space.
But whatever the merits of the park, it may be the only development possible under a ruling issued last summer. State courts upheld the state's authority to use the land, which had been reclaimed from Lake Champlain in the 1830's and long used by the Central Vermont Railroad, for public purposes under the state's Public Trust Doctrine. Under that doctrine, the state claimed the right to the land once it fell into disuse by the railroad.
The same principle would apply to another waterfront parcel, of 43 acres, owned by the railroad, which must give the city first refusal on its sale. City appraisers say the land is worth about $1.6 million, while the railroad wants more than $9 milion. An arbiter is expected to resolve the difference this spring.
Also in the works is a city takeover of the Naval Reserve Station, if voters agree to spend $1.5 million for it. City planners want to use the 29,000-square-foot station for galleries, open-air markets, restaurants and performing arts. Outside there may be additional boat dockage.
The 50,000-square-foot former Moran Generating Station, another neglected waterfront structure, could house an aquarium, a planetarium and a research center, city planners say.
But private developers wonder who will visit the site without housing to create a distinct, year-round waterfront community. Thomas Cullins, an architect whose office overlooks the waterfront, said: "It looks as though they put something in the plan for everybody. Once it's a park, you're never in all of history going to rip up a park. It's death."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Moran Generating Station on Lake Champlain, Burlington, Vt., may be renovated for recreational use. (Paul O. Boisvert for The New Times)

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Dr. Harry J. Hartley;
Cheers and Problems for UConn President

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
HARRY J. HARTLEY was chosen last month from 117 candidates to be the 12th president of the University of Connecticut. A 52-year-old native of Pennsylvania who has spent his entire career in public higher education, Dr. Hartley came to UConn in 1972 as a professor of educational finance, served the school three years as dean of the School of Education and seven years as vice president for finance and administration.
He is well-liked on campus, chosen by the student newspaper as Man of the Year in 1978, and by the faculty senate as distinguished professor of the year in 1984. 
 When his selection was announced during a basketball game at the university's new Gampel Pavilion, the crowd of students, faculty members and alumni rose and shouted, "Harry! Harry!"
The walls of his office at Storrs are lined with cards, and the tables covered with flowers, from well-wishers. In a recent interview in that office, Dr. Hartley discussed his plans. Here are some excerpts from the conversation.
 Q. With all the financial and other problems facing the state and its institutions, why did you want to become UConn's president?
 A. How much different is that from being its chief fiscal officer? To me, it isn't that much different, and I really think a person familiar with financial issues has the right background for Connecticut in 1990. I trust my judgment better than I would someone who isn't in finance. But recessions come and go. It's the economic cycle. I think it will be nice to plan for the economic recovery.
 Q. A lot was made of the fact that your immediate predecessors were here only a few years. How much did your being here 19 years have to do with your selection, and how long are you going to be here?
 A. I'm not going to dwell on that, but I would simply say that with the last three presidents, and I did serve under all three of them as a fiscal vice president, it began to look like UConn was a stepping stone. Each one had the same pattern: each one came from outside, each one stayed exactly five years, and then each one went back outside.
There was a view, and it's coming out now as I read editorials and letters and so on, that there ought to be someone from Connecticut, someone from UConn, capable of doing this, who is committed to staying at the University of Connecticut. I think I fit that mold. I plan to retire here, and I've said that to anyone who has asked me.
 Q. There were 117 candidates for the job. If you were running the search, would you have hired someone without interviewing more than one of them?
 A. Well, eight of the trustees did interview the three finalists. Some of the others met some of the finalists. As I understand it, they were eventually down to two, because one of the finalists withdrew, and the other person had not been a president, was from out of state and was not familiar with Connecticut. I think the other trustees asked the screening committee, "What do you think?"
The key thing in selecting any administrator is not the absolute values of the individual but ratherthe "fit." What is the institution, what are its needs right now, and what skills does that person have? You may have an outstanding candidate, but it may not be the right fit.
 Q. Is that "fit" one reason you seem to be enjoying such popularity among faculty, students, legislators, alumni and so on?
 A. I guess the answer is yes. I'm very humbled by this. I don't know if you saw that first game at Gampel, but when you get a standing ovation, when you get students chanting, "Harry! Harry!" -- I had goosebumps, I had tears.
But my hat still fits. A good percentage of it is what I represent. It's not Harry, it's that I represent blue and white. I care about UConn. If there is one thing I understand it's the organizational culture of UConn. I think that's what the reaction was.
Q. Is that going to help you?
A. One way it's going to help me is that we are a united family right now. For example, the Thomas Commission made some controversial suggestions about reorganizing UConn. The consultants, who were from Florida, didn't understand the tradition and culture of UConn. They talked about abolishing the Board of Trustees and abolishing the system of regional campuses.
A Board of Trustees gives us what little autonomy we have and brings decision making closer to our clients, the students. And closing the regional campuses would make us the University of Storrs. Sometimes it takes that external threat to unite the family. And I do intend to build on it.
 Q. You have some tough decisions ahead of you. Is that good relationship going to hinder that process?
 A. Yes, but I've made tough decisions before as the chief fiscal officer. Many of the decisions I've had to make were against people, to reduce staffing levels.
I try to make the decisions as fairly and objectively as I can, but I'm very sensitive to the fact that any negative decision I make affects real, live human beings. There is no pleasant way to offer up cuts, but I'm going to try to do it as fairly as I can.
 Q. Governor Weicker has suggested some state agencies could face as much as a 20 percent cut in their budget. How would UConn deal with that?
 A. At that point UConn would have to declare financial exigency, a technical term having to do with reductions in staff, the elimination of programs and services. A 20 percent cut translates into about $30 million for us in the general fund alone.
Almost all of the general fund spending, about 93 percent, is salaries, and if we have to cut $30 million, it doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out it will take major staff reductions.
I think my credibility is being watched to see whether I am I going to resist all cuts. I think that would be unrealistic and it would probably backfire. However, there is a point at which it would have serious implications to the future of the institution. I don't know exactly where that point is, but at 20 percent, and even at 13 percent, it would create permanent damage.
At the 7 percent level, I think there are things we could do -- and I'm not advocating it -- but I think there are things we could do without major, permanent structural damage to the instructional program.
 Q. As tuition rises and enrollment declines because of staffing cutbacks, is UConn in danger becoming out of reach of the students it has traditionally attracted?
 A. One of UConn's objectives that I am very sensitive to is access. One of our goals is to provide access to qualified students who might not otherwise be able to afford to go to college. My first chance came in July, in my first month as interim president, when I submitted a budget.
Tuition increases have been 15 percent the last couple of years, but I lowered that to 7.5 percent. However, in this fiscal emergency we are in, it is one of the options I'm looking at, to restore some additional increase in the tuition fund. We will be submitting plans for a 6, 13 and 20 percent increase.
 Q. UConn started as an agricultural school in 1881, but that part of the institution is not growing as quickly as the rest of the university. What is the School of Agriculture's future?
 A. The other half of that school's title is more interesting: the School of Agriculture and Natural Resources. Yesterday I was at the Bartlett Arboretum in Stamford, the plant science department.
One of the red hot areas right now is turf management, for golf courses and so on. I just visited the pathobiology department on campus. Right now there is a major fear of Lyme disease. They are doing a lot of research, such as whether milk might contain it -- so far, none. We're putting up two new buildings for animal industries, one for dairy and the other for the horse barn, with privately raised monies.
I'm there at every one of these dedications because these are our roots. People still eat food, they still have plants.
 Q. With a big new sports complex and a successful 1989-90 basketball season, there's been some grumbling about athletics taking precedence over academics. Do you think that's happening?
 A. I view it the other way around. I think athletics is catching up to our academic status. We're a first-rate academic institution; we have achieved the status of Research University I ranked by the Carnegie Foundation;, we rank in the top 30 in Federal research funding. We're a first-rate school, and athletics caught up with that.
In my opinion, we can do both. But what's nice about athletics is when they go out on the court, it doesn't say "Chemistry Department" on the uniforms, it says "University of Connecticut."
And the Gampel Pavilion is not just a basketball arena. The entire sports and leisure studies department is now located over there. They were in three different buildings before. Now we can have a single commencement. And we can use it for interscholastic athletics.

HEADLINE: Publisher Buys A Lotus Unit

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
The International Data Group, which publishes periodicals dealing with information technology, has acquired the Lotus Publishing Corporation from the Lotus Development Corporation in Cambridge, Mass.
Neither company would disclose the price of the acquisition, but a Lotus spokesman said the agreement called for Lotus Development to share in profits from Lotus Publishing for an undisclosed period. Lotus Development does not disclose revenues and earnings for its separate business units, but industry estimates put revenues for Lotus publishing at $10 million in 1990. 
 Lotus publishes Lotus magazine, a monthly publication with an audited circulation of 368,000; Lotus Books, a line of books published in conjunction with Simon & Schuster Inc., and direct mail materials, all aimed at the 14 million users of Lotus Development's 1-2-3 software package as well as the company's other software products.
An International Data Group spokesman said Lotus Publishing was not profitable in its 1990 fiscal year. He added that plans were under way to begin Lotus newsletters and videos and to enter the conference and exposition business.
Internationl Data is the parent of Computerworld, a leading weekly newspaper in the information systems industry. Mark D. Flanagan will remain as president and chief executive of Lotus Publishing, which will become an independent business unit within International Data. The company will retain its staff and offices in Cambridge, Mass.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
War or Peace: Wall Street Waits

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Credit market analysts and participants are awaiting Tuesday's midnight deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait with a rising sense of urgency.
If President Saddam Hussein of Iraq decides to leave Kuwait peacefully by the deadline, bond yields would fall sharply. Consumer confidence, which has fallen badly since the Aug. 2 invasion, would revive, providing the economy with a much-needed lift. 
 An outbreak of hostilities would also produce a swift response in the fixed-income markets. Seeking safety, investors would probably put even more money into short-term instruments like Treasury bills and sell bonds. Short-term interest rates fell last week as bond yields rose, steepening the yield curve.
 
'The Instant Shooting Starts'
 "The instant shooting starts, the yield curve will twist, with bond yields going higher and short rates falling," said Jerry L. Jordan, a senior vice president at the First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. "But there will not be much activity in terms of medium- and long-term markets, so price quotes won't mean very much. It won't be a very fluid market."
The first few days of war would be a time of extreme anxiety, which would not abate until the probable course of the fighting had been determined, analysts said.
Analysts said a short war in which the United States and its allies emerge victorious and oilfields remain intact would have much the same effect on the economy and on interest rates as a timely exit from Kuwait by Saddam Hussein.
"I would argue that a war would temporarily aid the economy if it is short in nature," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "However, the general economic malaise was in place before the Iraqi invasion, and a short war would provide only a temporary boost. After that, the economy would fall back into its rut."
 
Toll on the Economy
 A war that stretches out for more than a month, however, would begin to take a much more serious toll on the economy.
High oil prices would drive up inflation, and the Federal budget deficit would probably soar, reflecting the higher costs of a longer war. Consumer confidence would probably fall further, and the current recession would deepen. Long-term interest rates would move higher.
At the moment, the chances of a protracted conflict do not appear great, the analysts said. Moreover, fears about damage to Saudi oilfields are probably misplaced.
"There is every reason to think that Saddam could not take out the Saudi fields," said a former American diplomat with much experience in Saudi Arabia. "The Saudis have extensive security in the oilfields to limit damage and allow production to continue even if there is extensive fire or bombardment. I am sure there is no other country in the world that has in place such sophisticated security."
From the economy's perspective, a continuation of the current stalemate would be almost as damaging as a drawn-out war.
"Stalemate in the Middle East is almost the worst of all possible worlds for the economy," said Stuart Hoffman, chief economist at the Pittsburgh National Bank. "Nobody likes uncertainty."
Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montagu Economics, said very few investment or business decisions have been made this month, largely because of the situation in the Middle East. "The longer that persists, the less overall activity we will have, and the longer it will take the Fed's easing tactics to provoke any new economic activity," he said.
Mr. Fabbri, who said he did not believe shots would be fired, projected the economy would contract for several more quarters, even though interest rates would fall and inflation would decline.
A host of economic reports are expected to be released this week, but the data shrink in importance compared with developments in the Persian Gulf. Trading activity will probably be thin and extremely choppy.
"At the moment we are ticker-tape trading, and volatility is the watchword," said Steven Slifer, a senior vice president and financial market economist at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. "I suspect we are in store for more of that this week. The economic statistics will take a back seat to the war."
Economists predict the data, which include reports on December retail sales and consumer prices, will show that the economy remained weak last month.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
TURKEY GIVES U.S. LIMITED BASE USE

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Turkey agreed this weekend to let the United States use air bases here in a war against neighboring Iraq, but said operations would be confined to "humanitarian and limited logistical support."
The decision, reached at a long Cabinet meeting Saturday night, means that American pilots would not be allowed to stage air strikes against Iraq directly from Turkish territory. 
 Instead, officials explained, the Americans would be able to use Turkish installations, notably the Incirlik Air Base in southern Turkey, for such purposes as refueling fighter planes or ferrying the wounded out of the war zone. But to take off for a raid against Iraq, American aircraft presumably would first have to go elsewhere.
"We will give humanitarian and limited logistical support, and nothing other than this," said Mehmet Yazar, the chief Government spokesman.
 
Baker Meets Turks
 The Turkish decision was relayed today to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who met in Ankara with President Turgut Ozal and other leaders as he ended a swing through Middle Eastern capitals to confer with members of the anti-Iraq coalition.
No mention of Turkish military support was included, however, in public statements about what was discussed. Rather, they focused on mutual expressions of support in the Persian Gulf crisis and on Turkey's hopes for further economic aid and trade concessions to help compensate for part of the $5.5 billion that officials say the country has lost by enforcing the United Nations embargo against Iraq.
In a statement released by his office, Mr. Ozal told Mr. Baker that the Congressional vote on Saturday to give President Bush the authority to go to war "might help increase the chances for a peaceful solution."
Despite the limited nature of Turkey's permission to use its air bases for war, the decision significantly increases its participation in the multination force arrayed against Baghdad. Even this circumscribed action is certain to upset Turks, including some senior military officers and foreign-policy advisers, who worry that Iraq might regard it as a provocation justifying retaliation.
 
Big Anti-War Rally Held
 That view was expressed today at an outdoor anti-war rally in Istanbul that was attended by an estimated 40,000 protesters and sponsored by the main opposition group, the Social Democratic Populist Party.
"Ozal is gambling with the lives of our citizens," Erdal Inonu, the party's leader, told the crowd. "We are definitely against the use of Turkish bases in this conflict."
Some of objections are rooted in unhappiness with Mr. Ozal himself, who is accused by critics of unconstitutionally ursurping too many powers as he single-handedly guides Turkish policy in the crisis. But the protests also reflect a traditional caution here about involvement in any fight among Arabs, on the argument that Turkey is slated by geography to live with and trade with often unpredictable and sometimes dangerous neighbors like Iraq.
So the problem for Turkey has been to support the American-led coalition and perhaps also remove President Saddam Hussein, who is almost universally loathed here, while not appearing to exceed actions mandated by various United Nations resolutions.

HEADLINE: Insilco Declares Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 13

 BODY:
The Insilco Corporation, a diversified company whose products include military equipment, Rolodex files and textbooks, filed today for bankruptcy protection from its creditors.
The company said it had bargained fruitlessly since May 1 to get easier payment terms from its leading bondholders. The company has a total debt of $764 million. 
 Insilco, based in Midland, Tex., was acquired in 1988 by two Texas oilmen, Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown, for $1.1 billion, which included the assumption of $208 million in debt.
 
$530 Million in 'Junk Bonds'
 It had struggled for the last year under a heavy debt load that included $530 million in high-yield "junk bonds" and senior notes with yields of 9.5 percent to 16.75 percent.
Debt costs totaled $113.5 million last year and had threatened to overwhelm the company for months. Its 1990 sales were approximately $700 million, a spokesman said today.
The bankruptcy filing was a blow to Merrill Lynch & Company, the investment bank that raised nearly $1 billion for the Insilco takeover in 1988. It also provided a new warning that many companies operating with huge debts piled on during takeovers, buyouts and financial restructurings in the late 1980's would default on those payments in a weakened economy.
In a statement, Insilco blamed its troubles on "an increasingly difficult business environment and recessionary economy." The company earned $44.8 million from operations in the nine months that ended in September and reported a net loss of $52.4 million for the period. Its sales totaled $501.3 million.
 
Four Units Not Included
 Four Insilco subsidiaries were not included in the filing. They were Daceasy Inc., a publisher of accounting software; the Taylor Publishing Company, a textbook publisher; the Valentec International Corporation, a military equipment maker, and Stewart Connector Systems Inc., which manufactures industrial equipment.
Insilco said that its cash flow from operations was positive, but that it was unlikely to be able to meet future debt payments.
"After reviewing all available options, management concluded that a filing was necessary to preserve the assets and values of the Insilco operations," the spokesman said.
Besides bondholders, other large creditors included a group of banks with loans outstanding to Insilco of $234 million. Wells Fargo & Company was the lead bank in the financing arrangement.
In a series of assets sales, Insilco raised $160 million in the last two years that was used to reduce debt. The 1988 buyout by Mr. Wagner and Mr. Brown was executed with $980 million in borrowed money. One of the auctioned subsidiaries was Red Devil paints, one of Insilco best-known consumer brands.
 
Bid Picked Over Managers'
 The Wagner-Brown group took Insilco private after the company's directors chose its offer over one initiated by management.
Insilco, a descendant of the International Silver Company, was listed at the time of the takeover on the New York Stock Exchange. The company shed its silverware business in 1983. In 1989, Mr. Wagner and Mr. Brown moved the company's headquarters to Midland from Meriden, Conn.
The buyout, completed in late 1988, came after Mr. Wagner and Mr. Brown had made huge profits in takeover battles but had never succeeded in completing a large buyout.
 
Teamed With Pickens
 They joined T. Boone Pickens in his 1984 attempt to acquire the Gulf Oil Company and, later, the Phillips Petroleum Company and the Unocal Corporation. On their own, they made separate, unwelcomed bids for the Midcon Corporation, the Panhandle Eastern Corporation and the USG Corporation.
Insilco said today that it would continue to operate all 12 subsidiaries, which have a total payroll of 6,600 employees and are in several states and foreign countries.
Before the bankruptcy filing, a group of banks agreed to advance Insilco $57 million to be used for operations, the company said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Newspapers Raising Prices as Advertising Falls

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Across the country, newspaper prices have been increasing in a trend that has not been seen since the early 1980's, when prices jumped to their current levels.
While nearly 90 percent of the nation's newspapers now sell on newsstands or in racks for 25 cents or 35 cents apiece, several industry executives said they expect most papers to sell for at least 35 cents or even 50 cents within two years. 
 Similarly, although about 62 percent of the nation's Sunday papers now sell for less than $1, some executive predict that most Sunday papers will soon cost $1, $1.25 or even $1.50.
Yesterday, The Los Angeles Times raised the price of its Sunday paper to $1.25, up from $1, which had been the price since 1983.
A week ago, 11 newspapers owned by the Gannett Company raised the price of their Sunday issues to $1.50.
 
Moves by Three Dailies
 In the last three months, The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, The Kansas City Star and The Belleville News-Democrat in Illinois -- all owned by Capital Cities/ABC Inc. -- increased the single-copy price of their daily papers to 50 cents. Both the Fort Worth and Belleville papers had been sold for 25 cents and The Kansas City Star had cost 35 cents.
In early December, The Wall Street Journal raised its price to 75 cents from 50 cents.
Today, The New York Times raised the price of its national edition to 75 cents in the Midwest and the Southwest. It had cost 50 cents in the Midwest and 60 cents in the Southwest. As a test, The Times has been selling for 75 cents in the Southeast since September, but remains at 50 cents in the Far West and Northeast, and 40 cents in the New York City area.
Industry executives said circulation rates were rising because of the depressed advertising market and increased publishing costs. For example, the price of newsprint has gone up twice in the last seven months.
"The newspaper is still one of the best deals in town," said Jeffrey S. Klein, assistant to the publisher of The Los Angeles Times.
But in an industry that perceives increasing readership as a key to its future, there has been considerable reluctance to charge more for a newspaper because sales almost always drop, at least temporarily.
 
Ads vs. Circulation
 Publishers must weigh the appeal of higher revenues against the effects of lost circulation on advertisers. At the very least, newspapers that raise their prices must struggle to regain their former circulation.
Through most of the 1980's, both the total amount of advertising and the ad rates -- which generate about 75 percent of the revenue at most papers -- were increasing steadily and there was less pressure to raise prices.
In recent months, however, many newspapers have seen stunning drops in advertising because of the recession. Historically, when advertising revenue flags, publishers demand more money from circulation.
"People are likely to be more emboldened when they haven't got anyplace else to go," said Phillip J. Meek, president of the publishing group for Capital Cities/ABC.
 
The Payoff in Fort Worth
 The financial returns can be substantial, even if fewer copies are sold.
For instance, Weldon Whiteman, circulation director of The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, said his paper lost 24 percent of its single-copy sales after it doubled its price to 50 cents in November. About 25,000 copies, out of a daily circulation of 259,000, are sold in racks and at newstands.
But while The Star-Telegram received 16 cents a copy from wholesalers when the price was 25 cents, it now gets 32 cents a copy. Even with a 24 percent drop in the number of papers sold, annual revenues from single-copy sales would increase by about $650,000, to nearly $2 million.
When the single-copy price was increased, The Star-Telegram also raised the price of home-delivery subscriptions to $10.95 a month from $9.95. Mr. Whiteman said the paper's home-delivery circulation of roughly 230,000 dropped by only 1,000. Though some subscribers canceled, the single-copy price increase had apparently pushed some other people to subscribe rather than pay more to buy the paper each day.
 
Earlier Price Increases
 In the early 1980's, the last time that newspaper prices surged industrywide, most papers moved from 15 cents or 20 cents a copy to 25 cents and some crept up later to 35 cents. The most popular price for Sunday papers in 1980 was 50 cents or less; by 1985, almost half of them were selling for 75 cents or $1.
Similarly, in the mid-1970's,, most papers increased to 15 cents from 10 cents and Sunday papers to 50 cents from 25 cents.
In each case, the newspaper industry was in an advertising slump.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Takes Over Airport for Atlantic City

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
After more than a decade of squabbling and intergovernmental rivalry, the State of New Jersey has acquired Atlantic City's tiny airport, promising to turn it into a "world class" place that will open this area to expanded tourism and a larger gambling market.
Though financing for the $11.3 million acquisition still has to be worked out and ground-breaking for a new and greatly expanded airport terminal and runways is at least six months away, backers promise great things. 
 "This airport will be the catalyst that spurs economic activity in the region," Senator Frank R. Lautenberg said at the announcement of the purchase on Jan. 9. "It is a known fact that when a major airport comes into being, there is a flurry of sustained economic activity that follows."
The agreement breaks a 12-year stalemate that has kept the airport from expanding.
 
City Tried to Keep Control
 Atlantic City, under successive mayors but most notably during the six-year tenure of Mayor James L. Usry, was determined to retain ownership and control of the airport.
The city not only owned the 83 acres on which the terminal stands but also had effective control of 5,000 surrounding acres used by the Federal Aviation Administration Technical Center. The city's contract with the Federal Government provided that if the land was used for anything other than Federal aviation, it would revert to the city.
For years, the city refused to allow sale to the state or county governments, saying it would invoke the reversion clause if it lost control of the airport property.
But when Mayor James A. Whelan took office last summer, one of the first things he did was offer to sell the airport to the state at what he called "a fair price."
Beyond the payment of the $11.3 million, which the city will use for capital improvements and repairs, it will continue to receive $300,000 a year through 1999 from Pan Am World Services Inc., which holds the contract for operations at the airport.
 
Beyond 'Skin-Deep Gold Coast'
 The state's acquisition of the city's 83 acres and the terminal building paves the way for creation of a South Jersey Transportation Authority to operate the airport. The airport is 12 miles west of Atlantic City and is now used primarily for charter flights serving the casino industry.
Gov. Jim Florio, who announced the acquisition, said expanding the airport would mean transforming the area into "something more than just a skin-deep gold coast."
The expansion plan will allow negotiations with major air carriers about establishing more regularly scheduled service from cities around the country.
In addition to the charter flights, USAir offers twice-a-day regularly scheduled flights to and from Philadelphia, Baltimore, Chicago and Pittsburgh.
Thomas D. Carver, president of the Casino Association of New Jersey, the trade group in Atlantic City, said he believed there was potential for major air service but the economic climate might make it difficult.
 
Trying to Replace Charters
 "We know we have the market," he said, "but Atlantic City is what is called a 'resort destination' and that means we are not high up on the list of cities to be served with air routes."
But he said there was potential for regular service between Atlantic City and Boston, Chicago, Washington and "some of the cities in the Sunbelt" like Atlanta. Planners are also trying to find ways to replace existing charter service to the New York area with regularly scheduled commercial service.
But Mr. Carver said the development of a major air terminal in the Atlantic City area was not intended simply to be a feeder service for the casino industry.
"There are 300,000 air passengers in this area who use the Philadelphia airport because there is no air service here," he said.
Thomas M. Downs, the New Jersey Transportation Commissioner, also said in an interview that the counties surrounding the airport, Cumberland, Salem, Atlantic and Cape May, "are the growth areas."
 
Shore Area Is Growing
 Part of the reason, he said, is that property values, while going up 25 to 30 percent last year, are still lower than elsewhere in the state.
"It's been down so long it looks like up," he said. "But what is happening is that people are making life style choices to live near the seashore, and that makes it a growth area. Low-cost areas like southern New Jersey have experienced moderate to rapid growth because the dollar values are better."
The $11.3 million for the acquisition and, later, money for improvement and expansion will not come from general revenue funds. Instead, it will come from Federal Aviation Administration Trust Fund grants and state money probably backed by revenue bonds covered by airline fees.
Mr. Downs and others also say that the South Jersey area, from the Shore to Camden, also has potential for growth as a high-technology manufacturing and research area, particularly because of the F.A.A.'s Technical Center at the airport.
"That is the single piece that no one else has," Mr. Downs said. "This is one of the highest-tech aviation facilities in the country, where they test the air traffic control systems for the entire country.
"The Federal Government will spend over a billion dollars here over the next five years, and there are already a thousand or more people employed in private-sector subcontracting. That could double, so the potential is here."

HEADLINE: Chief of Bridges To Seek Advice On Repair Plan

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
New York City's Transportation Commissioner, Lucius J. Riccio, said yesterday that he planned to enlist consulting engineers from outside the department to re-evaluate completely the Bridge Bureau's budget and maintenance priorities. He acted in the face of a city move to scale down a 10-year plan for the repair of all bridges.
Department engineers have said that the retrenchment, part of a round of deep city budget cuts, will inevitably lead to the closing of dozens of bridges. Recent inspections by city and state engineers have discovered conditions far worse than had been foreseen when the plan was adopted. 
 The current 10-year plan was adopted under the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, but its goals and blueprints had been endorsed by the administration of David N. Dinkins.
 
Praise of Plan Dims
 The plan was the first effort to repair all the city bridges and institute a maintenance program of washing, painting and lubricating them to prevent further deterioration. The plan grew out of the 1988 closing of the Williamsburg Bridge, which had deteriorated badly after years of neglect.
But Mr. Riccio, who had praised the plan when he took office, says now that it is not complete and may no longer be appropriate for these hard economic times.
"If you look at it," he said, "it isn't much of a plan -- it doesn't specify what bridges need the most attention and at what time."
The Commissioner said that given the city's financial woes, he must re-examine which bridges are in need of immediate attention and which can stand delay. "There are some bridges that you can afford to repair, and others that you can't and might have to be closed," he said.
Mr. Riccio said that he was seeking qualified professional engineers, preferably on a volunteer basis, to help the city re-evaluate its bridge program.
 
Limited Resources Noted
 "I want to make sure that we are making the smartest decisions with the limited resources that we have," the Commissioner said, "and that we have a complete and thorough analysis of the bridge situation."
After dismissing his deputy bridge commissioner last week, Mr. Riccio is personally overseeing the city's Bridge Bureau until a replacement is found. The former deputy, David Steinberger, had spoken out against cuts in the city's program for bridge maintenance and rehabilitation.
The city has cut the bridge maintenance program for the fiscal year that begins in July by 38 percent from what was outlined in the 10-year plan -- to $5.8 million from $9.4 million in 1991. Spending over the next five years would drop to $930 million from a planned $1.2 billion, city officials have said.
Mr. Riccio did transfer $60 million in funds from highway repair programs to bridges in an effort to offset the cuts.
City engineers have said that as a result of the cuts, many bridges will not be painted or cleaned and scores of deteriorating ones will not be repaired until after 1995.
Mr. Riccio said priority would be given to heavily used bridges and those in worst shape, like the East River bridges.
Last year the city commissioned a report by a group of civil engineering professors from five city colleges. They warned that the city's deteriorating bridges could not survive further reductions in maintenance and repair.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
If It's Tuesday, It Must Be Time To Fight Crime

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
When Mayor David N. Dinkins declared last year that New Yorkers must "take back our streets, by night as well as by day" nobody said it would be easy. Yet this may be one war in which some couch potatoes willingly enlist.
The Mayor acknowledged that the centerpiece of any war on crime had to be an expanded police force. Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown has managed to increase street patrols modestly through redeployment. But the prognosis for even the scaled-down public-safety agenda proposed jointly by Mr. Dinkins and the City Council last month is problematic, given the scale of economies that the Mayor is due to announce this week. 
 Another component of his exhortation last year could turn out to be nearly free, though. The Mayor appealed to New Yorkers "to come out to help stop the violence" and referred vaguely to his administration's commitment to "organizing Tuesday nights out against crime." Since then, his Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Mark Green, has transformed an imaginative concept into a concrete program that may augur a relatively minor, but measurable, improvement in the city's fragile quality of life.
Underlying the concept are three premises: that restaurants, theaters and garages can be persuaded to reduce prices one night a week when business, customarily slack, is worse because of the recession; that the bargains will induce more people to go out, and that there is greater safety in numbers.
 The proposal by Mr. Green, whose first premise has passed its initial test, represents a confluence of benefits. It is arguably pro-consumer, anti-crime and good for business. And it is unlikely to drain government resources and might even gen erate greater tax revenue.
 In earlier wars, Tuesday was associated with meatlessness (then regarded as a sacrifice, not a dietary goal). Mr. Green hopes to couple going out with Tuesday night in much the same way that the sports and television industries have linked Monday night with football (their success is one reason Mr. Green's proposed nights out are planned for Tuesdays) and that a pasta promoter attempted to tie Wednesdays with a brand of spaghetti.
Already, leading industry executives have endorsed these suggestions for Tuesday night discounts:
Participating movie theaters would reduce prices by about a third -- from $7.50 to $5, for example; restaurants would offer a 15 percent discount on dinner bills; parking garages would grant a flat $3 off regular rates; Broadway and Off-Broadway theatrical producers, many of whom already provide same-day, half-price tickets on consignment at booths operated by the nonprofit Theater Development Fund, would advertise the reduced rates and, with the fund, might waive all or part of the $2 a ticket service charge.
The discount proposal has been embraced by representatives of the Metropolitan Theater Owners, the Metropolitan Parking Association, the New York State Restaurant Association and the League of American Theaters and Producers. The American Express Company plans to publish and distribute a directory of participating establishments.
If necessity is the mother of invention, this one can claim at least two fathers. Mr. Dinkins's idea was inspired by an annual National Night Out Against Crime -- the seventh of which was marked last August in communities across the country -- and by Monday night discounts initiated a decade ago by movie-theater owners in France to lure potential filmgoers from their television screens.
While Mr. Green's proposal may help revive New York's entertainment industry, it risks inviting references to the Mayor's penchant for party-going ("no new tuxes," he promised, jocularly, last month). Nonetheless, while the former Mayor Edward I. Koch protested unsuccessfully against higher movie-theater ticket prices, Mr. Dinkins may actually succeed in lowering them.
How much the proposal advances the "new public order" that the Mayor has advocated will depend on the degree to which people participate and whether the police can adequately guarantee their lives and liberty as they pursue happiness.
In 1989, the last year for which complete figures are available, Tuesday was the busiest day of the week for New York City burglars and auto thieves and the second busiest for rapists and robbers. Implicit in Mr. Dinkins's appeal to take back the streets is an alarming acknowledgement: that many streets are now out of control. Even a small reduction in crime, though, would surely be worth the price of that admission.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Plans $500 Million in New Taxes in Next Fiscal Year

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration will propose to balance New York City's budget for the coming fiscal year with nearly $1 billion in service cuts and more than $500 million in new taxes, city officials said last night.
Most of the new revenue would come from an increase in property taxes, an uphill fight in the City Council in an election year. 
 Mayor David N. Dinkins and senior officials agreed on details of the spending plan in recent days as they prepared to present their preliminary budget on Wednesday. They hope to close a budget gap of more than $2 billion projected for the fiscal year that starts July 1.
At the same time some actions outlined inthe plan would go toward closing a gap of $500 million in the current fiscal year.
Budget Director Philip R. Michael declined to say just how large the proposed property-tax increase would be or what it would mean for the typical homeowner. But he said the overall tax plan would bring in between $500 million and $600 million.
 
Income-Tax Rise to Be Sought
 Officials said they would propose that part of the increase come from raising the personal income-tax surcharge, which would require approval by the State Legislature.
Many economists believe that increasing the property tax would do the least damage to the local economy. But the Council hastraditionally resisted increases for small homeowners, and with all 35 exisiting Council seats and 16 new ones at stake in a special election this year, that resistance is not likely to change. The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, has vowed that tax increases must be a last resort after waste is cut from the budget.
Some city officials said the size of the proposed tax package had crept up in recent days as Mr. Dinkins resisted making deeper budget cuts. But Mr. Michael said that both the amount of the cuts and the amount of proposed taxes had increased as officials revised downward their projections of how much money could be raised through bond refinancing.
The city hopes to gain $200 millionthrough productivity improvements in its labor force and increased revenue collections, mostly through improvements in tax audits. It expects to pick up $100 million more through reductions in state and Federal mandates that require the city to perform certain functions, and it hopes to close the rest of the gap through bond refinancing and other financial maneuvers.
 
'Striking' Reductions Hinted
 Asked about service cuts, which would require a number of agencies to trim their operating budgets by more than 17.5 percent and to reduce everything from parks maintenance to street cleaning, Mr. Michael said, "I think it's going to be pretty striking how far the Mayor's gone."
Officials said that the plan would lead to thousands of layoffs in a number of agencies but that they had not yet determined the precise number.
The budget proposals, made as the city strives to cope with the effects of a regional economic slump and almost a decade of steady growth in the city work force, are sure to prompt debate, not only with the Council, which must approve the budget, but also with various constituency groups around the city that will fight to preserve their pet programs. Officials said the city's five district attorneys were bitterly resisting proposed cuts to their agencies.
 
Some Eliminations Planned
 Some smaller city agencies would be eliminated altogether and their functions shifted to other departments. They include the Taxi and Limousine Commission, which would be merged into the Consumer Affairs Department, and the Board of Standards and Appeals and the Mayor's Office of Construction, which would be folded into the Buildings Department.
But some other consolidations originally considered, like collapsing the Department of Cultural Affairs into another agency, were shelved after running into intense opposition.
Mr. Michael said that the plan was only a blueprint, but that because of the strict procedures instituted after the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's, it was more detailed than most plans that other governments might present so far in advance of a new fiscal year. "This gives us a terrific opportunity for six months of real planning," he said.

HEADLINE: Peru, Its U.S. Aid Imperiled, Plots a New Drug Strategy

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru Jan. 13

 BODY:
With Peru facing a March 1 deadline for the possible cutoff of $100 million in American anti-drug aid, officials here are working to fashion a new strategy to cut exports of the raw material of cocaine.
Despite millions of dollars in American aid money spent over the last three years to eradicate coca bushes, Peru's cultivation increased by 25 percent in the same period, reaching roughly 450,000 acres today. 
 Charging that Peruvian corruption has undermined eradication and interdiction efforts, some American drug officials are arguing in Washington that President Bush should not certify to Congress on March 1 that Peru is cooperating in the drug war.
Without this certification, Peru would fall into a sort of bureaucratic outlaw status. Peru would lose $100 million in United States economic and military aid scheduled for 1991. By law, the United States would have to vote against loans for Peru in multilateral banks.
"There is a real risk that Peru will be declared ineligible for aid," Diego Garcia Sayan, a human rights lawyer, said Thursday at a conference he organized to alert his countrymen to the problem.
 
Many Peruvians Unconcerned
 Although Peru's position as the source of 60 percent of the world's coca crop has become the overriding issue in relations with the United States, many Peruvians profess a lack of concern. Peruvians are more concerned by other statistics: a 1990 inflation rate of 7,650 percent, and a 1990 toll of 3,384 killed in political violence.
Helping a depressed economy, coca base has become the nation's single most successful export, earning about $1.5 billion last year. When Lima's largest selling newspaper, La Republica, recently published an eight-page interview with Peru's President, Alberto K. Fujimori, a question on narcotics only surfaced on the sixth page.
But the fast approaching deadline for certification has forced the six-month-old Fujimori Government to start moving on a new antidrug strategy.
"Our fear is that if Peru is decertified, the people will come out of the woodwork who want to legalize cocaine and to tax it," said an economist who is heading a Government antidrug task force.
 
Coca Prices Crash
 The Fujimori approach, which will be unveiled in Washington next month, stresses the interdiction of planes and crop substitution.
In contrast, the American-endorsed strategy has almost entirely relied on eradication and land seizures.
After four years, the eradication effort, directed out of a $1.2 million American-built base in the Huallaga Valley, has only blunted the explosive spread of the coca crop.
Indeed, American efforts notwithstanding, the crop has grown so fast that prices crashed in 1990. Today, a kilo bag of dry coca leaves fetches only 40 American cents in the Huallaga, well below the $1.40 break-even cost for growers.
Hoping to take advantage of these market forces, Mr. Fujimori wants to use $60 million in planned American economic aid to launch an aggressive crop substitution program.
 
The Weakest Link
 To further drive down the cost, the Peruvian authorities want to cut the drug chain at its weakest link -- the long-haul planes that carry semirefined cocaine base from Peru's growing areas to Colombia's cocaine laboratories.
On paper, Peru's current strategy of seizing coca base on the ground appears successful -- four tons last year. But this amount represents only 1 percent of the estimated 400 tons that were shipped to Colombia.
Officials of the Drug Enforcement Administration have complained that seizures would be greater if corrupt army officers in the Huallaga would stop tipping off traffickers before police raids from the base at Santa Lucia.
"There is little doubt that there was a fair amount of ratting going on," a diplomat here said.
Peruvians planning the new drug strategy acknowledge that corruption and interservice rivalry will threaten the air interdiction effort.
"You can't throw army generals who earn $350 a month against the drug business," the planner said.
 
One Effort Stalls
 Instead, a new agency, the Autonomous Authority for Alternative Development, is to use part of the planned $39 million in American military aid to form a highly paid, well-equipped and well-armed military unit that would intercept drug planes. By creating a transportation bottleneck, the Government hopes to further drive down prices paid farmers for their leaves.
But a timid effort against drug planes stalled in December when traffickers immediately fought back with bribes and blackmail, their two most powerful weapons.
In mid-December, a Peruvian Navy plane forced down a Colombian trafficker's plane in the Huallaga area. Within hours, traffickers were working the telephones, threatening to kill family members of key military commanders. The the military ordered a suspension of the campaign.
"Don't forget who are the drug traffickers in Peru -- the Shining Path, the M.R.T.A. and the soldiers," the planner said, referring to Peru's two Marxist guerrilla armies, both active in the Huallaga. "They all know how to shoot,"
A serious effort against the planes would require special high-security measures to protect lives of the campaign directors.
In a second effort, on Dec. 31, the Peruvian police caught traffickers loading coca base into a Colombian plane in Uchiza, a Huallaga town. Three police officers were ordered to accompany the Colombian as he flew to Santa Lucia, the American-built base 20 miles away.
Instead, the police officers were found later that day at an oil company airstrip several hundred miles north of Uchiza. The Colombian plane was nowhere to be found. The police officers had $24,000 in their pockets.
