HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Baker Says Anti-Iraq Allies, Except Syria, Agree on Force

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that except for Syria, the nations of the anti-Iraq coalition were in agreement on the timing and necessity of force to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait after midnight Tuesday.
Speaking to reporters at the end of his 10-nation tour, which involved talks with Washington's major military allies in the force against Iraq, Mr. Baker indicated that as far as the United States was concerned, both it and its allies were ready to open fire on Iraqi forces in Kuwait anytime after midnight Tuesday, Eastern standard time. 
 No further consultations are necessary, save for the precise hour of attack, unless Iraq makes some serious gesture to leave Kuwait before the deadline, American officials indicated.
"As we conclude this trip," Mr. Baker said after his talks this morning with President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, "it seems to me that the international coalition is well prepared politically, economically and militarily for any eventuality as we move toward midnight Jan. 15."
 
'No One Has Balked'
 "No one has balked," a senior Administration official said of Mr. Baker's visit to Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, the United Arab Emirates, Turkey, Switzerland and Syria and to the exiled Kuwaiti leadership in Taif, Saudi Arabia.
"France will fight," the official said, "if that is what it comes to. With respect to France, the deadline is real. In my opinion, France and other countries will want to do everything they can in order to try and achieve a political solution before midnight on the 15th of January. But if the balloon goes up, the French will be there."
Although the Soviet Union has apparently decided to use the diversion of the Persian Gulf crisis to crack down on the Baltics, much the way Moscow used the 1956 Suez crisis to invade Hungary, Mr. Baker did not appear to be particularly concerned now that events in the Soviet Union would disrupt the Administration's gulf strategy.
The senior Administration official traveling aboard Mr. Baker's aircraft said Washington saw no signs that events in the Baltics were either diminishing the Soviet commitment to see Iraqi troops out of Kuwait or were leading President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to conclude that he could now more easily defy the international coalition.
 
Incentive for Gorbachev
 If anything, the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, now has more incentive than ever to toe the American line in the gulf, in hopes that this might reduce the negative impact and publicity that his Baltic crackdown is generating with the American public and American decision-makers.
At the same time, though, the Bush Administration is clearly going to calibrate its response to the crackdown in Lithuania to make sure that Washington does not alienate Moscow to the point where it diminishes its support for America's gulf policy.
Still, juggling two full-blown crises at once is clearly taxing senior Administration policy makers. Mr. Baker telephoned the President three different times from three different countries on Saturday and at least twice on Sunday as he traveled from Turkey to London.
The senior Administration official said that of the 28 nations with "ground forces" in Saudi Arabia, only Syria's 15,000-man force is not certain to take part in any offensive action to dislodge Iraqi troops from Kuwait and Syria would prefer instead to confine its role to simply defending Saudi Arabia.
 
Defending Palestinian Cause
 President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, American officials said, has become concerned about how Mr. Hussein has successfully depicted himself as the leading defender of the Palestinian cause, a role that Mr. Assad believes rightly belongs to him, and is therefore leery about siding with Western powers in an offensive against Iraq.
The Syrian leader feels that going beyond using his troops to defend Saudi Arabia could undermine his Arab nationalist credentials, although he is still considering Arab requests for a more offensive role.
The official said that while France, like others, was doing all that it could to find a political solution -- even dangling an international conference before Mr. Hussein as a face-saving cover for him to withdraw from Kuwait -- President Francois Mitterrand has assured Mr. Bush that his forces will be engaged if and when the fighting has to begin after Jan. 15.
The official said some countries that have sent only small naval or air units to the gulf and no ground forces were not certain to take part in any fighting because their units were originally sent either to defend Saudi Arabia or to help impose the United Nations naval embargo on Iraq and their legislatures have not taken action yet to reassign them for offensive purposes.
 
Major Deployments by 4 Nations
 Nevertheless, these small naval and air units, from countries like Greece, have virtually no military significance, since in the event of a war the vast majority of air and naval power will be deployed by the United States, France, Saudi Arabia and Britain.
The key points from the perspective of American officials is that all the countries that have committed ground forces have signaled their willingness to use them.
The Administration official would not comment on limitations that President Ozal has imposed on the use of Turkish bases in a war to drive Iraq out of Kuwait, limitations that Mr. Ozal reiterated to Mr. Baker in their talks today.
The Turkish public remains highly ambivalent about the gulf crisis and their Government's involvement.
These reservations are based in part on a neutralist tradition in the Turkish Army, but even more on a concern by Turks that if Iraq is devastated by war, a power vacuum would be created that would generate chaos on their eastern frontier, which has been unstable for years because of the presence of millions of Kurds seeking independence.

HEADLINE: After Layoffs, St. Louis Rethinks Future, Again

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Outside the gargantuan 400-acre complex of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation it rained ice this week; inside the dozens of buildings there was a blizzard of pink slips. In the wake of the Defense Department decision to scrap the unbuilt, multibillion-dollar A-12 attack aircraft, the aerospace company began laying off one out of every seven workers.
The St. Louis economy was in trouble even before the latest layoffs, the second set in six months at McDonnell Douglas. A Chrysler plant in nearby Fenton, Mo., was trying, vainly, to stave off a shutdown. The real estate market went stagnant. 
 Although Missouri's population has increased slightly in recent years, each year since 1988 more people have left the state than have moved into it. There was a net loss of 6,000 people in 1989 and 7,000 in 1990. The figure for 1991 is predicted to be 10,000.
 
A Powerful Symbol
 But McDonnell Douglas, which employs 3 percent of the metropolitan St. Louis work force of 1.2 million, is a powerful symbol. Like Stan Musial, the slugger who carried the St. Louis Cardinals through the 1940's and 1950's, "MDC" has been part muscle and part myth. To see the company drop 9,000 of 42,000 employees in six months recalls the bitter lesson of the early 1980's: An economy too closely tied to making automobiles and airplanes is an economy looking for an accident.
"This was our earthquake," said one McDonnell executive, referring to the quake that, despite predictions last year, did not happen in southeast Missouri.
The A-12's other builder, the General Dynamics Corporation, also has headquarters here, but its layoffs will primarily come at plants elsewhere.
Now this region, where people find poetry in blueprints and pride in engineering feats like the Gateway Arch, must again rethink its future. The unemployment rate in the St. Louis area, 6.5 percent, slightly above the national average of 6.1 percent, is expected to jump to 7 percent this month.
While it still has stable companies that employ thousands, like the Anheuser-Busch Companies, the Monsanto Company and Ralston Purina, and has a fast-growing health services field that has added 2,000 to 5,000 jobs annually since the mid-1980's, the metropolitan region still lost 17 percent of its manufacturing jobs in the 1980's, nearly triple the national loss.
 
Fewer Manufacturing Jobs
 "In terms of manufacturing employment, we lost 44,000 jobs," said Cletus C. Coughlin, a research officer at the Federal Reserve Bank in St. Louis. "Then it picked up a bit until the net loss was 35,000 between 1979 and 1989. One in four jobs here used to be in manufacturing. Now it's one in five, or a little more than five."
Russell Signorino, a researcher with the Missouri Division of Employment Security, said: "There's always been a sense of dependability in this area, a sense that makes you say, when you go to work for one of the larger employers, 'There will always be opportunity there. I can make a career there.'
"That's not reality any more. Anywhere. You have to be ready to deal with major changes that are possibly out of your control and out of the control of your employer. What has happened with McDonnell Douglas, with the auto industry, with financial services, it's going to occur everywhere."
The recent ups and downs of Tim Garrett, a 40-year-old tool and die maker laid off from McDonnell Douglas last week, are an eloquent illustration. "I came here about five years ago from a business that the Japanese had bought and shut down," he said. "I came here for this job. But the odds of anyone getting a job as a tool and die maker in this area are about nil now."
"I'm talking to a few of us, trying to get a couple of cars to drive to Wichita on Monday," in the hopes of finding jobs at a Boeing Company plant there, he said. If not, "we've got a little in savings. The question is, do you stay and weather this out? You could spend all your money waiting, and then how do you go looking?"
 
'Much Worse Last Time'
 Yet despite the gloomy prognosis, and the steady loss of jobs -- leaving about 85,000 people unemployed in the 10 counties in southwestern Illinois and eastern Missouri that make up the St. Louis metropolitan area -- it is hard to find unadulterated pessimism. Economists echo one another as they say, "It was much worse last time."
"Last time," was a decade ago, when the auto industry here went through its nightmare years. In 1979, more than 70,000 people were employed making cars here; one-third of those jobs disappeared in the next five years. By this spring, economists expect the number to be about 36,000.
The economy somersaulted so badly in that period that, by 1984, 130,000 people were unemployed and the unemployment rate approached 12 percent. But by the latter part of the decade, there was a minirevival both in the city's neighborhoods and the downtown.
The area's population continued to radiate outward, as building booms took place farther from the city. The region's population had dipped by 50,000 from 1970 to 1980 to 2.38 million; by the late 1980's it was back above 2.4 million.
The shock of the early 1980's was a harsh lesson in the virtue of economic diversity. Last week's upheaval at McDonnell Douglas was a lesson out of the same book, economists say. But it is a lesson easier to learn in theory than in practice -- especially in the scores of small communities around the city.
 
Beginning of Layoffs
 Last July, McDonnell had a major "reduction in force." By mid-fall, about 4,000 workers had been laid off or pensioned off. Some, like Lawrence Lieberman, had worked for the company most of their working lives.
Mr. Lieberman was one of scores of mid-level managers pressed to take early retirement when the layoffs hit. Since then, the 64-year-old chemical engineer, who earned $65,000 a year ago, has found no part-time work -- "unless I want to flip hamburgers or be a security guard," he said.
But there is more respect than resentment in his tone when he speaks of the company. Most of all, he regrets the way the layoffs have bolstered the attitude of new workers that a career is a sometime thing. "Only in the last four or five years has the attitude changed to: 'I'm going to be here four or five years and then go on to something else,' " Mr. Lieberman said. "That's not the way to look at it."
More and more workers see no other way to look at it. Beyond the shocks of the McDonnell layoffs, there are other worries here. For instance, some are worried about Trans World Airlines. If that company has to undergo a major shakeout, will St. Louis lose the prestige and economic advantage of having its airport as T.W.A.'s hub?
Another worry is what the state will be able to do to ease the city's pain. Missouri has one of the lowest per-capita tax rates in the country for state income and sales taxes. Retraining is now the buzzword here, but it is not clear how much the region can afford.
 
Steady Employers Remain
 Yet there are other large companies that remain steady employers. Anheuser-Busch, for instance, employs 5,500 workers locally. Although Monsanto had some business reversals, employment in the region's chemical industry stood at 19,800 in November, up 700 from a year earlier. But these employers cannot make up for the troubles elsewhere.
"If our business was of a cyclical nature, the layoffs would give a terrific opportunity to employ a terrific number of people," said Michael Roarty, an executive vice president at Anheuser-Busch. "At Busch it doesn't work like that. We can't absorb those people when thrown into the mainstream."

HEADLINE: State of the States, 1991: Rocky, Almost Everywhere

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 11

 BODY:
It is normally a time for upbeat comments about bright futures and expansive political visions. But governors from coast to coast, Republicans as well as Democrats, conservatives and liberals, have stood before their state legislatures in recent days to open the new year with refrains that were as depressing as they were similar.
The state of their states, they said, was anything but healthy, and the watchwords were retrenchment, caution and, inevitably, more taxes. 
 "There have been few times in the history of this state when the dual threats of war and a faltering economy have so dramatically and precipitously affected our lives," said Gov. John R. McKernan Jr. of Maine, a Republican, as he unveiled plans last week to lay off state workers, cut spending for most departments by 15 percent and raise new revenue to balance the budget.
 
California Faces Big Deficit
 His words found an echo 3,000 miles away a few days later from the new Governor of California, Pete Wilson. Standing in the ornate State Assembly chamber here, where some of the most innovative and costly social programs in America have been conceived, Mr. Wilson told lawmakers on Wednesday that the nation's most populous state was facing a budget deficit of $7 billion over the next 18 months.
The next morning, Mr. Wilson issued an austerity budget that would sharply cut welfare payments to single mothers, raise vehicle license fees and taxes on alcoholic beverages, extend the sales tax to newspapers, magazines, snacks and candy ("luxuries," Mr. Wilson called them), cut much of the state's planned increases in financial aid expected by school districts and community colleges and raise tuition at state universities by 20 percent. But Mr. Wilson, a moderate Republican, still found some money for prenatal care and other programs that fit his theory that the cure for social ills lies more in prevention than remediation.
It was sobering to know that all this was the good news. Like Mr. Wilson, many governors were basing their estimates on the assumption that the economy would rebound by midyear. Much worse could be in store, Mr. Wilson conceded. "We are in considerable flux," he said. "There is a distinct possibility of a worsening of the recession."
 
Drastic Moves by Democrats
 He spoke just a day after Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, a Democrat, asked the State's General Assembly to grant him authority to furlough 100,000 state workers if necessary. "Clearly now is not the time to initiate new programs or to expand discretionary spending," he said.
The new Governor of Florida, Lawton M. Chiles Jr., a Democrat, was forced to cut $270 million from the state budget just three days after taking office, and the new Governor of Michigan, John Engler, a Republican, is expected to announce plans to lay off 8,000 state employees, 12 percent of the work force, amid skepticism that he could keep his campaign pledge to cut property taxes by 20 percent.
So it goes around the country, as governors press ahead into a recession that has forced even liberal Democrats like Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York to talk like fiscal conservatives.
"The immediate goal is to live within our means, closing the gap between what we would have proposed to spend and our diminished resources," Mr. Cuomo said in his State of the State Message on Wednesday as he faces what could be a budget shortage of $4 billion in the next fiscal year.
A day earlier, Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey offered a modest plan to create 7,000 new jobs and help middle-income people buy homes, but he faced the prospect of closing a $600 million budget gap at a time when it was politically impossible to raise taxes. Last year, at Mr. Florio's urging, the Legislature passed the largest tax increase in the state's history, and the political repercussions have been extreme.
So far, 28 of the 50 states have been forced to look at spending cuts or for added revenues to close budget gaps for the current fiscal year, and more are expected to join them, according to the National Association of State Budget Officers and the National Governors' Association.
Next week, six more new governors wade into this sea of red ink: two Republicans, Jim Edgar of Illinois and George V. Voinovich of Ohio, and four Democrats, Joan Finney of Kansas, David Walters of Oklahoma, Barbara Roberts of Oregon and Ann Richards of Texas.
When all the nation's governors have been installed, there will be 28 Democratic governors, 19 Republicans and 2 independents, both of whom are former Republicans; one state, Arizona, remains without a governor-elect pending a runoff election on Feb. 26.
 
Plans for a Lottery
 In Texas, no stranger to fiscal troubles, Governor Richards faces a $4.2 billion shortage in the two-year budget for 1992-93. She has said she hopes that a state lottery, along with a hiring freeze and some spending cuts, will avert the need for a tax increase.
Probably nowhere is the state of the states more dismal than in New England. In Massachusetts, with a long tradition of high services and high taxes, the new Governor, William F. Weld, a Republican, took office on Jan. 3 after a campaign in which he vowed to trim state government. In his inaugural address, the former Federal prosecutor prescribed what he called "entrepreneurial government."
"Let us make history as well as headlines by reinventing the way state government functions in this cradle of democratic capitalism," he said.
The fiscal dilemma is particularly pointed in California, a state that has grown in population by a staggering 24 percent, or 5.7 million people, in the last decade, mainly from immigration. This has added an enormous burden in social services and needs for new roads, classrooms, water supplies as well as more police and fire protection.
Governor Wilson rejected both across-the-board cuts and any general increase in income or sales taxes. He proposed to cut welfare grants under the Aid to Familes with Dependent Children program by 9 percent, reducing the monthly grant to a parent with two children to $633 from $694, for example. California welfare benefits are higher than any state's except Alaska. Mr. Wilson said he preferred to offer essential services rather than cash to such families.
The leadership of the Democratic-controlled Legislature did not like everything Mr. Wilson proposed, but, given the stressful times, neither did the Democrats reject his message. "We do not agree with some of the things the Governor proposes," said the President Pro Tempore of the State Senate, David A. Roberti of Los Angeles. "But we recognize the bleakness of the situation we face."

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
Questions About New Glaxo Drugs

BYLINE: By Steven Prokesch

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
IN the last decade, Glaxo Holdings P.L.C. has been one of the strongest British stocks, largely as a result of Zantac, its anti-ulcer medicine that is the world's top-selling drug. In the year that ended June 30, Zantac accounted for 49 percent of Glaxo's sales of 2.85 billion ($4.98 billion).
But a slip in Glaxo's price in recent weeks on the London Stock Exchange has raised the question of whether the long rise is over. While not expecting an immediate plunge, several analysts believe the stock, long an overperformer relative to the market, could turn into an underperformer in the months ahead. They have recently downgraded their earnings estimates for Glaxo. 
 Glaxo is seeking regulatory approval around the world for several potentially important drugs. But analysts' doubts are mounting about whether sales will grow rapidly enough to compensate for a slowdown in the sales of Zantac, which is facing a powerful new competitor, Losec (Prilosec in the United States) made by Astra A.B. of Sweden.
With Glaxo still selling at a premium of 55 to 60 percent relative to the London market, "We think it looks expensive," said Jacquelyne S. Cantle, an analyst at Smith New Court Securities P.L.C. in London. She said Glaxo was trading at 15 times expected earnings for the year that ends June 30. She and other analysts predict that when the Persian Gulf crisis is over and the British economy begins to revive, investors will move out of drug stocks and into now-depressed cyclical stocks.
For now, Miss Cantle says investors should consider reducing their Glaxo holdings and buying more reasonably priced shares of British drugcompanies whose earnings she expects to grow more rapidly in the next couple of years. These include SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. and Fisons P.L.C.
Analysts say the dollar's strength against the pound is also hurting Glaxo's earnings. The United States accounted for about 40 percent of Glaxo's sales in the 1990 fiscal year.
But the biggest problem appears to be competition from Losec, which has been doing very well in Europe. Losec, a new type of drug known as a proton-pump inhibitor, is believed to be more effective in treating ulcers than the H2 antagonists, a class of drugs that now dominates the market. This class includes Zantac; Tagamet, from SmithKline Beecham, and Pepcid, from Merck & Company.
Analysts have been expecting the United States Food and Drug Administration to approve Losec within a few weeks for treatment of peptic ulcers and other gastrointestinal diseases where treatment involves reducing stomach-acid production.
Losec, which is licensed to Merck for sale in the United States, now has F.D.A. approval only for very limited use. While it has only about 5 percent of the $1.5 billion American market for anti-ulcer drugs, some analysts predict its share could grow to 15 percent in the United States and worldwide within two years.
The importance of the impending F.D.A. decision was apparent on Friday. It was learned then that a medical magazine would claim that the F.D.A. would not give Losec full approval but might permit it to be used only after other drugs like Zantac had been tried. That caused Glaxo's stock to jump 24 pence (46 cents) in London, to close at 8.42 ($16.06). Analysts were divided about the significance of the report. A week ago, the stock had sunk to 8.11, down from 8.74 in mid-December.
Glaxo's American depository receipts, which reached $34.63 in mid-December on the New York Stock Exchange, closed Friday at $32.75 each, up 87.5 cents.
Analysts predict that Zantac's sales, which in the local currencies of its markets rose 16 percent in fiscal 1990, will grow only 10 to 15 percent in fiscal 1991 and will continue to slow from there.
But Glaxo has other promising new drugs for which it is seeking regulatory approval. Those that analysts say have the highest potential include Ondansetron, a drug for combating nausea and vomiting in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy; Sumatriptan, a potentially revolutionary treatment for migraine headaches, and Salmeterol, a drug that unlike existing ones, would provide asthma sufferers enough medication to sleep through the night.
By the mid- to late 1990's, Ondansetron's annual sales could reach $400 million, Sumatriptan's $1 billion and Salmeterol's $750 million, said Paul Krikler at Goldman Sachs International Ltd.
The problem is the next year or two. In the year that ends June 30, several analysts expect Glaxo's earnings to grow by 5 percent at most. But echoing others, Mr. Krikler said: "I am positive on Glaxo for the longer term."
That view is not unanimous. While Glaxo says it is confident that patents protect Zantac until 2002, Robin J. Gilbert, an analyst at James Capel & Company, said it was unclear whether the protection would last beyond 1995. Companies that make generic drugs "are expecting to target Zantac," he said. It remains to be seen, he added, just how big sellers the new Glaxo drugs will be.

HEADLINE: Financing Is Offered on S.& L. Assets

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 13

 BODY:
In an auction next month, Federal officials plan to offer purchasers financing for up to 85 percent of the price of dozens of apartment buildings in Texas that the Government acquired in the savings industry bailout.
So far, the Government has not been able to attract enough bidders on these and billions of dollars of other foreclosed properties. 
 The auction, which also includes a few office buildings and retail centers, will be the largest so far with financing provided by notes from the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency in charge of the Government's savings and loan bailout. The Government appraised the properties -- almost all are in Texas -- at a total current value of $181 million.
 
Cash Demand Dropped
 The amount of capital available to finance real estate purchases has been reduced as bank examiners have cracked down on real estate lending and a glut of office buildings has produced large losses for individual investors, insurance companies, pension funds and financial institutions.
That is the main reason the Bush Administration was criticized for initially demanding cash for thousands of properties when Resolution Trust was organized in 1989. The Administration had wanted to recover as much money for the Treasury as rapidly as possible.
But analysts, economists and investors said real estate is rarely sold without most of the payment being borrowed. The decision last month to increase the amount of Resolution Trust financing available to $7 billion, from $1 billion, was more realistic, many real estate professionals said. At least $250 million of the total is restricted to financing the sales of low-income housing.
"Unless you want to permit a complete free fall in property values, I don't know that there is any alternative," said Bernard Weinstein, an economist at the University of North Texas in Denton. "The R.T.C. has been very sensitive to local market conditions. They don't want to start another wave of distressed selling."
 
Controls $34.6 Billion
 The agency already has granted approximately $50 million in promissory notes to property acquirers. On Sept. 30, the Resolution Trust controlled $17.5 billion in real estate it had acquired from insolvent savings institutions and another $17.1 billion in past-due loans backed mainly by real estate.
Craig Hall, chief executive of the Hall Financial Group, a Dallas-based company that manages 45,000 apartment units, including 20,000 in Texas, applauded the expanded financing program. "Given the magnitude of the problem the R.T.C. has, they have to consider a variety of approaches," he said.
Several private investors cautioned that the financing effort would fail if officials priced properties too high. In that case, rent payments could not meet monthly interest payments and maintenance costs, projects would fall into default and back into Government hands. Taxpayers would then face even steeper bills from the savings industry crisis.
Sophisticated buyers will not gloss over huge expenses to repair and improve troubled properties simply to take advantage of the Government's financing if the auction price is too high, said Alan Vitale, treasurer of the Woodlands Corporation, a developer based in the Houston area.
At the auction, bidders must pay a cash deposit equal to at least 15 percent of the purchase price. The balance can be financed at a fixed interest rate of 10 percent by the Resolution Trust. The debt is owed in 1998 but can be extended twice for one year if market conditions are bad.
 
Region in Recovery
 The Texas economy's gradual recovery during the last three years has slowed since the Persian Gulf crisis. Still, many economists have said the state is unlikely to follow the rest of the nation into recession. Apartment occupancy rates exceed 90 percent in big cities in Texas for the first time in seven years.
Mr. Hall said market values for Texas apartment projects were not likely to rise much in the years ahead. Dozens of troubled projects in the state remain to be forced onto the market through foreclosures. Moreover, falling home prices have given many renters an affordable alternative to paying higher rents.
Still, the Government's plan to sell dozens of apartment buildings to single buyers, among them insurance companies, pension funds and private investor groups, is a good one, Mr. Hall said. "There are more purchasers for that kind of volume than people might realize," he said.
Resolution Trust has scheduled a conference on Tuesday in Washington to discuss the 61 properties and mortgages in the auction. Bids are due on Feb. 21, with the results to be announced on Feb. 22.
The properties were culled from loan portfolios of two Texas savings institutions the Government took over in 1989: Commonwealth Federal Savings of Houston and Alamo Federal Savings of San Antonio.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
With a Sense of Foreboding, Jordan Puts Troops on Alert

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Wedged between Israel and Iraq, Jordan has ordered a military alert and stationed thousands of troops in defensive positions overlooking the Jordan Valley, in part as a signal to Israel to avoid involvement in the Persian Gulf crisis, diplomats here said.
The troop deployment, which has been observed by Israeli forces from positions in the occupied West Bank, reflects a deepening mood of foreboding as the possibility of war approaches. This is spurring many Arab leaders to urge both the United States and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to avert a conflict that could envelop and reshape the region. 
 "You may win one battle, but you will lose the entire Arab world" by fighting against Arabs, King Hussein of Jordan told an American television interviewer here this weekend as the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline approaches for Iraq to leave Kuwait or risk attack.
 
Arab Appeals to Iraq
 Jordan, whose population is more than half-Palestinian, has been portrayed as an ally of Iraq in the gulf crisis. Other Arab leaders, notably those of Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Syria, who have backed the American-led military buildup in the Persian Gulf, have also directed last-minute appeals to Iraq.
Both Syria and Egypt have contributed troops to the multinational force massing in Saudi Arabia, but, increasingly, Arab worries are focusing on the prospect of Israel retaliating against a strike by Iraq if war breaks out.
Israel's commitment to retaliation against an Iraqi missile strike is profoundly worrying to King Hussein, whose 74,000-man army is thought unable to withstand any Israeli ground assault. But a Western military specialist here said: "The Israelis can strike back at Baghdad by air. They do not need to enter Jordan. If they did, it would be difficult to stop them."
Jordan's latest deployment, according to diplomats who spoke in return for anonymity, involves tens of thousands of troops from four divisions who have been moved from bases in the east of the country to prepared positions in the high ground overlooking the Jordan Valley.
"The idea is apparently to deter Israel," a Western official said.
By Western accounts, Jordan's Army has 1,130 British and American battle tanks while its Air Force, whose budget was reduced last year because of the country's economic crisis, relies on aging American F-5 and French Mirage F-1 planes. Some of its recent air-defense systems, including ground-to-air missiles and anti-aircraft guns, were purchased from the Soviet Union.
The deployment of ground forces is concentrated in the area abutting the Israeli-occupied West Bank, which Jordan lost in the 1967 Middle East war, diplomats said. The army is 80 percent composed of Bedouins widely regarded as loyal to King Hussein.
In recent days, Israeli officials have reported seeing troops move into positions in the hills that had not been used for many years. Prime Minister Mudar Badran, in an interview published here on Saturday, sought to allay Israeli fears by saying Iraq had agreed not to use Jordan as a corridor for ground attacks on Israel. But he indicated that Jordan might call on Iraq to help defend it if it is attacked. Syria has also said it would help defend Jordan against Israel.

HEADLINE: Retailers Are Facing Hard Choices

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
After the worst and most perplexing Christmas season in more than a decade, American retailers face an agonizing quandary: Should they be cautious and conservative, or aggressive, hoping to force their luck?
As industry leaders gather in New York today for the annual National Retail Federation meeting, caution seems to be the prevailing mood. 
 Many executives say they would like to try more innovative merchandising and marketing and add new kinds of stores. But they quickly point out that now is not the time for drastic changes. They cite the economic uncertainty of the recession, the Middle East crisis and the slow-to-buy mentality of consumers.
 
Stakes Are High
 Perhaps more than in any recent year, the stakes are high in 1991. In recent interviews, every economist and many retailers predicted that sales and earnings would show no gain, or a decline, in the first half of the year, assuming a Middle East war or prolonged stalemate. They said they expected a gradual improvement in the second half of the year, assuming a resolution in the Middle East.
Retailers find some glimmers of hope in the prospect of lower interest rates.
The urgency this year is that weak retailers and those with high debts stand to lose local or national market share unless they move to improve their marketing position with new operating concepts.
"In such a situation, we can either roll over and play dead or be imaginative and aggressive," said Stanley Marcus, the former chairman of Neiman Marcus. "There really isn't much choice this year. There's a danger and hazard no matter what we do."
Those that have been successful in the last few years, notably general discount merchants like Wal-Mart Stores, specialty outlets like the Circuit City Stores electronics chain and clothing stores like the Limited, have not hesitated to announce strong expansion plans.
These chains plan to open new stores or make acquisitions to increase the size of their existing units or enter new markets.
That will make it much harder for several giant retailers already under severe pressure. These include Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, which last week announced it was eliminating 21,000 jobs to cut expenses; Federated Department Stores and the Allied Stores Corporation, two major chains now in voluntary bankruptcy; R. H. Macy & Company, which has been selling equity to reduce debt, and Ames Department Stores, a discounter that is in voluntary bankruptcy.
 
Altered Priorities
 Are there culprits for retailing's distress? One of America's most renowned designers, Geoffrey Beene, criticized the industry's merger and acquisition binge, saying the result had altered priorities to "cater to owners and creditors, not to the customers."
For now, Kenneth A. Macke, chairman and chief executive of the Dayton Hudson Corporation of Minneapolis, said: "It is a time to execute better all that we do rather than a time for uniqueness. The consumer is restless and has expectations of us that we can't afford to ignore in terms of service, being in stock on desirable goods and offering fair prices. We expect a tough first half and then a gradual pickup. But we are planning to be very cautious so that we don't have a lot of leftover inventory."
That strategy means strict control over how much and what style of merchandise to order, even to the point of risking running short on some items that customers want.
But stores that can afford to are trying new concepts in merchandising. Circuit City plans to open many more of its small Impulse stores that sell smaller-size electronics items.
People who follow the industry say it seems clear that the more "focused" retailer fared the best in 1990 and in the holiday season. For retailers, focused means presenting a clear picture of merchandise and service so that their store becomes a destination for consumers rather than a place to wander into.
Despite a 1990 that many retailers would rather forget, there were still several successes. Among them was Montgomery Ward, which expects to report record profits for 1990. Executives there mentioned their strategy for selling a four-head videocassette recorder for $248, the amount usually charged for a two-head machine that does not have comparable video or audio quality.
As Bernard Brennan, Ward's chairman, put it: "This was a way we could focus on particular merchandise. We sat down with some VCR producers, showed them our specs and guaranteed a large order. Last year, we sold almost $40 million worth of those recorders, or 160,000 units. That was about 3 percent of the total U.S. VCR market in sales."
For 1991, one potentially promising new retailing move is in the works by Frederick Atkins Inc., the New York-based research-merchandising organization owned by 29 large retail chains. It has developed what it calls an environmentally friendly line of sportswear called "Clean Clothes," which is expected to be sold in stores early next month. This 400-item line, which officials hope will tap the growing interest in ecology, is made of all-cotton fabrics with no synthetics. Paper wrappings are recyclable and buttons are made of wood rather than plastic.
Lee Abraham, chairman of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, a large research-merchandising arm in New York owned by large retailers, said, "One of my chief concerns is that given the current, economic conditions, retailers may resist investing in the technology they need to move forward strategically."

HEADLINE: NO SHORTAGE SEEN IN SUPPLIES OF OIL DURING A GULF WAR

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
A war in the Persian Gulf may not create shortages of oil in the United States, oil company executives, Government officials and other experts say. But they caution that prices may surge if panic buying drains supplies from gas stations and distribution centers.
While military officials say the Saudi oilfields are adequately defended against an Iraqi attack and would not suffer major damage, a war is expected to cut Saudi exports by more than a third, as oilfield workers flee and operations are closed. That situation would last until the United States and its allies establish air superiority. 
 But even that reduction in Saudi imports is unlikely to create a shortage of crude oil in importing countries, industry experts say.
 
Optimism on Price
 Indeed, some experts predict that the price of a barrel of crude oil may not rise above the $40 peak it reached in the fall. That would be a sharp contrast to the days immediately after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, when some people predicted $100-a-barrel oil in case of war.
Experts point out that in the long run, war will not affect oil supplies because oil underground is virtually invulnerable to attack. If wells are damaged badly enough, new ones might have to be drilled, but the companies will know where to set the holes.
There is also optimism that Iraq will not be able to interfere seriously with tanker traffic.
 
Little Naval Threat
 "Iraq doesn't have much of a navy to speak of," said Paul E. Mawn, an oil logistics consultant at Temple Barker Sloane Inc., a Boston consulting firm. Mr. Mawn is a captain in the Naval Reserve and a member of a logistics panel set up by the Chief of Naval Operations.
While guerrilla attacks are possible, Mr. Mawn said, "We control the seas and we control the air, and we will continue to do so."
Vahan Zanoyan, an analyst at the Petroleum Finance Company, a consulting firm in Washington, observed, "It's not easy to create a physical shortage."
As a precaution against attacks, oil-producing countries have moved large stocks of oil into tankers anchored closer to customers, or into storage on land.
Iran, for example, has so much oil at sea that some oil company executives have taken to calling it "the Iranian strategic petroleum reserve," a reference to the United States' own underground supply.
The Saudis have also moved large supplies of oil to sea and to land-based storage sites outside the Persian Gulf. Between them, the two countries probably have 60 million barrels or more situated near importing countries, experts say.
Stocks held by oil-importing countries also appear to be adequate.
John J. Easton Jr., the Assistant Secretary of Energy for International Affairs and Energy Emergencies, testified before the House Energy and Commerce Committee on Wednesday that as of the end of the third quarter of last year, "Worldwide, commercial stocks in market economies are about 150 million barrels above the average level for the last four years."
Mr. Easton's figures did not include the United States' Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which contains 583 million barrels of oil, and which Mr. Easton described as "primed and waiting."
Germany and Japan also hold substantial strategic reserves of oil.
 
Weathering a Shortage
 So even if Saudi exports were reduced by as much as three million barrels a day, from last month's production levels of about eight million barrels a day, the level of commercial and strategic reserves suggests that the world could weather a long period with three million barrels a day less of Saudi oil.
"The only way the U.S. has a serious problem is if there's panic," said Theodore Eck, chief economist of the Amoco Corporation. That would occur, he said, if many people decided to rush out and buy gasoline or other products "before the hoarders do."
At the Phillips Petroleum Company in Bartlesville, Okla., C. J. Silas, the company's president, said in a speech last week, "I personally feel that a shortfall of three million barrels of oil a day would be manageable."
But he added, "My biggest fear is that people will perceive a coming shortage and immediately start buying and even hoarding oil."
 
Response of Drivers
 At Texaco, William K. Tell Jr., senior vice president, said in a telephone interview that most drivers feel comfortable with as low as an eighth of a tank of gas and fill their tanks once a week. If they all decided on the day war broke out to fill their tanks immediately, demand would rise sevenfold, he said.
The result, he said, would be to drain some stations and create gas lines. This did not happen when Iraq took over Kuwait because few motorists realized immediately that a crisis had begun, experts say.
On the oil futures market, where companies try to lock in prices of oil for future delivery, there are clear signs that traders expect oil prices to fall in future months. On Friday, oil for delivery in February closed at $27.29 a barrel, and oil for delivery in August was $5 less, at $22.38.
Such pricing has been the case for weeks, demonstrating that traders believe that whatever happens in the near term, the long-term threat is less.
But even this optimism would not stop a short-term spike in prices, with customers and speculators rushing to buy whatever supplies are available.
"We're not being held hostage by Saddam Hussein, but by those blue suede shoes on the floor of the New York Mercantile Exchange," said Douglas G. Elmets, a spokesman for the Atlantic Richfield Company, referring to oil traders.
A price spike, he said, would reflect the traders' "reacting emotionally rather than rationally."
The anticipated reduction in Saudi exports reflects the expectation that the Saudis will shut wells, gathering stations and terminals in a war.
Experts said the first wells shut would be those off the coast of the Neutral Zone between Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. On-shore wells in the Neutral Zone were shut in August, but the offshore wells have continued to produce about 250,000 barrels a day.
Next, the experts said, would be the gulf wells slightly south, off the Saudi coast, where the Safaniya, Zuluf and Marjan fields together produce at least two million barrels a day.
In the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, offshore platforms were the only oil operations conclusively knocked out, because they tower over the water, are easy to locate and hard to defend.
Other candidates for closing are the Saudis' two Persian Gulf loading terminals, at Ras Tannurah and Jubail. But experts note that these sites are 200 miles from Kuwait City, and even further from Iraq, a long way for attack planes to penetrate.
A third major terminal is at Yanbu, on the Red Sea, and is supplied with oil from eastern Saudi Arabia by a pipeline called the Petroline, with a capacity of 3.2 million barrels.
A parallel pipeline, IPSA 2, was built to carry up to 1.6 million barrels a day of Iraqi oil to the Red Sea. Western experts are not sure whether that pipeline has junctions that allow it to be filled within Saudi Arabia, but those could be added, they say.
 
$80 Price Is Seen
 ROME, Jan. 13 (REUTERS) -- A six- to nine-month Persian Gulf war could push oil prices above $80 a barrel, the head of Italy's state-owned energy company contends.
Gabriele Cagliari, chairman of the Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, told the Socialist Party newspaper Avanti that such a price jump would lead to a fall in demand of 2.5 million barrels a day for the first three months of a war and of 3 million for the next three months.
A war lasting between one and two months, he said in an interview published today, could push the oil price to $60 a barrel initially for psychological reasons, even before any damage to oil fields. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, oil prices have soared to as high as $41 a barrel before easing to a current range of $25 to $28.

HEADLINE: SOVIET CRACKDOWN;
Bush Deplores Soviet Crackdown But Takes No Steps in Response

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
President Bush today condemned the Soviet Union's military action in Lithuania, saying there was "no justification for the use of force" in the breakaway Soviet republic. But the President refrained from taking immediate steps to punish Moscow for its actions.
Mr. Bush and some of his senior aides also expressed growing concern about the turmoil in the Soviet Union, and one of those aides, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, said the Lithuania crisis could herald the end of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts at political and economic reform. 
 In a brief news conference this afternoon on the South Lawn of the White House, Mr. Bush read from a statement warning that events in the Baltic states "threaten to set back, or perhaps even reverse, the process of reform" that Mr. Gorbachev undertook when he came to power in 1985.
 "We condemn these acts which could not help but affect our relationship," he said. "At this hour, the United States in the West will redouble our efforts to strengthen and encourage peaceful change in the Soviet Union." [Text of statement, page A7.]
The President called the Soviet actions "a great tragedy" for the people of Lithuania and added: "The brave people and the leaders of the Baltic states have, indeed, acted with dignity and restraint."
Coming on the heels of the vote in Congress authorizing the use of force against Iraq in the Persian Gulf, the events in Lithuania have vastly complicated the questions of diplomacy, strategy and politics facing the President. [News Analysis, page A7.]
 Mr. Bush refused to say whether the crackdown would cause him to cancel a scheduled summit meeting with Mr. Gorbachev next month, saying such an action was "hypothetical." Questions had previously arisen over whether the talks would go ahead because of the prospect of war in the Persian Gulf.
Other officials also suggested that for the time being the Administration would stand by its decision last month to ease restrictions on trade with the Soviet Union imposed by Congress in 1975.
Mr. Bush's statement did not attack Mr. Gorbachev by name, calling instead on "Soviet leaders" to renounce violence and to resume negotiations with the separatist leaders in the Baltic republics.
 
Gorbachev's Role Undetermined
 In a question-and-answer session after he read his statement, Mr. Bush said he did not know whether Mr. Gorbachev was responsible for the assault in Lithuania's capital, Vilnius, which left at least 13 people dead, or whether military or internal security officials acted without his blessing.
"I cannot answer that question. I just don't know the facts on it," the President said.
Mr. Bush said he was concerned about the growing turmoil in the Soviet Union, and that Mr. Gorbachev had told him recently that he is "very much concerned" as well.
Mr. Bush did not say when that exchange took place, but he last spoke with the Soviet leader on Friday morning. Administration officials have said that Mr. Bush raised his concerns about the Baltic republics in guarded terms at that time, but that Mr. Gorbachev was reluctant to discuss the issue.
 
Concern Among Officials
 Other senior Government officials here and abroad reacted with growing concern but restrained anger to Moscow's military action.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, in a statement issued in Ankara, Turkey, called the Soviet moves "deeply disturbing" and fundamentally opposed to Mr. Gorbachev's policies of economic and political reform.
"Soviet interests above all else require the reform process to go forward. Only with continued reform will progress and hope for the Soviet Union be possible," his statement said. "In the end, enduring U.S.-Soviet cooperation, indeed partnerships, depend on continued reforms."
A senior official aboard Mr. Baker's plane, speaking on condition of anonymity, later said that the Administration had been concerned about Soviet action in the Baltics for several months, and had repeatedly urged Moscow to negotiate a peaceful settlement there.
 
'The Wrong Direction'
 The official called the crackdown "tragic," saying it was moving United States-Soviet relations "in the wrong direction." But he added that the Administration had not decided yet to take retaliatory measures.
In the most recent comparable crackdown on internal dissent, the killing of student protesters in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in June 1989, the Bush Administration suspended military sales to China, broke off high-level government contacts, and supported a suspension of World Bank development loans. Those actions were widely regarded as modest.
In the case of the Soviet Union, the senior official said, "Let me say that there are still, in my opinion, areas where it is to the mutual advantage of the two countries to continue to try to work things out."
 
Agenda for Summit Talks
 Among other major unresolved items on the superpower agenda are the carrying out of the treaty limiting conventional armed forces in Europe -- now embroiled in charges that the Soviet military is cheating on the terms of the pact -- and the signing of the treaty reducing long-range nuclear weapons, scheduled for the February summit meeting.
That official said the summit talks remain on schedule. But in Washington, the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, said the future of the talks "depends on what happens in the next few hours, the next few days, and I think that that's certainly under discussion" now. Mr. Sununu was interviewed on the CBS News program "Face the Nation."
Mr. Cheney, appearing on the ABC News program "This Week," said the Soviet crackdown may well signal that Mr. Gorbachev's program of economic and political reform has failed.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
As Deadline Nears, America Speaks of Fear and Resolve

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
On what many Americans see as the eve of war in the Persian Gulf, the mood of the nation yesterday was somber, divided, apprehensive: a people caught between a desire for peace and the burden of what Woodrow Wilson called the right more precious than peace.
The months of futile diplomacy had apparently come down to a final day. The President had issued his strongest warning. The troops and aircraft carriers were in place. Congress had given its speeches and its assent. Time was running out -- but still the haunting uncertainties lingered.
 
An Odd, Unreal Quality
 In New York and Chicago and San Francisco, in cities and small towns across the nation, the January weekend had an odd, unreal quality, as visits with scores of Americans showed. Weddings were held, football games were played, families sat down to dinner and ordinary people went about their customary lives. 
 But in houses of worship, prayers and sermons were offered against war. In Los Angeles, 4,000 people went to an antiwar protest out of the Vietnam War era. In Atlanta and Houston and St. Louis and Detroit, people spoke with profound emotion of their fears for loved ones and for the future of the country.
And everywhere lurked undercurrents that were not easy to define -- a sense that the crisis was moving inexorably out of control, that one's own voice had been lost in the rush of events, that America was poised for better or worse on the threshold of a historic day, one that might prove proud or tragic in the months or years to come.
 
Dramatic Evidence of Division
 With tomorrow's United Nations deadline looming and no sign that Saddam Hussein will withdraw his forces from Kuwait, Americans were still grappling with their feelings. A New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted Jan. 5-7 reflected the ambivalence, showing almost the same support for attacking Iraq as for giving economic sanctions more time.
And interviews with scores of people across the country provided dramatic evidence that the United States was a nation divided.
"The price of democracy is high," Ellis Casden, of Stamford, Conn., said outside Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., before the playoff game yesterday between the Giants and the Chicago Bears. "We have been the guardians of peace. We can't let this go without doing something about it. The Middle East is a powder keg, and it's not going to go away."
But Mr. Casden's son, Greg, a 20-year-old student at Green Mountain College in Vermont, said the war, if it came, would be a fight over oil rather than democratic principles. "I think it's pretty obscene," he declared.
At St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan, John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, said he believed in the sincerity of the Bush Administration and Congress, but he declared: "Our Government can err in its deliberations and its decisions."
The Cardinal urged Americans not to accept that war is unavoidable, and said everyone had a moral obligation to raise questions up to and beyond tomorrow's deadline. "It is the highest form of loyalty to ask whether what we are doing is right," he said.
On a sunlit afternoon in St. Louis, Debbie Swallow, 39 years old, took her infant daughter, Danielle, to watch Big Bird cavort on stage in "Sesame Street Live." Waiting in line for tickets, she said: "I'd hate to see another Vietnam."
In a nation that has not experienced real war in well over a decade, the Persian Gulf crisis seemed surreal to Gale Orem, 47, a legal secretary in Houston. "I don't think our society knows much of war," she said. "It's like a horror movie we can turn off if we want to. In America, we live on a yellow brick road of sorts -- and that may be our undoing."

GRAPHIC: Photos: David Fisher, left, a camp counselor, and Steve Herz, a law student in Chicago, both watched Congressional hearings on TV. HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
A war in the Persian Gulf may not create oil shortages in the U.S., oil company executives, Government officials and other experts say. But they caution that prices might surge if panic buying drains supplies from gas stations and product distributors. In addition, a war is expected to cut Saudi exports by more than a third, as oilfield workers flee and operations are closed. [Page A1.]
Facing tough times, retailers are asking themselves whether they should play it safe or take chances with bold marketing and merchandising strategies. Industry leaders gather today for the National Retail Federation meeting. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Management of T.V.A. Is Cut Into Three Parts

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 13

 BODY:
The Tennessee Valley Authority, the nation's largest power agency, has reorganized its management in an effort to improve service.
The reorganization, which took effect last week, divides the management of the Federal agency into three operating groups, in charge of power generation, customer services, and resources and economic development.
"Now that our costs are under better control, it's time to challenge ourselves with new goals that put customer service at the top of our priority list and at the top of our organization," the chairman, Marvin T. Runyon, said Tuesday.
The plan did not include any layoffs of the agency's 26,000 employees. A reorganization three years ago cost 8,000 employees their jobs. "No significant reductions are expected at all," said a spokesman, John Moulton.
The power generation group, headed by Oliver Kingsley Jr., the agency's former nuclear chief, will manage and operate all of T.V.A.'s fossil fuel, hydroelectric and nuclear power operations.
Mary Sharpe Hayes, the former vice president of marketing and strategic planning, is president of the customer group, which will oversee service to industrial customers and power distributors like municipal or citizen-owned utilities.
The resource group offers natural resource and economic development programs to residents of the seven-state T.V.A. region. Bill Willis, the authority's former senior executive officer, is president.
The T.V.A. It operates in Alabama, Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, North Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Congress in Step;
After the Vote, Margins Are Ignored, But Potential Divisions Are Serious

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
A Congress that had seemed loath to deal with the Persian Gulf finally went ahead when its leaders despaired of getting President Bush to promise to ask formally for their support before attacking Iraq, some members of Congress and highly placed aides said today.
 And a President who had previously told the leaders that he wanted action only if they could assure him the result would be overwhelming then went ahead and asked, and lobbied hard but won only a bare five-vote victory in the Senate. 
 Today no one was talking about the margins, or the history. President Bush said: "We went to Congress. Both houses of Congress affirmed the policy of this Government." The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said, "It is clear that the Congress has spoken, and the exact size of the vote is irrelevant."
The Democratic leaders who had fought so hard for resolutions demanding continued reliance on economic sanctions had been quick to say, even before they lost the Saturday votes, that they would stand behind American troops if President Bush took them into battle, insisting that there would be no moves to cut off funds after Saturday's definitive vote.
 
Potential Divisions
 But even so, the voting patterns showed serious potential divisions. The partisan ones were obvious; 70 percent of the Democratic senators and representatives who voted Saturday opposed force and 98 percent of the Republicans favored it.
But the regional divisions were almost as sharp. Southern lawmakers voted 86 to 32 for force, and their senators in particular provided the Democratic votes that were essential to Mr. Bush's victory. Lawmakers from the Southwest favored force by 35 to 13. Mountain state lawmakers went 16 to 8 in favor of force.
But New Englanders, including a unanimous Massachusetts delegation, opposed force by 23 to 13. Midwesterners were narrowly opposed, 74 to 63, and lawmakers from the Middle Atlantic region favored force but only by 51 to 45. Pacific Coast lawmakers were almost evenly split, with 38 favoring force and 35 opposed.
Those differences, if there is war and it is not short, may divide the country more seriously than the party splits, for the Democrats on the losing side have been earnestly seeking to close ranks with the victors.
If there was a nearly universal area of agreement today, it was among lawmakers who felt proud that Congress had faced the issue and decided it, reasserting its prerogatives after decades of going along with Presidents who acted first and consulted later.
 
Message Is Restraint
 But institutional concerns were also a factor in its taking as long as it did to speak. Last fall, after Mr. Bush announced a doubling of troop strength to provide offensive capacity in the gulf, there were many calls from both Republicans and Democrats for Congress to return in special session. The leaders resisted, noting that there would be 49 new lawmakers in just two months. Instead, they held hearings from which one clear message was restraint.
Two other arguments were offered today. Mr. Foley said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" that a vote even as recently as a month ago would have been seen by many members and outsiders as no more than "another quiver in the diplomatic armory." He said that if Congress was going to vote what he called "a real, practical equivalent of a declaration of war," then it should do so in absolutely clear focus, with no one in doubt about what the vote implied.
A complementary explanation for delay came from well-placed Congressional strategists. They said that the other possibility late last fall was a Congressional vote, with more Democrats than were with their leaders on Saturday calling for a reversal of the troop buildup. But with no prospect of a majority big enough to override a veto, that course would only have made the dispute ineradicably partisan.
As it happened, the vote was more partisan than the atmosphere. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, occasionally discerned party motives among Democrats opposed to force. But few other Bush supporters did so, and it is rare for Congress to work so late into the night in as good a humor as was maintained late Friday and early Saturday.
 
How the Action Unfolded
 Even in the new Congress, action came more quickly than the leaders had expected. On Jan. 3, the first day of the 102d Congress, Mr. Foley and Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic majority leader, each promised Congressional action on the war issue, but each was vague about just when would be the appropriate time.
Liberal critics of Mr. Bush's policy demanded a vote before the Jan. 15 deadline, angrily on the Senate floor and more quietly in meetings in the House.
The leaders said they had hoped for a Presidential request for Congressional action before any conflict, but eventually gave up on it. On Friday, Jan. 4, Mr. Mitchell said the Senate would act before the deadline, and on Sunday, Jan. 6, Mr. Foley promised House action, and also predicted that Mr. Bush's side would win. Then, with his irons in the fire, Mr. Bush made the request and got busy lobbying.
And Monday, according to Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, he will sign the joint resolution authorizing him to go to war.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Robert H. Michel, right, the minority leader of the House, after the Congressional vote authorizing the use of force against Iraq. With him was Representative William S. Broomfield. (Reuters)
 
Map: Map of the United States showing how the House voted by shading.

HEADLINE: SOVIET CRACKDOWN;
For Lithuanian-Americans, the News About Home Seems Terrible Indeed

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
Alina and Edward Staknys of Jamaica, Queens, are preoccupied by the news these days. They pore over newspapers, listen to reports by two radio stations at once and wait anxiously for television news broadcasts.
Their fascination with the news has nothing to do with the threat of war in the Persian Gulf region, but with the Communist crackdown in the country where they both grew up, Lithuania. 
 "We were beginning to believe in Mikhail Gorbachev," said Mr. Staknys, a retired electrical engineer. "But this has set us back 50 years."
 
'Does Anyone Care?'
 Alina Staknys, a former high school teacher, said: "We were never crushed so cruelly. And the world's attention is diverted. Does anyone care?"
For thousands of Americans of Lithuanian descent, these are days of pain coupled with the sense of having been abandoned.
According to the Lithuanian Information Center, in the East New York section of Brooklyn, there are 750,000 people who identify themselves as being of Lithuanian descent in the United States, 15,000 of them in the New York metropolitan area. The largest Lithuanian community is in Chicago, which has 100,000 people; other cities with sizable Lithuanian populations are Cleveland, Detroit, Los Angeles and Boston.
Adjacent to the information office is the Lithuanian Cultural Center, a modern building that serves as a social center.
Lithuanian-Americans gathered at the building yesterday for the latest bit of news from their homeland. The information center, through electronic links with parliament, has been providing direct accounts of the crackdown and of how the government is coping during the crisis.
The people who gathered at the center mourned for the 13 civilians killed by Soviet troops and they spoke of the heroism of those who had stood in resistance.
 
Wearing Lithuanian Colors
 Comparisons with the situation in the gulf and the crackdown on the democracy movement in China came quickly to their lips.
"Why is Saddam Hussein not allowed to go into Kuwait while Gorbachev is allowed to march into Lithuania, a democratic country?" asked Aleksandras Sepkus, an artist and recent emigre from Vilnius.
"Is it because there is no oil in Lithuania? Is it because Saddam Hussein talks like a madman and Gorbachev won the Nobel Peace Prize?" he asked.
Mrs. Staknys said that one woman who stood in resistance in Vilnius had been crushed by an advancing tank. "Even the Chinese didn't do that," she said. "We all saw the picture of how a tank stopped because one man stood in the way. But the Russians didn't stop."
The Rev. Casimir Pugevicius said that when the regular Sunday service at Annunciation church in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn was finished, he led the congregation in half an hour more of prayers and hymns for peace in Lithuania.
"The people wanted it and needed it," he said.
 
Appeal to U.S. on Aid to Moscow
 CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (Special to The New York Times) -- Lithuanian-Americans sent hundreds of telegrams to President Bush and members of Congress today, urging a cutoff of United States aid to the Soviet Union and a formal recognition for an independent government in Lithuania.
About 1,500 people, members of the nation's largest Lithuanian community, demonstrated here on Saturday and today in Philadelphia and Los Angeles.
Hundreds of people throughout the Midwest placed calls today to the Lithuanian Hotline, an information network based in the Lithuanian World Center in Le Motte, Ill., a center for Lithuanian immigrants, officials of the center said. Vytatuas Januskis, a real estate developer who helped start the hotline last March, said 3,000 to 4,000 telegrams had been sent to the White House and Congress by this evening.
Mr. Januskis, who attended a conference on economic development in Vilnius last fall, said, "I left there extremely optimistic, so now this is a real damper."

HEADLINE: Art Center for Newark Receives $3 Million

 BODY:
An ambitious proposal to build a performing-arts center in Newark got a lift yesterday with the announcement of a $3 million donation from the Samuel I. Newhouse Foundation, the philanthropic arm of Advance Publications , which publishes The Star-Ledger of Newark.
The gift, the largest ever made by the Newhouse Foundation in New Jersey, brings the amount pledged by New Jersey's businesses for construction of the center to $33 million. The Prudential Insurance Company has committed $3 million, and the Federal Government has committed $1.2 million for planning and design. 
 In addition, New Jersey has committed $20 million through the Economic Development Authority, which is to issue bonds in the spring to pay for site work and the acquisition of a 12-acre parcel of land in downtown Newark.
 
Like Lincoln Center
 In November, Barton Myers, a 56-year-old Los Angeles architect, was commissioned to design a $70-million 2,700-seat multi-use concert hall, which would be the first building of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, a Lincoln Center-like complex near the central business district in Newark.
The hall would be a home for music, dance and theater. It would also house the New Jersey Symphony and would include rehearsal spaces, restaurants and cafes.
In addition to $70 million for the concert hall, another $70 million will be required for site work to complete the first phase of the arts center plan.
 
Of Resurgence
 The proposal envisions the arts as a magnet to attract suburbanites to Newark. "Newark's future and the success of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center are closely linked," said Donald E. Newhouse, vice president of the Newhouse Foundation. "We have seen similar situations across the country wherein a city's resurgence is accelerated by the creation of a center for the performing arts."
Lawrence P. Goldman, the president of the arts center, said that a master plan for the center had been completed and that it would be announced in the next few weeks.
