SECTION: Section C; Page 6; Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1857 words

HEADLINE: Shoal Creek Decision Puts Golf on a New Course

BYLINE: By JAIME DIAZ

 BODY:
IT'S still debatable whether what has come to be known simply as "Shoal Creek" sounded the death knell for the nation's exclusionary private golf clubs or was merely an annoying wake-up alarm that has left most of America's privileged reaching for the snooze button.
 When the Shoal Creek Country Club, an all-white club near Birmingham, Ala., gave a black man an honorary membership last July as part of an agreement to head off picketing of the P.G.A. Championship by civil rights groups, Arthur Ashe, whose recent three-volume work charts the progress of the black athlete in America, called it a major breakthrough. 
 "What happened at Shoal Creek is only 20 percent about sports," Ashe said. "It's about society, commerce and culture. It's the upper echelon of white society finally being forced to say, 'All right, it's time.' "
Ashe predicted: "We are going to see a veritable flood of quiet, muted but very significant invitations to blacks to join previously all-white clubs. In two or three years, it's going to be completely different."
Six months later, a lot has happened, and some things are indeed different. Because of Shoal Creek, major professional golf will almost surely never again be played at clubs with exclusionary membership practices. Several prestigious clubs that hold tournaments, most notably Augusta National, now have a black member or are in the process of admitting one or more.
Increased attention has been focused on public figures and their relationship with these clubs. When Tom Watson resigned from the Kansas City Country Club recently because it refused membership to the Jewish businessman Henry Bloch, it was news. (The club later reversed its decision, but Watson did not re-join.) And it was news when Vice President Dan Quayle recently played Cypress Point, the highly exclusive club on the Monterey Peninsula that terminated its association with the PGA Tour rather than conform to a new anti-discrimination policy.
But a large question remains: How much has Shoal Creek actually changed the attitudes fundamental to the perpetuation of exclusionary or all-white golf clubs?
So far, this is still a matter of opinion. Many observers say six months is too short of a time to reverse or even measure a mind-set that has existed since private golf clubs were founded in America in the 1890's.
"It's going to take more time," said Ron Townsend, a television executive who is the first black member at the Augusta National. "I think some attitudes have been affected, but it's going to be awhile before we see if that will be put into practice."
Skeptics can point to Shoal Creek itself. When the club agreed to accept the black businessman Louis Willie Jr. as an honorary member, it also gave assurances that it would begin processing a regular membership for a second black. The prospective member was unidentified,, and no specific timetable beyond a few months was given for how long the processing would take. But as of last week, there was no evidence that the matter has been addressed.
"At the time, there was another man considered," explained the club's president, Tom Rast. "I don't know the status of that right now. The membership committee could have decided that he was not qualified or it could still be in the mill. I don't know. Beyond that, we would rather stay mum on it."
William Bell, the black Birmingham city councilman who in June objected to $1,500 in city funds being used to buy space in the P.G.A. Championship program, said: "I would not be surprised if they never had anyone in mind. The reality is you can't change institutions overnight. In people's hearts and minds, nothing has really changed."
On the other hand, there are those who believe they have seen evidence that Ashe's prediction is coming true.
"I've been getting calls from all over the country from blacks who have been asked to join clubs," said Darwin Davis, a senior vice president at Equitable's Manhattan office, who last year accepted an invitation to join St. Andrew's Country Club in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. "People want to know things like what the interview is like, how people treat you at the club. It's a different climate."
Davis is one of five black members at St. Andrew's, which makes this club, which is generally regarded as the birthplace of American golf, the one with the most black members among the highly exclusive clubs in Westchester County.
"Since I joined, no one has even alluded to race, it's been a total non-event," said Davis, who testified last June before a United States Senate Judiciary Committee hearing regarding club membership practices. "I believe wholeheartedly that while there are some, America is not made up of a whole bunch of bigots who don't like black people. Since Shoal Creek, I think a lot of people who never really thought a lot about the issue are embarrassed, and they're saying, 'Let's open the doors.' "
The most tangible change brought about by Shoal Creek has come in professional golf. When IBM, fearing it could be perceived as associating with bigotry, withdrew its advertising from the telecast of the P.G.A. Championship, several companies followed. The exodus showed golf's ruling bodies that their multimillion-dollar television deals, and the image of the game, were in jeopardy.
Since then, the PGA Tour, the Professional Golfers' Association of America, and the United States Golf Association have adopted policies prohibiting host clubs from having membership practices that discriminate on the basis of race, religion or sex. The five clubs that chose to drop their spot on the PGA Tour rather than conform include Cypress Point and Butler National. The P.G.A. of America lost Aronimink Country Club as the site of the 1993 P.G.A. Championship when the club said its seven-year waiting list for membership could not be altered to expedite a minority-group member.
And the U.S.G.A. lost the St. Louis Country Club as the site of the 1992 Women's Amateur. The all-white club gave poorly conditioned greens as its official reason for withdrawing.
The PGA Tour last week completed contracts that allow it to monitor the membership practices of the private clubs that make up approximately half of the 118 host sites it uses for the regular, Senior and Ben Hogan tours. Not all the clubs have a member who is female, black or from another minority group, but with the incentive of holding a tournament, all have made contractual assurances they will not conduct exclusionary membership practices.
"We were overnight faced with a set of circumstances that we had literally never thought about," said Tim Finchem, deputy commissioner of the PGA Tour. "We changed the process by which we choose our courses because we were faced with the prospect of having our tour associated with exclusionary practices. It was fundamentally clear that to fool around with the possibility that our image could be tarnished was not in our long-term interest."
But private clubs that hold professional tournaments make up only a miniscule percentage of the more than 5,000 private clubs in the United States. It has been estimated by a highly placed U.S.G.A. official that at least three out of four private clubs do not have black members. If Shoal Creek is to have a real effect, it has to be manifested in the membership of a significant number of these clubs.
The pressures to effect change appear to be more internal than external. Several factors make it relatively easy for exclusionary clubs to stay that way. First and foremost, the Constitution guarantees the right of free association.
"There is a fundamental conflict in our society between the rights people can exercise regarding with whom they choose to socialize and the reality that discrimination is invidious and exclusionary," said Frank (Sandy) Tatum, an attorney and a former president of the U.S.G.A. "Those are two things this country was built on."
The only laws that apply economic pressure to private clubs are state measures that threaten the favorable tax status many clubs enjoy by being designated open space or "green-belt" areas. The tax pressure looks like it will intensify. In 1990, legislators from 14 states proposed laws aimed at ending discriminatory practices at private clubs.
No clubs, even the most homogenous, are known to have written bylaws stopping membership on the basis of race or religion. The uproar over Shoal Creek's all-white membership would never have been heard if the club's founder, Hall Thompson, had not said publicly what had long been privately held: "We don't discriminate in every other area except the blacks."
It is also a fact that blacks make up less than 3 percent of all golfers, and that blacks as a group have a lower per-capita income than whites. It is simple, and sometimes accurate, for clubs to say they cannot find black people who both play golf and can afford the expense.
Tatum is a member at both Cypress Point and San Francisco Golf Club, both of which do not have black members. Although he believes the effects of Shoal Creek have been good for golf, he has not suffered a crisis of conscience by belonging to clubs that do not have blacks.
"These are social clubs, not political entities, organized for the purpose of getting together to play golf," Tatum said. "In that situation, I think I have an obligation not to foul up the reason for the setting. We live in a complex society, and it doesn't always go the way we want it to go, particularly in regard to discrimination. But the fact is, a club is entitled to arbitrarily decide who is chosen to be a member. There is a clear right to discriminate in that sense."
But some feel that social pressure is becoming more intense as the idea of exclusionary clubs becomes more out of step with society as a whole.
"One motivation to stop discrimination at clubs is enlightened self interest," said Stuart Lewengrub, southeastern regional director of the Anti-Defamation League. "No corporation wants to be even remotely associated with anything that is tainted with bigotry."
So far, corporate America has not been refusing to pay memberships for its executives, or asking them to resign. But Charles S. Mechem Jr., the new commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association who was a chief executive officer at Great American Broadcasting, believes that Shoal Creek has raised awareness among the business elite.
"Most corporate heads that I know are very sympathetic to the issue to begin with," Mechem said. "They are saying, 'Yes, this is something we do all the time in our business world, and something we need to change in our nonbusiness world.' I think the awareness level by them will accelerate the whole trend toward righting some wrongs."
Al Washington, vice president of human resources at Time-Warner Communications and one of the black members at St. Andrew's, agrees.
"Shoal Creek has heightened the awareness of everyone," Washington said. "People are looking to make accommodations for minorities and women to play this sport. It's simply a matter of having the desire and the goal."

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Atlanta;
Vague Possibility Now a Step Away

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 13

 BODY:
For Liz Doyle, as for so many others, what even a week ago seemed a vague, unlikely possibility now seems only a horrifying step away.
"I went to a friend's birthday party today, and the very first thing we talked about was how it did not seem real until Secretary Baker said, 'regrettably,' and then you start seeing pictures of men and women on TV and you realize they might not come back," said Ms. Doyle, a 34-year-old who works in tourism marketing. 
 "Nothing seems to be more important now than the fact we're going to war, the economy, everything. It's a very helpless feeling."
The certitude that conflict is impending may not have been unanimous, but it was close.
In Atlanta, which likes to think of itself as a place on a winning streak exemplified by its successful bid for the 1996 summer Olympics, there is a widespread sense that the nation is poised at the edge of a fateful precipice with no clear idea of what lurks below.
"I pray about it, mostly for the troops there, the young people, and I've been praying more as it gets closer," said Mia Hawkins, a 25-year-old accountant, who was interviewed Saturday at Lenox Square, a huge mall in the affluent Buckhead section that comes as close as anything to being Atlanta's Main Street.
 
Talk of Biblical Prophecies
 On the surface the area's shop-till-you-drop ethic seems intact, but it is not hard to find the anxious undercurrents.
Shane Quarels, a 33-year-old director of advertising for an Atlanta firm, said she was planning to get two kittens from the humane society. That led a friend from Savannah to tell her that so many soldiers from Fort Stewart there had to give up their pets, residents had organized a campaign to adopt the pets until the soldiers return.
"Being in the Bible Belt, there's so much talk about the biblical prophecies that there will be a war in the Middle East that will be so horrendous it will be the end of the world," she said.
Most people raise fears that are less apocalyptic, but still worrisome.
Bob Hayslip, a 40-year-old office equipment salesman, is worried enough about the possibility of terrorism that he has advised his 18-year-old daughter to drive on her class trip to Miami in May rather than fly.
 
Learning From the Crisis
 Ms. Quarels's friend, 31-year-old Nichola Coe of Savannah, fears that the war will make the current recession more severe. And living in a military community, what she fears most is the toll a war would bring.
"I find myself thinking about it about 70 percent of the time," she said. "So many families have people over there. I think about what it's like now and can't help thinking what it will be like if some of them come back in body bags."
Along with the anxiety many people find a sense of clarity: the Gulf crisis is telling Americans things about themselves that they did not know.
A mental health counselor, who declined to give his name, said that along with its sobering aspects, the crisis had revealed something rather appealing about Americans.
"I'm struck by how reluctant the American people are to go to war," he said. "In that sense it's something of a blessing. It shows we're not as sadistic or malevolent a people as we sometimes think."
 
Concern About the Draft
 A group of young men discussing the war at the Five Paces Inn, a small hangout about a mile down Peachtree Street from Lenox Square, have their own reasons for worry.
"If it's a long war, more than six months, I figure they'll reinstate the draft," said 24-year-old Matt Jarinda.
But for him the crisis is also a reminder how quickly and frighteningly the world situation can change. "You have all those R.O.T.C. students who thought they were getting a free ride through college," he said. "No one in their wildest dreams ever thought they'd be over in Saudi Arabia."

HEADLINE: Capital Gains Relief

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A Dec. 25 editorial opposes capital gains tax relief. But "tax equality for all forms of income" is not the issue because capital gains or losses are not income. Investors' net capital gains are the result of risk taking over time to achieve a reward for increasing the value of private property. This has been the driving force of the United States economy since its founding. Capital gains should not be taxed at all because they are most often entrepreneurially achieved from wages and savings already taxed.
 
VICTOR D. ZIMINSKY JR.
V.P., Shearson Lehman Brothers
New York, Dec. 26, 1990

HEADLINE: Johannesburg Journal;
A White Liberal Finds Old Foes Are Now Allies

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 13

 BODY:
When President F. W. de Klerk asked Harry SchwarzHarry Schwarz to become South Africa's next ambassador to the United States, it was as if President Bush, in looking for a diplomatic troubleshooter to sell his policies abroad, had settled upon Senator Edward M. Kennedy.
Mr. Schwarz's opposition to the ruling National Party now led by Mr. de Klerk dates to the 1950's, when he helped found the Torch Commando, an organization of World War II veterans who took to the streets to demonstrate against the Government's move to disfranchise voters of mixed race. 
 Mr. Schwarz had served as a bomber navigator in the Royal Air Force and the South African Air Force in the Mediterranean theater during the war.
Since 1974, he has been a member of Parliament for the Progressive Federal Party and its successor, the Democratic Party, assailing the National Party for mismanaging the economy in its preoccupation with apartheid.
 
A Crucial Assignment
 But Mr. Schwarz, who is 66 years old, consented to leave Parliament and a prosperous Johannesburg law practice for Pretoria's most crucial diplomatic posting because, he said, what he has fought for is coming to pass. He arrives in Washington next month.
His decision illustrates the extent to which Mr. de Klerk's policies of change are supported by white liberals who hold no brief for the National Party. The Democratic Party pulled 21 percent of the white vote in the Parliamentary elections in September 1989, but has found it increasingly hard to define how it differs from President de Klerk.
An immigrant son of German Jews who emigrated to South Africa with the rise of Hitler, Mr. Schwarz has little in common with the Afrikaans-speaking establishment that dominates the National Party and the Government. But his reputation as an outsider without apartheid's baggage prompted President de Klerk to choose Mr. Schwarz to convince Americans that the changes underway are permanent.
As part of the arrangement, Mr. de Klerk agreed that the National Party would not try to win the parliamentary seat vacated by Mr. Schwarz in Yeoville, a Johannesburg suburb.
 
Views Are Unchanged
 "He hasn't asked me to change my political convictions," said Mr. Schwarz, speaking of Mr. de Klerk. "He knows that I'm implacably opposed to apartheid. Otherwise, there's no logic in asking me to do this job." Nor, Mr. Schwarz added, was he bound for Washington to represent South Africa's five million whites.
"I've made it clear that I want to be ambassador for 37 million people," Mr. Schwarz said during an interview at his law firm's spacious office in downtown Johannesburg.
"Even though 37 million haven't chosen me, I'm going to look after them."
In going to Washington, Mr. Schwarz said, he wants to tell Americans that they are responsible for seeing the dismantling of apartheid through to a democratic conclusion.
"Americans have, I think quite correctly, taken a moral stance against apartheid. They decided to translate this moral stance into action through sanctions," he said.
 
'A Moral Obligation'
 But once apartheid goes, Mr. Schwarz said, "Do you then walk away from the South African situation? I say you shouldn't, and morally you're not entitled to do it. I think you've got a moral obligation to see that the system that follows is quite consistent with American values, and that those values are political and economic."
South Africans deserve the same rights under a new constitution that Americans exercise under the United States Constitution, Mr. Schwarz said, including a separation of executive, legislative and judicial powers and a Supreme Court to enforce civil rights.
"I think the Americans are a little shy abut marketing that," he said.
And American concern, he said, should extend to economic assistance for reconstruction of a non-racial South Africa.
"I believe that freedom isn't complete when you are living in poverty and degradation," Mr. Schwarz said. If a post-apartheid economy stopped generating wealth, he said, inability to meet popular aspirations could tempt even a democratic government to resort to autocratic measures.
 
'Desire for Quick Fixes'
 "What concerns me is the desire for quick fixes. If you apply quick fixes in South Africa, it may take 15 to 25 years to overcome the price that has to be paid for a quick fix and I don't think we have time to make mistakes."
Like his former parliamentary comrade Helen Suzman, Mr. Schwarz takes a dim view of sanctions, which he says hurt the wrong people through joblessness and hunger. He believes that sanctions should be lifted now that Mr. de Klerk is moving to scrap apartheid.
"Once you accept the inevitability of the process, I think the need to suffer falls away," Mr. Schwarz said. It would be impossible, he said, to resegregate public facilities or close down black labor unions.
Mr. Schwarz's views open him to criticism from more radical opponents of apartheid, but his antipathy toward racism stems from childhood. A dozen years before the National Party came to power, Hendrick Verwoerd, who was later to become Prime Minister, led a campaign to bar Jewish refugees from South Africa. As a 12-year-old, Mr. Schwarz watched his grandfather and grandmother booed as they arrived on the last German ship in 1936.
 
'Grandparents Were Jeered'
 "I can't ever forget what happened at the dockside when people were protesting when my grandparents were coming off the boat," he said. It taught him, Mr. Schwarz said, that "if you're a racist in respect of one group of people, you're a racist -- full stop."
To argue his case, Mr. Schwarz must open Congressional doors on Capitol Hill that have been closed to South African envoys.
"I think I've got a fairly difficult job and I'm not the person that can convince people overnight," Mr. Schwarz said. "What I ask is that people be prepared to listen to me."
He recalled having lunch here in November with Joe Slovo, an African National Congress official who is also general secretary of the South African Communist Party. Mr. Schwarz earlier published an open letter to Mr. Slovo proposing that they debate the meaning of democracy.
"If I can sit down and have lunch with a leadership figure in the Communist Party, why should I not be able to do that with an American politician? " Mr. Schwarz said.

HEADLINE: Mexican Inflation at 30%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Mexican consumer prices rose by 30 percent in 1990, the central bank reported last week. The figure is higher than the previous year but still somewhat heartening in a country that once suffered triple-digit inflation. Officials have pledged to cut the 1990 figure in half this year as they press for a free-trade agreement with the United States and Canada.

HEADLINE: WARSAW JOURNAL;
Church's Bane: Madonna and Other Temptations

BYLINE: By GABRIELLE GLASER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Only a few sounds are audible at the main office of the seminary here: the swishing of cassocks as priests glide across the marble floor, and the chirping of swallows that inhabit the lush inner courtyards, thick with ferns and poinsettias.
For decades, the daily routine of priests here has borne little resemblance to the difficulties and uncertainties of life elsewhere in the country. Poland is one of five nations where the number of seminary students has steadily risen in the last decade. 
 Roman Catholic officials say the new democratic Poland, which many of them struggled to achieve, poses problems for the church. Many express concern that the growing influence of the West will help deter young men from the priesthood.
 
'A Great Test'
 "The coming years will be a great test for us," said the Rev. Jan Palyga, editor of a Catholic youth magazine here. "We predicted as our economic situation improves, the living standard will follow and the influence of the West will loom even larger than it does today."
Not so long ago in Poland things Western were pleasures only to be enjoyed in secret. Now, the records and videos of Madonna, whose illusions to Catholicism last year were criticized by the church as blasphemous, are best sellers, and sex shops and pornography are turning up in all the tiny villages.
While the West faces a chronic dearth of priests, the number in Poland rose to 24,678 in 1989, from 20,234 in 1980, the Polish episcopate office said. That leaves one priest for every 1,280 church members, compared with 1,650 church members per priest in the United States. Burundi, Ruwanda, Zaire and India are the only other countries to record an increase of priests in recent years, Vatican statistics show.
The number of women in Poland ordained as nuns has risen too. In 1980, there were 915; in 1989, the figure was 1,427, the episcopate office said.
Poland is one of the few countries that has priests in sufficient numbers to send abroad, and many go to Brazil and Central Africa. Until the mid-1980's, Poles had difficulty obtaining passports to travel outside the East bloc. But the priesthood afforded almost unrestricted travel.
 
Following Favorite Son
 Church officials list a number of reasons why young men are attracted to the priesthood. Most obvious in this nation where more than 90 percent of the population considers itself Roman Catholic is a desire to follow the path of the nation's favorite son, Pope John Paul II. His photograph can be seen above almost every shop door, on placards dangling from rearview mirrors and on tiny rectangular keychains.
"John Paul is beloved everywhere, but especially here," said the Rev. Szymon Stefanowicz, a priest at the Jasna Gora Monastery in Czestochowa. "Is it any wonder why young men want to be like him? He is such a good force in the world."
The priesthood is also prestigious in this country, and a son's enrollment in a seminary is as much a cause for celebration for Polish parents as an American child's acceptance into law or medical school.
Some say the reasons are more complex. Many cite the compulsion to answer the call of God, while others say the attraction is more practical.
 
Security and Freedom
 For the last 45 years, young Polish couples have been obliged to wait decades for apartments, telephones and cars, and until economic changes were introduced a year ago, hours for essentials like milk and eggs. The seminary, on the other hand, has offered secure housing, freedom for intellectual pursuit and the chance to travel outside the country.
"In the West, children are born with everything -- television, computers and cars," said Brother Marian Laskowski, a 24-year-old monk from Elblag in northern Poland who plans to become a priest. "In Poland, we are born with very little."
Brother Laskowski said he joined the seminary because he was drawn to God but acknowledged he sometimes challenged the wisdom of his decision.
"I see people coming in here wearing jeans, and I am spending the best years of my life behind these cold marble walls," Brother Laskowski, dressed in a heavy brown robe, said as he minded a stand selling icons at St. John's Cathedral in Warsaw.
 
Flourished Amid Repression
 Despite four and a half decades of Communist rule, Poland managed to move freely to the rhythms of the Catholic Church. Unlike the Soviet Union, where open worshipers faced persecution and the Orthodox Church was controlled by the authorities, the church in Poland withstood its period of repression and flourished independently, becoming a rival center of power to the Government.
Even during the martial-law period in the early 1980's, the pulpit was often a bastion of dissent. The Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, the outspoken critic of Communism who was killed by the secret police in 1984, is revered as a martyr across the country.
Last September, voluntary religious education classes returned to public schools after 34 years, a move largely prompted by the church. And while construction of religious buildings in many Catholic countries has all but halted in recent decades, new foundations are laid almost weekly for them in Poland. Almost 1,000 churches and other religious buildings have been built in Poland since 1985.
Father Stefanowicz said Poles paid more attention to the church than Catholics in the West because they regarded it as an extended family. "This feeling has disappeared from rich countries like France and America, where everyone has his own apartment," he said.
"In Poland, we have the Pope as our Holy Father, the Virgin as our Holy Mother, and the rest as brothers and sisters. The church was always something we could count on, and young men have always wanted to be a part of it. But now, no one can say what will happen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: During the last decade, the Catholic Church in Poland has had one of the fastest-growing priesthoods in the world. Young Polish priests gathered for Mass recently at the Black Madonna shrine in Jasna Gora. (Witold Jaroslaw Szulecki for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Careers;
Colleges Help Alumni Who Lose Jobs

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
UNIVERSITIES are facing a troubling question: How much help can and should they give their alumni who lose middle-management jobs?
The growing problem comes at a time of ever-tightening budgets, and yet the universities count on alumni heavily for financial support -- and that means deciding how to handle the situation is not easy. 
 "I don't use adjectives easily, and I don't have any numbers, but the increase in alumni contacting us for help has been dramatic," Thomas C. Devlin, director of Cornell University's career center, said last week.
At Purdue University, Dennis J. Weidenaar, dean of the Krannert School of Management, reports a sharp increase in the number of jobless alumni seeking help to find work. "It is running about double a year ago," he said.
Vicki Lynn, director of the career development center at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, said last week that there had been a 65 percent increase in late fall in the number of alumni seeking help, compared with the period a year ago. Graduates of Rensselaer mostly are engineers or scientists, many of whom had little trouble finding jobs when they left school in recent years.
Mr. Devlin said that undergraduates were so worried about the job market that increasing numbers were applying to professional schools. At the same time, he said, the alumni were not going to professional schools as often. "Their problem is primarily economic -- mortgages, children in school at a time they are out of work or expect to lose their jobs," he said, adding that "the uncertainty in the world" was another problem.
Mr. Devlin's center gives the jobless alumni the names of fellow alumni with high-stature jobs "who are receptive to phone calls."
Most alumni reaching his office have been about "three months out of work" and they are realistic about taking more time to find jobs, he said.
At Purdue's management school, the alumni are "looking for places to send their resumes." The career center is also hearing increasingly from alumni who want career counseling either by telephone or in person, Dr. Weidenaar said.
"I did a little research and we found an interesting breakdown," he said. "Two groups predominate: One group tends to be four years out of college and the other large group has been out 13 to 15 years," he said. They tend to be in three areas -- human resources, marketing and operations.
He said that some companies, like Eli Lilly, which is based in Indianapolis, are still recruiting as heavily on campus as in past years, but that the auto companies have cut recruiting. These might be two hints for job-seeking alumni, he said -- health-care companies might have openings, but auto companies are probably still laying workers off. These are the kinds of clues that career offices can provide.
Mrs. Lynn of Rensselaer explained that her career center regularly "publishes profiles of alumni backgrounds and sends them to 160 companies, like General Electric, Raytheon and Corning, to name a few.
"The alumni who contact me are not interested in the registry," she said. "They want counseling. They want to know where they went wrong, what strategies to use, and how to package themselves." They come back to campus for face-to-face interviews with her and her assistants.
"We start with the resume because many don't have a clue about that," Mrs Lynn said. "They prepare it as if it was an employment application. So we start from scratch. We charge $50 for counseling, up from $25 last year."
For the time spent, she said, the alumni would have to pay $1,000 to $2,000 at an outside counseling firm.
Ten years ago, she recalled, the career center consisted of her and an assistant. Today, it has a staff of 15. "Not all of them do counseling," she said, explaining that the center's role has increased in other ways.
On Jan. 26, Mrs. Lynn is holding an all-day crash course called "Careerathalon" to teach business etiquette, something she has long felt most prospective young managers needed. The need is evidently understood on campus. Although she expected only 100 to attend, 340 undergraduates have already signed up for it, along with about 50 faculty members.
"It's like a finishing school," she said.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
The New Surge In Self-Employed

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
THE late 20th century has left quite a mark on the American labor force. The very image of the worker has switched from blue-collar factory hand to white-collar sales clerk. Women have become almost as visible as men at work. And now, it turns out, the self-employed are making a comeback -- mainly because so many women are choosing to work for themselves.
The big question is whether this new surge in self-employment, evident in Labor Department data since 1987, represents an improvement for those in their own businesses. Researchers do not know yet, but one bit of evidence is striking. Women on their own, whatever their skills, education or race, earn less per hour on average than women drawing wages. Self-employed men, in contrast, earn more than their job-holding male peers. 
 That nugget of information came to light in new research by Theresa J. Devine, a labor economist at Pennsylvania State University, who sifted through Labor Department data to pinpoint the self-employment trend. Her findings and other calculations show that self-employment, after increasing smartly in the 1970's, leveled off in the mid-1980's, and started to rise again in 1987.
"We were a nation of small shopkeepers and farmers in the 19th century and then people felt that to get ahead they had to take jobs in factories and big companies," said Rona Feit, senior fellow at the Corporation for Enterprise Development. "Now we're starting small businesses again."
Ms. Devine, Ms. Feit and other experts say they can only guess at the reasons why men and women, and particularly women, are going out on their own in growing numbers. Roughly 7 percent of all employed women are self-employed today, up from 5.9 percent in 1986, while for men the rise has been to about 12.5 percent, from 11.8 percent in 1986. In most cases, the new proprietors do most of the work themselves, hiring few people to help.
Why do they do it? The speculation covers a variety of reasons.
On the positive side, many women apparently start their own businesses so they can work at home or near it, on flexible schedules, while raising children. Or they try to achieve an independence not possible in a corporate job. Such conclusions are suggested in Ms. Devine's findings.
Three out of every four self-employed women, for example, are married and can risk self-employment because they have the security of health insurance from their husbands' jobs, Ms. Devine speculates. Many self-employed women are also college educated, which means they could probably get regular jobs but prefer the freedom and challenge of running their own enterprises.
Finally, self-employed women tend to work part time, perhaps to accommodate child-rearing, Ms.Devine says. In contrast, self-employed men usually work full time, investing more energy in their enterprises, which might help to explain why the women do not earn as much per hour on average as women who work for wages, while men do better than their male peers holding jobs.
On a more troubling note, self-employment spurted upward during the 1981-82 recession and is likely to do so in the current recession. The unemployed, unable to find new jobs, try to start their own businesses. "There is definitely a recession component in self-employment," said Richard Boden of the Small Business Administration.
Other special factors also drive the trend. Asian immigrants, for example, are well represented in the new wave of self-employed, Ms. Devine found. So are Hispanic people. Self-employment is clearly a way up for the nation's new wave of immigrants. But blacks are underrepresented as small proprietors, perhaps, economists say, because they have more difficulty than other groups in getting start-up loans and they run into more discrimination in trying to sell products or services.
Then there is the baby-boom factor: Millions of baby boomers competed for jobs just as companies cut back to be more competitive. The squeeze prompted thousands to try self-employment as an alternative, often by starting retail operations, says William Dunkelberg, chief economist at the National Federation of Independent Business.
The federation sponsors a long-term study of 13,000 small businesses formed in 1985. "Most of these start-ups were in retail -- boutiques, small food establishments and the like -- where entry was easy but the failure rate after three years has been high," Mr. Dunkelberg said.
Now that fewer young workers are entering the labor force, will self-employment continue to rise? During the current recession it will, economists say. And perhaps afterward as well, if immigration remains at a high level and women continue to view self-employment as a road to their goals.

HEADLINE: United Church of Christ Urges Fight Against Rising Racism

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
The United Church of Christ has issued a pastoral letter warning that racism is a deepening problem in America.
More than three decades after the start of the civil rights movement, the letter said, poverty is worse for nonwhite Americans and racially motivated violence has increased. 
 It said that racist attitudes "permeate most of our institutions" and that racism underlies economic and social disparities between whites and nonwhites.
"As a result of racial discrimination," the letter said, "all over the United States there are 'quiet riots' in the form of unemployment, poverty, social disorganization, family disintegration, housing and school deterioration, and crime."
On Sunday, a day before the Federal holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., church leaders will read the letter to more than 6,000 congregations of the United Church of Christ, a 1.7-million-member Protestant denomination.
 
'Sound a National Alarm'
 While the letter carries both theological and social meaning for church members, it is intended to draw wider attention to the issue of racism, said the Rev. Benjamin Chavis Jr., a veteran civil rights leader and a church official.
"We are trying to sound a national alarm," Mr. Chavis said in a recent interview. "We believe the leadership of our nation has focused so much on the world situation that we're losing sight of the domestic, the internal deterioration of our society. We should have made much more progress toward racial harmony."
The church is urging its followers to recognize racism as a sin and to become active in the political process on behalf of equality.
The pastoral letter is only the third in the history of the United Church of Christ, said Mr. Chavis, who is executive director of the church's Commission for Racial Justice.
The letter expressed alarmed at the increasing frequency of violent acts against members of minority groups. The violence cannot be dismissed as isolated acts of fringe groups and extremists, it said.
The attacks are "visible consequences of racist attitudes" throughout society, the letter said, and reflect a growing climate of racial intolerance and hostility.
An accompanying background paper cited Federal statistics showing increasing inequities in living standards for whites and nonwhites.
 
'Virtually No Progress'
 A small percentage of nonwhite Americans made some socioeconomic gains in the 1970's and 1980's, the church said, but the quality of life for most Americans of racial minority is worse today than it was in the 1960's.
"Virtually no progress toward social and economic equality for African Americans has been made since the early 1970's," it said. In addition, racism is a daily problem for Hispanic Americans, Indians, Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders, the letter said.
Citing President Bush's veto of a civil rights bill last year, Mr. Chavis said the Federal Government "has become the obstacle" to racial justice.
Unless there was a change, Mr. Chavis said, he feared that American society "could explode from within" in ways worse than the urban riots of the 1960's.

HEADLINE: Funds Shift By Taiwan

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Taiwan, which controls one of the world's largest foreign exchange reserves, has pulled tens of billions of dollars out of United States commercial banks, which it fears could fail in an economic recession prolonged by a Persian Gulf war.
Officials of Taiwan's central bank said today that Taiwan had moved most of its United States dollar holdings to the Federal Reserve and to banks in Europe, Japan and Australia.
The officials said that about $35 billion -- 58 percent of the county's currency reserves -- had been moved out of United States commercial banks since late 1990.
They said about $20 billion had been placed in the Federal Reserve, with the rest going to European, Japanese and Australian banks. A smaller amount was also deposited in overseas branches of Taiwanese banks, they said.
"The shift is mainly to protect our reserves as we face more risks by depositing our money in U.S. banks," a senior bank official told reporters.
Taiwan's booming economy, built on exports to the United States, has generated foreign exchange reserves of about $73 billion, competing with Japan's as the largest in the world.

HEADLINE: Nicaragua Sinks Further as Chamorro's Magic Fails

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Despite expectations of a quick economic turnaround after the inauguration of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro last April, the Nicaraguan economy has not recovered and is now deteriorating amid large deficits and continued high military spending, economists and diplomats say.
The flood of new private investment that Mrs. Chamorro's election was predicted to release has been reduced to a trickle by investors' fears of new civil unrest. Foreign aid has been held up by concerns about Government disarray and free spending that has forced Mrs. Chamorro to draw down the country's scarce reserves by roughly $50 million in the last two months alone. 
 In Managua, traffic has become sprinkled with the shiny vehicles of visiting exiles weighing whether to return. But there has been little new long-term investment to help reverse a decade of economic decline.
On the rutted streets of the capital, beggars have begun to go door to door in search of handouts, and currency changers wave thick stacks of local bills that lose up to half their value each month due to five-digit inflation.
"A worker, a carpenter, a tailor can't even afford a pound of meat a week for his family," said Alfredo Vega Mendoza, a 50-year-old clothing salesman, carrying a small bag of rice and other purchases from a Managua market. "There hasn't been any kind of change -- that's all a lie."
 
High Cost of Concessions
 Mrs. Chamorro's aides staked the economy's future on her ability to win commitments of aid from the international community, and credits from international institutions like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, which American sanctions effectively made unavailable to Nicaragua under the Sandinistas.
But the arrival of a mission from the I.M.F., World Bank and Inter-American Development Bank this month is also certain to focus hard international scrutiny on the admitted disarray of the Chamorro Government's economic policies. And it is expected to highlight the high economic cost that the Government has paid for its policy of cushioning its transition to power with salary concessions and slow reductions in Nicaragua's armed forces.
"The concern is that the policies will not measure up, and instead of opening the door to new credit, the visit will only make things harder by confirming the worst impression that donor countries have about this Government," said a European diplomat whose country has been approached for aid.
The Government's economic problems have weakened the effect of the outside aid that is already coming in, including $300 million in emergency American aid approved last year, and they have effectively delayed other major foreign commitments.
Part of the American aid is the key to benchmarks of economic progress the Government has been unable to meet. Other important donors, like Japan, which has tentatively committed large amounts of aid, have dragged their feet, waiting for signs that the Government can make effective use of the money.
 
Production Shrinks
 Once expected to hold steady or even increase by the end of 1990, the economy's overall production shrank by as much as 5 percent -- even more than the relative loss suffered in the final year of Sandinista rule -- and is continuing to fall, Government analysts say.
The deteriorating production has been accompanied by a resurgence of the hyperinflation that stripped the value of local currency for several years in a row. The Nicaraguan cordoba, which was reissued in February 1988 by the Sandinista Government at an exchange rate of 10 to the American dollar, now trades at roughly 3.2 million to the dollar. The Government's plan to introduce a new dollar equivalent currency, the gold cordoba, has been frozen by a lack of reserves to back it.
Diplomats and independent economists here attribute much of the economy's trouble to the Government's inability to control social and military spending.
Under a plan developed by Francisco Mayorga Balladares, a Yale-educated economist and key member of Mrs. Chamorro's campaign circle, the Government's monthly deficit fell from more than $30 million in the month after the President's inauguration to roughly $8 million in September. Mr. Mayorga also succeeded in obtaining large foreign aid commitments at a June conference of potential aid donors in Rome.
 
Tight Restraint Abandoned
 But after worsening clashes with Mrs. Chamorro's family advisers, Mr. Mayorga was forced to resign in October. And the tight budgetary restraint he imposed was gradually abandoned, first in generous settlements of nationwide Sandinista strikes in May and July, and later in broader employment and salary concessions that formed part of a national pact signed with unions and business leaders on Oct. 26.
As part of its policy of avoiding confrontation with the Sandinista-dominated military, the Government has also made a series of secret payments to the army that have amounted to as much as several million dollars a month above its formal budget, said diplomats and Government officials who have witnessed the payments.
Signs of economic crisis have grown more urgent. The Government's monthly deficit has risen to at least $35 million, and inflation has surged again to roughly 50 percent a month.
Early in December, Mrs. Chamorro's son-in-law and chief strategist, Antonio Lacayo Oyanguren, led the Nicaraguan delegation to another donor's conference in Paris. But the delegation came away empty-handed after presenting a report that aid officials said made little attempt to justify the Government's deepening deficit.
"The Rome document found acceptance among almost everyone; the Paris document found acceptance among almost no one," said another independent foreign expert. "The difference between was politics."

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Group Told Recession May Be Short

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Two economists told the annual convention of the National Retail Federation in New York yesterday that the recession would be of relatively short duration and would be followed by a gradual improvement as the year progressed. But both speakers took pains to hedge their forecasts.
"I expect the economy to experience only a mild contraction so that consumer spending should not be severely impacted," Rosalind Wells, chief economist for the federation, the nation's largest retail trade association, told an audience of more than 600 at the New York Hilton Hotel. 
 Ms. Wells forecast that real spending would increase one-quarter percent this year, compared with 1 percent last year. But she added: "Once again, durables will be hardest hit, falling 3 1/2 percent. Nondurables will decline 1/2 percent, while services will expand by 2 percent." Durable goods -- merchandise like refrigerators and furniture and electronics items, expected to last more than three years -- rose a weak 3 percent in 1990.
W. Lee Hoskins, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, told the retailers: "At the moment, the data we are seeing are consistent with the idea that the decline will be brief and, indeed, may be largely behind us." He added that the buildup in business inventories had been slight compared with previous recessions. And, he said, "Capital goods and export markets may continue to provide the economy with a much-needed lift."
But Mr. Hoskins also described the current business activity decline as "serious." He said that while much of the recent softness had been centered in the coastal states and was predominantly in the construction, automotive and retail industries, "we cannot dismiss the possibility that weakness will become more pervasive." He added, "As is always the case, it is impossible to foretell with precision either when the decline will end or what shape the ensuing recovery will be."
The retail group's 80th annual convention, which includes a trade exhibit on management information systems, anti-theft devices and warehouse equipment at the Sheraton Centre down the street from the Hilton , opened Sunday for a four-day run. The retail industry is in considerable turmoil because of erratic sales, widespread consolidations and a continued concern about the Mideast crisis and its impact on consumer spending.
 
Unpredictable Retail Sales
 Since August, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, retail sales have become even more unpredictable than they were throughout an already difficult year. But in speeches and hallway interviews, retailers said they thought a peaceful resolution of the Mideast confrontation could bring a groundswell of consumer confidence that could invigorate retail sales.
Yet the recent disappointing Christmas season was not forgotten as a noon-hour speaker at the Sheraton looked around at an audience of 500 and remarked, "I didn't see this many people in our stores during the entire month of December."
Forecasting 1991 results for general merchandise, apparel and home furnishings, Ms. Wells said that she expected the retail category to increase 3 3/4 percent, or 1 1/2 percent after inflation, against a 3 1/2 percent rise, or 1 percent after inflation, in 1990.
In more specific terms, she said apparel sales should be up 5 percent during the year, with women's wear again outpacing men's and children's apparel. "The pattern of weaker durables and better growth in more decorative, less expensive home merchandise is likely to continue this year since housing is not expected to experience a strong demand," she said.
But Ms. Wells added: "In spite of the modest overall numbers, this year's quarterly general merchandise sales pattern will be much more favorable for retailers than 1990. But my outlook for the first half of the year remains subdued. I think stores will continue to struggle for sales gains." If the economy picks up in the second half, however, she said that 1991 Christmas business could jump 6 to 7 percent above last year's.

HEADLINE: Mitchell and Dole Set Senate Legislative Agendas

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Emerging briefly from the shadow of the Persian Gulf crisis, the Senate Democratic and Republican leaders introduced bills today setting out their legislative priorities for the 102d Congress.
"As important as the gulf crisis is, we cannot turn our backs on the other business of this nation," said George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate Democratic leader. "We are elected to put our own house in order, not only to seek a new world order." 
 The one area where Mr. Mitchell and Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, both introduced measures was on revamping the financing of Congressional campaigns. While the proposals differ sharply, their introduction reflects a new urgency on the issue as the Senate Ethics Committee prepares for deliberations over the conduct of five Senators accused of doing favors for a major donor.
Although the five bills introduced by each leader dealt primarily with domestic matters, they also included measures related to the military presence in the gulf. In a gesture to veterans, Mr. Mitchell designated as Senate Bill No. 1 a proposal to provide cost-of-living increases to disabled veterans and survivors of veterans.
 
Strong Nod for the Veteran
 Noting that Federal retirees, Social Security recipients and others collecting Federal benefits got cost-of-living increases last year, Mr. Mitchell said, "The least we can do for those now standing ready to serve is to show promptly that their nation will honor its commitments for that service."
In a similar gesture, Mr. Dole proposed a bill to give the Internal Revenue Service authority to extend tax filing deadlines to those in the military deployed in the gulf.
Mr. Mitchell's introduction of specific domestic proposals was a marked contrast to when he first took over as majority leader at the opening session two years ago and was criticized for not laying out his major objectives for the session. Instead, he spoke in broad terms about establishing a "new social contract" between the Government and the people.
The second bill he introduced today was to establish a council that would issue an annual progress report on national education goals. The intention, he said, was "a bill that makes our progress measurable" in addressing issues like illiteracy and teacher training.
Another bill is intended to ease the overburdened foster care and child welfare services. Among other provisions, it would insure that every child under 6 years of age could stay on Medicaid for six months after becoming eligible.
 
Medical Leave Measure
 Mr. Mitchell also introduced a bill that was vetoed last year by President Bush: it would provide unpaid family and medical leave for working people for reasons like a baby's birth or the illness of a child or parent.
The Senate did not follow the House in immediately reintroducing the civil rights bill that Mr. Bush vetoed last year. But Mr. Mitchell said such a measure was "the most significant" of the legislation that was not officially proposed today.
Other priorities, Mr. Mitchell said, would include measures to conserve energy, repair the nation's roads and bridges, overhaul the bank insurance deposit system and ease a recession.
Measures introduced by Mr. Dole included a proposal that the United States give direct aid to democratically elected governments that have a Communist-ruling majority. Another bill would replace a governmental system that limits older worker's Social Security earnings.
Both the Senate and House passed campaign finance measures last year, but the legislation never made it to conference committee, with both chambers divided over key provisions.
 
Campaign Reform Pressed
 The measure introduced today by Mr. Mitchell is virtually identical to the one the Senate passed last year. Among other things, campaigns that limit their overall spending would get vouchers for discounts in buying broadcast time for television commercials. The bill would also ban political action committees from donating to candidates for Federal office.
The bill does not go as far as calling for public financing of Congressional campaigns as a way to limit spending, but Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, said he planned to introduce such a measure again.
Mr. Dole's bill would also ban political action committee contributions, but does not call for limiting overall spending.
Taking aim at the five Senators in the "Keating Five" case -- four of whom are Democrats -- Mr. Dole also proposed requiring the "public disclosure of all Congressional contacts with Federal agencies concerning enforcement matters." He added that lawmakers should be comfortable about reading about their intervention on the front page of the newspaper.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Sharp Gyrations Mark Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Talk of war and peace in the Middle East led to sharp gyrations in the credit markets yesterday, but by late in the session prices of Treasury securities were little changed.
Most activity was in the short-term Treasury bill market. Demand at the weekly auction of three-month bills was so high that the average discount rate fell to its lowest level in three years. 
 The failure of Javier Perez de Cuellar, the Secretary General of the United Nations, to advance negotiations for a peaceful Iraqi withdrawl from Kuwait during his weekend mission to Baghdad pushed prices of notes and bonds down sharply during overnight trading, and the lower prices held most of the day.
 
Price Declines Evaporate
 But the price declines evaporated rapidly after Cable News Network reported at 3:15 P.M. yesterday that Iraq was willing to withdraw from Kuwait but was not willing to do so under the dictates of a deadline.
Fifteen minutes later, Bernard Shaw, CNN's reporter in Baghdad, quoting an unnamed Iraqi official, re-emphasized that in Iraq's view the central problem with pulling the troops out of Kuwait was the idea of dealing with a deadline.
The report and subsequent statement did not seem to represent any real change in Iraq's position. But the initial report had the effect of persuading nervous market participants to buy back securities they had sold earlier.
"Until the market knows whether or not we are going to war and how the war itself is likely to go, wild swings based on whatever rumor is swirling around will be the standard," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh. "All of this on top of a very shaky economy is a very vicious brew."
Befitting an extremely nervous, uncertain market, the volatile price movements came on very thin trading.
Because of the gulf crisis, "most participants have not wanted to do anything at all since the start of the year," said Maria Fiorini Ramirez, president of Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc. "It just doesn't pay to be involved."
 
Focus on Short Term
 Investors who were willing to do some buying were focusing on securities with maturities of a year or less, like short-term Treasury bills.
Buying in the secondary market for Treasury bills and at the weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills was strong throughout the session.
"The only place we are seeing any liquidity is in bills," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America. "At this point, taking a position any further out the maturity spectrum is a gamble that is not worth taking. It's a little like going swimming in the ocean when there is a major hurricane watch out."
At the weekly auction, the only sale of new Treasury securities scheduled to be held this week, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 6.12 percent, down sharply from the 6.52 percent average rate at last week's sale. It is the lowest rate on a three-month bill since April 1988.
Meanwhile, six-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 6.21 percent, compared with an average rate of 6.51 percent a week ago.
Noncompetitive bids at the auctions, a good proxy of demand from individual investors, set records for both the three-month and six-month bills. More than $2 billion worth of noncompetitive bids were submitted for the three-month bills. Noncompetitive bids for the six-month bills totaled $1.5 billion.
 
Benchmark Issue Unchanged
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 104 1/4 late yesterday, to yield 8.35 percent, unchanged on the day. Before the CNN report, the benchmark issue had fallen by about 3/4 point.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 6/ 32, down 2/32, to yield 8.16 percent. And the 7 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 7/32, down 1/32, to yield 7.12 percent.
The CNN report erased much of what had earlier been a big drop in interest rates on Treasury bills outstanding.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.11 percent, down four basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell one basis point, to a late offered rate of 6.20 percent.
Despite volatile market conditions, the Florida Turnpike Authority offered $333 million of securities in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.
 
Insured by Ambac
 The issue, which consists of serial and term bonds, is fully insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation.
Maturities on the serial bonds range from 1995 through 2007, with yields from 6 percent in 1995 to 7.15 percent in 2007.
The term bonds were offered with a maximum yield of 7.28 percent on securities maturing in 2018.
Prudential-Bache Securities acted as lead manager for the negotiated offering. The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Participants in the secondary market for municipal bonds said prices of most widely quoted issues dipped by about 1/4 point in very light trading.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues rose by about 1/8 point.
No new corporate issues were priced yesterday.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: PUBLIC OPINION;
Americans Don't Expect Short War

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
A majority of Americans say they are satisfied that President Bush has done everything he should to prevent war in the Persian Gulf. But the country remains deeply divided over whether fighting Iraq is the right policy, and most people do not expect the short war with relatively low casualties that Mr. Bush and his officials have talked about, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows.
While the poll suggests that Mr. Bush has been able to maintain public approval for his handling of the crisis, with 58 percent saying they approve and 33 percent saying they disapprove, it also shows where his political vulnerabilities may lie. And it provides the most detailed view to date of Americans' gloomy expectations about what a war in the gulf would be like. 
 Most of the 1,512 people who were questioned from Friday through Sunday said they expected the war to last several months to more than a year, to require heavy combat on the ground, produce thousands of American deaths and make a major attack by Iraqi agents within the United States likely.
 
Fear of Another Vietnam
 In the end, the greatest political threat to Mr. Bush could come from precisely what he has tried to counter in his public statements: the fear of many Americans, as expressed in follow-up interviews conducted after the survey was completed, that war in the gulf could bring about a repetition of the United States' bitter experience in Vietnam.
"Basically, I guess we're hoping that it's not a Vietnam, not going in nudging and pushing, but going full force and getting it over with minimal loss of lives," said Drew A. Collins, an Ohio banker.
Even among those who say Mr. Bush should give economic sanction more time, four out of ten said they would consider a short war with low casualties worth fighting. But at the same time, the poll showed that nearly half of those who said Mr. Bush should act now expressed the view that the price for getting Iraq out of Kuwait would not be worth paying if a war dragged on with heavy casualties.
The nationwide telephone survey, which carried a possible sampling error of three percentage points one way or the other, was conducted after the failure of the Iraqi-American talks in Geneva last Wednesday and while Congress debated and then voted for a resolution authorizing Mr. Bush to use force in the gulf.
 
Fight Now or Wait?
 A solid majority, 66 percent, said they expected that the country would end up in a war, an increase of nine percentage points from a poll conducted a week earlier. But they were evenly split on whether Mr. Bush should immediately begin hostilities or wait to give economic sanctions more time.
The follow-up interviews suggested that some of those who called for action soon were expressing a desire to get it over with rather than registering enthusiastic support for Mr. Bush's position.
"We should be real sure we're going to get this thing done or not do it at all," said Robert T. Grindle, a 58-year-old Korean War veteran from Blue Hill, Me. "Bush opened his mouth and we have to back him up. We appointed him President and have to back him but Bush -- he said too much, got himself in trouble."
 
Majorities for Conflicting Views
 Fifty-five percent of Americans said Mr. Bush had done "everything he should to avoid war." But 59 percent continued to say that Mr. Bush should seek a meeting with President Saddam Hussein before midnight tonight, the United Nations deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait or face the use of force.
Although Mr. Bush has said he rules out any negotiation or compromise with Iraq, a majority of Americans -- 56 percent -- said it would be acceptable for the United States to first agree to an international conference on Arab-Israeli problems if Iraq would then withdraw from Kuwait. Forty-seven percent said it would be acceptable to them if the ousted leadership of Kuwait offered to trade a piece of the country's territory in return for Iraq's withdrawal from most of Kuwait.
Although the Bush Administration has devoted much attention in recent weeks to its attempts to explain the reasons for sending troops to Saudi Arabia, Americans remained divided on why those forces are there.
 
Oil or Morality?
 Forty-two percent said it was mainly to stop Iraq from attacking its neighbors, 29 percent said it was mainly to protect oil supplies, and 11 percent said it was mainly to restore the leadership of Kuwait.
But when it came to deciding whether those reasons were "good enough to go to war," the poll showed an even split overall. Only among those who said American troops were sent to stop attacks by Iraq did a majority say that was a good enough reason for a war.
The groups most polarized by the gulf crisis were blacks and whites and men and women. By margins of 15 percentage points or more, blacks and women were more opposed to early action, more disapproving of Mr. Bush and his handling of the gulf crisis, and more inclined to say that a war of any duration was not worth fighting.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Closes Day at $400.10, Highest in Over 3 Months

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metal prices surged yesterday on fears that war in the Persian Gulf is becoming inevitable as the deadline for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait approaches.
Gold closed at its highest level in more than three months. In New York, gold's contract for immediate delivery broke $400 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange, increasing $8.50 a troy ounce to close at $400.10, in reaction to the failure by the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, to secure a peaceful solution to the crisis. 
 The last time the immediate contract for gold surpassed $400 was on Oct. 8.
Analysts said the failure of Mr. Perez de Cuellar to secure peace before the Jan. 15 deadline helped support gold prices in early trading.
Once gold futures reached their highs, prices fluctuated in a narrow range, responding to the strength in the crude oil market, said Bette Raptopoulos, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Crude oil rose $3.49 a barrel, to $30.78.
Silver futures traded higher in league with gold, Ms. Raptopoulos said. But platinum prices were lower on belief a war would result in reduced demand for the metal, used in auto catalytic converters.
Gold settled $8.80 to $8.50 higher, with the active contract for delivery in February up $8.30, to $401.60 a troy ounce. Silver was 9.2 cents to 8.2 cents higher, with March at $4.230 a troy ounce. And platinum was 90 cents lower, with January at $417.70 a troy ounce.
On other markets, grain and soybean futures prices closed mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade.
The market received some strength from beliefs that in the short term, prices would receive help from a conflict in the Persian Gulf, said Dan Cekander, an analyst with Rodman & Renshaw Inc.
Mr. Cekander said, however, that increased oil prices caused by a war would result in a recession if the war was a long one. That would cause reduced demand for grains, he said.
Soybean futures were weaker following Friday's United States Agriculture Department crop report that forecast stocks larger than traders had expected.
Wheat futures were also under pressure from the Agriculture Department report, which placed winter wheat seedings at 51.018 million acres.
Corn futures were higher because the report showed strong feed use.
Wheat was 3 3/4 cents to 5 cents lower, with March at $2.48 3/4 a bushel; corn was 1 1/4 cent to 3 1/4 cents higher, with March at $2.33 1/2 a bushel; oats were 1/4 cent to 3/4 cent higher, with March at $1.11 1/4 a bushel; soybeans were 2 1/2 cents to 4 3/4 cents lower, with January at $5.51 1/4 a bushel.
Frozen concentrated orange juice futures soared on New York's Cotton Exchange in reaction to the unexpectedly low 1990-91 orange crop estimate.
The Agriculture Department revised downward its forecast for the California crop from 63 million boxes to 25 million. The reduction was a result of a severe freeze in the state in December.
The department also reduced its forecast for the Florida crop from 165 million boxes to 151 million. The Agriculture Department also reduced the overall yield estimates.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
UAL's Unions Prepared To Renew Buyout Effort

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 14

 BODY:
United Airlines' union workers are ready to renew their efforts to buy the company once the economy improves, the head of the pilots union said. "The union employees at United are fully prepared and economically capable of maintaining their role as major players in any acquisition efforts at our company," Frederick C. Dubinsky, chairman of the United chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association, said.
Mr. Dubinsky and the union organized last year's employee bid to buy United's parent, the UAL Corporation, for $4.4 billion. The attempt failed for lack of financing after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait sent financial markets reeling. Mr. Dubinksy told a meeting of O'Hare International Airport employees and business workers that "the possibility of employee ownership, at least at United, should not be regarded as permanently over."

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: THE KUWAITIS;
Kuwaiti Threatens Attack on Iraqi Civilian Targets

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 14

 BODY:
The Crown Prince of Kuwait says the multinational coalition against Iraq would strike deep inside the country at civilian as well as military targets if Iraq bombed Kuwait City after allied forces retake it.
"If he bombs Kuwait, we'll do the same to Iraqi cities," Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, Kuwait's Crown Prince and Prime Minister, warned in an interview in Jidda on Sunday. 
 The Crown Prince refused to say who would strike nonmilitary targets in Iraq, though the Kuwaiti Air Force, most of which escaped the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion, is capable of such attacks. He also declined to say whether Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d had sanctioned such strikes when he met in Taif, Saudi Arabia, on Friday with the Emir of Kuwait and other senior officials of the Kuwaiti Government-in-exile, including the Crown Prince.
The Crown Prince confirmed that Kuwait had agreed to increase payments for the support of American forces in the region, though he declined to say by how much. Other Kuwaiti officials said they had already pledged about $2.5 billion for the American military deployment here and had provided about $4 billion to Arab allies.
 
Sanctions Said to Fail
 Based on reports from Iraq to the Kuwaiti Government-in-exile, he said he had concluded that sanctions had failed and would continue to fail to force Iraq out of Kuwait. "He has gotten what he needs, perhaps not in the quantities he wants, but enough," Sheik Saad asserted. "What we know is that sanctions have not forced him out in five months, and that they will not work six months from now."
He spoke in a private room inside the Conference Palace, a Saudi Government conference center in Jidda where the Kuwaiti Government-in-exile has been holding meetings with Islamic delegations and with Kuwaiti opposition groups.
Kuwaiti officials met throughout the day Sunday with a members of a committee established in October to monitor a commitment by the Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, to open the Government to greater participation when the country is liberated. Several members of the committee described the discussions as "frank and very loud at times." One participant said that the ruling Sabah family was still resisting demands from some committee members that a new and more representative government be created when Kuwaitis return to their country.
The Crown Prince reiterated the Emir's commitment to carry out Kuwait's Constitution, which calls for a Parliament, free elections and a free press. But he refused to discuss specific demands by reformist groups or to go beyond the rather vague commitment to change the Government once Kuwait is liberated.
 
Sabah Dominance Doubted
 But other Government officials said most Kuwaitis agreed that a decline in the Sabahs' dominance of key posts was inevitable. "Given what's happened and the sentiment of those who have remained in Kuwait, we cannot return to the status quo ante," said Sulaiman al-Mutawa, Minister of Planning and one of the few Cabinet members who is not a member of the Sabah family.
"We're insisting on a real Kuwaiti partnership," said Abdulaziz al-Sagr, the head of Kuwait's Chamber of Commerce. "We're all in the same boat now."
The Crown Prince rejected suggestions that Iraq and Kuwait should sit down together after an Iraqi withdrawal and settle outstanding territorial and economic differences, as several Arab leaders and the United Nations Security Council have recommended. "We sat down with them before August 2d," he said. "It did not work, and we won't do it again. If they still have grievances, they can be discussed before the Arab League."
When asked how the Arab League could mediate anything since it had been shattered by the Persian Gulf crisis, the Crown Prince simply smiled and said, "Yes, it's very sad."
