HEADLINE: DINKINS ABANDONS PROPOSAL TO CLOSE 41 FIRE COMPANIES

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
After intense pressure from the public and the city's firefighter unions, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he had abandoned the idea of closing 41 more fire companies across New York City.
But at the same time, city officials raised the specter of deep school cuts by announcing that the city was going ahead with plans to cut $429 million, or more than 6 percent, from the total school budget next year. 
 The changes are part of hundreds of individual decisions, from raising taxes to cutting as many as 20,000 jobs, that have been reached as Mayor Dinkins prepared a financial plan showing how he would close a $2.1 billion budget gap in the fiscal year beginning July 1. The plan, to be released tomorrow, is the first step in the budget process and is likely to be altered to deal with changing economic conditions and various political pressures.
 
Relief From Cuomo?
 City officials who attended budget briefings said that despite some painful reductions the need for extreme cuts in the Fire Department and other basic city services has been reduced by decisions to raise taxes by up to $600 million and to use often criticized one-time savings from bond refinancings.
The plan included political wrinkles, intended in part to prod Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Legislature to provide budget relief for the city, despite the state's own looming budget gap. This included, the officials said, the implicit threat of the layoffs of thousands of teachers next fall if the state did not increase state aid.
The announcement of the school cuts came as the Board of Education and the teachers' union yesterday closed in on an agreement to defer several days' wages into the future as a means of averting thousands of layoffs Feb. 1, but yesterday they were still apart on precisely how many paydays to put off.
 
3 Fire Companies Closed
 The Fire Department was slated for a $57 million cut next year, a cut that the department argued would require the closing of 41 fire companies, in addition to three companies already closed. Each closing would save a little more than $1 million.
But after the fire company closings touched off community demonstrations -- and after firefighter unions blamed the closing for the death of two men in a fire in Richmond Hill, Queens, only blocks from one of the closed companies, Engine 294 -- the administration backed off from closing further fire companies, apparently concluding the small savings was not worth the political or social cost.
It did this even though some fiscal analysts have long argued that the Fire Department was too large and unwieldy -- with too many fire companies in some neighborhoods and not enough in others -- especially since the number of fires had fallen sharply since the 1970's.
"The Mayor made the judgment that this is the level of pain that he would be willing to deal with," one top Dinkins aide said. "If conditions worsen in the future, there could be more pain."
By last night, city officials said they had identified only $6 million in cuts in the Fire Department, as opposed to the $57 million in cuts originally sought.
 
'If I May Be Heard'
 The emotion created by the fire company issue was evident again last night in Springfield Gardens, Queens, at the first town meeting of the Dinkins administration. Many in the crowd of at least 1,000 people yelled, "No fire cuts, no fire cuts." The chant became so loud that at one point, the Mayor said; "If I may be heard, you may hear something you like. There will be no further closings." He said the closing of Engine 294 should not be blamed for the two deaths.
The Mayor's remarks drew huge applause. even though he added, "I cannot say what will happen in the future, if the state hits us with huge budget cuts."
The cuts, outlined in briefings in the last few days, will include the following:
*The elimination of the "clean team," 300 sanitation workers who pushed brooms to clean up business districts, and a delay in the expansion of the city's current recycling program. Nearly 1,000 sanitation jobs would be cut, including up to 260 or so through layoffs.
*The elimination of the city's "Giant Step program," which provided intensive pre-kindergarten classes for 3,300 youngsters. The officials said the city would try to get more money for Federal Head Start slots to replace the program. Closing Giant Step, a showcase of the Koch administration, will save $10 million, the officials said.
*Deep cuts in the Parks Department, including a delay in the opening of pools and lifeguard protection at beaches, both until July 4. The petting zoo section of the Central Park Zoo would be closed to save $140,000 over the next 18 months. In all 350 jobs would be cut, 200 through layoffs.
*The replacement of 6,000 burned-out street lights would be delayed; many traffic agents would write tickets rather than direct traffic; parking meters charges would rise, and the Staten Island Ferry would be raised from 50 cents to $1, under the plan.
*A delay in the expansion of the bridge maintenance program.
The plan called for up to $600 million in tax increases, including $300 million in property-tax increases -- or $60 a year -- with the balance made up through an increase in the personal income tax rate.
Carol O'Cleireacain, the city's finance commissioner, said that when combined with other increases and changes in property-tax rules -- including a pending $25 increase to pay for Mr. Dinkins's pending anti-crime package, taxes would go up $263 a year for the typical homeowner.
City officials said the nature of the cuts was similiar to recent reductions in many private companies, focusing on middle-level managers at the headquarters of city agencies in order to reduce cuts in the field.
It was clear that the administration was able to spare some agencies the worst of the pain.
The city's Human Resources Administration, for example, was required to make $88 million in cuts in the next fiscal year, but was spared $40 million of that, when the agency argued it could obtain increased Federal aid. Of $72 million in cuts at the city's Health and Hospital Corporation, $42 million was to be offset by revenue increases produced by the hospitals from patients and insurers.
Given Mr. Dinkins's decision to spare some agencies the worst of the cuts, some city officials were startled at the huge cuts sought from the Board of Education, which, under the city's worst case scenario, would mean eliminating more than 7,000 jobs in the next year.
But City Hall aides said that the $429 million cut represented a fair measure of political bluster, as part of a campaign to wrench as much school aid as possible from the State Legislature.
School officials had been bracing for a $245 million cut, a figure that assumed a $184 million increase in state aid, mainly an increase to cover the cost of inflation. But late last week, city officials decided to take it out of the budget, because of the state's uncertain fiscal situation, and then raised the amount of the cuts.
Stanley Litow, deputy chancellor for operations, called the higher level of cuts "distressing," but he said that he expected the Legislature to increase education aid because of political pressure from school districts around the state.
The financial plan to be released tomorrow will outline how the city expects to close a $500 million gap in the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, as well as the $2.1 billion in the next fiscal year.
The teacher negotiations, which took place at City Hall and the midtown headquarters of the United Federation of Teachers, mean that an initial plan for a payless furlough that would shut school for three days in February has been given a secondary status for now.

HEADLINE: Tax Value Off For Property In New York

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
In a report that provides the first government confirmation that New York City's real-estate market has tumbled sharply, the City Finance Department estimated yesterday that the taxable value of all property in the city fell by 7 percent in the last year.
The decline -- the first in a decade -- reflected market forces that real-estate professionals have noted for many months. The economic retrenchment, combined with the building boom of the 1980's, has produced widespread vacancies in office buildings, a steep drop in the price of apartments and houses and even a reduction of apartment rents in many neighborhoods.
 
Based on Assessors' Estimates
 The Finance Department, in releasing its annual assessment report, tentatively set the taxable value of all property at $85 billion, compared with $91.5 billion last year. The figure is based on city assessors' estimates of the value of each of the 938,004 properties in the city. Each property is supposed to be reassessed every year. 
 In many ways, the city report understates the severity of the decline in many parts of the real-estate market. The city's estimate of a property's taxable value -- its assessment -- is limited by state laws and generally does not reflect full market values. The assessments on some properties, including apartment and office buildings, are about 45 percent of market value.
Assessments on one-, two- and three-family houses are limited to about 8 percent of their market value. State law limits any rise in assessments on such houses to a maximum of 6 percent a year.
As a result, during the real-estate surge of the last decade, a huge gap arose between market values and assessments on such houses. Thus, a drop in their assessments may mask a much sharper decline in market value.
Prices on Manhattan cooperative and condominium apartments -- perhaps the most overheated segment of New York City's market during the 1980's -- have fallen as much as 25 to 50 percent in the last three years, said Clark P. Halstead, managing partner of the Halstead Property Company, a major Manhattan brokerage concern. In recent months other brokers have put the price decline at 20 to 30 percent.
"The last six months," Mr. Halstead said, "have been a kind of free fall."
By law, though, the city's assessments on co-op and condo buildings have no relation to market values of individual apartments. The assessments must be computed as if the cooperative or condominium were a rental building, with its value based on the building's potential rental income. "I'm not sure we can take any particular guidance from assessed values," Mr. Halstead said. "It's an abstraction."
On commercial properties and most apartment buildings, the city phases in assessment increases over five years. As a result, even though the overall assessments declined, the billable assessments -- the basis of the actual tax bills, which includes the phase-in of previous increases -- actually went up. The Finance Department set the billable assessment total at $79 billion, $3 billion more than last year.
Owners have about two months to appeal the tentative assessments. Deadlines vary with the type of property.
Assessed values of about 80 percent of the apartment buildings and commercial properties fell or stayed the same, said Martha E. Stark, a special assistant for property-tax reform to Finance Commissioner Carol O'Cleireacain. But the assessed value of two-thirds of the one-, two- and three-family houses rose. That is because of the large gap between market values and assessments for such property.
The state limit on assessment increases for houses led to many being assessed in recent years at 4 or 5 percent of market value. So while the market value of a house may have declined in the last year, its assessment could still increase without breaching the 8 percent level.
The typical single-family homeowner is paying a property-tax bill of $1,356 during the current city fiscal year, which began last July. Based on the new tentative assessments, the typical homeowner would pay a property-tax bill of $1,577 during the next fiscal year, Ms. Stark said.
The increase reflects both the rise in assessments for one-, two- and three-family houses and technical adjustments in the share of the property-tax burden paid for each category of property. It also includes a projected rise of $400 million in property taxes. The city's tax rate is now $9.84 for each $100 in assessed value for houses. If property taxes are raised by a total of more than $400 million, the cost to the typical homeowner would be about $20 more for every additional $100 million.
Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, a trade group, said he was particularly pleased that the decreases were most pronounced for commercial property and apartment buildings, which he said had long borne an unfair tax burden. "I think this indicates the Finance Department is on top of the market values and it demonstrates that they are moving in the right direction," he said.

HEADLINE: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: WASHINGTON;
White House Sticks to Its Subdued Reaction to Baltic Crackdown

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Moving cautiously in response to the Soviet military action in Lithuania, Bush Administration officials said today that the White House was reluctant to take stringent economic or political measures against Moscow.
Instead, officials said the Administration was weighing some mild punitive actions, like temporarily suspending technical exchanges. 
 The officials' comments were an indication that despite pressure from some members of Congress and Baltic-American groups, the Administration was loath to take any actions that would disrupt the coalition arrayed against Iraq or undermine the relationship between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, said that "we don't really know at this point" exactly what role Mr. Gorbachev played in the Soviet Army action in Vilnius in which 14 people were killed. Mr. Gorbachev said today in Moscow that he found out about the assault only after it happened, but he did not disavow the action or say it was unjustified. His comments left unclear whether he had approved a crackdown that led to the violent events of Sunday.
Mr. Fitzwater said the United States Ambassador to Moscow, Jack Matlock, had received high-level assurances from the Kremlin that Mr. Gorbachev continues to seek a peaceful solution to the Baltic crisis.
Mr. Bush and his advisers were focused on the Kuwait crisis today, but they also devoted some time to analyzing the events in the Soviet Union.
Administration officials said they did not want to do anything to disturb the balance in the coalition arrayed against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, but the officials were also worried about the angry reaction of many Americans, in Congress and elsewhere, who accused the Bush Administration of selling out Lithuania.
"It would be a sad irony if the price of Soviet support for freeing Kuwait was American acquiescence in Soviet aggression against another illegally annexed country," Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, said on the NBC program "Today" this morning.
At a briefing for Congressional leaders this afternoon, some lawmakers told Mr. Bush that if the Administration did not go far enough in punishing Moscow, they might try to push through legislation that would prohibit export credits to the Soviet Union.
 
Aid Being Abused, Dole Says
 The Senate minority leader, Robert Dole of Kansas, called on the United States to suspend all remaining agricultural export credits for the Soviets because of the events in Lithuania.
"I believe that unless Gorbachev puts an immediate end to the threats, blackmail and aggression, the United States should not deal with him in a business-as-usual manner," Mr. Dole said in a statement.
Mr. Dole said that the Prime Minister of the Soviet republic of Moldavia told him last week that the 15 republics would receive food aid from the central Government only if they signed a union treaty with Moscow.
"Gorbachev is trying to use our grain credits," Mr. Dole said, "to blackmail Moldavia, the Baltic republics and any other republic that doesn't agree to sign the union treaty. Gorbachev has offered the people of these republics two options: sign or starve."
 
Warning by Kennedy
 Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts warned Mr. Gorbachev that Soviet actions could "lead to a cutoff of the substantial assistance we are now providing."
Mr. Fitzwater said in his White House briefing today that the Soviet Union has already tapped $800 million of the $1 billion in emergency food credits extended to them by the United States last month.
Mr. Fitzwater suggested that if the relationship between the superpowers sours, economic sanctions might be imposed because "the only real tools we have are the economic opportunities that have been granted as a result of that improving relationship."
The spokesman also said that the Soviet-American summit meeting planned for next month may be cancelled, because of the turmoil in the Middle East and in the Baltics.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: THE U.N.;
France and 3 Arab States Issue an Appeal to Hussein

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 14

 BODY:
France and three Arab countries issued 11th-hour appeals tonight urging President Saddam Hussein to announce Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait before midnight Tuesday to avoid a war with the United States and its allies.
France's Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, was considering a visit to Baghdad on Tuesday for further discussions if the Iraqi leadership shows any interest in the proposal being presented in Iraq by Arab leaders, diplomats say. 
 In return for such a commitment to withdraw, they want the United Nations Security Council to promise Iraq it will not be attacked and to mount a new drive to resolve the dispute over Palestine between Israel and its Arab neighbors.
But American and other Western diplomats were pessimistic about the chances of resolving the crisis peacefully on the basis of the 11th-hour proposals.
"We are taking an intransigent Saddam Hussein and giving him more and more, shaving away the proposals of the Security Council," Thomas R. Pickering, the United States representative, told reporters tonight. Mr. Pickering said he did not expect the Security Council to back the French plan. "We do not believe it is an appropriate time or appropriate circumstances for such a statement," he said.
 
Accord on Plan Unlikely
 This hostile American stance appeared to rule out any chance of the Security Council agreeing to the French plan tonight. This is because France wants Zaire, which currently holds the council's rotating presidency, to make the offer in the form a statement.
But such a move would require the support of all 15 council members, giving the United States an effective veto.
The French initiative and a similar one put forth jointly by Algeria, Yemen and Libya came the evening before the deadline of midnight Tuesday, New York time, when under the terms of a United Nations resolution, the United States and its allies are authorized to attack Iraq if it continues to occupy and claim Kuwait.
The last-ditch initiatives followed on the heels of an unsuccessful peace mission to Baghdad by United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar who returned here today after failing to secure any concessions from the Iraqi leader.
Arriving back in New York this morning, the Secretary General told reporters that his meeting with Mr. Hussein had been "polite but, unfortunately, unsuccessful."
 
Secretary General Snubbed
 "No, he didn't express any desire to withdraw from Kuwait," the Secretary General added. "I have not been offered anything from the Iraqi authorities which I consider a step towards peace."
Officials say the Iraqis deliberately snubbed the Secretary General during his brief visit to Baghdad, keeping him waiting for more than six hours while President Hussein met with groups of parliamentarians and peace campaigners.
Diplomats said tonight that the the Iraqi President had asked the Secretary General to make proposals for a settlement, but Mr. Perez de Cuellar declined, saying he was bound by the decisions of the Security Council.
The six-point French initiative, which was circulated here, called for a meeting of the Security Council to issue "a last appeal" to the Iraqi leader to agree to surrender Kuwait before the United Nations deadline, announce a timetable for completing the withdrawal and begin "a rapid and massive retreat."
Under the proposal the Council would tell Baghdad that the United Nations is ready to send in a military peacekeeping force to verify the withdrawal and maintain order. It would also offer Iraq guarantees that the countries with forces in the gulf would not attack.
Iraq would then be offered a chance to negotiate a peaceful settlement of its differences with Kuwait. And the Council would finally say that it was ready to make "an active contribution" to a settlement of the Palestinian issue by convening "at the appropriate moment" an international conference to assure "the security, stability and development of this region of the world."
 
Arab Plan Similar
 The six-point Arab plan, put forward by Yemen, Algeria and Libya, closely resembles the French proposal. It also called for Iraq to agree to give up Kuwait in return for a promise that it would not be attacked, for the removal of economic sanctions and for a Security Council committment to resolve the Palestinian issue.
A Yemeni delegation, including the country's Prime Minister, Foreign Minister and the president of its Parliament, was in Baghdad today pressing the proposal along with the the Prime Minister of Libya. The President and Foreign Minister of Algeria are expected there shortly to add their voices to the appeal.
Meanwhile, diplomats here say Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has told allied leaders during his current visit to Canada that he is dissappointed with the failure of the Secretary General's mission, which he had hoped might show Iraq to be more flexible than it had been during his negotiations with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Geneva last week.
The diplomats also said Mr. Baker told allied leaders that he believes Saddam Hussein has what he described as a "Nasser complex."
Mr. Baker was said to mean that the Iraqi leader may be planning to let the United States and its allies start an aerial bombardment of his forces before he sues for peace in a manner reminiscent of what the late Egyptian leader, Gamal Abdel Nasser, did during the war with Israel in 1967. When Nasser encountered defeat and offered to resign, he succeeded in generating great waves of popular enthusiasm for his leadership among the Arab masses.

HEADLINE: New Surveys Of the Universe Confound Theorists

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
ASTRONOMERS' increasing power of observation is exposing awkward weaknesses in cosmology's cherished theories and imposing ever-narrowing limits on the imaginations of scientists engaged in the audacious vocation of figuring out the origin, evolution and ultimate fate of the universe.
Recent surveys of the heavens by telescopes and spacecraft have astonished scientists with the discovery of enormous conglomerations of galaxies that cannot be accounted for in current theory. Such large structures, and associated voids, imply gravitational forces from unseen matter that must represent at least 90 percent of the mass in the universe. 
 The nature of this hidden mass is the most confounding problem in cosmology, astrophysicists say, perhaps in all of physical science. And one of the favorite explanations, which posits the existence of invisible exotic particles known as cold dark matter, has just suffered a serious setback from an analysis of infrared galactic observations reported this month.
Until scientists can determine the nature and amount of the cosmic mass, they will not be able to resolve the issue of whether there is enough material for gravitational forces to keep the universe expanding but at a decreasing rate. Too much mass, and the universe would contract and collapse on itself. Too little, and it expands forever virtually to a vanishing point.
"These are confused times," said Dr. P. J. E. Peebles, an astrophysicist at Princeton University.
Dr. Margaret J. Geller of the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics said: "Something fundamental is missing in our models. "We clearly do not know how to make large structure in the context of the Big Bang."
But nothing has been learned, cosmologists insist, to question the foundation on which they seek to erect their theoretical edifices. For the last 25 years, nearly all astrophysicists have agreed that the universe -- time and space, everything -- began in an explosive instant, the Big Bang, and it has been expanding in all directions ever since.
"The basic Big Bang model has withstood the test of observations and experiments amazingly well," said Dr. David N. Schramm, an astrophysicist at the University of Chicago. "Just because you can't understand the physics of predicting tornadoes or earthquakes, you don't question the assumption of the round earth."
Indeed, new findings by astronomy and particle physics have strengthened scientists' faith in the Big Bang cosmology. Powerful accelerators have recently produced elementary particles of a kind predicted to have been created by the Big Bang. An American spacecraft, the Cosmic Background Explorer, or COBE, has found the temperature (a cool 2.7 degrees above absolute zero) and other properties of the background microwave radiation in the universe, the presumed afterglow of the Big Bang, to accord precisely with theory.
At a meeting of the American Astronomical Society yesterday in Philadelphia, Dr. John C. Mather, the chief COBE scientist, said: "We have confirmed the Big Bang theory very well. But the theory is sufficiently broad in possibilities to allow for many variations that are still open to question."
 
From Smooth to Lumpy
 The faint radiation pervading the cosmos was discovered in 1965, and it is considered the best evidence that the universe began with an explosion. But some of the same new observations seem to undermine concepts of what has happened in the 10 billion to 20 billion years since the Big Bang.
In its measurements last year, the COBE spacecraft failed to find any local variations in the radiation's intensity. Nowhere could the craft's infrared detectors see any point brighter than its surroundings by even one part in 25,000. The early universe was an incredibly smooth and homogeneous mix of energy and matter, as would be expected after the Big Bang.
Cosmologists are thus at a loss to understand how a smooth universe evolved to its present clumpy texture. They have recognized and grappled with this question for more than a decade, but never more so than in the last couple years. Technological advances, including electronic devices improving the light-collecting efficiency of telescopes, have enabled astronomers to see more of the universe's shape and dynamics.
"This is the first age in which we can really map the universe," Dr. Geller said.
 One surprise has followed another. Not only is the universe composed of billions of galaxies of stars but by clusters of galaxies and superclusters linked together gravitationally in patterns like the "great wall" observed two years ago. Its discoverers, Dr. Geller and Dr. John P. Huchra, estimate the wall stretches across the heavens for more than half a billion light-years.
In between dense galactic structures Dr. Thomas J. Broadhurst of the University of London found gaping voids of comparable magnitude. Other astronomers have reported that the Milky Way and neighboring galaxies seem to be falling toward some enormous but unseen mass, known as the "great attractor."
Cosmology's turmoil is compounded by other observations of extremely distant quasars, sources of intense radiation assumed to be at the cores of galaxies. More than two dozen quasars have been detected out toward the edge of the universe, hence close to the beginning of time. If these distances are confirmed, it means that stars were clustering in galaxies much earlier than had been thought possible in Big Bang theory.
 
Hunt for Missing Mass
 All of which lends urgency to the search for the hidden mass that is supposed to hold together the universe and create its galactic tapestry.
Scientists began in earnest to invent solutions to the missing mass a decade ago. That was when Dr. Alan Guth, now a physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, proposed the inflation theory that has become a widely accepted elaboration of Big Bang cosmology. A rapid expansion of the universe at the moment of creation could explain the initially smooth conditions and even the "seeds" for galaxy formation.
The inflation theory predicted that the universe should contain 100 times the matter visible in stars; otherwise it is difficult to explain its expansion rate and why it was not, in effect, stillborn. Some of the missing mass can be inferred from the observed gravitational effects on the dynamics of galaxies. But, according to studies of light elements produced in the Big Bang, no more than 10 percent of the mass should be ordinary matter like that in stars and planets.
 Some 90 percent of the assumed mass is thus believed to be made of something scientists cannot see or imagine. The leading candidate has been cold dark matter, which is theorized to be an assortment of exotic and as yet undetected tiny particles that are considered "cold" because they move relatively slowly and "dark" because they do not absorb or radiate light. Physicists sometimes call them WIMP's, for weakly interacting, yet massive particles.
Though no one has detected such particles, cold dark matter won strong support because it successfully accounted for structure on the scale of galaxies and clusters of galaxies. But it ran into trouble with the discovery of the "great wall" and other structures that seemed to be five times larger than anything possible with cold dark matter.
In an analysis of surveys by the Infrared Astronomical Satellite, British and Canadian scientists wrote this month in the journal Nature, "There is more structure on large scales than is predicted by the standard cold dark matter theory of galaxy formation."
 
Conclusions Called Remarkable
 Dr. David Lindley, associate editor of the journal, commented that the conclusions were "all the more remarkable for coming from a group of authors that includes some of the theory's longtime supporters."
Two of the authors were Dr. Carlos Frenk of the University of Durham in England and Dr. George Efstathiou of the University of Oxford. They and Dr. Marc Davis of the University of California at Berkeley and Dr. Simon D. M. White of the University of Arizona performed the computer simulations that established cold dark matter as a plausible explanation of galaxy formation.
Dr. Frenk said in an interview that the Nature editors misrepresented the report's conclusions. He said three of the four basic elements of the theory were unaffected by the findings. "It must be emphasized," Dr. Frenk said, "that the discrepancy between the standard model and the new data, although highly significant, is relatively small."
But other astrophysicists, who had already become skeptical, said the cold dark matter theory was in serious trouble because of the universe's observed large structure. "It's not dead, but it's on the ropes," Dr. Schramm said.
So it is back to the drawing boards for theoreticians, either to revive cold dark matter in modified form or re-examine alternative proposals -- or think of something entirely new. Any number of alternative concepts -- cosmic strings or texture, stellar explosions, even hot dark matter -- have been examined in the past to explain how galaxies were formed. All have been found wanting, but not entirely discarded.
Dr. Peebles said new attention would be directed toward "hot matter," higher-energy particles that could account for the dark matter. Experiments by Soviet and American scientists last year determined that some forms of tiny invisible particles called neutrinos do have some slight mass. This could revive interest in neutrinos as dark-matter candidates.
In recent months, scientists have expressed interest in the discarded Einstein concept of the cosmological constant. This suggests that empty space, though a vacuum, possesses an energy density creating an outward pressure on space counteracting the inward pull of gravity. Dr. Efstathiou proposed last month that the energy densities of the cosmological constant could explain how large-scale structures were formed within the standard cold dark matter model.
Despite the confusion over dark matter, theorists came away from a symposium last month at Brighton, England, excited and encouraged by new observations of galactic velocities and volumes that they think yield evidence seeming to confirm one important part of Big Bang cosmology. "Observers are beginning to see that omega is creeping up, approaching unity," Dr. Schramm said.
Translated, that means that measurements of the average density of the universe are getting closer to the critical density, which has been estimated to be at present about six hydrogen atoms per cubic meter. If the actual average density is found to equal this critical density, a state referred to as omega one, it would indicate that the universe is poised precisely between an endless expansion and an ultimate collapse.
"This is an even more interesting result than all the clumping," Dr. Frenk said. "This tells us the future of the universe. And critical density, in the mind of most cosmologists, means dark matter, in all likelihood cold dark matter."
Other astrophysicists are not so sure about either the new density measurements or the reality of cold dark matter. They are worried, as Dr. Geller said, that all their models are "vaguely unsatisfying" and in need of constant repair and renovation to accord with new observations.
Looking at the bright side, cosmologists say they welcome the new observations because they put their work on a more scientific footing.
 
Collapse of Ptolemy's Theory
 But more than one scientist, pondering the ferment of observational surprises and repeated revisions of theories, has been reminded of Ptolemy's epicycles. The theory of an Earth-centered universe survived more than 1,000 years, but only fashioning circles within circles of planetary motions in reponse to awkward observations. Finally, it fell of its own complexity and in the 16th-century was replaced by the simpler and more accurate Copernican theory.
The thought makes cosmologists uncomfortable. For all the problems in trying to understand what the universe is made of and what holds it together, they emphasize that it does not follow that the Big Bang theory is in danger of collapsing.
So far, Dr. Geller said, interpretations of cosmic structure on the basis of current mapping of the heavens are far from definitive -- more like trying to picture the whole world from a survey of Rhode Island. "Someday," she said, "we may find that we haven't been putting the pieces together in the right way, and when we do, it will seem so obvious that we'll wonder why we hadn't thought of it much sooner."

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 726 words

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: NEXT STEP IN THE GULF - IT'S ALMOST MIDNIGHT;
Restraint, Mr. Bush

BYLINE: By Daniel Patrick Moynihan; Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, is a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As we wait to see what will happen now in the Persian Gulf, it may be useful to record what was supposed to happen but did not. We were supposed to see the emergence of a "new world order" in the course of the first crisis of the post-cold-war era. For a period, it looked as if we might just; then, in an instant, we relapsed into the cold war mode.
The Iraqi invasion caught us unprepared as to the identity of friend and foe. We had been backing Iraq. A week before the invasion, the State Department stoutly opposed the Iraq International Law Compliance Act, as reported from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, cutting off agricultural subsidies until they stopped using poison gas. 
 By contrast, we had endured Kuwait, a none too pretty principality much given at international conferences to pronouncements concerning "the Zionist entity" receiving "economic, technological and political assistance from the United States." How then to respond to an invasion that threatened, among other things, Saudia Arabia.
We turned to international law, a code of conduct neutral as to the parties' prior posturings. In one news conference in August, President Bush used the term six times. We turned to the U.N. For the first time ever in such a situation, the permanent members were in accord.
Pursuant to Security Council resolutions, we dispatched forces to defend and to deter, and to uphold economic sanctions. Something very like a world police action commenced to take shape. Then, of a sudden, on Nov. 8 the body rejected the transplant. We lapsed back into the cold war mode of massive mililtary deployment.
War plans were drawn. The public was informed that intelligence findings -- necessarily secret -- pointed to the inevitabililty of hostilities. Terror alerts were sounded. The F.B.I. began checking on yet another ethnic group. At the turn of the year, the President would state on TV: "Standing up against this aggression -- no price is too heavy to pay for it."
This, of course, is the language John F. Kennedy used 30 years ago next Sunday, at the height of the cold war: "pay any price, bear any burden." Many thought the Soviet Union had opened a lead in ICBM's, the ultimate weapon of destruction. World Communism was at its apogee, its progress declared irreversible: the next and final stage of history.
How could such terms come to be applied to the depredations of a third world thug? Any price? A million Arab civilian casualities? Of course not. Some price, to be sure. But a proportionate price. Our share. Curiously, this is more a possibility now than any time since November. Thanks to last week's debate and Saturday's vote in Congress. And thanks also to that Soviet tank in Vilnius crushing a human before our eyes.
Saturday's vote authorizes the President to go to war. He asked for this authority and got it. For a moment, there he was asserting, in the cold war mode, that he didn't need it. The Constitution took something of a beating during the cold war. How could it not have in the course of 30 to 40 years in which Presidents knew they would have 10 minutes at most to decide whether to launch a thermonuclear second strike?
All right; that was then. Now a certain normality reappears. Which is to say a sense of proportion. Why should this not now phase over into a sense of proportion about what is at stake in the gulf? Important principles, yes. Ultimate issues, no. Nothing worth the war now being contemplated. Time is on our side. Were Mr. Bush to show, in Dwight Eisenhower's phrase, "the courage of patience" he could end up with Mr. Eisenhower's stature as a military strategist.
Just as importantly, we have got to pay attention to the breakup of the Soviet Union. And to the fact that through half a century of the cold war our vast intelligence system learned everything there was to know about the Soviet Union except that it was breaking up. We could be returning to the chaos of 1919 in that vast wretchedly governed, wretchedly unhappy land. The 75 year struggle against totalitarianism has reached its endgame, but the final outcome remains, of course, uncertain. This is a state that still possesses 10,000 nuclear warheads, and civil war inches closer by the day. That for certain is a war the world does not need -- which needs to be uppermost in our mind.

HEADLINE: Murder Trial Focusing On Battered-Wife Issue

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES

 BODY:
The facts are not in dispute: On the night of May 23, 1989, Sarah Smith, a 43-year-old social worker, shot her sleeping husband once in the head with a .25-caliber pistol that she had taken from his pocket.
She wrapped his hulking 6-foot-3-inch body in two blankets, hoisted it onto a dolly and wheeled it to a car, and put it in the trunk. She then drove to Yonkers and left his body in a schoolyard. A week later, she turned herself in to an officer she knew at her local police station, in the 40th Precinct in the South Bronx. 
 Twenty months later, Sarah Smith stands trial in State Supreme Court in the Bronx, in a case that has called up all the turbulent issues about battered women. Mrs. Smith, who supported her unemployed husband, Owen Smith, 31, throughout their seven-year marriage, describes him as an abusive alcoholic and cocaine addict who terrorized her and threatened to kill her the night of his death.
Mrs. Smith's lawyer is Michael G. Dowd, who has successfully defended other battered wives, including Karen Straw, a 29-year-old Queens woman who stabbed her estranged husband to death in 1987 during an argument, and was acquitted. The case gained national attention and was hailed by womens' rights groups as a victory for all abused wives, many of whom had been imprisoned for fighting back under similar circumstances.
 
Last Case Before Suspension
 For Mr. Dowd, who is donating his services, this is his last case before beginning a five-year suspension for making kickbacks on a contract to collect overdue fines for the New York City Parking Violations Bureau. He made the payments at the direction of the late Donald R. Manes, then the Queens Borough President. He is allowed to finish this trial, and said he expected it to last no more than two weeks.
"If I had to choose my last case, this would be it," Mr. Dowd said. "I can't think of a more worthwhile case."
Mr. Dowd calls his client the "classic profile of the battered woman." But unlike Mrs. Straw, Mrs. Smith neither called the police when her husband abused her nor asked the courts for an order of protection -- primarily, Mr. Dowd said, because she had read several news stories about women killed by their husbands after seeking such help. But the prosecution questions why she had not felt the same way about her first husband, whom she left after he had abused her.
 
Quietly Sobbing in Chair
 Mr. Smith, a Jamaican who was an illegal immigrant when he met his wife, was allowed to stay once they married. He was 11 years younger than Mrs. Smith and liked to go out at night and drink, smoke marijuana and use cocaine, said her lawyer. Mrs. Smith would stay home with her daughters. The older is now a 26-year-old nurse; the younger, now 20 and in college, is Mrs. Smith's foster daughter, whom she took in when the girl was 8 after finding out the child was being abused.
During opening arguments on Friday, Mrs. Smith sat in the defendant's chair, quietly sobbing as Mr. Dowd detailed threats and abuse during the last three years of the couple's seven-year marriage.
He told the jury that Mr. Smith began to change for the worse after he obtained his green card, or legalization papers, in 1986. Mr. Dowd said that Mr. Smith repeatedly raped her, refusing to let her see her two daughters under the threat of harming them. He choked her during arguments, the lawyer said, and called her office, a few blocks from their apartment, several times a day to check her whereabouts.
Mr. Dowd also said that during Mr. Smith's rages, he would point one of his several guns out the window or at the walls of the couple's apartment and shoot. Mr. Smith had been arrested five times on charges including selling and possessing drugs and assaulting an officer. Mr. Dowd added that Mr. Smith effectively threatened his wife by persuading her that he would escape prosecution for killing her, as he had for the other offenses.
He described Mrs. Smith as a striver who overcame years of abuse by her father and her first husband. For four years, Mrs. Smith studied at night for a degree from the College of New Rochelle while working full time at a welfare office. She graduated in 1982.
Mr. Dowd portrayed Mrs. Smith as a loving wife who had believed she could help her husband overcome his addictions and curb his violent episodes.
"But on the night of May, 23, 1989, around 10 P.M.," Mr. Dowd said, "Owen Smith told her that this would be the night he would kill her."
The prosecution, headed by Assistant District Attorney Elisa Koenderman, argued that as a bright woman with a college education, Mrs. Smith knew her options and chose the wrong one. Ms. Koenderman said that during their marriage, Mrs. Smith began to resent her husband more and more. The prosecutor said that if threatened, Mrs. Smith could have walked out the door instead of shooting her husband in the brain while he slept.
Mrs. Smith spent a month and a half in jail before being released on her own recognizance.
The District Attorney had offered to recommend a prison term of 4 to 12 years if she pleaded guilty to manslaughter. Now, if convicted of both second-degree murder and criminal weapon possession, she could face a minimum sentence of 15 years to life in prison.
On Friday, Ms. Koenderman called three witnesses, the man who found Mr. Smith's body and a police officer and a detective from the Yonkers Police Department who were later called to the scene. She also showed the jury two photographs of the body, and submitted in evidence the bloodied blankets Mrs. Smith wrapped Mr. Smith in.
The prosecution is to continue its case today.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 29, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 15 about the trial of Sarah Smith, a Bronx woman who killed her husband, misstated an element of her defense. Mrs. Smith contended that her husband was awake when she shot him; she did not accept the prosecution contention that he was asleep. The error was cited yesterday by a judge who overturned Mrs. Smith's murder conviction. An article about the case appears today on page B1.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Dataquest Losing Chief To Gartner, Its Rival

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Manny A. FernandezManny A. Fernandez, chief executive of Dataquest Inc., is leaving to become president and chief operating officer of the rival Gartner Group Inc., Gartner said yesterday. Both companies provide research on companies in the computer and other technological industries.
Mr. Fernandez, 44 years old, will join Gartner, based in Stamford, Conn., on Monday, said Gideon I. Gartner, 55, the founder and head of the research firm. Mr. Fernandez will also become chief executive April 1, the company said. Mr. Gartner said he would remain as chairman and, after April 1, would focus on strategy and the company's research processes. 
 Mr. Gartner founded the company 11 years ago after a career at the International Business Machines Corporation and as a technology analyst on Wall Street. His firm, which became known for the quality of its I.B.M.-watching, went public in 1986 and two years later was purchased by Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., the London-based advertising company, for $94 million, Mr. Gartner said.
But the marriage did not last. Saatchi, running into financial problems, began to divest itself of its consulting and research businesses. After early attempts to sell the company fell through, Mr. Gartner and a Boston-based investors group called Information Partners bought the company back in October.
Mr. Gartner said Saatchi had put the sale price at $63.5 million. "But that price had all sorts of adjustments," Mr. Gartner added. "In fact it was significantly lower." But he did not say by how much.
Dataquest, based in San Jose, Calif., is "twice as old as we are but we are growing a lot faster," Mr. Gartner said yesterday. "We are doing just under $100 million in revenue and they are in the low 60's," he added.
"I've been looking for a successor for a long time," Mr. Gartner said, adding that Saatchi had not allowed him to bring one in for cost reasons.
Mr. Fernandez said he was an old friend and competitor of Mr. Gartner. "This is an incredible opportunity," he said. Gartner "has all the excitement and potential of a small entrepreneurial company and at the same time is a company that is profitable and has a great franchise in the market," he added.
Mr. Fernandez headed Dataquest, which is a subsidiary of Dun & Bradstreet, for six and a half years. Earlier he was president and chief executive of the Gavilan Computer Corporation. At Dataquest, he will be succeeded by the company's chief operating officer, Glen Haney.

HEADLINE: Roger W. Tubby, 80, Publisher; Promoted the Adirondack Region

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Roger W. Tubby, a newspaperman and Government official who briefly served as press secretary to President Harry S. Truman in 1952, died yesterday at his home in Saranac Lake, N.Y. He was 80 years old.
He died of cancer, his family said. 
 For the last 35 years, with time out in the 1960's for service as press spokesman for the State Department and for an ambassadorial post in Geneva, Mr. Tubby had been a resident and indefatigable promoter of the Adirondack region of New York State.
In 1954, shortly after he became co-publisher of The Adirondack Daily Enterprise in Saranac Lake, he founded the Adirondack Park Association, now the 14-county Adirondack North Country Association. Until his death he remained a major advocate of economic aid for the region and preservation of its scenic and historic attractions.
His efforts were reflected in his chairmanship of the New York State Tourism Advisory Council from 1985 until his retirement in 1988.
 
Government Service in Wartime
 Mr. Tubby went to Washington in World War II as an information officer on foreign trade and became press officer in the State Department after the war. In 1950 he joined the White House press staff and was press secretary in the last three months of the Truman Presidency.
In 1961 he returned to the State Department as Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs. Later he spent seven years as United States representative to United Nations agencies in Geneva, holding the rank of ambassador, and three years as dean of academic relations at the Foreign Relations Institute in Washington.
His love of the Adirondacks absorbed most of his energies in later life. In September1988, shortly before Mr. Tubby stepped down as head of the Tourism Advisory Council, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo cited his "hands-on administration, good counsel and wisdom" as "a bulwark of the state's tourism industry for decades."
 
Native of Connecticut
 A native of Greenwich, Conn., and a graduate of Choate School and Yale University, Mr. Tubby did postgraduate study at the London School of Economics. His first newspaper job was reporting for The Bennington Banner in Vermont in 1938. Two years later he became the paper's managing editor.
In 1942 he began his Government service on the staff of the Board of Economic Warfare in Washington. He moved to the Foreign Economic Administration as director of information in 1944 and later held a similar post in the Commerce Department's Office of International Trade.
From 1945 to 1949 Mr. Tubby was press officer for the State Department, and in 1950 he was named assistant press secretary at the White House. He moved up to acting press secretary in the fall of 1952 and to the post of chief spokesman that December.
 
Stevenson Aide in 1956
 In 1956 he was an aide to Adlai E. Stevenson in Mr. Stevenson's unsuccessful campaign for President against Dwight D. Eisenhower. By that time he had bought, with James Loeb Jr., The Adirondack Daily Enterprise. He was active in its management until 1970 and remained a columnist until his final illness.
In 1974 he ran unsuccessfully for the House of Representatives as a Democrat. The next year he was appointed New York State's Deputy Commissioner of Parks and Recreation in charge of operations and planning, a post he held for two years.
He is survived by his wife, the former Anne Williams ; his mother, Frances Olitsky of Greenwich, Conn.; three daughters, Suzanne Batra of Greenbelt, Md., Jean Prentiss Sherwood of Rockville, Md., and Brenda Chandler of Portland, Me.; a son, Peter, of Adamstown, Md.; a sister, Ruth Rubinstein of London and nine grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Sir Robert Jackson Is Dead at 79; A Former Major Official at U.N.

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Sir Robert Jackson, a former Under Secretary General of the United Nations, died of a stroke on Saturday morning in the apartment of his son in London, the United Nations Secretariat said yesterday. He was 79 years old.
Sir Robert, an Australian, lived in Manhattan and was visiting his son, Robert Jr., at the time of his death. He was knighted in 1956 and named a Knight Commander of the Royal Victorian Order in 1962. 
 An international administrator and consultant, Sir Robert served the United Nations -- and the Governments of Australia, India, Pakistan and other countries -- in many capacities over the years. As an Under Secretary from 1972 until his retirement in 1987, he was one of the highest officials in the United Nations system.
He was particularly known for his work in relief and humanitarian activities in Bangladesh, Cambodia and elsewhere and in economic development in more than 60 developing countries. He was also the guiding spirit of a 1970 document, called the Jackson report, that led to changes in the United Nations system of providing economic aid to developing countries.
 
Called a Founding Father
 Luis Maria Gomez, an Argentinian who is the Associate Administrator of the United Nations Development Program, said yesterday that Sir Robert "was one of the founding fathers of the U.N. system and a profound reformer of its technical operations mechanism."
Another former Under Secretary General, Sir Brian Urquhart, a Briton, wrote in his memoirs, published in 1987, that Sir Robert's "capacity to work at full pressure, taking into account a large variety of economic, political, logistical, financial and natural factors and making them into a coherent operational plan, was a marvelous thing to see."
Sir Robert oversaw reconstruction efforts for the United Nations in the early 1970's in Bangladesh after the Pakistani civil war. These efforts included putting the inland transportation system back into operation.
His main collaborator on the Jackson report -- an 18-month team effort -- was Margaret Joan Anstee, who was then an employee of the United Nations Development Program and is now herself an Under Secretary General.
 
Major Innovations
 Sarah Timpson, a member of the program's Senior Policy Group, said yesterday that the report had led to such majr innovations as a system for fostering "consensus between the northern, donor nations and the southern, recipient nations, which has been the basis for the U.N.D.P.'s way of operating ever since."
Robert Gillman Allen Jackson was born Nov. 8, 1911, in Melbourne, Australia. He entered the Australian Navy in 1929 and switched to Britain's Royal Navy in 1937. During World War II he served largely in staff posts, in Malta and elsewhere, and then returned to civilian life.
From 1945 to 1947 he was Senior Deputy Director General of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration and oversaw activities of that agency in Europe and other places where World War II had caused destruction.
He held various British and Australian honors in addition to his knighthoods.
In 1950 Sir Robert was married to Barbara Ward, the British economist and author who in 1976 was made a life peer with the title of Baroness Jackson of Lodsworth. They were separated at the time of her death in 1981.
He is survived by his son, a grandson and a granddaughter.
Burial is to be Jan. 21 in London. Arrangements for a memorial service in Manhattan are being made by officials of the United Nations Development Program.

HEADLINE: Gift to Barnard Honors Iphigene Sulzberger

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
The late Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger, central figure in the family that has published The New York Times since 1896, was honored yesterday with a $5 million contribution from her family to her alma mater, Barnard College.
Barnard's president, Ellen V. Futter, announced that Centennial Hall, the college's newest dormitory, would be renamed for Mrs. Sulzberger, who died last February at the age of 97. 
 "Barnard College is the institution to which our mother was most devoted throughout her life," said her son, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the publisher of The Times. "It speaks to her concerns for education, for New York City and for women. We are delighted to honor our mother by making this gift to the college that she loved."
His sisters, Marian S. Heiskell, Ruth S. Holmberg and Dr. Judith P. Sulzberger, joined him in the donation to the Campaign for Barnard, a $100 million capital fund campaign that will go toward retaining and recruiting faculty, improving the physical structures on the campus and raising financial aid.
 
Over the Halfway Mark
 The first phase of the campaign, which will end in 1994, seeks to raise $60 million. The $5 million contribution from Mrs. Sulzberger's family puts it over the halfway mark less than one year after the campaign began.
Mrs. Sulzberger graduated in 1914 from Barnard, where she studied economics and American and modern European history. She was the daughter of Adolph S. Ochs, who acquired The Times in 1896. Her husband, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, was the publisher of The Times from 1935 to 1961.
While at Barnard, she was attracted to journalism as a career and in her senior year took a course at the School of Journalism at Columbia University. Although her father decided that a newspaper office was no place for women, Mrs. Sulzberger played a critical though unobtrusive role in shaping The Times throughout the century.
"Mrs. Sulzberger has a special place in Barnard's history and in our hearts," Ms. Futter said. "For over three-quarters of a century, Iphigene Sulzberger was unwavering in her dedication to the college."
Mrs. Sulzberger was on Barnard's board from 1937 to 1968, when she became a trustee emeritus. She spearheaded the effort to raise funds for a library at the college, the Adele Lehman Hall-Wollman Library, which cost $2.15 million and was dedicated in 1960.
The 17-story, 400-bed dormitory to be renamed for Mrs. Sulzberger, which was designed by James Stewart Polshek & Partners, has received several architectural awards, including the New York State Association for Architects-American Institute of Architects Award for Design Excellence and the New York City Chapter of the American Institute of Architects Award for Distinguished Architecture.
The dormitory, on the campus between 116th and 117th Streets, facing Broadway, was completed two years ago. It is the first to be built by the college in 20 years and will transform Barnard into a fully residential college for the first time in its history.
"We are now able to offer a room to every student if they want it," said a Barnard spokeswoman, Gail Zarr. "People living on campus have different needs and give the campus a different social flavor."

HEADLINE: India's Violence Damaging Tourist Industry

BYLINE: By SANJOY HAZARIKA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Political uncertainity and thousands of deaths in sectarian and caste violence last year have led to widespread tourist cancellations and jeopardized plans by the Indian Government, which has billed 1991 as "Visit India Year," to generate funds from tourism.
The designation of India as an unsafe destination by Western countries, including the United States and Japan, has also led to a drop in visitors. 
 "The tourism and travel industry in India is facing the worst crisis in the last 30 years," said O. P. Ahuja, president of the Indian Association of Tour Operators. Based on initial figures from officials and tour organizers, Mr. Ahuja said tourist arrivals were "tending to slide to minus growth" rather than the increase of about 9 percent over 1989 that had been projected.
The problem is aggravated by what is widely seen as a lack of planning and policy. The new Minister for Tourism is Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal, who is 75 and has rarely traveled abroad. Mr. Lal is a strong supporter of rural life and at one point had proclaimed his opposition to luxury hotels. His views on ways to develop tourism are not known.Mr. Lal recently created ripples of concern and amusement when he announced that farmers wearing turbans and dhotis -- or the long pieces of cloth that are wrapped around the legs in India -- will be entitled to a 50 percent discount when they stay at Government-run luxury hotels. "Eighty percent of India's population is rural and they are afraid of entering a five-star hotel," Mr. Lal said in an interview with The Sunday Times of India. "I want to change this."
Ghulam Naqsbandh, a vice president of Sita Travels, a leading tour organizer, said: "In most countries, if you were planning for a 'Visit Year,' you'dplan and upgrade your facilities and work on it for years. Here we've had hardly one year and where are the new hotels, the better rooms, transport, connections that we need?"
Tour agencies, airline officials, government policy makers and others blamed political factors for the widespread tourist cancellations that followed. These included last year's political crisis that led to the collapse of the minority Government of V. P. Singh and its replacement by another minority Government led by Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar. Also cited were the extremist violence that engulfed Kashmir, one of the most popular travel destinations in South Asia, and the Hindu-Muslim riots in Agra, site of the Taj Mahal, which shut the city down for several days.
Official figures show no growth inlast year's tourist arrivals over those for 1989. According to these statistics, about 1.3 million tourists visited India in 1990. But hotel executives and tour operators said they were faced with major cancellations after August when riots began in Northern India over reservations in jobs for backward Hindu castes.
Sectarian rioting fueled by a dispute over a mosque that Hindus say is a Hindu shrine has damaged towns, villages and cities in a nearly 1,000-mile belt stretching from the popular northwestern state of Rajasthan, famed for its ethnic fairs and fabrics, palaces and forts, maharajahs as hoteliers and gracious hosts, to the backward state of Bihar in the east.
The countries that have notified their nationals that India is unsafe because of the violence -- the worst since thepartition riots of 1947 that accompanied independence from Britain -- include the United States, Britain, France, Italy, Germany and Japan. In addition, because of an economic crunch, the Soviet Union has canceled all organized tours to India for the next 3 months, causing a further drop of about 25,000 visitors.
A gasoline crunch in October and November, followed by a Government decision to increase oil prices after the Persian Gulf crisis, led to the cancellation of many organized bus tours and a 25 percent rise in domestic air fares.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
No Accounting For Bad Banks

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WHICH banks should be counted as the walking dead, doomed to follow the Bank of New England into Federal receivership? Regulators are not telling -- and could not, even if they were so inclined. For the accounting methods currently used by banks, argues Lawrence White, an economist at New York University's business school, offer only the haziest clues to their net worth.
Mr. White should know: As one of three members of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, he watched with chagrin as the savings and loan cowboys ran out of excuses in the late 1980's and left Uncle Sam to pay the bill. His book, "The S & L Scandal," to be published next month by Oxford University Press, reflects on what went wrong and what could be done to prevent a repeat performance. 
 The key to successful bank regulation, Mr. White believes, is knowing what banks are really worth. Traditional accounting methods gave hundreds of bankrupt savings and loans the wiggle room to evade closure in the late 1980's. And without a change to so-called market-value accounting, he argues, even the cleverest schemes for keeping banks on the straight and narrow path are likely to go awry.
When a car is wrecked, the insurance company's liability is reduced by the amount of the deductible. When a bank is wrecked, the deposit insurance fund's liability is reduced by the amount of capital the bank stockholders leave on the table. That is one good reason why Washington sets minimum capital standards for banks -- and why, in theory, regulators ought to be able to figure out that banksare heading south long before depositors or the insurance fund are in danger of getting stiffed.
The catch is that the regulators are dependent on the numbers. And the calculation of a bank's legally defined net worth is more a ritual than a true accounting, one bearing about as much relationship to the real world as a performance of kabuki.
The price of a corporate bond listed on a public exchange fluctuates with interest rates and credit ratings; any investor who cares to know what his holding is worth need only call a broker. By contrast, the value of a home mortgage or a business loan on a bank's books is usually whatever the bank shelled out.
Such cost-based accounting may have provided all the information regulators needed when loan defaults were rare and banks were virtually assured a fat spread between the interest they paid on deposits and the interest they received on loans. But since the late 1960's, this cozy arrangement has failed, and with it the ability of regulators to bite before they are bitten.
Financial deregulation left banks vulnerable torising deposit rates. Meanwhile, increasing competition narrowed margins on blue-chip loans, driving banks into higher-risk assets, like i.o.u.'s backed by the full faith and credit of the Government of Zaire. And the go-go types who invaded the industry soon discovered that traditional accounting was an invitation to creativity: Losing assets could be carried at cost, while winners could be sold and the profits added to net worth.
Some reformers want to link deposit insurance premiums to the size of a bank's capital cushion; safe drivers pay less -- why not give a break to safe bankers? Others want to narrow the regulators' room for manuever, forcing them to close a failing bank before members of Congress can persuade them to forbear. But in Mr. White's view, no plan for reducing banks' incentive to take big risks or to spare taxpayers the consequences of bank errors can be any better than the accounting system on which it rests.
What is needed, he argues, is a system in which banks' assets and liabilities are "marked to market" every month or every quarter, much the way a mutual fund recomputes the total value of the stocks it owns at the end of each trading day. In fact, Mr. White would go further and add a "dynamic accounting" requirement: Banks would be asked to project the likely impact of changes in interest rates or exchange rates on their net worth.
Critics of market-based accounting say it probably cannot be done well because the values of some bank assets are elusive: Boston office buildings without tenants are, after all, a lot harder to appraise than shares of I.B.M. stock. And even if it could be done, they say, it should not be done: Rapid fluctuations in estimated net worth would spook both depositors and regulators.
Mr. White is not impressed. If accurate market-based assessments of net worth are not possible or desirable, he asks, why bother with inaccurate and often misleading assessments based on acquisition costs? Why, indeed?

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Jordan;
Seeing War Near, King Hussein Vows to Protect Jordan's Land and Sky

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 15

 BODY:
King Hussein of Jordan, evidently abandoning all hope for Western or Arab diplomacy in the Persian Gulf crisis, sought tonight to ready his people for embroilment in war and said the Middle East stood on the verge of imminent catastrophe.
"We are now hearing the drums of war, which are threatening all of us with the most dangerous consequences," he said in a television address to his nation of three million people. 
 "Our region is now on the verge of an abyss as the gulf crisis evolves into an imminent catastrophe," he said.
In what seemed a message to both Israel and Iraq, the King said that his armed forces -- outgunned by both of Jordan's militarily powerful neighbors -- would "protect the land and skies of our country and prevent anyone from crossing in one direction or the other."
Iraq has said it will attack Israel if the United States-dominated forces massed in the Persian Gulf and Saudi Arabia go on the offensive to reverse Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
 
Potentially Acute Problem
 The threat of conflict has confronted Jordan with a potentially acute problem since both Iraqi missiles or aircraft and Israeli warplanes would need to cross Jordanian airspace if the two opposed powers fought each other. Military specialists here say it is far from clear how Jordan would confront intrusions into its air space.
Since the eruption of the gulf crisis, King Hussein, traditionally pro-Western, has faced difficult choices. More than half of the population he rules is of Palestinian descent and has shown widespread support for Iraq. But by acknowledging Palestinian sentiments in his foreign policies, he has cut himself off from crucial sources of economic assistance from the gulf Arabs allied with Washington against Baghdad.
The Jordanian King has sought, thus, to promote what he terms an Arab solution to the crisis - a notion rejected by the United States. In a display of affinity with the Islamic sentiment that has deepened in his country since the start of the crisis, the King appeared on television tonight with a full-grown beard - generally taken in the Muslim world as a sign of piety.
As the leader of a land which, Western diplomats say, stands to lose much from the crisis, whatever its outcome, the King seemed somber and strained.
 
'The Ghost of War'
 "The doors of reason and negotiation have been shut, leaving the ghost of war hovering over the Arab people and the Arab nation," he said.
"We stand with a clear conscience since I have done all I possibly can do to achieve a political settlement to the gulf crisis," he said.
The 15-minute address sought to stress national unity, reflecting the King's concern that conflict in the Persian Gulf, spreading into a wider war, would strain the frail assemblage of Palestinians and Jordanians that forms his country.
Jordan, the King said, had placed its armed forces on the highest state of alert. According to diplomats, the army has deployed to defensive positions overlooking the Jordan Valley facing Israel.
 
Makes No Direct Appeal
 The King made no direct appeal to President Saddam Hussein or to President George Bush to soften their policies.
"If forced to fight, we will fight fiercely," he said. "Our banners will remain high. Our country will remain secure. Our land and our honor will not be touched while we live."
The address was apparently intended to solidify the support the King has gained both by permitting a degree of democracy in his domestic politics and by tilting toward Iraq in his foreign policy.
The speech was evidently designed, too, to bring home to many people the gravity of the crisis. "We are now in the highest state of preparedness to face any situation," the King said.

HEADLINE: Buenos Aires Journal;
Bluntly Put, Graft Is Rife: U.S. Envoy Speaks Out

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 15

 BODY:
The official corruption that is routine dinner-table talk in Argentina, but generally cannot be proved, has been thrust into banner headlines by a blunt accusation from the normally polite and circumspect American Ambassador.
In a letter made public last week, the Ambassador, Terence A. Todman, said Government officials had asked for "substantial payments" from Swift-Armour of Argentina to permit the company to import the machinery needed to build a $115 million meat processing plant. 
 Mr. Todman did not use the word bribe, but everyone knew that was what he was talking about.
President Carlos Saul Menem and his Government reacted with a mixture of anger and chagrin.
On the one hand, there were those who wondered privately why the puritanical gringos had to bring all of this out so directly instead of handling it quietly, in what is said to be the Japanese or European style.
 
Corruption 'Highly Developed'
 On the other hand, Foreign Minister Domingo Cavallo recognized in an interview published recently that corruption is "too highly developed in all of Argentine society." He said the Menem administration was committed to ending it in the Government but was hindered by unclear rules of the economic game, poor state organization, imprecise legislation and too much discretionary power in the hands of officials.
The Argentine press jumped on the story with gusto, first pointing the finger at one of the President's brothers-in-law, Emir Yoma, as the man who had withdrawn the Swift-Armour file from the Economy Ministry and was, therefore, in possession of the information necessary to offer to resolve the three-year-old request and demand a payment. Mr. Yoma denied the charge and threatened to sue for infamy.
Newspapers and magazines also began to focus on Mr. Menem's own flamboyant and expensive way of life and raised questions about the propriety of it.
The newspaper Pagina 12, which Mr. Menem accused of "journalistic delinquency" when it first broke the news of the Todman complaint, later reported that the red Ferrari 348 the President received in November as the gift of Italian businessmen friends was linked to ventures planned by those friends in Argentina, including four luxury hotels.
When the car was first noticed at the presidential palace in November the rumor went around that the President intended to donate it to a children's hospital, but when a television talk-show host asked Mr. Menem about that he denied such plans.
"It's mine, mine," he said. "They gave it to me. Why should I give it away?"
 
Envoy Not Usually Critical
 Ambassador Todman, a diplomat of long experience at high levels, including a stint as an Assistant Secretary of State, has normally been very supportive and optimistic toward the Menem administration in his year and a half in Argentina, particularly toward the effort to create a free-market economic system.
Even in background sessions with American journalists, he has seldom been critical of the Government, presenting an upbeat, protective attitude that differed from the style of his immediate predecessors and of American ambassadors in most other South American countries.
The fact that he went public with the reported bribe request to Swift-Armour and seven cases of reported bureaucratic roadblocks against American investments apparently reflected a growing frustration with the absence of response or action through other channels.
His letter to Economy Minister Erman Gonzalez, with "very urgent" written at the top, was dated Dec. 10, but no written response had yet been received when Pagina 12 carried the first report on it on Jan. 6.
A few days later, the Economy Minister issued a written response, which led the newspaper La Nacion to comment that Mr. Todman might have "a notion about time that is not very well understood here."
 
Good Relations With Embassy
 Pagina 12 never said how it obtained the original information on the complaint, which Mr. Todman later backed up with public statements. But despite its sometimes leftist tint, the irreverent tabloid is known to have good relations with the American Embassy staff, which appreciates the reputation for honesty and hard work of Pagina 12's reporters and the newspaper's tendency to back up its stories with lots of detail.
Swift-Armour's Argentine executives have been the most silent in the whole episode. After scheduling a news conference on Jan. 9, they canceled it and issued a statement saying their company had "not been the object of any Government pressure."
La Nacion characterized this as a decision "not to make waves." Mr. Gonzalez, the Economy Minister, said the Swift-Armour import request had, in fact, been approved, presumably after Mr. Todman's letter.
The other issues raised in Mr. Todman's letter -- involving a Ford subsidiary, Federal Express Corporation, Firestone, Goodyear and other companies -- did not allude specifically to bribes but generally complained of red tape and other hindrances.
Mr. Gonzalez, in his reply, denied any discrimination against American companies and said Mr. Todman's "legitimate interest" in supporting them "could lead to an indiscriminate belief in the reasonableness of all of the requests they make to the Argentine state."

A newspaper linked the gift to ventures planned in Argentina by those businessmen. (Photographs by Associated Press)
