HEADLINE: Loss of a Job Doesn't Keep Some From Aiding the Neediest

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
Linda Winston, an unemployed New York City teacher, has been contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund since her childhood, and her lack of a job this year was not going to change that.
In the midst of sending out resumes and looking into possible new careers, the 57-year-old reading and writing specialist, who has a doctorate in anthropology, sent $150 to the fund. 
 "If I had been working it would have been 10 times as large," she said in an interview yesterday. "I had decided that I was going to give even before The Times started running stories about the Neediest."
 
First Contribution Recalled
 Ms. Winston said that she had lived in Greenwich, Conn., for the last 20 years and that anyone who visited the city often could see how much worse things had become. She conceded that the times were trying for her right now, but said she would pull through.
"I just remember how thrilling my first contribution was years ago," she said. "It felt like being part of family -- it was as though I had sent a check to my grandfather to give money to poor people in the neighborhood. It's still very important to me."
The 79th annual appeal for the Neediest Cases opened in November and runs through February. The New York Times pays for the campaign's overhead, and the proceeds are distributed to seven charities to help the sick and the poor. More than 11,000 people and organizations have already contributed to this year's drive.
Many contributors mention their concerns about the recession, and some talk about how it has had a personal impact on their lives. Many contributions are accompanied by notes that mention salary cuts, layoffs and closed businesses.
 
Hurting but Grateful
 "Though one of the two of us is unemployed, we are neither homeless, hungry or loveless, and wish to contribute," wrote Betsy Lampl of Riverdale, the Bronx. She enclosed a check for $25.
Laura and William Ortiz of Mount Vernon, N.Y., wrote that they were having a "lean Christmas" this year because one of them was unemployed. But they considered themselves fortunate for having health, youth and confidence, and sent $15 to the fund in a "spirit of hope so that others may be benefited."
Another donor, Toby Spitz, has seen the income from her business, an executive recruiting concern, drop by 50 percent in the last two years, but she increased her donation $50 from last year. She gave $200 to the fund.
Mrs. Spitz said in an interview yesterday that she considered her circumstances quite good, compared with some of the lawyers for whom her company is trying to find work.
"Some of these people were earning salaries of more than $100,000," she said. "They'll eventually find a job, but it's still a very sudden change in circumstances and they've taken a very large dive."

HEADLINE: Recession Forces Sharp School Cuts

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Squeezed by the tough financial times, the Gloria Floyd Elementary School in Dade County, Fla., has enlisted parents' help in a way it had never before done. The school asked them to contribute toilet paper, tissues and paper towels.
"Every little thing helps," said Andrea Rosenblatt, the principal. The school had already cut $50,000 from its budget this school year as part of districtwide reductions, keeping Ms. Rosenblatt from filling a vacancy for a kindergarten teacher. 
 As the recession has deepened, so have the fiscal worries for the nation's largest urban school systems. Projected tax revenue from a variety of sources is falling short of expectations. From New York to Houston to Los Angeles, schools are slashing already lean budgets and administrative staffs.
Others are trimming activities like music, art and athletics, scuttling overdue renovations or building programs and leaving teaching positions unfilled. In the worst cases, teachers have been cut. In Boston, 300 to 350 teachers were not rehired at the start of the school year.
 
Philadelphia Turns Down Heat
 "It's been absolutely devastating," said Constance Clayton, the School Superintendent in Philadelphia, where the school district started the year with a $25 million deficit. In one cost-cutting measure, the temperature was turned down to 68 degrees from 76 degrees in some schools, she said, a move that is expected to save about $3 million in the school year.
The recession has affected all schools, whether they are private or public, suburban or urban. But the largest urban systems have been hit more severely because of an array of costly programs for their disproportionately higher enrollments of poor, minority and immigrant children. Often such programs are required by the Federal or state government, which may provide some of the financing.
School systems have also been bedeviled by higher fuel and heating costs as a result of the Persian Gulf crisis, as well as the timing of the recession. By striking in midyear, the recession has put schools in the difficult spot of cutting services and programs while they are in operation.
"The problem is, these are not well-financed systems in the best of times," said Michael Casserly, assistant director of the Council of Great City Schools, an association of the nation's 47 largest school systems. "When they run into financial problems, they are having to cut well into the bone."
 
More Stability in Midwest
 Amid the financial calamity are some pockets of equilibrium. Chicago schools, for example, have not been forced to make any budget cuts this year. A spokeswoman said the Midwestern economy had not declined as sharply as the economies on both coasts, and added that Chicago schools were already operating in an austere fiscal environment.
In other places, the stepped-up support of businesses and parent groups has helped with a variety of assistance programs, including money, supplies, services and even personnel. In Los Angeles, parents have been recruited by some schools to serve as volunteer teacher aides.
But even these efforts cannot ease the fiscal stresses on the largest school systems. New York City's system, the nation's largest with 948,000 students, has had to trim $160 million from its $6.5 billion budget this year and is now looking at ways to cut another $90 million.
 
Administrative Cuts First
 Previous cuts have centered in the central office bureaucracy, where the 4,040-person staff will have been reduced to 3,600 by the end of the school year, said Jim Vlasto, a spokesman for the school board.
But the current $90 million in cuts ordered by the city, which finances the school system, has been hotly debated. Unless agreements on furloughs or delayed wage increases are reached with the school system's unions, the layoff of 4,000 teachers is likely, school officials say. Another consideration is the reduction of a $4.3 billion school construction and renovation program by 20 percent.
The situation is similarly grim in Dade County, which includes Miami and is the nation's fourth largest school system with 295,000 students. To offset declining state aid, the Dade County school system cut $16.7 million from its $1.6 billion budget last fall, and this winter it trimmed another $3.6 million.
The cuts were achieved by forcing schools to return part of their allocations from the district, inducing school personnel to take early retirement, instituting a hiring freeze and banning overtime.
"This has been the tightest budget crunch that I have had to face in the 12 years that I have been a principal," said Bonnie Wheatley, principal of the Pinecrest Elementary School, who expects to run out of copier paper and trash bags before the end of the school year. "I'm on a bare-bones budget this year."
 
Moving to Keep Teachers
 To keep her teaching staff intact, Mrs. Wheatley asked her Parent-Teacher Association to donate more proceeds from its fund-raising efforts. Revenue from a school supplies store run by the P.T.A., which had been used to buy teaching aids like computer programs, is now going into a special fund for recession emergencies.
"We are very anxious that she keep the academic staff intact," said Bobette Reeder, the Pinecrest P.T.A. president. "Our parents will do anything to keep that from happening."
With the combination of parental support and the consolidation or cuts of non-education personnel, districts have protected most classrooms and educational programs from budget cuts so far. In Philadelphia, administrators reduced their $25 million deficit by about 50 percent at midyear by cutting their administrative staff through attrition and consolidation.
But the longer the economic recession lasts -- and there is widespread disagreement in forecasting the slump's severity and duration -- the more likely it is that classrooms and teachers will be affected.
Philadelphia is already projecting a deficit of $22 million to $25 million for next year's school budget. "We'll make every effort to achieve non-direct classroom cuts," said Irvin Davis, managing director of the Philadelphia system, but he added, "I can't say today that I can accomplish that."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Biggest Quarterly Loss Is Expected at UAL

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 15

 BODY:
The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines and one of the nation's strongest carriers, said today that it expected to post the largest quarterly operating loss in its history.
UAL's chairman, Stephen M. Wolf, projected the loss in a letter to employees last week. He called the 1991 outlook "even more troubling," a company spokeswoman said. 
 UAL's 1990 fourth-quarter and year-end results are to be reported on Jan. 31.
UAL's largest previous loss was of $192 million in the second quarter of 1985. Analysts said that on an operating basis, the carrier is likely to lose $200 million to $250 million in the fourth quarter of 1990.
By informing employees of the expected loss, UAL is "trying to set the stage that times are tough," Paul Karos, an analyst at the First Boston Corporation, said. "It's going to get tough for everyone," he added.
Like other air carriers, United has been suffering from reduced traffic because of the weak economy while paying sharply higher fuel prices because of the conflict in the Persian Gulf.
Analysts have been predicting fourth-quarter losses for nearly all United States carriers except the Southwest Airlines Company and perhaps Alaska Air Group Inc. The fourth quarter is traditionally one of the industry's weakest because there is little vacation travel.
Over all, the industry is expected to lose an additional $1 billion in the first quarter of 1991, after a $2 billion hemorrhage for all of 1990. The 1990 red ink was more than twice as much as the industry had ever lost previously.
Despite the dismal fourth-quarter expectations, analysts said UAL would be profitable for 1990 as a whole, earning about $3 a share. UAL earned about $15 a share for all of 1989. UAL's stock slipped 75 cents today, to $113.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Thanks to a strong balance sheet and lucrative Pacific routes, United should weather 1991 better than other carriers, analysts said. They attributed that comparative strength mostly to the UAL's Pacific routes, which were augmented recently by the inauguration of a Chicago-Tokyo route. UAL said today that Japan has granted it the right to operate the new route until March 2. Last week, a cargo carrier dispute over slots at Narita Airport in Tokyo threatened to stall the flights.
But labor problems linger at United. Negotiations on the pilots' international agreement with the airline broke off Saturday without a resolution. Arbitration is scheduled to begin on Jan. 21.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals End Lower In Light, Uncertain Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metals prices moved in a narrow range yesterday before settling lower in light trading on New York's Commodity Exchange.
The market moved back and forth, said Peter Cardillo of Jesup, Josephthal & Company, on word of peace initiatives by the French and calls by Britain and the Soviet Union for a final appeal to the Iraqis to withdraw. 
 "The market is now in a wait-and-see attitude," Mr. Cardillo said.
Gold was $1.30 to $3.60 lower, with the active February contract down $1.40, to $400.20 an ounce; the January contract fell back below $400, to $398.80, off $1.30 from Monday's close.
Silver was 3.4 cents to 3.5 cents lower, with March at $4.222 an ounce.
Copper prices plunged on the Comex as threatened strikes in South America failed to occur, Mr. Cardillo said.
Also hurting copper was the faltering economy, particularly declining sales of new cars and a drop in new housing construction.
Copper was 1.50 cents to 3.75 cents lower, with January at $1.0865 a pound.
Frozen concentrated orange juice futures continued to rally following the release on Friday of the United States Agriculture Department's crop report. The department drastically reduced its estimate of the size of the California and Florida orange crops.
An analyst said expectations of a smaller Brazilian crop had given the market additional strength.
Frozen concentrated orange juice was 3.85 cents to 4.90 cents higher, with January at $1.250 a pound.
Grain and soybean futures were mostly higher in light trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.
"The funds had no choice but to trade," said William Biedermann, an analyst with Allendale Inc. in Chicago. "The general public was off to the side. They did not want to be involved at this time" in the market.
Soybean futures received help on ideas that they could serve as a hedge against the inflation that would result if war broke out, Mr. Biedermann said.
Wheat was 1/2 cent to 2 1/2 cents lower, with March at $2.46 1/4 a bushel; corn was 1 1/4 cents to 2 cents higher, with March at $2.34 3/4 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1 1/4 cents higher, with March at $1.12 1/2 a bushel; soybeans were 4 1/4 cents to 8 1/2 cents higher, with January at $5.56 1/2 a bushel.
Livestock futures were mixed and pork futures higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
Live cattle were 0.40 cent lower to 0.05 cent higher, with February at 75.30 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.45 cent lower to 0.05 cent higher, with January at 87.22 cents a pound; hogs were 0.15 cent to 0.48 cent higher, with February at 51.10 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 0.85 cent to 1.18 cents higher, with February at 69.25 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Steady in a Slow Day As Traders Await Deadline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed in quiet trading yesterday as traders sat on the sidelines before the midnight war deadline, limiting their reactions to the most dramatic of Persian Gulf developments.
Currency traders shed their traditional hopes for a strengthening dollar in the nervous quiet that descended on markets. Several participants said they would prefer to see the dollar open lower today if it meant war had not broken out. 
 "Basically, people are afraid to take positions ahead of signs of war," said Thomas Palladino, currency trader for Oesterreichische Landerbank in New York. "There could be a big swing one way or the other."
Analysts said the one Middle East event that seemed to nudge the dollar higher was the failure of France's last-minute initiative to prevent war in the gulf. "There is a fatal moment where one must act," Prime Minister Michel Rocard told French lawmakers. "This moment has, alas, arrived -- after we have done everything to avoid it."
Traders said the dollar was slightly undermined by hopes that a last-minute diplomatic initiative was secretly taking place. The dollar, like gold, is considered a safe-harbor investment and generally increases in value during international turmoil.
Traders said they brushed aside several Persian Gulf developments that had they occurred last week might have prompted marked dollar swings. For example, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, told reporters that a decision on starting an attack against Iraq was likely to come "sooner rather than later" after the midnight deadline. "That usually would make people buy," Mr. Palladino said.
 
Mark Strengthened
 But analysts said news that the German central bank would hold a meeting tomorrow strengthened the mark because of heightened prospects of higher German interest rates.
The dollar fell slightly against the mark in New York, closing at 1.5420 marks compared with late Monday's 1.5457.
"Clearly, the economic fundamentals are weighing against the dollar, but the background of war is superseding anything," said Ronald Holzer, chief dealer for the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.9045 yesterday from $1.9050 late Monday. In New York, sterling fetched $1.9095, up from late Monday's $1.9035.
Tokyo markets were closed for a national holiday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 135.85 yen, while in New York it bought 135.73 yen, more than Monday's 135.15.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, were: 1.2845 Swiss francs, up from 1.2823; 5.2420 French francs, up from 5.2390; 1,160.00 Italian lire, down from 1,161.25, and 1.1471 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1487.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Notes and Bonds Decline in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The looming reality of war enveloped the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped after a report this afternoon that France had abandoned all hope that a peaceful resolution to the Persian Gulf crisis could be reached before midnight.
A new French peace initiative had been mentioned on Monday and again yesterday morning. However, at around 2:30 yesterday afternoon news service reports informed market participants that those efforts had been abandoned. That caused bond prices to dip by about 3/8 point. 
 The move into Treasury bills, meanwhile, continued yesterday, as interest rates on the short-term securities fell further.
Trading remained extremely light, as the United Nation's midnight deadline approached for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait.
"You can't do anything in a situation like this," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S.G. Warburg & Company. "You aren't talking about dealing with risk here; you are talking about absolute uncertainty."
 
Retail Sales Report
 Traders basically ignored a report showing that retail sales fell four-tenths of a percentage point in December, another number that confirmed the economy was very weak in the fourth quarter.
Reports expected today on industrial production and consumer prices will probably be summarily dismissed, traders and analysts said.
"As an economist, I will be interested to see the industrial production figures," said Nancy Kimelman, chief economist at Technical Data in Boston. "But this is such a politically driven market that not many other people will pay much attention."
A government bond trader said that "all we are doing is waiting," adding, "We are held hostage to the political situation, and there is nothing you can do about it."
Yesterday morning President Bush met for 30 minutes with his top economic advisers, including Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, to discuss what might happen in the economy in the event of war.
"They could have been discussing what would be least disruptive for the financial markets," the bond trader said.
Mr. Liro and others said the markets would be up to the challenge of an outbreak in hostilities.
"We are looking for a lot less reaction to the beginning of war than what happened in October of 1987," Mr. Liro said. "They were fast markets back then, but that is what you are here for. I would think the bond market is up to the task of maintaining an orderly situation."
 
30-Year Bond Offering

By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 103 7/8, down 11/32, to yield 8.39 percent, compared to 8.35 percent late Monday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102, down 6/32, to yield 8.19 percent. And the 7 1/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 7/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 7.12 percent.
Demand continued strong in the short-term market, however.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.05 percent, down six basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by five basis points, to a late offered rate of 6.14 percent.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the City of Los Angeles Department of Water and Power offered $150 million worth of securities at competitive bid.
A bid from an investor group led by Merrill Lynch & Company won the issue, which consists of serial bonds maturing from 1997 to 2011 and a term bond that matures in 2031.
The serial bonds were reoffered at yields from 6 percent in 1997 to 7 percent in 2011. The term bond was reoffered at a price to yield 7.23 percent.
The securities are rated AA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for municipal bonds, traders said prices of most widely quoted issues dipped by 1/8 point to 1/4 point.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues were unchanged in very light trading.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Changes at Home;
Amid the Grief and Worry, Life Will Go On as Before

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Beyond casualty lists and the concern and disquietude that war inevitably brings, what would an outbreak of fighting in the Persian Gulf mean for the day-to-day routine of Americans on the home front?
While Government and business officials do not minimize the impact of war on the nation's psyche, they say that unless fighting in the gulf drags on for several months, most Americans will encounter little or no disruption. 
 During the first hours of conflict, the officials say, there may be a brief surge in demand for petroleum by concerned drivers and homeowners, some telephone lines may be jammed beyond capacity by panicky callers, unease could disrupt financial markets and delays could be long as airports step up anti-terrorist efforts.
But barring a war that drags on for months, which many military experts consider unlikely, there is little expectation that the home front will experience the kind of massive disruptions that occurred during World War II, or for that matter the considerably lesser disruptions of the Korean and Vietnam Wars.
 
Military Draft and Rationing
 "Things have gone very smoothly so far and we expect them to continue that way if all goes as planned," said Larry Wilson, a spokesman for the Defense Logistics Agency, the supply procurement arm of the Defense Department and a major player in the gulf buildup.
Government officials say they do not foresee a gulf conflict that would require resumption of the draft to replace fallen troops or to expand the armed forces, now made up entirely of volunteers. They also say no consideration is being given to rationing or price controls because war stockpiles are plentiful and there is enough flexibility in the country's industrial base to meet replenishment demands.
Since World War I, rationing and price controls have been major factors on the home front only in World War II. There were some economic restrictions during the Korean and Vietnam wars, but they had far less impact on the home front, especially during the Vietnam era, when the military buildup occurred gradually over a long period.
The military buildup in the gulf is the most rapid dispatch of a massive armed force this country, or any other country, has ever undertaken.
"And it's been done with almost no disruption anywhere on the civilian front," said Mr. Wilson. "We had a lot of stuff stockpiled that requires a long time to acquire from manufacturers and the country's economy has easily absorbed the demands we have otherwise been forced to make upon it. We don't foresee any shortages down the road unless something happens we haven't anticipated."
Should military shortages begin to occur, the Defense Department has the authority, under a Presidential order, to demand that manufacturers and other businesses meet military needs first and forgo filling contracts in the civilian sector. That power has not been exercised thus far in the Gulf crisis.
As for manpower, Federal officials say they could resume the draft, which ended in 1973, on a few days' notice because all men 18 years old and older are required by law to be registered with the Selective Service. But they say they expect no such notice, because they do not foresee losses of a magnitude that would create a need for involuntary inductions.
"We haven't even gotten an exploratory phone call from anybody at the Pentagon," said Lew Brodsky, an assistant director of the Selective Service. "More to the point, we haven't heard from anybody in Congress, and that's where approval would have to come from to resume any callups."
At the White House, officials say no thought has been given to imposing rationing or price controls.
 
Seeing No Need for Concern
 "Nobody around here thinks there is any need to think about such things at this point," said one economic specialist in the Bush Administration. "The only possible shortage might be oil, mainly if people panic and start stockpiling, and, anyway, if a real crunch comes we can always fall back on the strategic reserve we've stored away. Otherwise there's plenty of everything and enough slack in the economy to quickly replace whatever we use up. If you don't have shortages, you don't have rationing or price controls."
When the Pentagon decided to speed the flow of food to troops in the gulf by purchasing some standard brand supermarket items, among them microwaveable meals, manufacturers responded immediately by by stepping up production, averting shortages among civilians.
"We just put on an extra shift of people to get the job done," said Allan Krejci, an official for the Hormel Company, a major food processor. "If they want more, we'll provide it. There's plenty of production capacity."
Similarly, the nation's major airlines have been able to supply the Pentagon with all the wide-body planes it needs to ferry troops to the gulf. Officials say a few domestic flights have been canceled or delayed as a result, but they insist that enough planes have been available, and will be available in the future, to answer passenger demands, not only on the home front but also on the war front.

HEADLINE: California Housing Dip

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 15

 BODY:
Consumer fears about the recession and a scarcity of financing for developers helped to push new housing construction in California in November to its lowest level in eight years, an industry group reported today.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
500 at Wang Face Layoffs

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOWELL, Mass., Jan. 15

 BODY:
In the latest item of bad news for New England's high-technology industry, Wang Laboratories Inc., said yesterday that it would be laying off 500 workers in the next three weeks.
 Richard W. Miller, Wang's president and chief executive, informed employees of the layoffs in a memo. He said that despite significant progress in fixing internal business affairs "to the point of achieving a modest profit in the Sept. 30 fiscal quarter" and the repayment of a $575 million bank group debt, "severe new external challenges have emerged in the form of an economic recession and threats to world peace."
 Since June 30, 1989, Wang has laid off more than 10,000 workers and now has a worldwide employee total of 19,000. Under Mr. Miller, the company has concentrated on cutting costs and on the emerging area of image processing. It reported a profit in the first quarter of the 1991 fiscal year. Second-quarter results are due out next week.
A Wang spokeswoman said that the cost of the layoffs would be charged against income in the third quarter.
 Wang's class B shares were unchanged today at $2.375 on the American Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Panel Is Asked to Punish 3 Senators

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Declaring to the Senate Ethics Committee that the "political heart and soul of this country" was at stake, the panel's special counsel made an impassioned case today that three Senators should be punished for their dealings with the savings and loan executive Charles H. Keating Jr.
In his closing arguments at the longest public hearings into the conduct of members of Congress, the counsel, Robert S. Bennett, portrayed Senators Alan Cranston and Dennis DeConcini as crass politicians who had done favors for Mr. Keating's savings and loan association because he was a big contributor to their political efforts. 
And several times he bluntly suggested that Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. had perjured himself before the committee, which he characterized as the lawmaker's most striking impropriety.
Mr. Bennett depicted the two other Senators in the case, John McCain and John Glenn, as admirably breaking off their ties with Mr. Keating when it became clear that his own conduct was in doubt.
The counsel had been instructed by the panel to set out no conclusions about how the members should act. But he left no doubt that he believed Senators Cranston, DeConcini and Riegle should be punished and that Senators McCain and Glenn should be cleared.
 
Options for the Committee
 Besides clearing any of the lawmakers, the panel could vote to send them letters of reprimand criticizing their behavior. Or it could take the more serious step of recommending that the full Senate vote to condemn the Senators' actions. It could also advise the Senate to expel any of the members, but that is considered the least likely outcome.
On the eve of a possible war in the Persian Gulf, Mr. Bennett appealed to the committee not to lose sight of the case's significance. "We're talking about ethics when our nation could be at war, literally, in a matter of hours," he declared late this afternoon.
Reciting the possiblility of war, a recession and other troubles facing the nation, Mr. Bennett looked directly at members of the panel and said: "In comparison to these crises, some may say that ethics is unimportant. But I say to you: To accept this conclusion would be a terrible mistake, because with an economy in trouble and war hanging over our heads, it is all the more important that the American people have confidence in you and your ability to judge your peers and reach an honorable and definite decision."
Peppering his summation with highlights of 25 days of testimony, Mr. Bennett outlined his case that three Senators violated clear standards of conduct in intervening with Federal regulators on behalf of Mr. Keating. Mr. Bennett rejected earlier arguments from the five Senators that they had violated no specific rules because there were none that addressed such actions as contacting Federal regulators on behalf of Mr. Keating's failing Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif.
 
Keating Facing Charges
 The counsel argued, for instance, that Senator McCain, an Arizona Republican, and Senator Glenn, an Ohio Democrat, followed appropriate standards in knowing when to cut off contacts. "Mr. Keating called Mr. McCain a wimp," Mr. Bennett said, because he did not follow "the Keating agenda to get the bank board off his back."
Lincoln was seized by the Federal Government in 1989 at a loss of more than $2 billion to taxpayers. Mr. Keating is facing fraud charges in California. He or his associates had donated a total of $1.3 million to the five Senators or their causes.
Since the hearing's opening on Nov. 15, the five Senators or their lawyers repeatedly argued that they were treating Mr. Keating as they would have any other constituent, and they denied they were rewarding him for his contributions.
Closing arguments for the five Senators are scheduled before the committee on Wednesday. Then the panel of three Republicans and three Democrats will deliberate in closed session, possibly for several days, on the fate of their peers.
Mr. Glenn was the only of the five Senators who sat in the cavernous Senate Hart Office Building's hearing room to hear Mr. Bennett, and he stayed mostly to hear the summation of his involvment.
In a calm, measured voice, Mr. Bennett offered example after example of how the Senators acted behind the scenes to help Mr. Keating. He said the case of Mr. Cranston, a California Democrat, stood out because of the striking relationship between donations from Mr. Keating and efforts by the Senator to help him.
 
Contributions and Requests
 "This pattern of coupling large contributions from Mr. Keating with requests for action was repeated on four occasions," Mr. Bennett said. Even after he learned that the regulators were recommending that the Justice Department investigate Lincoln for criminal misconduct, the counsel asserted, Mr. Cranston personally contacted Federal regulators at least 12 times on behalf of Lincoln.
Mr. Bennett said that Mr. DeConcini, an Arizona Democrat, also pressed regulators to help Lincoln long after he was told of the criminal referral. He described how Mr. DeConcini took a leading role in advocating Lincoln's case in two meetings between the Senators and Federal regulators in April 1987.
The counsel suggested that Mr. DeConcini "ignored all the red flags" in continuing to help Lincoln.
And in his most pointed comments about Mr. Riegle, a Michigan Democrat, Mr. Bennett strongly suggested that the lawmaker perjured himself before the committee more than once. He cited other witnesses who contradicted Mr. Riegle's testimony that he had no role in arranging the first meeting with regulators, and who also disputed his contention that meetings with Mr. Keating during a trip to Phoenix had anything to do with raising money.
"If you were to determine that Senator Riegle was not honest with you, was intentionally not honest with you," he told the committee, "then I think this committee has to act on that." Mr. Bennett made clear that he was as troubled with the Senator's performance before the committee as he was with his dealings with Mr. Keating.
 
Facing Responsibility
 While he told committee members that he knew of the pressures they faced in judging their fellow Senators, he implored them to step up to their responsibility.
"A case like this breaks the rhythm of the Senate," he said. "You're really uncomfortable with this, as you should be."
Still, Mr. Bennett reminded the lawmakers: "You are holding in your collective hands the heart, the political heart and soul of this country. And whatever decision you make, this institution is going to be stronger or weaker."
Urging them to think about the American public, not just their fellow Senators, Mr. Bennett said: "These are your friends, you know each others families, you legislate with each other, you need each other, you raise funds for each other, you help each other in their campaigns." He went on to remind them that after they act, "The American people are going to either have more or less respect for this institution."
 
Bitter Exchange Between Lawyers
 As evidence of what may lie ahead as the committee deliberates, Mr. Bennett earlier today engaged in a bitter, personal exchange with James Hamilton, Mr. DeConcini's lawyer. Mr. Hamilton sought to introduce affidavits from two former United States Attorneys who questioned whether Mr. Bennett was acting too much like a prosecutor.
The committee voted not to accept the documents, saying they were not germane to the case. Once that happened, Mr. Hamilton told the panel, "If this matter goes to the floor, Mr. Bennett's conduct is going to be an issue."
Mr. Bennett angrily shot back that "the not-so-subtle threat to this committee is an outrage." He told committee members: "You should be offended by it. Senator DeConcini is simply trying to burn the messenger, to discredit me, and it will not work. I will not be intimidated by such obvious tactics."
Senator Jesse Helms, a North Carlina Republican, and one of the panel members defended Mr. Bennett, said to Mr. Hamilton: "Special counsel Bennett will not be a villain in this piece. If you want to take it to the floor and you can, we'll see you on the floor of the United States Senate."

HEADLINE: New Boom Hits Suburbs: Evictions and Foreclosures

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Evictions for nonpayment of rent and mortgage foreclosures are increasing rapidly in New Jersey, Connecticut and New York. More middle-class tenants and homeowners, pressed by rising unemployment and large mortgages, are joining low- and moderate-income families for whom finding affordable shelter has long been a struggle.
The largest increases have been in New Jersey, which had the biggest housing boom in the 1980's in the New York metropolitan region. Economists say that even during the recession years a decade ago, building permits were being issued at a rate 25 percent above the national average. This, they say, led to overselling to some underqualified buyers, who are now unable to make their payments. 
 Sue McElroy, a state field worker in affluent Bergen County who counsels families worried about becoming homeless, sees a new population at risk. "I had my first two Ph.D.'s the other day," she said. "These are people who never expected to be in this position, and they're reticent about seeking help from government," she said. The number of eviction actions filed in New Jersey last year was 163,994, a 25.8 percent increase from 130,383 in 1986, according to the Administrative Office of the Courts. Mortgage foreclosures more than doubled in two years, reaching 17,715 last year, up from 11,816 in 1989 and 8,812 in 1988.
 
Even in Bedroom Communities
 Some of the biggest percentage increases in landlord-tenant disputes over the last five years have occurred in affluent bedroom counties like Monmouth, with a 42 percent increase, and Bergen, with 31 percent.
While the large urban counties still have the largest number of eviction cases, the rates of increase in court activity are smaller. Essex has had a 24 percent increase; Hudson, 14 percent, and Camden, 11 percent.
In Bergen County, where housing costs are 8 to 10 percent higher than in the rest of the state, Ms. McElroy said some potential clients were living in $1,200-a-month apartments that they could no longer afford because one or more family members had lost a job or were earning less money.
"We try to find them an apartment for $700 to $800, but we also recommend they immediately seek financial counseling," said Ms. McElroy, who works for the state's Homelessness Prevention Program. "They have to realize they can no longer afford that $300-a-month car payment, dinners out in restaurants or that Visa card.
"It is this downturn in their life style that causes the most distress, the most emotional upset and the greatest anxiety. They just can't believe it."
Eviction notices went to 8,132 tenants in Bergen last year, compared with 6,278 in 1988 and 6,228 in 1986. Foreclosures rose to 772 in 1989, compared with 518 the year before.
Through the first nine months of 1990 the foreclosure rate in New Jersey stood at 1.11 percent of the outstanding mortgages in the state, compared with 0.80 percent in 1989, according to the American Bankers Association.
In Connecticut the 1990 rate was 0.71 percent, compared with 0.27 in 1989, and in New York it was 0.69 percent, compared with 0.54 the previous year.
The only Northeastern state with a higher rate was Pennsylvania, with a rate of 1.21 percent for the first nine months of 1990.
 
'Traced Back to the Good Times'
 "That's really quite high," Rae D. Rosen, vice president of the Federal Home Loan Bank, said of the New Jersey figures.
"It can probably be traced back to the good times in the mid-1980's when employment was high and more women were entering the work force," she said. "Couples bought homes and were fully mortgaged up to their two-income level. When one of them lost a job they were unable to make the payments."
Myron Weinstein, chief of the Office of Foreclosure for the New Jersey courts, said, "Even in the recession years of 1981 and '82 the volume of mortgage foreclosures was half of what it is now, and at that time the mortgage rate on loans was 18 percent."
Interest rates are lower today, but because of the soaring cost of housing in the middle 1980's, monthly mortgage payments for new buyers are often far larger than a decade ago.
 
Harder to Find Buyers
 Ms. Rosen said another problem was the adjustable-rate mortgages popular in the mid-1980's, which allowed buyers to qualify for mortgages with artifically low first-year payments. When rates rose the next year, many families were already fully extended.
Families trying to sell a house they can no longer afford are also running into a tight lending market for buyers. If potential buyers have trouble getting mortgages, families in trouble have a harder time selling and staving off foreclosure.
Homes lost through foreclosure are offered through sheriffs' sales in the 21 counties. In Monmouth County where sales are scheduled every Monday, the Sheriff's office sold 258 homes in 1990, compared with 117 the year before.
Lately, however, the sales have been producing little revenue. "There aren't any bidders," said Sheriff William M. Lanzaro. "People used to make a living buying homes at sheriff's sales and re-selling them, but banks have stopped lending money, so everyone's scared and nobody's taking a chance."
 
Holding On in Monmouth
 With its shore resorts and farmland, Monmouth became one of the fastest-growing counties in New Jersey starting in the late 1950's. People who moved in during the height of the 1980's boom are finding it difficult to hold on to their homes and life styles.
There were 1,005 mortgage foreclosures in Monmouth in 1989, up from 533 in 1988. The number of eviction actions in 1990 was 7,899, compared with 6,755 in 1988 and 5,566 in 1986.
Dorothy Hartman, the liaison between the courts and the Monmouth County Board of Social Services, said, "My desk is a good indication of the state's economy." Mrs. Hartman's telephone number is on every eviction notice, and when her workload piles up the economy is in trouble, she said.
On Fridays, Mrs. Hartman and her assistant, Sally Waters, each wearing yellow outfits, walk the hall outside the landlord-tenant court in Freehold. "We're known as the Ladies in Yellow," she said. "It's an easy way for the tenants to spot us."
 
Deals in the Corridor
 During the time Judge Lawrence M. Lawson gives tenants and landlords to try to settle their disputes in the corridor, Mrs. Hartman and Mrs. Waters go to work. They identify tenants who may be eligible for public assistance, food stamps or rent subsidies. They try to make deals. Often a landlord agrees to an extension, even if only for a few days, to let Mrs. Hartman try to find some money for the tenant.
On a recent day, she was able to help Theresa Clark, a 21-year-old mother of two small children, who takes home $828 a month from her job in a bank's credit department and pays $525 for an apartment in Asbury Park. "I had to buy some things for the kids and couldn't make the rent payment," she said. Mrs. Hartman found that she was eligible for $1,000 in food stamps.
"The landlord was good," Mrs. Hartman said. "He agreed to accept a voucher for the back rent."
While Ms. Clark was helped, James Sheridan of Middletown, a 34-year-old father of five, was not. Mr. Sheridan, who received a medical discharge from the Navy, lost his job as a movie theater manager in October.
The loss of income added such stress to his marriage, he said, that he and his wife have separated. In December he could not meet his $1,000 rent. Because of a legal dispute over his marital problems, Mr. Sheridan said he could not receive any public assistance.
"I don't want my family out on the street, even though I'm no longer living there," he said.

HEADLINE: Bergen's Budget Plan Calls for 317 Layoffs

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 15

 BODY:
Bergen County's newly elected Executive, William Schuber, today proposed a $338.3 million budget that calls for dismissal of 317 of the county's 5,175 workers and a half-cent increase in the county property-tax rate.
The budget represents a 3.9 percent spending increase, the smallest since Bergen adopted the executive style of government in 1986. Property-tax revenue would be $206.5 million, up from $195.6 million in 1990, Mr. Schuber said. He proposed a county tax rate of 24.3 cents per $100 of assessed valuation, up from 23.8 cents last year. 
 The layoffs come on top of a loss of 260 county jobs through attrition.
Other proposed economies included reduction of the county's car fleet, 15 percent cuts in county grants to nonprofit and community-based groups, and program trims in the Departments of Human Services, Health and Public Works. He also proposed raising $1 million by increasing fees by $4 at golf courses run by the county, charging admission for the first time at the county zoo and increasing tuition at a school for licensed practical nurses at the county's hospital, Bergen Pines.
At the same time, Mr. Schuber proposed a 30.3 percent spending increase, to $747,073, for his office.

HEADLINE: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: The Kremlin;
MOSCOW APPOINTS FOREIGN MINISTER

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, the Soviet Ambassador to the United States, succeeded Eduard A. Shevardnadze as Foreign Minister today and pledged to maintain good relations and cooperate with the West despite the crackdown in Lithuania.
Mr. Bessmertnykh, a 57-year-old career diplomat and longtime American expert who has spent much of his career in Washington, is well known to senior American officials and to President Bush. Mr. Bush has not yet said whether he would postpone a Feb. 11-13 summit meeting in Moscow with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev because of the crises in the Baltic republics and the Persian Gulf, but the Soviet side clearly wants it to go ahead. 
 By submitting his nomination to the standing Soviet legislature today, Mr. Gorbachev was apparently signaling a desire for continued cooperation with both the United States and Western Europe despite the Soviet leadership's turn to the military and a hard line in the Baltic republics.
"The latest events in the Baltics will inevitably affect our policy," Mr. Bessmertnykh said at a brief news conference after winning an overwhelming vote of confirmation. "We must work out ways to prevent and avoid such things, having in mind their foreign policy aspects as well," he said. But he added, "Statesmen, especially in major countries, should pursue a considered policy."
 
Prospect of War Assessed
Speaking of the prospect of war in the gulf, Mr. Bessmertnykh said, "I don't think that the chances for a peaceful solution of the problem have been lost finally." But a Foreign Ministry spokesman later said there was "not much solid reason for hope." The Soviet Union has withdrawn all but 235 of its citizens from Iraq.
The Soviet Union has supported the United States in the gulf crisis, endorsing the use of force if necessary to get Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, but has placed more emphasis than the United States on the need to exhaust every opportunity for a political solution first.
An interview today in Komsomolskaya Pravda, Yevgeny M. Primakov, an adviser to Mr. Gorbachev thought to have been in the running for the Foreign Ministry post, suggested that the Soviet policy might come under strain if the United States goes to war. Mr. Primakov said that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had told him that he knew he would have to withdraw someday, but that he needed to save face.
A statement by the Foreign Ministry blamed Iraq's "stubborness" and "failure to comply with the norms of international behavior" for the crisis, and said the Soviet Union would support "any constructive steps aimed at preventing armed conflict in the Persian Gulf," possibly including a French initiative at the United Nations today.
The crisis caused by Iraq's refusal to withdraw from Kuwait by today, the deadline set by the United Nations Security Council in November, was also discussed by Deputy Foreign Minister Aleksandr Belonogov and the United States Ambassador, Jack F. Matlock, on Tuesday, Mr. Churkin said.
 
U.S. Opposes Linkage
The United States opposes linkage in the French proposal between the crisis in the gulf and the Palestinian problem. Mr. Primakov, who tried unsuccessfully last year to persuade Mr. Hussein to withdraw, said that linkage was unavoidable and that the Iraqi leader knew that the Soviet Union's attitude was not identical with that of the United States.
Mr. Bessmertnykh told the Soviet legislators that Mr. Shevardnadze's surprise resignation last month in protest against what he called approaching dictatorship had allayed his pleasure in being nominated for the job.
Mr. Gorbachev also renominated Boris Pugo, the Minister of the Interior who justified the crackdown in Lithuania on Monday, to the equivalent post in his new presidential cabinet, and got the legislature's swift approval.
A Soviet Communist Party official said last week that Mr. Gorbachev had turned to the police and the army for political support because his policy of economic reform was in danger of collapsing in the general disorder.
 
Praise From Gorbachev
 Nominating Mr. Bessmertnykh, Mr. Gorbachev described him as a "great professional, a person of broad views, refined culture and modesty," and said he had great respect for him.
Mr. Shevardnadze, until his resignation, was a soulmate from the earliest days of Mr. Gorbachev's struggle to set the Soviet Union on a new course, and he implied in his resignation speech that he thought his leader was backsliding.
Mr. Shevardnadze will try to continue to influence Soviet foreign policy outside official channels, the ministry's spokesman said, and a diplomat close to him here said he had a Western-style think tank in mind.
Mr. Gorbachev's evident turn to the Soviet internal police and the army and the wide latitude he apparently gave them to act in the Baltic republics have raised questions about how much influence the Foreign Ministry has, and indeed whether the President is fully in charge of his domestic policy.
Soviet troops rolled into Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, on Sunday morning at the request of a Communist-dominated Committee of National Salvation that was to have taken over power from the separatist elected Parliament, according to messages broadcast with the army's help throughout Vilnius that day, but since the deaths of 15 people in the crackdown, the republic's Parliament has neither been dissolved nor occupied by the army.
Following Mr. Gorbachev's lead Monday, the Foreign Ministry's spokesman, Vitaly Churkin, said today, "We need law and order," but he added that the Soviet leadership was intent on finding a political settlement to the dispute over Baltic independence.
"In political life there are sometimes moments we face where we have to choose not between good and bad, but between bad and worse," Mr. Churkin said, offering this as his personal opinion, not an official one.
But he referred detailed questions as to why the troops had opened fire to the Interior Ministry or the military.
Mr. Churkin also said today that foreign correspondents accredited to the ministry remained free to travel to Lithuania and the other Baltic republics, as long as they followed prescribed procedures.

HEADLINE: Demand Soars For Gold Coins

 BODY:
The United States Mint said yesterday that sales of its American Eagle bullion gold coin had skyrocketed yesterday and Monday. Analysts say fears about the possibility of war in the Middle East had caused demand to soar.
Laura Johnston, a spokeswoman for the Mint, said 31,000 ounces of the gold coins were sold between Monday afternoon and yesterday afternoon. By comparison, 33,000 ounces were sold in all of December. So far this month, 48,000 ounces of the bullion coins have been sold, Ms. Johnston said.
Demand for the coins, which trade at a small premium over the market price for bullion itself, has been falling in recent years. And sales remained sluggish last year until the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
"We have seen in the last week a really dramatic increase in gold Eagle sales as a direct result of the activities in the Middle East," said Rick D. Lawson, vice president of the Rhode Island Hospital Trust National Bank, a commercial bank subsidiary of the Bank of Boston, an authorized distributor of the American Eagle gold and silver coins.
He added, "Gold is seen as a safe haven in times of economic or political upheaval."

HEADLINE: Sales of U.S.-Made Vehicles Down 31.4% in Early January

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Paralyzed by consumers' uncertainties about a weak economy and the prospect of war, sales of cars and trucks made in the United States were mired at recessionary levels in early January.
Sales of all types of vehicles for the Jan. 1 through Jan. 10 period fell 31.4 percent compared with early January of last year. Both periods contained eight selling days. 
 The current figures look especially dismal because they compare with a period last year when auto makers were slashing prices to clear backlogs of unsold vehicles and sales were very strong.
The 10 manufacturers with United States plants sold approximately 110,500 cars in the period this year, down 30.4 percent from last year's sales of 158,800 in early January. On a seasonally adjusted basis, cars sold at an annual rate of 5.8 million, compared with 8.5 million during the same period last year. The rate for December was 6.7 million; for the last 60 days, it was 6.5 million.
Sales of light trucks -- pickup trucks, mini-vans and four-wheel-drive vehicles -- which account for about one-third of all vehicles sold in the United States, fell 33 percent, to 67,987.
The approach of the Jan. 15 deadline for a possible military confrontation in the Persian Gulf had a withering effect on consumer confidence, dealers reported.
"As this day has drawn near, people have been reluctant to even visit car showrooms," said Jack Simmons, general manager of Orange Buick in Orlando, Fla. While used-car sales have been excellent, Mr. Simmons said, sales of new cars have fallen 10 to 15 percent since November.
Some industry analysts suggested that an outbreak of hostilities in the Persian Gulf might have a salutary effect on vehicle sales by removing some of the uncertainty that hangs over prospective buyers.
"We feel consumer psychology is as much of a factor as the consumer's pocketbook," said Tom Webb, an economist for the National Automobile Dealers' Association in McLean, Va. "Even the outbreak of war might improve the situation slightly, if it appeared the war was going to be short and there was an end in sight."
Others were less sanguine. "It's all a big mystery when the market will improve," said Joel Pitcoff, a market analyst for the Ford Motor Company. "We've got our fingers crossed."
The sales totals for the 1991 period include an estimate of the number of vehicles sold by the Chrysler Corporation -- 13,200 domestically produced cars, down 35.2 percent, and 12,540 light trucks, a drop of 53.5 percent. Chrysler reports sales only at the end of each month. The estimate was provided by Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry newsletter.
 
Sales of Imports
 Several auto makers also reported their sales in the United States of imported vehicles. The Toyota Motor Corporation sold 6,103 imported cars in early January, down 2.5 percent, and 4,144 imported light trucks, up 22.2 percent. The Honda Motor Company's sales of imported cars rose 17.4 percent, to 5,853 cars.
The General Motors Corporation sold 2,448 imported cars, down 42.7 percent, while Ford's import sales fell 45.4 percent, to 1,030 cars.
Japanese car makers reported a collective decline of 1.8 percent in sales of cars produced at their United States plants. Sales of light trucks made at the so-called transplants more than doubled during the period.
The Big Three American auto makers posted an overall decline of 32.9 percent in sales of domestically produced cars and a drop of 34.7 percent in sales of light trucks.
General Motors sold 55,182 domestically produced cars in early January, a decline of 27.8 percent. G.M.'s light-truck sales fell 26 percent, to 30,145 units.
Ford's car sales fell 39.9 percent, to 29,680. Ford sold 23,059 light trucks during the period, a decline of 29.8 percent.
Honda sold 5,674 cars made at its plant in Marysville, Ohio, an increase of 2.6 percent over the period last year.
Toyota's sales of cars made at United States factories fell 35.4 percent, to 2,663 cars.
The Nissan Motor Company sold 1,770 cars, nearly double the number it sold last year, and 1,924 light trucks, more than double last year's level. Both vehicles are manufactured at Nissan's assembly plant in Smyrna, Tenn.

HEADLINE: Wall St. Already in Position for War

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
On the day of the deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait, traders, dealers and fund managers in markets from equities to foreign exchange said they hoped they were ready for war, which most of them now expected.
Currency positions were hedged. Warrants and puts were bought to protect postions in the stock market. Mutual funds that considered cash a haven had sold stocks. And bond investors who wanted to be conservative had already moved to shorter maturities. 
 "I do think it would have been a pretty sleepy investor to not be aware of the possibility of a war," said Alistair Ross Goobey, chief international strategist at James Capel Ltd. in London. "Most of the people we talk too have taken their positions."
But through all the war talk, these same traders, fund managers and analysts generally adhered to their longer-term views of how to invest this spring and later in the year. They tried to look beyond a war, which they hope is quick.
 
A Short-Term Situation
 "We could have sold all our bonds and gone to cash if we thought the world was coming to an end," said Gordon Johns, managing director of Kemper Investment Management Company Ltd. in London. "But we still have a view of bonds that is long-term bullish. What we have at the moment is a short-term technical situation. From an investment point of view that is what it is."
Wall Street people tended to agree with Mr. Johns on how to play the eve of war.
"The best thing you can do today in this atmosphere is do nothing," he said. After a war begins there are some who will jump in for bargains and others who will wait, not willing to take the risk in what could be very volatile markets.
What many investors and fund managers sought right now was a position that would protect them if the onset of hostilities shook the markets. This means, for example, protection through hedges against a quick rally in the dollar. Or this could mean a move to bonds with shorter maturities, which should be less volatile in the confusion that the war will immediately generate.
 
Demand for T-Bills Soars
 Many investors apparently made such a move on Monday. The demand for three-month Treasury bills at the weekly auction was so heavy that the average discount rate of 6.12 percent fell to its lowest level in almost three years. The demand was also high for six-month Treasury bills.,
Richard E. Witten, partner for foreign exchange at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said Goldman's trading lately had not been to take positions but to manage risk. It was intended to protect the firm against wide swings in currency values. With a war, the dollar, which has fallen sharply in the last seven months, could rise sharply.
Some managers think the beginning of war will end the uncertainity that has dominated financial markets for months. But Mr. Witten said that the war will "just create other uncertainities."
But many investors and fund managers also want to be positioned to exploit a rally in markets around the world if a war is quick and successful. The markets will likely move so fast, this strategy requires having cash ready. And it also means being willing to buy stocks or bonds if the market falls sharply at the first shots in the Middle East.
 
A Risk on the Upside
 Mr. Ross Goobey is ready for this second strategy. "If there is not a prolonged war, the risk in the stock markets is more on the upside," he said.
Nimrod Fachler, managing director at Mitchell Hutchins, said he would do nothing if war began. He said he would move only when he was able to conclude "that the war will be successful -- then I am going to buy stocks selectively in Euorpe and lengthen the bond maturities."
In the oil market, Peter C. Beutel, energy director at Pegasus Econometric Group in New Jersey, said he was recommending that his clients just basically hedge their positions so they can stay out of the market just after a war begins. "At this time our biggest concern is to play defense," he said.
Only in the gold market yesterday did there seem to be some last-minute postioning for the likelihood of a war in the Persian Gulf. Ian C. MacDonald, manager of precious metals at Credit Suisse in New York, said there was "fresh demand from the Middle East." Gold breached the $400 level yesterday but closed at $398.80, which still leaves it about $25 below where it was about a year ago.
He said that given the false starts in the last year with gold rallies, he would be cautious about buying. He said that heavy sellng by gold producers, which he has been seeing, could limit the gains for gold, which could also fall sharply if a quick victory against Iraq was won.

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
Initial Days of a War May Not Hurt Stocks

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The initiation of wars has caused some of the most dramatic plunges in stock market history. Unexpected events often shock markets, and wars have been among the most surprising.
But a Middle East war, if it does occur soon, could provoke little reaction initially, simply because it is so widely expected. However, if the war goes badly, as happened in the early months of World War II, initial complacency could be replaced by panic. 
 While many wars have begun with quick selloffs in stocks, the pattern has not been uniform. For example, recent American invasions, of Grenada in 1983 and of Panama in 1989, both ended quickly and had little market impact. There was some surprise at the beginnings of the invasions, especially in Grenada, but neither conflict seemed likely to be important in the long run.
But if it is the long-term impact of a war that is most important to investors, figuring out what that will be can be very difficult. At the beginning of both World War I and the 1973 Middle East conflict, investors badly misread the market implications.
"When there is a reaction in the stock market, it is often wrong," Laszlo Birinyi, a market analyst at Birinyi Associates, said after looking at past market reactions to invasions. "It proves again what Mr. Keynes said, that there is nothing more difficult than a rational investment policy in an irrational world."
A classic case of investor confusion was seen at the start of World War I in 1914. After the Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.67 percent in two trading days following the first declaration of war on July 28, the New York Stock Exchange was closed from Aug. 1 until Dec. 12. But the initial part of the war proved a boon to American business, and prices soared in 1915.
Prices plunged in 1917, however, after Germany began attacking American shipping, presaging American involvement in the war. The actual American declaration of war on April 6, 1917 was anticipated and had only a brief effect on the market.
By the time World War II began with Germany's invasion of Poland on Sept. 1, 1939, American investors had sniffed profits, and within a week, the Dow was up 11.63 percent. By the next spring, however, the Dow fell 15.5 percent in a week as German troops swept through France. Not until the stock market crash in 1987 were investors to suffer a larger percentage drop in one week.
There was another selloff after Japan bombed Pearl Harbor, when the Dow lost 5.03 percent in the week following the attack on Dec. 7, 1941.
The Korean War also served as a shock to investors, and Dow stocks lost 4.65 percent of their value in the week following the news of the invasion of South Korea by North Korea on June 25, 1950. But the effect was short-lived, and by September the Dow had recovered all its losses.
 In Mideast confrontations, the market reactions have moved every way. There was little reaction to the Suez crisis in 1956, when France and Britain tried to keep Egypt from controlling the Suez Canal. After the start of the Arab-Israeli war on June 5, 1967, the Dow dropped 1.81 percent on the first day of trading. But almost all of that loss was made up the next day, and the war proved to be a non-event for the stock market in the long term.
With that history in mind, investors reacted with equanimity to the next Arab-Israeli war, which began on Oct. 6, 1973. The Dow actually rose the next session. In that case, however, the confidence was misplaced: The war led to the Arab oil embargo, to sharply higher oil prices, and to a severe recession that sent stock prices plunging. Dow stocks lost 39.81 percent of their value in the year after the conflict began.
 It was that experience that colored the market's reaction to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and the rise in oil prices that followed it. The Dow is down 14.1 percent since the invasion on Aug. 2, 1990, with a 5.3 percent drop so far this month, as the United Nations deadline of Jan. 15 for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to order a withdrawal from Kuwait approached. Much of the recent decline came on extraordinarily low volume, as investors reacted by taking positions and then waiting
"There is a fair amount of defensive posturing among investors, assuming the worst," Robert Farrell, Merrill Lynch's chief market analyst, said yesterday. "It seems to me that if a shooting war starts, the market could rally, not because it is good news, but because it is an uncertainty resolved. If there is the unexpected, where Saddam Hussein agrees to pull out, then I think you also get a rally, and maybe a bigger one."
But while a war may have been anticipated and discounted by investors, it is likely that most investors expect any war to be short and end in a decisive American victory. Signs of a prolonged war, or word of Iraqi battlefield victories, could send prices reeling.
The Vietnam War was probably more important than the Korean War in terms of long-term impact on the nation and on the stock market. President Lyndon B. Johnson's unwillingness to pay for the war by cutting social programs helped set off inflation and bring on the 1970 recession.
But Vietnam was a war that had little in the way of immediate market impact, as it grew without any obvious beginning. Neither the Tonkin Gulf incident on Aug. 2, 1964, in which North Vietnam was said to have attacked American ships, nor the Tet offensive the began on Jan. 30, 1968, in which Communist troops attacked Saigon, had much impact on the market, although each event dominated the news at the time.
The long-term impact of this war, if it comes, will be similarly hard to evaluate. Already, it is exacerbating a budget deficit that was severe, and it could lead to a significant change in America's role in the world. But it is unlikely that the start of the war will lead to sharp changes in investor perceptions.
"Back last fall, when war was a possibility but not deemed imminent, we hazarded the guess that if war broke out in the gulf, there would be an immediate 200-point drop on the Dow," said William LeFevre, a market strategist at Advest Inc. "It is now our view that 1991's Dow decline has discounted much of that supposed 200-point shock to stocks, should war develop."
What may not have been discounted, of course, is how the war will develop, or what effect it will have on the recession that has already begun. As investors draw conclusions in these areas, a war could have a major effect on the stock market.

HEADLINE: Liquidation Fears Rise For Eastern

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Eastern Airlines, which last November fought off an attempt by its creditors to shut down the carrier, may stop flying within days and be liquidated because it is short of cash and cannot find more, a person familiar with the airline's finances said yesterday.
If Eastern is forced to liquidate, there may be little left for its creditors because the process can be expensive and would probably deplete much of the carrier's escrow accounts, which now total about $500 million. Among Eastern's biggest unsecured creditors are Airbus Industrie, Boeing, General Electric and Pratt & Whitney. Its secured creditors are mostly bondholders.
 
Still Seeking Partners
 Martin R. Shugrue Jr., the court-appointed trustee who is running Eastern, said the airline was still seeking investment partners to keep flying and reorganize with a new business plan under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. He said yesterday that the carrier was talking with two potential investors, but he would not name them. Even after a shutdown, Eastern could again begin operating with an infusion from an outside investor. 
 Ticket holders are expected to be reimbursed if the carrier stops flying. The Federal Bankruptcy Court has set aside $50 million for that purpose.
The carrier's condition was disclosed last Thursday in a meeting in the chambers of Burton R. Lifland, the chief judge of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, who is overseeing Eastern's attempt to reorganize.
Mr. Shugrue said at the meeting that Eastern's cash was rapidly running out, a person familiar with the meeting said. The person did not want to be identified.
The person said Mr. Shugrue was preparing the airline for a shutdown and liquidation while also seeking other alternatives.
The Wall Street Journal had reported yesterday that Eastern could face a shutdown as early as next week. Mr. Shugrue, who spoke at the International Aviation Club in Washington yesterday, said in response to the report that it was accurate "in that we have indeed scoured the industry for purchasers and partners."
He added, "In fact, as we speak today, we are in discussions with two such potential partners whose investment interest in Eastern is real." One analyst, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said, however, that he believed there was little chance of finding a savior for Eastern.
 
Reorganization Plan
 Mr. Shugrue said that Eastern had just completed a reorganization plan that would greatly change the economics and operations of the airline and allow Eastern to come out of bankruptcy.
"Despite the underlying strength of this business plan, with the turmoil in the industry today Eastern admittedly faces an uphill struggle and would benefit greatly from an investment partner to help the airline implement this new business plan," he said.
Mr. Shugrue did not name the potential partners. Northwest Airlines has expressed interest in Eastern's Atlanta hub, while most other big United States carriers have expressed interest in pieces of the airline, A Northwest representative could not be reached yesterday for comment.
Eastern's condition is a huge disappointment for Mr. Shugrue. Last November, he and Eastern's lawyers opposed a motion by the airline's unsecured creditors to liquidate the carrier because it could not stem its losses. Mr. Shugrue persuaded Judge Lifland to release $135 million from escrow to enable him to try to win back business fliers: Eastern allowed them to fly first class on a full-coach fare.
Mr. Shugrue predicted that the carrier would break even by March and would no longer need cash infusions from the creditors.
 
Concerns About Safety
 But Mr. Shugrue was trying to win back business travelers as the recession was cutting into business travel.Concerns about Eastern's safety also continued to be raised in the press and in a grand jury investigation of Eastern employees suspected of signing off on repairs and maintenance that had not been performed.
Like other big carriers, Eastern has also seen its fuel bills soar because of the Persian Gulf crisis. And competitors that at first had not matched Eastern's lower fares, became more aggressive in their pricing.
Even without the higher fuel prices and the recession, Mr. Shugrue would have faced a struggle. There was the legacy of years of labor strife and a long strike that crippled the carrier's operations for a while and forced it into bankruptcy protection in March 1989.

HEADLINE: Lack of Day Care Cited in Benefits Appeal

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Jan. 15

 BODY:
A woman who was dismissed from her job because she regularly missed work to care for her sick infant is appealing her denial of unemployment benefits to the Minnesota Court of Appeals.
The 32-year-old woman, Diane McCourtney, was absent from her job as an accounts clerk with a Minnetonka computer company, Seagate Technology, about half the time from January through April of last year. She said she had to stay home because she could not find affordable day care for her ill son, James, now 15 months old.
She was dismissed May 1 for excessive absenteeism. Her claim for jobless benefits totaling $5,486 was contested by Seagate and denied by the state Jobs and Training Department. She appealed twice to the agency and lost.
Ms. McCourtney, who is still out of work, is pregnant with twins and has applied for a child-care license.
James, who had frequently been stricken with respiratory ailments, is now healthy. Ms. McCourtney's husband, Larry Olson, who was disabled by a back injury in early 1990 and could not lift the boy, now earns $25,000 a year as a salesman.

HEADLINE: Oil Traders Are Calm At Deadline

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The oil market stared war in the face yesterday, and barely moved.
In a market that has been gyrating with every whisper of Persian Gulf news, trading was notably contained as the midnight deadline for Iraq to pull out of Kuwait approached. Experts said the lack of news to change expectations on prices -- which jumped on Monday to over $30 a barrel -- appeared to dominate trading. 
 For now, "basically, all the bad news is out, and all the good news is out, too," said John H. Lichtblau of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, explaining the tepid trading on what was very likely the eve of a confrontation the market had feared for months.
 
Everyone Talks War
 Everyone is talking war, he said, but global oil supplies are high and Saudi Arabia seems to be heavily defended.
Crude oil for February delivery closed down 71 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange, at $30.07, having wandered over the relatively small range of $1.50 in the course of the day.
Stocks, facing the same uncertainty, stumbled up and down. At the close the Dow was at 2,490.59, up 6.68. Treasury notes and bonds dipped in light trading, the dollar was little changed and gold fell slightly.
With a deadline for war near, some oil users might have been tempted to buy extra supplies, but Mr. Lichtblau pointed out, "You take a risk if you buy oil at $35 or $40; if there is a war, it could be short-lived, or it may not affect supplies."
 
Saudi Oilfield Security
 In either case, a buyer could find his inventory worth much less in a few days. Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist and senior managing director at Bear, Stearns & Company, said yesterday, "The Iraqi Air Force threat to the Saudi oilfields is the key threat that has been hanging up the market for weeks." If the United States and its allies achieve quick air superiority, he said, oil will tumble. Stocks, he added, would follow with a "multi-hundred-point rally."
Shahrokh Nikkhah, a vice president at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., had another theory for why oil went lower yesterday. "I think the market's trying to tell us that there is not going to be a war," he said. President Saddam Hussein, he said, might feel after the deadline passes that his pride and face had been maintained, and that diplomacy was now possible.
Among the oil companies, however, there were signs that a rough stretch lies ahead. Mobil and Phillips Petroleum announced steps to limit hoarding.
Mobil said it had asked its bulk customers if they would restrict their purchases of gasoline and heating oil to 100 percent of the volume for which they had contracted, which, the company noted, was more oil than most of them generally buy.
The company said that some of its terminals "have been hit by withdrawals greatly in excess of local demand," but that "there is no industry shortage of petroleum products, and industry inventories are adequate to meet normal demand."
Phillips said customers who buy in a single day more than 1/30th of their monthly contract volume of gasoline or distillates would be charged an additional 10 cents a gallon for excess gallons. Distillates are primarily heating oil and diesel oil.
 
Speculators Liquidate
 While some distributors may be stocking up, the only hectic trading in the pits on the futures exchange was at the end of the day, when "locals," or speculators who buy and sell on their own account, without ever taking delivery, decided to liquidate their positions rather than go home last night holding fixed-price obligations that could wipe them out.
"People are not willing to be wrong," said Tom Blakeslee, an analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group, of Hoboken, N.J.
Early in the day, locals had guessed that prices would rise, and bought contracts that obligated them to buy oil at a future date, according to market-watchers. If war fears rose, the value of these contracts would rise.
"But we got near the end of the day," said Thomas R. Sparico, managing director of Geldermann Energy, a brokerage house, "and the phones never lit up with the rest of the world coming to buy." So the locals liquidated their positions, and the price sank.
 
Heating Oil Also Falls
 Heating oil also fell, by 4.28 cents, to 84.7 cents a gallon. Unleaded gasoline was down by 5.22 cents to 77.04 cents a gallon.
Most experts still expect a price spike if shooting breaks out, but are beginning to doubt it will be very big.
On the eve of the United Nations deadline for Iraq to get out of Kuwait, the American Petroleum Institute reported that crude oil stocks for the week ending Jan. 11 rose to 323 million barrels, from 321.7 million the previous week. The figure compares to 345.1 million barrels last year.
Stocks of heating oil and other distillates were in a normal seasonal decline, said the institute, the industry's main trade association. Gasoline stocks were off from the previous week but ahead of last year. Crude imports, however, were way down: 5.4 million barrels a day, the same as the earlier week, compared with 6.2 million barrels last year.
