HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
John Hancock Preview Of Changes at the Top

BYLINE: By Daniel F. Cuff

 BODY:
John Hancock Financial Services, the nation's ninth-largest insurer, announced changes at the top yesterday that will take place a year from now.
Stephen L. Brown, 54 years old, will become chairman and chief executive, succeeding E. James Morton, who will retire at age 65 after five years as chairman and 42 years with the company. Mr. Brown, now president and chief operations officer, will be succeeded in that position by William L. Boyan, 57. 
 "We generally do things pretty far in advance around here," Mr. Morton said yesterday, referring to the early announcement of the changes, "although this might be a record." He added that the company wanted to announce the change before scheduled meetings of salespeople.
One of those businesses, the John Hancock Freedom Securities Corporation, had an announcement of its own yesterday. It named George V. McGough the chairman and chief executive of its broker-dealer unit, Sutro & Company in San Francisco, and its parent, the Sutro Group. Mr. McGough, 50, is a longtime executive of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.
The official name of the Boston-based company is the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, but that is relegated to small print on the company's stationery. "We call ourselves John Hancock Financial Services because we're in so many businesses," Mr. Morton said.
John Hancock, unlike some companies in the insurance industry, has not yet shown any cracks in its financial underpinnings. It is a mutual company, owned by policyholders, as is the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, which has said it will go public to raise needed capital.
"We weren't as aggressive as the Equitable was," Mr. Morton said. "We have had in 1989, and it appears also in 1990, the two best years in our history in terms of improved balance sheet and earnings.
"But I don't care to predict the future. We probably have an above-average holding of real estate. A lot of people worry about that. We've had a low rate of default and delinquencies, but we do wonder what the future will hold, and certainly if there is a long recession, we will take some hits also."
Mr. Morton has taken some maverick positions on industry issues. He advocates pro-competitive legislation that would, for example, allow banks in insurance, not a popular industry position. But he protested yesterday that what he really wanted was to allow insurance companies to own banks as the quid pro quo. "Our position has been for rational reform for many years now," he said, adding that he did not quite understand the iconoclast tag affixed to him.
Mr. Morton is a Yale graduate who joined the company in 1949 as an actuarial trainee. His successor, Mr. Brown, also advanced through the actuarial department after joining Hancock in 1958.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Maze of Troubles Posing Challenges To Power and Popularity of Dinkins

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
As he confronts the fiscal problems that may be the biggest challenge of his career, Mayor David N. Dinkins faces cracks in his political coalition, malaise among his staff, aspersions on his integrity and the acknowledged prospect that "things may worsen before they improve."
In preparing the preliminary city budget that he is to present today, Mr. Dinkins's closest aides say, the Mayor showed both moments of despair and more optimism than most of them feel. Yet events and his own dogged responses to them have combined to keep him on the defensive for months, undermining his popularity and probably his power. 
 At times, even Mr. Dinkins, whose cautious rise through clubhouse politics led few to foresee his fate, seems almost unable to believe the peculiar burdens that have befallen him.
"I've fought this fight my entire life," he said last week, trying to reassure a coalition of social-service organizations, whose representatives were protesting his budget cuts, that he would not forsake them. "Indeed, I didn't start out to become mayor of this city. It happened along the way."
 
Some Deep Doubts
 So serious are the economic problems -- a budget gap of $2 billion, spending cuts of nearly $1 billion and more than $500 million in proposed new or higher taxes -- and so deep are the doubts about how they can be resolved that Mr. Dinkins finds few champions these days.
At a meeting Monday night in Springfield Gardens, Queens, the most rock-solid turf in his election, he received a friendly but flat reception from worried residents. At a sodden breakfast meeting with business leaders in Manhattan yesterday, he had to prompt them to applaud, even when he announced a droplet of good news: he will begin reducing, by one-quarter of a percentage point a year, the 6 percent commercial rent tax that has been anathema to them.
On Saturday, the Mayor interrupted an all-day budget meeting at Gracie Mansion to visit the Rev. Al Sharpton in a Brooklyn hospital after he had been stabbed in Bensonhurst. As he returned, the Mayor briefly held his head in his hands. "I thought, 'Oh, boy,' " one senior adviser said.
On top of everything else, a report last week from an independent city investigation into a stock transaction between Mr. Dinkins and his son found evidence that cast doubt on the Mayor's account of events. While not recommending any further legal action, the chief investigator took the unusual step of saying that he had not cleared the Mayor, either.
Amid such stress, his aides say, Mr. Dinkins is acutely conscious and proud of his special role as the city's first black mayor -- especially to the children he cites as his most precious constituents. The aides say he is privately defiant and determined not only to endure but also to prevail.
But as the Mayor struggles, there are complaints from commissioners, the City Council and state officials that he does not meet with them often enough. Last week, after Transportation Commissioner Lucius J. Riccio dismissed a deputy who had warned about dangers on the Manhattan Bridge, it developed that the Mayor had not met one on one with Mr. Riccio in his entire tenure, instead communicating through deputy mayors.
For a Mayor often faulted as lacking decisiveness, every decision has its pitfalls. In ruling, for the moment, against closing any more fire companies after a fatal fire blocks from the site of a recently closed engine company in Queens, Mr. Dinkins insisted on Monday that the move was not related to assertions by firefighters that the deaths might have been avoided if the fire company had been open -- claims that the administration disputes.
The Mayor may have wisely weighed the political risks in further closings, but he also risked planting deeper worry in the public mind that such closings are devoutly to be feared, and this might make it even more difficult for him to close more fire companies later if he must to balance the budget, as he says he might.
 
Too Full a Plate?
 His aides insist such choices are ultimately the Mayor's alone, but they suggest that his plate may sometimes get too full. "He tends to put the same kind of energy into a smaller issue as into one that is major," one aide said. "He doesn't not pay attention to the big stuff, but it's disarming."
Another senior adviser said the Mayor had gone over and over the budget decisions and details to assure that he knew them back and forth. "It's not something that people are ever going to place in front of him and prompt him," the aide said.
On the other hand, senior aides acknowleged that Mr. Dinkins did not have adequate control of his time. Plans are in the works for staff changes intended to better organize his team.
The most significant speculation has centered on his chief political aide and former campaign manager, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, who 10 days ago was widely reported by several of his friends to be on the verge of leaving, until the Mayor implored him to stay. Mr. Lynch has denied such speculation, but not discouraged it. While saying he had no immediate plans to leave, he conceded in a recent interview that it has been a troubled time for him.
"Yes, my soul is bleeding, for the Mayor and this trying year," said Mr. Lynch. "When there's a mistake or a miscue, or we don't do something, it ends up at his feet."
Mr. Lynch said he blames himself for much of the criticism the Mayor received for his handling of a bitter black-led boycott of Korean-American grocery stores in Brooklyn, and the difficulties in lobbying the City Council and the Legislature that have delayed passage of Mr. Dinkins's proposed anti-crime package.
But Mr. Lynch also bore major responsibility for some of the administration's biggest successes: the Mayor's speech on racial harmony at a tense moment last spring, drawing the 1992 Democratic National Convention to New York and playing host to Nelson Mandela.
 
Some Changes Ahead
 As budget problems have dominated the agenda, First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel, always pre-eminent on the organizational charts but new to the Mayor's inner circle, has moved more and more to the fore. Senior officials say they expect that John Flateau, a former campaign aide, will come to City Hall as the Mayor's chief of staff, in charge of his schedule and taking over functions once assigned to Ken Sunshine, a Lynch protege shifted to other duties.
Mr. Steisel dismisses suggestions of a rift with Mr. Lynch but has said privately that peristent reports of one make his job difficult. In a sign of the difference between them, the low-key Mr. Lynch once told Mr. Steisel that while he was a good "leader of men," he hoped to make him into a "leader of leaders," less concerned about dominating his colleagues.
Despite such occasional sniping, some senior mayoral aides said they believed the Mayor's circle was working better together than it had. But keeping that up may be tough if finances continue to shrink.
"Nobody likes to feel that their back's against the wall," one senior aide said.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Iraq;
Gamble for Hussein: Power or Oblivion

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 15

 BODY:
President Saddam Hussein goes to the brink of war with the United States and its allies today because, many analysts say they believe, the Iraqi leader is trying to get -- up until the last possible instant -- the thing he most desires: recognition from the West and a protected role as the region's pre-eminent power.
The colossal willpower, stubbornness, ego or megalomania of the 54-year-old Arab leader, whatever the psychoanalysts of history eventually call it, has been one of the most remarkable phenomena of the Persian Gulf crisis that has carried this country of 17 million to the precipice of destructive national combat. 
 Today tens of thousands of Iraqis took to the streets to show that they are prepared to march off the cliff with their leader in defiance of the same ill-defined Western "arrogance" of which the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini so often complained.
 
From Disaster to Advantage
 What is the injury, real or perceived, that has driven Mr. Hussein and the ever-active, ever-organizing Baath party machine he created toward the collision with the daunting military alliance that awaits its orders in the Arabian desert?
After scores of interviews and conversations with Iraqis and foreign diplomats in this capital over the last six weeks and running up to the United Nations deadline, the most coherent conclusion is also the most simple and obvious. Nothing has been going Mr. Hussein's way since the end of the Iran-Iraq War and, under rising economic pressure, he abandoned the veneer of Arab statesman that he tried to burnish after the war and threw his military power angrily at Kuwait in a plunderous gamble that has failed.
Mr. Hussein may have been provoked, as many Arab leaders concede, but the path of violence and retribution he chose against the small emirate that faithfully fueled and financed his military engine during eight years of war with Iran have indelibly marked him as a dangerous and unreliable neighbor for the custodians of the world's oil wealth in the Persian Gulf.
Yet Mr. Hussein, ever determined to turn disaster to advantage, has sought to dig out of the trap Kuwait has proved to be by threatening to pull down the already shaky pillars of Middle Eastern stability unless he get what he wants: a secure role in the region and protection from the neighbors, particularly Israel, which he has so alarmed by his post-war militarism.
"Palestine" and "Holy War" may be the rallying cries of Mr. Hussein's crusade under an Iraqi flag newly inscribed in Arabic with "God Is Great," but politically he is relentlessly pursuing a program of damage control, survival and a new modus vivendi with Washington that would guarantee his future and a role for Iraq in the scales of regional power.
 
Capitulation or War
 As one member of Mr. Hussein's governing Arab Baath Socialist Party recently intimated, Iraq's decision to invade Kuwait may look horrible in retrospect, but Mr. Hussein is determined to make the best deal he can coming out of it, even at the risk of going down in flames and taking, perhaps, hundreds of thousands of Iraqis with him.
Most Iraqis close to the circle of power around Mr. Hussein agree that he has remained sharply focused in the final weeks of brinkmanship on one goal: getting the American Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, to come to Baghdad for the kind of Middle Eastern negotiation that would have tested the Bush Administration's diplomatic skill and political endurance.
The fact that Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker denied the Iraqi leader that forum for Iraqi recognition, which Mr. Hussein was carefully preparing as a summit of "mutual respect" among "equals," has forced him to face the most unpleasant of choices: abject capitulation or war.
The penultimate meeting between Mr. Baker and Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, was doomed to fail because, Iraqi specialists say, only Mr. Hussein, the tribal leader of a xenophobic political regime, can make concessions from his position of absolute power.
When Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker decided against walking into Mr. Hussein's political den, the Iraqi leader's face-saving choices in the crisis critically narrowed.
Mr. Hussein had already conceded to the Soviet envoy, Yevgeny M. Primakov, that Iraq would lose a war with the gulf alliance, but his retort to the Soviet official was one that may still echo through the presidential palace here until the bombs begin falling.
"If my choice is surrender or fight, I am inclined to fight," Mr. Hussein said, according to a diplomat briefed on the conversation. That is a dangerous choice for a man who gambles as Mr. Hussein does, and there is no shortage of Western, European and Asian diplomats in Baghdad who argue that it is too dangerous.
Partly out of that instinctive fear of Mr. Hussein's violent nature and his willingness to gamble everything to win, many of Washington's friends in Europe and the Middle East have urged the Bush Administration to meet with Mr. Hussein personally and construct the new security regime for the region that would have to recognize his role while providing the face-saving compromise on the Palestinian question to allow for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait.
That is a formula that was not attempted under the no-reward-for-aggression countercrusade by Mr. Bush, and there is no guarantee that such a formula would have worked, many analysts concede. After all, they said, if Mr. Hussein thought he could persuade the Bush Administration to accept that minimum deal to avert war, who can say that Mr. Hussein would not have been inspired to reach for more?

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Finding a Haven In Nestle Stock

BYLINE: By Steven Greenhouse

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
SOME analysts regard Nestle S.A., the world's largest food company, as a haven for investors during this period of geopolitical tension and economic slowdown, even though it has been hurt by the weak dollar and tough competition in the United States.
The way these analysts see it, if recession grips the world and despite the war in the Middle East, everyone will continue to need food. This means millions of people will continue to buy Nestle products, which include Nestle infant formula, Taster's Choice coffee and Stouffer frozen foods. 
 "If there is a worldwide recession, even food manufacturers will come under some pressure, but nothing like some other industries," said Deborah Rees, an analyst with Kleinwort Benson, a London-based brokerage.
Ms. Rees sees Nestle as a good "defensive" stock, one that will be less volatile than many other stocks should the war drive down the markets.
John L. Parker, an analyst with Barclays de Zoete Wedd, also has a "buy" recommendation for Nestle. "The key to Nestle's short-term performance is the degree to which the markets want to be in a safe haven situation," he said. "Beyond that, over the longer term, there is a pretty positive earnings story in Nestle."
Over the last year, however, Nestle, with $38 billion in 1989 revenues, has not seemed like much of a haven. The company has been bruised and beaten by the strong performance of the Swiss franc and the plunge of the dollar. One-fourth of Nestle's sales are in North America, so the company, based in Vevey, Switzerland, has been hit hard when its American sales are translated into Swiss francs.
A year ago, management was dreaming of a double-digit earnings increase for 1990, but now manyanalysts expect an earnings drop of more than 5 percent. Profits are expected to slide, notwithstanding a 3 percent increase in sales volume last year. The main reason for the drop in earnings is the Swiss franc's 15 percent rise against most currencies last year. Nestle has also been hurt by Brazil's economic crisis and by soaring fuel bills.
Michael Oertli, a Zurich-based analyst with UBS Phillips & Drew, changed his "buy" recommendation to "hold" last November when Nestle announced that its revenues were down almost 6 percent for the first 10 months of 1990 and that its net profits would probably fall for the year. Mr. Oertli is keeping Nestle on "hold," because "the whole situation of the stock market is that you don't have to buy Nestle because Nestle will not outperform the market." While Nestle might have less downward vulnerability than some other stocks, Mr. Oertli does not see huge near-term upward potential.
He forecasts that earnings per share dropped 11 percent drop for 1990, to 585 Swiss francs, or about $455, but he sees earnings per share climbing 8 percent this year, to 631 Swiss francs. Many analysts say Nestle's profits will snap back if the Swiss franc does not continue rising.
"For the long-term investor, we have always said, 'Don't sell Nestle,' " Mr. Oertli said. In yesterday's trading in Zurich, Nestle shares closed at 7,010 Swiss francs, down 50 francs on the day.
Despite the currency fluctuations, many analysts, including Ms. Rees and Mr. Parker, say Nestle's chief executive, Helmut Maucher, has put the company on a solid course. The company's revenues rose 21 percent, to 48 billion Swiss francs in 1989, and its profits rose 17.2 percent, or 656 francs a share, to 2.41 billion Swiss francs. Theseincreases were helped by a 12 percent drop in the Swiss franc in 1989 and a 4 percent jump in sales volume.
In 1988, Nestle bought Buitoni, the pasta maker, and Rowntree, Britain's largest chocolate maker. Nestle is integrating both into its worldwide network, hoping to realize economies of scale and growth. To challenge Kellogg's dominance in ready-to-eat cereals, Nestle set up a joint venture a year ago with General Mills to produce and market cereals in Europe. Then in December it set up a joint venture with Coca-Cola to cooperate in bottling and distributing Nestea iced tea and Nescafe iced coffee in cans. Analysts say both joint ventures have great promise.
Last November Nestle announced it would consolidate its American operations -- Carnation, Stouffer and Ohio-based Nestle Enterprises -- in the hope of achieving efficiencies and making its operations more responsive to the market. At the moment, Nestle's biggest headaches are coming from the United States, which has moved into a recession, while Nestle's other important markets, Asia and Europe, continue to grow. Nestle's pet food and frozen food businesses are coming under pressure as shoppers turn to less expensive alternatives and competitors turn up the pressure. Stouffer used to have 50 percent of the American market for frozen meals, but its market share and margins have been slashed because of tough competition from other frozen entrees, like Weight Watchers and Conagra's Healthy Choice.
"The high margins businesses, those with convenience, are getting hit the most right now," said Bertrand Facon, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston, the London-based investment bank.
Mr. Facon's recommendation for Nestle is "hold." He is not pessimistic about Nestle's chances, but since he expects world stock markets to rebound, he says: "People may turn to more cyclical stocks. People who used Nestle in terms of protection could go back to stocks that have more upside potential."
The lesson: If you see the glass half empty, you might buy Nestle. If you see it half full, you might look for more promising, cyclical stocks.

HEADLINE: Romania Seeks to Reduce Abortions

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania

 BODY:
The scarcity and high cost of contraceptives here as well as a lack of easily available information about birth control have left abortion as the primary means of family planning, slowing the country's recovery from the harsh population building policies of its former Communist dictator, health officials here said.
In his eagerness to swell the population of Romania from its present level of 23 million, Nicolae Ceaucescu had made the possession of any birth-control device a crime while outlawing abortions. All aspects of that policy were reversed after his overthrow and execution. But in the absence of other means, there has been an increase in the number of abortions. 
 "It is an emergency," said Alin Stanescu, director of the Romanian Health Ministry's mother and child protection division. "We agree that abortion is not good. But we have no choice for the time being."
In 1990, Romanian physicians performed about a million abortions on about 600,000 women, said Dr. Sorin Puia, director of Bucharest's Sirbu obstetric clinic and president of a family-planning organization.
 
A Legacy of Ceaucescu
 Some women underwent as many as three or four abortions, Mr. Stanescu said.
Romania, which has 5.5 million women of child-bearing age, now records about three abortions for every live birth, about the opposite of the ratio in the United States and most Western European countries, said Julia Plotnick, an American nurse working with Romania's Health Ministry on a family-planning program.
"What is for certain is that education about the use of contraceptives is necessary," said Mr. Stanescu as he explained why so many were resorting to the low-cost abortions. "A large part of the population doesn't know about birth control."
The problems facing the family-planning effort are in some ways a legacy of the Ceaucescu' regime's 1966 decision to outlaw all abortion and contraception as a result of the dictator's conviction that maximum population growth would pave Romania's way to economic prosperity.
 
The Human Consequences
 "He wanted everything to be the biggest, the biggest plan, the biggest house, the biggest birth rate," Mr. Stanescu said. "He did not consider the human consequences."
"Medical personnel, teachers, everyone was instructed to advocate a high birth rate," he said, adding that the secret police kept doctors and pregnant women under surveillance. Those suspected of interrupting or preventing pregnancies faced prosecution and often went to jail.
According to experts like Mr. Stanescu, that situation led many, perhaps even millions of women, to turn to quack abortionists.
Some women used sharp instruments in efforts to bring on miscarriages; others douched with water and salt or soap, antibiotics, an anti-coagulant and other drugs, shaving cream, linden tea and other folk-medicine concoctions, said Dr. Puia adding that such methods exacted a heavy toll.
 
Cervical Inflammation
 In the first half of 1989, the last year of Mr. Ceaucescu's rule, 626 women died as a direct result of back-room abortions, Dr. Puia said. About 400,000 women were hospitalized in 1989 for bleeding and other abortion-related complications.
About 40 percent of the 100,000 women that Sirbu clinic treats suffer chronic cervical inflammation as a result of back-room abortions, while 10 percent suffer inflammation of other parts of their reproductive systems, he said, adding that those figures are probably representative of the entire female population.
Dr. Puia said the widespread injuries caused by back-room abortions had produced an abnormally high incidence of premature births and made it imperative for specialists to examine women before prescribing even some of the safest contraceptives.
Three days after the December 1989 revolution that overthrew Mr. Ceausescu, Romania's provisional Government decreed Europe's most liberal abortion law. An abortion in Romania today costs about the same as a beer, far less expensive than a regular supply contraceptives, which are very hard to find regardless of price.
 
'Lack of Trust' in System
 The Government is afraid of raising the price of legal abortions because it might drive poor people back to quack abortionists, Mr. Stanescu said.
Romania's Health Ministry has made sex education, implementation of a family-planning program and initiation of domestic contraception production top priorities to cutdown on abortions, Mr. Stanescu said. Romania must now use scarce hard currency to import all its birth-control devices.
The problem is to educate people and medical personnel about contraceptives and develop a domestic industry that will be able to produce inexpensive birth-control devices, Ms. Plotnick said. But unlike children's homes in Romania, whose miserable conditions attracted substantial Western assistance after the revolution, obtaining foreign aid for family planning is a serious problem.
"The big play here is for the children in the institutions, not family planning," she said, explaining that $500,000 would be enough to implement a family-planning program.
"The Romanians have good ideas but no money," she said. "They could do it in a year with some funding and technology from the outside."
"As a professional I would rather spend my time delivering children than performing abortions," Dr. Puia said, expressing hope that 1991 would see the number of abortions drop. "It is an obligation to be optimistic."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Decline Slightly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Although war fears remained pervasive in the credit markets yesterday, comments about the economy by the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, were the major cause of a slight drop in the prices of Treasury securities.
Despite the decline in the price of bonds and notes, short-term Treasury bill rates continued to move lower. 
 Much of the very limited activity in yesterday's market, which closed before hostilities began in the Midde East, was in reaction to a report in The Washington Post that Mr. Greenspan had told a luncheon meeting on Tuesday that the economy seemed to have bottomed out in the fourth quarter. He made the remarks following a morning meeting with President Bush, the article said.
"The Greenspan comments hurt the front end pretty badly," one government bond trader said. "But to me, it seems to be part of a concerted effort to build up the confidence of businessmen. I don't think it indicates anything adverse for monetary policy."
 
Troublesome Data
 In addition, analysts said that economic data released yesterday did not necessarily bear out Mr. Greenspan's analysis.
Specifically, analysts said they were troubled by the six-tenths of 1 percent decline in industrial output for December, a figure the Fed released yesterday. The decline, the third consecutive monthly drop, was much larger than most analysts had been anticipating.
"The production numbers were dramatically weaker than expected," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J.
But with war anticipated, credit market participants shrugged off the industrial production figures as well as a report that the consumer price index had risen by three-tenths of 1 percent last month, slightly higher than expected.
 
Bond Yield Unchanged
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 103 27/32 late yesterday, down 1/ 32, to yield 8.39 percent, unchanged from late Tuesday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 29/ 32, down 3/32, to yield 8.21 percent. And the 7 1/4 percent two-year notes dipped by 3/32, to a price of 100 1/8, to yield 7.17 percent.
Late yesterday, the Treasury announced it would sell $12.5 billion worth of new two-year notes on Wednesday and $9 billion of new five-year notes on Jan. 24.
Following the announcement, the two-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.17 percent. The five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 7.82 percent.
Interest rates on short-term Treasury bills were unchanged to down slightly. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.03 percent, down 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged, at a discount rate of 6.14 percent.
 
Port Authority Issue
 In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey sold $100 million of securities at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by Lehman Brothers won the issue, which consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1992 through 1996 and from 2006 through 2012, and a term bond that matures in 2026.
The term bond, which represents more than 60 percent of the issue, was reoffered at a price to yield 7.08 percent.
The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged on the day.
Corporate bond traders said that prices of most issues in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds were unchanged to up about 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: National Tests Urged for Public Schools

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
A Presidential advisory group recommended to President Bush today the creation for the first time of national examinations for elementary and high school students.
The President's Education Policy Advisory Committee, a diverse group of 25 educators and business leaders, met with Mr. Bush for 50 minutes to discuss their recommendations and to call on him to "regain the crown" as the education President that he has said he wishes to be. The recommendations, which are not yet in final form, carry no legal weight, and it remains to be seen what Mr. Bush can or will do with them. 
 A White House spokesman said the meeting gave the President the opportunity to hear from a number of leaders. "He hasn't offered any position yet," the official said. "It's clear in the past that we do need to measure progress. But he hasn't made up his mind. This wasn't a decision meeting."
A Department of Education background paper released last August said the Administration was willing to support some form of national testing as long as the Federal Government's role was limited.
 
Monitoring Report Urged
 The recommendations urge Mr. Bush to create and issue "a regular report on the tests" so school officials and parents would know how the various tests reflected whatever national standards the White House and the nation's governors develop.
The establishment of national examinations would be politically sensitive. In Japan, Germany and most other industrial nations, student performance is driven by national examinations, but there has been longstanding resistance to such tests in the United States.
Some states fear showing poorly compared to other states; others argue that such tests could lead to a national, standardized curriculum, perhaps in many subjects, and remove control of curriculum from state and local jurisdiction. Still others fear that such examinations could determine a person's educational and career future.
"Teachers would teach to these standards," said Paul H. O'Neill, chief executive officer of the Aluminum Company of America and chairman of the advisory group. Without giving a breakdown of the vote, he said "the majority view of the committee" was to support such standards.
 
Strong Dissenting Voice
 At least one panel member disagreed. Joe Nathan, senior fellow at the Hubert H. Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Minnesota, has argued that American students are already tested too much. He feels that the panel should be investigating new ways of motivating students.
"The Federal Government can't just wave its hand and tell legislatures, 'Don't have your testing program' or tell local districts, 'Don't have your tests'," Mr. Nathan said. "Given the experience we've had with testing, a national test will end up stifling the most effective, the most creative and the finest teachers we have. I would find it ironic that an Administration that came in saying that it wanted to reduce the number of rules and regulations ended up imposing an extremely disruptive and negative set of tests on the country."
But Mr. O'Neill and other members of the advisory group argue that national tests are the only way to reach the national education goals for the year 2000 set by the President and the governors last March.
"The reason to have a national standard is to make sure we change," Mr. O'Neill said.
William T. Brock, former Secretary of Labor, said that giving parents the right to choose the schools their children would attend, a policy favored by the Administration, required establishing national standards so parents would be able to determine where their children would get the best education.
 
Testing for Job Skills
 The National Center on Education and the Economy, a nonprofit group, has also been considering plans to create a national examination to certify that young people have attained the skills and knowledge necessary for either further education or the job market. The Commisssion on the Skills of the American Workforce, a group of education and labor leaders, last June proposed that all 16-year-olds take a test to gain a certificate that employers could require as a job credential.
The only current Federal examination program is the National Assessment of Educational Progress, widely known as NAEP. The program conducts tests in various subjects like mathematics, reading, writing and science at the fourth-, eighth- and 12th-grade levels, reporting what students know but making no judgments about what they ought to know.
As a first step toward those judgments, NAEP is preparing to set national standards for its mathematics tests that would rank student achievement in fourth, eighth and 12th grades as "basic," "proficient" or "advanced," based on what a pupil should be able to do at those levels.
Some have argued that these standards should be the basis of any future national test, but NAEP is having difficulty getting broad agreement within its ranks on what should constitute each achievement level.

HEADLINE: Cutbacks Bring Loss At GlenFed

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16

 BODY:
GlenFed Inc., parent of the nation's fourth-largest savings and loan association, said today that it would add to loan-loss reserves, sell some assets, freeze management salaries and suspend its dividend. The company also said it would eliminate 600 jobs in the next quarter through attrition, but layoffs were not ruled out.
GlenFed said the moves, which it called "necessary and prudent," would result in a $140.8 million loss for the quarter. 
 On the New York Stock Exchange, GlenFed's shares dropped 87.5 cents each, to $4.625. The 15.9 percent decline was among the biggest of the day on the Big Board. In addition, the Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its credit rating to speculative grade on some debt of the Glendale Federal Bank, the company's banking subsidiary.
 
New Capital Rules
 GlenFed, which has $24.4 billion in assets and operates 235 branches of Glendale Federal in California, Washington and Florida, said it wanted to protect itself better from the effects of continued recession, as well as to insure that it stays in compliance with strict new capital requirements intended to keep the industry solvent.
"This positions the company on a pre-emptive basis to continue to meet the capital guidelines," said Keith P. Russell Jr., GlenFed's president.
Analysts said they had expected Glenfed's moves, which follow similar changes at banks and several other large California savings and loans.
In lowering the credit rating, Standard's & Poor's noted that the quarterly loss would cut into the bank's capital levels. S.& P. also said GlenFed's "moderately high exposure" in commercial real estate markets in Calfifornia could leave it vulnerable. But it added that today's moves might ultimately improve GlenFed's earnings power.
 
Reserves Are Increased
 GlenFed said it would add $141.8 million to its loan-loss reserves and reduce the value of some loans and real estate assets by about $75 million. Money was also set aside to cover the sale of the North American Title Company subsidiary to management.
GlenFed said it would carry out cost-cutting measures to save more than $160 million a year beginning within 18 months. The moves include cutting jobs and freezing management salaries for 18 months.
The company's board voted not to declare a quarterly dividend and probably will not resume payments for at least one year.
The quarterly loss compares with net earnings of $39.9 million, or $1.30 a share, in the period a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Drop of 0.6% in U.S. Output Erodes Hopes on Recession

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
A new Government report today showed a surprisingly big decline in industrial output that analysts said eroded confidence in the widely held, though far from unanimous, view that the recession would be brief and mild.
The decline of six-tenths of 1 percent was the third straight drop in production by the nation's factories, mines and utilities and brought the drop for the final quarter of 1990 to an annual rate of nearly 8 percent below that of the July-September period. 
 The drop in output, which many economists had expected would be negligible, showed the economy was still sinking rapidly last month when many analysts believed the decline had lost momentum, said David W. Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, a relative optimist himself. "There's no solace in these numbers for those who think the recession will be short."
 
Diminished Prospects
 The general view remained, however, that while the gross national product would contract during the current quarter, the decline would be less than the 2 to 4 percent that probably occurred in the fourth quarter. If so, this would support the Bush Administration and others in their contention that the worst of the recession is already past, but today's figures did seem to reduce the prospects that a turnaround would come soon. The report on the fourth-quarter G.N.P. is due Jan. 25.
"These output numbers are very weak," said Daniel Friel, an economist at the NCNB Corporation, in Charlotte, N.C.. He added that he found in them none of the signs of stability referred to this week by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, in an article today in The Washington Post.
 
Factory Use Slumps
 In related data, the Federal Reserve also found that utilization of industrial capacity slumped six-tenths of a point, to 80.4 percent, last month, and that utilization in manufacturing slumped nine-tenths of a point, to 79.3 percent.
In other Government reports today, the Labor Department calculated that consumer prices climbed three-tenths of 1 percent last month, slightly more than anticipated, while the Commerce Department disclosed that business inventories rose while sales fell in November. The widely followed ratio of inventories to sales now stands at 1.50, up from 1.48, meaning it would take one and a half months to use up stocks at that the November sales pace. [Page D8.]
The December decline in industrial output, while only one-third as large as the precipitous 1.8 percent drop in November, was still considered sizable. Many analysts had based expectations for little change on a previously reported lengthening of the December workweek, a figure that a Labor Department official had found puzzling.
One possible explanation offered today by economists was that companies have been quicker than usual in this recession to lay off workers and were then forced to use those that remained for longer periods. Another explanation was that Government statisticians use hours worked for gauging many forms of output but that for automobile assembly, which accounted for much of the December decline, they use the actual number of units built.
The decline was disappointing not only in its magnitude but also in its scope. No major market groups posted increases, and much of the 1.9 percent advance in output by utilities was because of colder weather.
If automobiles and trucks are excluded, the Industrial Production Index fell four-tenths of 1 percent; if motor vehicles and parts as well are excluded, the decline was three-tenths of 1 percent, the Fed reported.
Production of consumer goods was unchanged, but business equipment fell nine-tenths of 1 percent and construction supplies fell 1.5 percent to a level 6 percent below that of July. Output of materials fell 1 percent, mainly reflecting parts for motor vehicles.
 
Mines and Utilities Up
 By industry, factory output dropped nine-tenths of 1 percent, half the November plunge, while mining rose six-tenths of 1 percent. The hefty increase for utilities still recovered barely half the ground lost in November.
The utilization rate for primary processing industries tumbled 1.4 percentage points, compared with a seven-tenths of a point decline for advanced processing. "The drop in primary processing industries reflected significant output cutbacks at industries that supply the auto industry, like primary metals, fabricated metals products, rubber and plastics products and textiles," the Fed said.
The Industrial Production Index, at 107.1 percent of its 1987 average, now stands 1.4 percent below its level of December 1989.
Today's report also showed that the Fed reduced its estimate of November output to a decline of 1.8 percent instead of the 1.7 percent initially estimated. At the same time, however, it reduced the October decline to seven-tenths of 1 percent, from the nine-tenths of 1 percent previously estimated.

HEADLINE: A Short War Will Test Recession Assumptions

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
A brief Persian Gulf war would test one of the great assumptions about the national recession: that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait precipitated the recession and an American military victory will make the economy rebound. But evidence is accumulating that the recession has taken on a life of its own and will probably endure.
The phenomenon that links the gulf crisis and the economy, in the minds of many economists, is public confidence, which deteriorated sharply after the invasion on Aug. 2. Those who measure public confidence -- the Conference Board and the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center -- at first said the gulf crisis had precipitated the deterioration, in part because of rising oil prices. Now they argue that other factors are unnerving Americans, inhibiting the spending that invigorates the economy. 
 "When the crisis in the gulf is over, we might have a moment or two of euphoria -- a somewhat more positive consumer," said Fabian Linden, who directs the Conference Board's monthly consumer surveys. "But the euphoria will soon wear off if we don't resolve the basic issues confronting Americans."
 
Large Military Stockpiles
 Unlike past American wars, a prolonged war would not stimulate the economy through stepped-up production of war materiel. Equipment stockpiled in the last decade is reportedly sufficient to carry the United States forces for an extended period.
But the Bush Administration is hoping that the war will be short. It has argued that after a brief conflict the economy will rebound -- a contention that the consumer-confidence surveys do not seem to support. Mr. Linden and Richard T. Curtin, the University of Michigan's director of consumer research, list rising unemployment in recent months as the chief public concern dampening confidence, war or no war. Other blows to confidence, they said, have come from the collapse in real estate prices; the growing number of bank failures, particularly in New England in recent weeks, and a sharp decline in industrial production since October.
The Bush Administration has attributed the recession mainly to the Persian Gulf crisis, arguing in effect that if the war ends in a quick military victory, then a strengthening economy will stimulate hiring and resolve the unemployment problem. Mr. Bush's top economic advisers restated this message at a meeting with the President on Tuesday.
Similarly, the Federal Reserve has invoked the gulf crisis as a justification for its reluctance to cut interest rates more quickly than it has. While lower rates might help to stimulate the economy, Fed officials say, they might also encourage too much spending and investment once the Persian Gulf conflict ends and public confidence returns. Such exuberant outlays could cause shortages that drive up prices.
But if a resolution of the gulf crisis may not rescue the economy from recession, several weeks or months of fighting in the Persian Gulf can prolong it. Aside from the fresh blow to public confidence, economists say, oil prices will probably rise well above their present level of about $30 a barrel. That would greatly discourage spending as both consumers and businesses diverted funds and reduced profits to cover energy costs.
 
Cost of Oilfield Damage
"If the war is prolonged and there is damage to oilfields, that adds to the economic problems that already existed before August," said Joseph Minarik, senior economist on Congress's Joint Economic Committee.
In addition to this danger, military spending will fail to give the economy a boost because of the large military stockpiles. During the first four months of the Persian Gulf deployment, for example, the Defense Personnel Support Center disbursed $1.4 billion in equipment and food, or only $230 million more than in an average four-month period before the crisis.
"Whether they're eating in Saudi Arabia or they're eating in Houston, Tex., they're still eating the same amount of food," said William H. Ernst Jr., a Support Center spokesman.
Similarly, American troops in the Saudi Arabian desert are using tents from storage. "They never wear out; you roll them up, put them in preservative containers and store them," said Jack L. Allen, a spokesman for the Defense Construction Supply Center in Columbus, Ohio. "Some of this stuff dates back to Korea and Vietnam."
 
Spending on Fuel
 Perhaps the biggest materiel cost has been for fuel, to transport troops to the gulf and for operations there. Some $410 million in extra fuel contracts were awarded during the first four months, the Defense Department reports. In addition, numerous contracts have been awarded to ferry troops to Saudi Arabia and provide other services.
But these expenditures do not provide the boost to the economy that comes through war production. World War II is the classic example of a conflict that helped pull the nation out of a slump through such production. But even smaller-scale conflicts also lifted the American economy. The Korean War required a big increase in the production of weapons and other materiel, and this new industrial output in the early 1950's helped to end a recession. Production during the Vietnam War also made the economy boom in the late 1960's.
 
Decline Since the Spring
 The departure from precedent makes the nation's economic predicament hard to anticipate. The economy has been in decline since last spring, because of too much home and office construction, huge corporate debts built up in the 1980's, the weakness among the nation's banks resulting from unpaid real estate loans, and a reluctance among the banks to make new loans that also might fail. Cuts in lending dampen economic activity.
The upshot was that the Persian Gulf crisis accelerated a downturn already in progress, producing what Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist, calls "a long decline exacerbated by a sharp drop in August."
"The unwinding of the 80's got entangled with Kuwait and they are now so mixed up that even a positive, short-term resolution in the Persian Gulf would not solve the recession," Mr. Gordon said. "The damage to confidence and to business activity has been done."
 
Wall St. Optimism
 Mr. Gordon and some other economists, among them Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economic science, argue that even without the gulf crisis, the economy would have tipped into recession in late summer. But among economic forecasters, particularly those employed on Wall Street and in the banking industry, a more optimistic view reigns, according to the Blue Chip Economic Indicators, which is a monthly survey of 50 well-known forecasters.
"Three out of four of them believe that the trigger for the recession was the gulf crisis, and if it ends soon, the economy will begin to recover in the third quarter," said Robert J. Eggert, Blue Chip's president. "They don't think it would be a spectacular recovery, but the economy would begin to come back."
Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, makes a case for an economic revival after a brief gulf war. The key to his argument is real disposable personal income -- the money available for spending, adjusted for inflation. This income growth slowed last year, but was still positive in the third quarter and only went into sharp decline after the gulf crisis had driven up oil prices and the inflation rate.
By driving down oil prices, a quick victory will bolster purchasing power despite the numerous layoffs, bankruptcies and plant closings in recent months, Mr. Roach says.
"Initially, consumer confidence would improve," Mr. Roach said. "Businesses that had cut back in preparation for the worst would relax. Production would grow again and there would be some rehiring, and out of that process would come renewed income growth."

HEADLINE: For News, 3 Options

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
By declaring yesterday that the newspaper cannot continue to operate as it is, The Daily News narrowed its options to three: settling promptly with its striking unions, negotiating a sale or closing the paper.
 Certainly, there are formidable obstacles to both a sale and a negotiated settlement of the 12-week-old strike. 
 There are three principal issues to be resolved in the negotiations: the status of replacement workers, outstanding lawsuits filed by both unions and management, and The News's determination to win a contract that includes "management rights," which is shorthand for greatly increased control of the workplace.
 
800 Replacement Workers
 Since the strike began on Oct. 25, The News's strategy has been to publish and deliver the paper by using a combination of nonunion employees, union members who crossed the picket line and about 800 replacement workers.
The News has repeatedly characterized the new workers as "permanent replacements," suggesting that they would keep their jobs even after a settlement. But at least some of the "permanent replacements" signed a document agreeing that The News was free to dismiss them at any time.
Since the strike began, The News has been operating with far fewer workers and presumably, in the event of a settlement, the paper would not need any more workers than it already has.
The unions have insisted that all 2,300 striking workers be rehired and given seniority ahead of the permanent replacements so that, in a layoff that would almost inevitably come as part of any new contract, the remaining jobs would belong to union members.
 
Potential Lawsuit
 The News has said the status of the permanent replacements is subject to negotiation, which suggests to union leaders that they can be removed.
But in removing a whole category of workers because they were not in the union, company officals concede that they may be inviting a lawsuit for discrimination as well as a public relations problem. Many of the replacement workers are women and minority-group members, while many of those they replaced are white men.
Still, if the replacement workers remain, the incentive for unions to settle is nonexistent; there would be virtually no jobs for strikers to take.
Union leaders said that if a contract agreement was reached, they think the issue of lawsuits could be resolved relatively easily by both sides dropping all suits except those involving things like throwing bricks through windshields.
But neither unions nor News management have exhibited any inclination to make significant changes in their fundamental stances on a contract. The News has insisted on management rights that would leave staffing, overtime and other key issues to management's discretion. Unions have said such open-ended authority would effectively break the unions.
 
Dimmer Prospect of Sale
 Union leaders have said from the strike's outset that they wanted the Chicago-based Tribune Company -- which owns The News -- to sell it, something that until yesterday the company has been unwilling to consider.
But while there was some interest in buying The News before the strike, when it had circulation of 1.1 million and a steady flow of advertising revenue, the prospects are now much dimmer. The paper has lost at least half its circulation and almost all of its advertising.
"There are no prospects, in my opinion," said W. Dean Singleton, chief executive officer of Media News Group Inc., who said union leaders had approached him earlier about buying the paper.
Sam S. McKeel, president of The Sun-Times Company, another prime prospect in earlier months, said yesterday that he was not interested.
But Patrick A. Flanagan, managing director of The Fidelis Group, a Boston investment banking firm that has been trying to broker a sale through the unions, said that interest was still high because of the paper's position in the market and its prospects for recovering what has been lost. And a spokesman for Robert Maxwell, the British printing and publishing magnate, said he was investigating the situation.
 
Concessions Needed
 One major concern to any prospective buyer would be the approximately $100 million in job guarantees that go with the paper's ownership. Unions also estimate there is a $25 million liability in underfunded pension benefits and a similar amount in severance liability should the paper be closed. Even if the Tribune Company gave the paper to someone, these liabilities would represent a major potential expense to a buyer.
Any prospective buyer must get concessions from unions that would be similar to those sought by the Tribune Company, perhaps in exchange for a stake in the new ownership.
A new owner would also have to foot the bill during a rebuilding process that might or might not restore The News to former circulation and advertising levels and do so during the worst advertising recession in recent memory. Eventually, a new owner would have to assume that a major investment in new presses would be unavoidable, which would mean risking a great deal of capital.
And as part of the deal, a new owner would probably ask union members to give up their severance pay guarantees, which some union leaders have said could be worth $25 million and which union members would be reluctant to lose. Last year, many members of the Newspaper Guild were prepared to vote against a contract that would save The New York Post until severance packages were guaranteed.
Should a sale prove impossible, The News would probably make one final offer to unions. In the face of an abyss and a deadline, union members might be willing to accept what they have thus far spurned.
And should that ultimatum fail, The News will almost certainly close its doors.

HEADLINE: THE DINKINS BUDGET;
Dinkins Offers $29 Billion Budget With Cutbacks and Layoffs

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins presented a $29.3 billion preliminary budget for New York City yesterday whose mix of pain and uncertainty prompted the City Council and some fiscal watchdogs to suggest that he had not gone far enough in making cuts and led others to complain about how far he went.
The Mayor's plan, the first step in a long political dance before the budget is to be adopted in June, was narrowly balanced with thousands of layoffs -- most of them in the Board of Education -- service cuts and a range of proposed taxes and unpopular fees, even as the city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, warned that "the problem's going to get worse." 
 Striving to maintain the balanced city budget required by law, Mr. Dinkins announced plans to reduce hiring sharply, eliminating through layoffs or attrition nearly 25,000 full- and part-time city jobs that had been planned. That would leave about 8,500 fewer full-time workers on the city payroll by June than the 247,000 there were last November, the first annual decline in nearly a decade.
 
Property Tax Increase
 To help close a projected gap between revenues and expenditures of $2.2 billion for the fiscal year that starts July 1, Mr. Dinkins proposed $580 million in new or higher taxes, including a property tax increase that would mean a $60-a-year rise for a typical homeowner and an increase in the personal income tax that would cost an average resident $75.
The Mayor also proposed a new 1 percent tax on the value of motor vehicles to replace the current flat $15 annual automobile use tax. It would vary according to the age and worth of a car, ranging from $216 for a new $30,000 luxury sedan to $58 for a new $8,000 subcompact car.
"It is my hope that while no one is going to be happy with this budget, everyone is going to be impacted to some degree," Mr. Dinkins told a news conference at City Hall.
In an indication of the inextricable link between city and state finances, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo issued a statement saying the Mayor's plan "represents many difficult choices" but warning that "it is also clear that the city and state are in a worsening economy, which could cause further erosion in our financial plans."
State Comptroller Edward V. Regan questioned whether the Mayor's cuts went deep enough. Mr. Regan also announced yesterday that state tax collections in December fell $268 million below projections.
Officials in both the Legislature and Cuomo administration said the gap in the state budget for its coming fiscal year, which starts April 1, could be close to $5 billion, or $1 billion higher than previous estimates, while the gap for the current fiscal year could be more than $800 million, farhigher than previous estimates.
Mr. Cuomo, who amid his own deep troubles has expressed skepticism about the city's resolve to keep its fiscal house in order and has warned city officials to expect little help, received the plan as chairman of the State Financial Control Board. The watchdog agency, set up in the city fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, could reassume binding powers over the city's budget if it fell out of balance. Leaders of the City Council, whose approval is needed for Mr. Dinkins's budget and whose assent is required for new taxes, acknowledged that there would be some more taxes but did not commit their members, who are facing a special election this year, to any specifics. The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, questioned whether the budget was still growing too much, saying, "We will seek to eliminate waste and duplication before one dollar of new taxes is raised."
Spokesmen for legislative leaders in Albany, whose approval is needed for all but the property tax proposal, said it was premature to discuss the Mayor's plan until Mr. Cuomo presents his own budget in two weeks and the Mayor and City Council reach a consensus. They voiced skepticism about the auto tax and dismissed a smattering of other proposed taxes, including a 5-cent city gasoline tax, that have repeatedly failed to win approval in the past.
 
No Warm Reception
 "Any new taxes for the city at this point will not be warmly received in our house," said John E. McArdle, a spokesman for the Republican State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino of Oyster Bay, L.I.
Because the effects on the city of the state's own enormous budget problems are not yet known, Mr. Dinkins was hamstrung in saying just how many cuts might really be needed and which ones were floated as red flags to prod as much help as possible from the state, like the warning of as many as 6,500 layoffs in the school system.
City officials said they hoped negotiations with the state on delaying cuts in education aid until this summer and with unions representing the teachers and other school employees about deferring pay or taking unpaid furloughs could reduce the need for many such layoffs.
While the plan assumes no increase in state aid, it does not account for a potential decrease. "We're very leery about the state budget gap," Mr. Michael said.
Speaking of the future, Mr. Dinkins said, "We have to continue to regroup as we go."
 
Detailed but Tentative
 Because of the rapidly changing condition of city and state finances, the Mayor's plan was both more complex and detailed and more tentative than usual, and reaction from the fiscal monitors and public officials who began sorting it out yesterday was mixed.
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group financed by businesses, praised the Mayor's commitment to keeping the budget balanced but said he had not gone far enough. "Despite the fact that the local economy has turned around, the Mayor hasn't gotten the ship of state turned around yet," he said.
Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the Financial Control Board, said: "It's premature to draw a lot of conclusions that he did or didn't make the tough choices. Clearly, he's eliminating a lot of jobs, so one can't say he's not responding to the difficult circumstances.
 
No Deep Cuts for Police
 In the Dinkins plan, the cuts in services ranged widely, though not evenly, among city agencies. The Police Department -- which along with the Board of Education is among the agencies where cuts can most quickly be made -- was spared the deep cuts that most other departments were forced to make, having its spending cut by 2.2 percent, compared with more than 17 percent in some other agencies.
After a string of highly publicized crimes last summer, Mr. Dinkins proposed last fall a special $450 million tax package to finance the hiring of thousands of new police officers. With delicate negotiations on that still under way in the Legislature, he had little choice but to turn to the schools as a source of cuts.
Of more than 16,000 potential layoffs of full-time and part-time city workers outlined in the plan, more than 10,000 would come in the Board of Education, a total that Mr. Vallone and other officials said would never be tolerated.
But Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, who has previously resisted cuts, said: "Even the most cynical or jaded budgeteers know that cuts of this magnitude are tantamount to mortgaging our children's future."
Mr. Dinkins proposed cuts in other areas dear to the hearts of his liberal constituency, planning to reduce contracts for family planning services by 70 percent, increasing caseloads for social workers assigned to AIDS sufferers, delaying expansion of drug treatment programs, elminating city hospital pharmacy services for outpatients.
 
Delay for Recycling
 The Mayor's plan would also delay expansion of garbage recycling until next year, which critics said made it more likely that Mr. Dinkins would have to support trash incineration, and that could compromise a campaign promise.
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan said, "Where many cuts represented a choice not between bone and fat but between bone and bone, the Mayor has for the most part done a thoughtful job." But, she said, the budget does "come at a great cost."
Besides all the cuts and taxes, the plan would raise a host of fees, installing 1,000 parking meters in the theater district to charge 75 cents an hour for evening parking that is now free, cutting in half the time a coin will buy in 18,000 other meters, doubling the Staten Island ferry fare for the second time in two years, to $1, and doubling the price for ballfield permits in the parks, to $8.
Meanwhile, negotiations broke down yesterday afternoon between the city, the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers on a proposal for school employees to defer three to six days of wages as a way to prevent the layoffs of up to 4,000 workers.
Teachers' union officials said the stumbling block was the city's refusal to guarantee that there would be no layoffs if the proposal was accepted. The union has opposed another cost-cutting proposal to furlough school employees for several days.
 
Major Elements of The Dinkins Plan
 
Increase taxes to raise $580 million.
 
Cut 25,000 jobs through layoffs or attrition.
 
Eliminate 400 office positions and reduce other areas of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, saving $28 million.
 
Eliminate outpatient pharmacy services for insured patients.
 
Delay expanding drug-treatment programs.
 
Delay recycling programs. Eliminate the Sanitation Department's "Clean Team."
 
Double the fare on the Staten Island Ferry to $1.

HEADLINE: Transit Agency Plans Improvements

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Electronic turnstiles that deter fare beaters. A subway tracking system that tells passengers waiting on the platform when the next train will arrive. Emergency call boxes in each subway car that allow passengers to talk to the conductor.
These are just a few things that New York City transit officials proposed yesterday as part of a $7.3 billion five-year plan to continue rebuilding the region's transit system and to make the city's subways and buses safer and more convenient for passengers. 
 Under the program, officials would continue to buy new subway cars and buses, lay new track, replace signals and other obsolete equipment, and rebuild maintenance and storage yards but they also plan to rehabilitate subway stations and make them safer by installing new lighting, signage, and public-address systems.
 
A Chain of Rebuilding Programs
 But money for the capital-improvement program, which is financed by the city, state, and Federal governments, is uncertain. The program requires the approval of the State Legislature, which is scrambling to close mounting budget deficits in the wake of declining tax revenues.
Transit officials presented the plan yesterday to the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's parent agency. The plan is an extension of a $16 billion 10-year program that ends this year and a link in a chain of rebuilding programs that officials say might stretch into the next century.
M.T.A. officials will review the plan over the next month and present it along with other rebuilding proposals for the region's commuter railroads to the state in March.
Some state legislators have expressed their desire to finance another M.T.A. capital program, but the lawmakers have also said that in these tight economic times, they may limit such financing to necessities such as keeping the mechanics of the system in good working order. If the state's financial picture does not improve, the lawmakers said, many of the "customer oriented" items in the plan may not receive financing.
 
New Fans in the Subways
 In their presentation before the M.T.A. board, Transit Authority officials said that the new capital money would allow them to respond much faster to emergencies like the subway tunnel fire that killed two people last month.
The officials said that a new capital program would allow them to replace ventilation fans in subway tunnels and install state-of-the-art subway tracking and radio systems.
The current system for tracking and radioing trains is outdated and contributed to the agency's delay in responding to the subway fire, offiials admit. Many of the tunnel ventilation fans, including those nearest to the fire, have not been working for years.
"The automated tracking system that we seek in this plan will appreciably cut down on the time needed to locate trains and reroute them in emergencies," said Tom Prendergast, the authority's senior vice president for operations.
Alan F. Kiepper, the authority's president, used an old analogy to describe the importance of the proposed capital program: "Rebuilding the subway system is like eating an elephant. You have to eat it one bite at a time. We have already taken two big bites and we want take another one."
Some mass-transit advocacy groups said that the capital plan was ambitious and expressed doubt that the authority would receive all the money that it was seeking.
"It's a very ambitious program and I am concerned that they won't be able to accomplish it," said Beverly Dolinsky, executive director of the Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee, a consumer transit advocacy group.
About $4.8 billion or 66 percent of the capital program money will be used to replace equipment and structures -- like fans, tunnel lighting, signals, communications systems, track, power lines, stations, and yards.
To reduce crime, transit officials propose spending about $569 million to install new station lighting, public-address systems, signs, police communications, passenger call boxes on platforms, and intercoms in each subway car. The officials also plan to eliminate some cul-de-sac areas in stations that have high levels of crime.
To increase ridership, the officials plan to spend $1.1 billion to replace escalators and elevators, install electronic turnstiles throughout the entire system, connect the 63d Street Tunnel to Queens Boulevard, and develop centers where bus and subway lines merge, among other measures.
