HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: THE PRESIDENT;
Transcript of the Comments by Bush on the Air Strikes Against the Iraqis

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Bush's remarks in the Oval Office last night about the Persian Gulf action, as recorded by The New York Times:
Just two hours ago, allied air forces began an attack on military targets in Iraq and Kuwait. These attacks continue as I speak. Ground forces are not engaged. 
 This conflict started Aug. 2, when the dictator of Iraq invaded a small and helpless neighbor. Kuwait, a member of the Arab League and a member of the United Nations, was crushed, its people brutalized. Five months ago, Saddam Hussein started this cruel war against Kuwait; tonight, the battle has been joined.
This military action, taken in accord with United Nations resolutions and with the consent of the United States Congress, follows months of constant and virtually endless diplomatic activity on the part of the United Nations, the United States and many, many other countries.
Arab leaders sought what became known as an Arab solution, only to conclude that Saddam Hussein was unwilling to leave Kuwait. Others traveled to Baghdad in a variety of efforts to restore peace and justice. Our Secretary of State, James Baker, held an historic meeting in Geneva, only to be totally rebuffed.
This past weekend, in a last-ditch effort, the Secretary General of the United Nations went to the Middle East with peace in his heart -- his second such mission. And he came back from Baghdad with no progress at all in getting Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait.
 
No Choice but to Attack
 Now, the 28 countries with forces in the gulf area have exhausted all reasonable efforts to reach a peaceful resolution, and have no choice but to drive Saddam from Kuwait by force. We will not fail.
As I report to you, air attacks are under way against military targets in Iraq. We are determined to knock out Saddam Hussein's nuclear bomb potential. We will also destroy his chemical weapons facilities. Much of Saddam's artillery and tanks will be destroyed. Our operations are designed to best protect the lives of all the coalition forces by targeting Saddam's vast military arsenal.
Initial reports from General Schwartzkopf are that our operations are proceeding according to plan. Our objectives are clear: Saddam Hussein's forces will leave Kuwait. The legitimate government of Kuwait will be restored to its rightful place, and Kuwait will once again be free.
Iraq will eventually comply with all relevant United Nations resolutions, and then, when peace is restored, it is our hope that Iraq will live as a peaceful and cooperative member of the family of nations, thus enhancing the security and stability of the gulf.
 
'Why Not Wait?'
 Some may ask, why act now? Why not wait? The answer is clear. The world could wait no longer. Sanctions, though having some effect, showed no signs of accomplishing their objective. Sanctions were tried for well over five months, and we and our allies concluded that sanctions alone would not force Saddam from Kuwait.
While the world waited, Saddam Hussein systematically raped, pillaged and plundered a tiny nation no threat to his own. He subjected the people of Kuwait to unspeakable atrocities, and among those maimed and murdered, innocent children.
While the world waited, Saddam sought to add to the chemical weapons arsenal he now possesses, an infinitely more dangerous weapon of mass destruction -- a nuclear weapon. And while the world waited, while the world talked peace and withdrawal, Saddam Hussein dug in and moved massive forces into Kuwait.
While the world waited, while Saddam stalled, more damage was being done to the fragile economies of the Third World, emerging democracies of Eastern Europe, to the entire world, including to our own economy.
The United States, together with the United Nations, exhausted every means at our disposal to bring this crisis to a peaceful end. However, Saddam clearly felt that by stalling and threatening and defying the United Nations, he could weaken the forces arrayed against him.
While the world waited, Saddam Hussein met every overture of peace with open contempt. While the world prayed for peace, Saddam prepared for war.
I had hoped that when the United States Congress, in historic debate, took its resolute action, Saddam would realize he could not prevail, and would move out of Kuwait in accord with the United Nations resolutions. He did not do that. Instead, he remained intransigent, certain that time was on his side.
Saddam was warned over and over again to comply with the will of the United Nations, leave Kuwait or be driven out. Saddam has arrogantly rejected all warnings. Instead he tried to make this a dispute between Iraq and the United States of America.
Well he failed. Tonight 28 nations -- countries from five continents, Europe and Asia, Africa and the Arab League -- have forces in the Gulf area standing shoulder to shoulder against Saddam Hussein. These countries had hoped the use of force could be avoided. Regrettably, we now believe that only force will make him leave.
Prior to ordering our forces into battle, I instructed our military commanders to take every necessary step to prevail as quickly as possible, and with the greatest degree of protection possible for American and Allied servicemen and women. I've told the American people before that this will not be another Vietnam, and I repeat this here tonight. Our troops will have the best possible support in the entire world, and they will not be asked to fight with one hand tied behind their back. I'm hopeful that this fighting will not go on for long and that casualties will be held to an absolute minimum.
 
'An Historic Moment'
 This is an historic moment. We have in this past year made great progress in ending the long era of conflict and cold war. We have before us the opportunity to forge for ourselves and for future generations a new world order, a world where the rule of law, not the law of the jungle, governs the conduct of nations.
When we are successful, and we will be, we have a real chance at this new world order, an order in which a credible United Nations can use its peacekeeping role to fulfill the promise and vision of the U.N.'s founders. We have no argument with the people of Iraq. Indeed, for the innocents caught in this conflict, I pray for their safety.
Our goal is not the conquest of Iraq. It is the liberation of Kuwait. It is my hope that somehow the Iraqi people can, even now, convince their dictator that he must lay down his arms, leave Kuwait and let Iraq itself rejoin the family of peace loving nations.
Thomas Paine wrote many years ago: "These are the times that try men's souls." Those well-known words are so very true today. But even as planes of the multi-national forces attack Iraq, I prefer to think of peace, not war. I am convinced not only that we will prevail, but that out of the horror of combat will come the recognition that no nation can stand against a world united. No nation will be permitted to brutally assault its neighbor.
No President can easily commit our sons and daughters to war. They are the nation's finest. Ours is an all-volunteer force, magnificently trained, highly motivated. The troops know why they're there. And listen to what they say, because they've said it better than any President or Prime Minister ever could. Listen to Hollywood Huddleston, Marine lance corporal. He says: "Let's free these people so we can go home and be free again." And he's right. The terrible crimes and tortures committed by Saddam's henchmen against the innocent people of Kuwait are an affront to mankind and a challenge to the freedom of all.
 
'Worth Fighting For'
 Listen to one of our great officers out there, Marine Lieut. Gen. Walter Boomer. He said: "There are things worth fighting for. A world in which brutality and lawlessness are allowed to go unchecked isn't the kind of world we're going to want to live in."
Listen to Master Sgt. J. P. Kendall of the 82d Airborne: "We're here for more than just the price of a gallon of gas. What we're doing is going to chart the future of the world for the next hundred years. It's better to deal with this guy now than five years from now."
And finally, we should all sit up and listen to Jackie Jones, an Army lieutenant, when she says, "If we let him get away with this, who knows what's going to be next."
I've called upon Hollywood and Walter and J. P. and Jackie and all their courageous comrades-in-arms to do what must be done. Tonight, America and the world are deeply grateful to them and to their families.
And let me say to everyone listening or watching tonight: When the troops we've sent in finish their work, I'm determined to bring them home as soon as possible. Tonight, as our forces fight, they and their families are in our prayers.
May God bless each and every one of them and the coalition forces at our side in the Gulf, and may He continue to bless our nation, the United States of America.

HEADLINE: Businesses Brace for Temporary Sales Slump

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
As the nation went to war against Iraq, many business executives braced themselves last night for a possible sales slump. Retailers and others who depend on confident consumers or low gasoline prices said they expect their businesses to suffer, at least in the short term.
But a few industries, like long-distance telephone companies, said the public's apprehensiveness might actually help their business. 
 Retailers said they expect shoppers to stay home initially as they absorb the news. Whether sales rebound, they said, depends on the war's success.
"People won't be interested in going out shopping frivolously, for a little while at least," said Russell Solomon, the president of Tower Records, a chain based in Sacramento, Calif. The longer-term effect is uncertain, he said.
 
Effect on Markets
 Financial services executives have said in recent days that a war might compound the damage their firms suffered from the recession and the dearth of active individual investors. But bond and equity traders said yesterday that they expected volatility to multiply their opportunities.
James F. Higgins, president of the Dean Witter Financial Group, said his company had told its brokers to guard against panic. "In these times, we can have very volatile markets," he said. "It is very important not to fall into the pitfall of short-term emotionally driven decisions."
George L. Ball, the chairman and chief executive of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., urged investors to avoid quick reactions. "To the extent that investors base decisions on the commencement of a war, which has long been anticipated, they would be making a mistake," he said.
Other companies expressed fear that higher gasoline prices would reduce travel. "A great deal of our business comes by car from Southern California," said Phil Cooper, a spokesman for the Caesars Palace casino in Las Vegas, Nev. A long war or higher fuel prices could well reduce this traffic, he said, adding, "I don't think people are fleeing the casinos, but there is a tone of great concern."
 
Domestic Travel May Rise
 But in Los Angeles, a Hilton Hotels Corporation executive said domestic travel might improve as Americans shun travel abroad. "Since our company is principally within the United States, I would think that people might give further consideration to traveling here," said William C. Lebo Jr., Hilton's senior vice president and general counsel. "That would benefit us."
Within the military industry, executives at the Hughes Aircraft Company, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, assumed Hughes's missiles were being deployed in the Persian Gulf. The company manufactures TOW anti-tank missiles and other missiles used by Navy and Air Force jets.
Richard Dore, a spokesman for Hughes, said the company expected no quick reorders of missiles to replace used supplies. "I'm sure the military has more than a one- or two-day supply," he said.
In fact, Mr. Dore said Hughes executives were worried that the expense of the Middle East war would require cuts by the Pentagon in the future.
 
Harm to Military Industry
 "A lot of this action is being paid for out of current defense budgets," he said. "They have to be taking that money from somewhere. Unless that money is somehow replaced this could actually be very damaging to the defense industry."
William T. Esrey, the chairman and chief executive of United Telecommunications Inc. and its major subsidiary, U S Sprint, said he expects the long-distance industry to benefit as Americans make calls to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis.
"I think you'll see a substantial effect," he said. When he heard about the American strike against Baghdad, he reached for the phone. "I talked to my family," he said. "It's human instinct."
Bert C. Roberts Jr., the president of the MCI Communications Corporation, said the long-distance carriers would benefit from the extra calling in proportion to their market shares.
MCI will give special priority to Government communications during the crisis, he said.
 
Worries About Morale
 Some executives said they worried about the war's effect on employee morale.
"I think like a lot of us, I'm still in shock," said Sandra L. Kurtzig, president and chief executive of ASK Computer Systems, a software company in Mountain View, Calif.
Ms. Kurtzig said she heard the news while in a meeting with employees, some of whom are only 21 or 22 years old and could be called to fight if a draft were reinstated. "These employees were 3, 4, 5 years old when the Vietnam War ended," she said. "It's amazing to me how little understanding they have about what war is."
She said company travel would be reduced and might be eliminated because of the fear of terrorism. "If any employees felt concerned about traveling, they certainly would not have to do it," she said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Volatile Trading Expected After Dollar's Drop in Asia

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Traders said last night that they expect the currency markets in New York to be volatile today, responding, as one dealer said, to just "fragments of news." But they expect that the surprising fall of the dollar overnight should continue unless news from the Persian Gulf does not remain positive for the U.S.-led coalition.
"We haven't heard from the Iraqis yet," said one trader last night. "We are dealing more in a psychological market than a financial one." 
 Several banks in New York had some extra staff in last night to be ready to respond to the beginning of a war. The same was true in Europe.
After just a brief rally the dollar fell sharply throughout Asia overnight, outfoxing those who had thought the dollar would rise when war began in the Persian Gulf.
Traders in New York said that there were reports that both the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the Bank of Japan were selling dollars in Asia as part of an expected effort to calm markets and prevent an overreaction to the attack. Financial officials both in the United States and elsewhere have said recently that they would make efforts to keep all financial markets calm.
In addition, they said that many traders in the market who had bought dollars in anticipation of it rising began to sell when they heard reports of the intervention and the rally ran out of steam.
"A lot of people were anticipating or afraid of the fact that the dollar would move up with a war," said a trader at a major bank in New York. "Once that it was apparent that this was not gong to be the case, the world changed its mind about the dollar."
He also added that once the concern about the war is pushed aside in investors mind, the focus will turn back to the economic fundamentals for the dollar, all of which are bad. The United States is in a recession and the Federal Reserve is expected to continue to lower interest rates here, which will weaken the dollar further.
In Philadelphia, where the Stock Exchange conducts night trading in foreign currency options, about 1,000 option contracts were traded in the first hour after the attack, a spokesman said.
As overnight traders in the foreign currency options market in Philadelphia learned of the apparent success of the initial raid, just after 9 P.M. Eastern standard time, the dollar defied expectations and began to drift lower. Arnold Staloff, a partner in Bloom Staloff Corporation, said the most likely cause was that central banks around the world, coordinated by the Federal Reserve System, were selling dollars to prevent a strong surge in price.
The dollar ended trading in New York yesterday at 136.83 yen and 1.5462 marks, compared with 135.73 yen and 1.5420 marks on Tuesday.
In trading in New York yesterday, the British pound fell to $1.9050 from late Tuesday's $1.9095.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.2890 Swiss francs, up from 1.2845; 5.2605 French francs, up from 5.2420; 1,163.50 Italian lire, up from 1,160.00.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Reacting to War
The opening of hostilities pushed up oil prices by as much as $7 a barrel in cash trading. But some large U.S. oil companies quickly said they would not change retail gasoline prices. [Page D1.]
In Tokyo today, the yen soared against the dollar and stock prices moved higher within hours of the first reports that air raids had begun. [D1.]
If the Persian Gulf war turns out to be brief, it will test one of the great assumptions about the national economy: that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait precipitated the recession. [D1.]
It is uncertain how the financial markets will react today, but traders indicated that a heavy selloff of stocks looked less likely than was originally feared. [D1.]
The three broadcast networks found their images as news leaders damaged by early dominance of the coverage by CNN. [D10.]
 
The Economy
Industrial output posted a surprisingly big decline, according to a Government report. [D8.]
Consumer prices rose 0.3 percent in December, the Labor Department said. [D8.]
Total sales by businesses fell 1.2 percent in November, helping to push inventories up 0.3 percent, the Government said. [D8.]
Insurance company executives in the U.S. predict their losses will be small now that war has erupted in the Persian Gulf. [D8.]
 
Companies
A.T.& T. has received a strong show of support for its takeover bid for NCR, reporting that it had received tenders for about 70 percent of the computer maker's common stock. [D1.]
AMR reported a loss of $215.1 million in the fourth quarter, the worst quarterly loss in company history. [D2.]
Ameritech announced a sharp drop in profits, and Wall Street analysts greeted the report as a poor omen for other results. [D5.]
GlenFed said it would add to loan-loss reserves, sell some assets, freeze management salaries and suspend its dividend. [D10.]
Digital Equipment reported that profits fell 28 percent, but analysts were pleased. [D5.]
Primerica reported that it had earned $98.8 million, or 89 cents a share, in the fourth quarter. [D12.]
Armco took a step toward becoming a bigger force in the stainless-steel market by agreeing to buy Cyclops. [D5.]
The Daily News threatened to close down soon or seek a buyer unless it stemmed heavy financial losses. [B1.]
 
 Markets
U.S. stocks defied war fears and actually rose a little, just hours before shooting started. The Dow rose 18.32, to 2,508.91. [D12.]
Comments by Greenspan were the main cause of a slight drop in the prices of Treasury securities. [D18.]
Currency trading was expected to be volatile today, traders said, after reports that the Fed and the Bank of Japan were selling dollars in Asia in an effort to calm markets. [D19.]
Gold prices climbed nearly $7 an ounce in trading on cash markets around the world after war erupted, slipping back to register gains of about $1.50 above its New York close at $403. [D19.]
 Today's Columns
Just hours before Pan Am filed for bankruptcy protection, management was still not certain it would have enough money to avoid liquidation. Talking Deals. [D2.]
Some analysts regard Nestle as a haven for investors amid the current tension and economic slowdown, even though it has been hurt by the weak dollar and U.S. competition. Market Place. [D12.]
Omnicom is negotiating to buy a minority stake in Abbott Mead Vickers. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D10.]

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Shaving Nickels From the Budget At City Hall

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
"Now more than ever," Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday as he sketched his latest budget strategy, "New York City's most precious natural resource is its collective imagination."
His four-year financial plan -- a preliminary budget, to be sure -- appeared to leave that potential resource largely untapped for the time being. Rather, the administration's 275-page agency-by-agency template for pruning expenses nickeled and dimed dozens of municipal programs. The economies would save hundreds of millions of dollars, but do they make the most sense? Could bureaucrats have been more creative and politically courageous in lopping off whole programs that the city can no longer afford? Will some economies be counterproductive? 
 The Mayor didn't dodge those questions.
"The only thing I haven't heard is, 'Let's sell a piece of Central Park,' " Mr. Dinkins said, by way of explaining the scope of alternatives presented, if not seriously considered.
He mentioned a few others, the boldest being transferring responsibility for maintaining East River bridges to the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority -- a transfer that would presumably be contingent on the imposition of tolls. He acknowl edged, though, that two panels he had ap pointed were just beginning to test the waters for changes of that magnitude.
 (The boldest shift actually proposed yesterday seemed to be the merger of two duplicative offices re sponsible for relocat ing homeless families to apartments.)
 Nor was Mr. Din kins sanguine about the possibility that some cuts might be false economies. "We know from our experience in the 1970's that the budget cuts of today lead to higher social costs a decade from now," he said. But he coupled that cautionary note with exasperation. It is one thing to press a Mayor to spare a program and quite another to be obligated, as he is, to pay for it.
"It ain't so damned simple," Mr. Dinkins said, adding that "one has to look at the total picture" -- a perspective that, during his first year as Mayor, he appeared at times to overlook.
The section listing dozens of departmental economies -- "David Scissorhand" was how one Queens parent portrayed Mr. Dinkins in a protest placard at a community meeting Monday night -- dramatized not merely the scope of proposed service reductions, if mostly at the margins. It also portrayed the dimension of services to which New Yorkers have become accustomed.
The financial plan would save $5.6 million next year by laying off 957 part-time school-crossing guards, nearly $1.5 million by exercising greater discretion over which prisoners are served halal and kosher meals, $173,000 by eliminating "long line painting" on highways and $1.1 million by delaying a proposed 42d Street Transitway in Manhattan. The latter -- like the city's Clean Team and proceeds from the expected sale of the Coliseum site -- is a perennial candidate for budget-cutting in the category of Generally Accepted Accounting Gimmicks. The Coliseum option, however, was listed this time as only a contingency.
Other cuts suggested included $1.2 million by reducing wattage in 20,000 more street lights on commercial strips (obscuring dirtier sidewalks and perhaps prompting the Mayor to rename his anti-crime program "Dark Streets, Safe City); $116,000 by shutting the Children's Zoo in Central Park; $274,000 by cutting the Parks Department's marionette program (unless someone pulls strings to save it); $1.4 million by switching to volunteer chaplains in the Health and Hospitals Corporation, and $108,000 by terminating "dry culture sewer cleaning" (the city's version of germ warfare).
It is commonly accepted that some of the hundreds of individual decisions that make up the preliminary budget are predicated on posturing: If the proposed economies in education and other programs generate enough of an outcry, maybe they won't have to be made -- particularly if another level of government comes to the rescue.
After years of rosy dreams, "we are coming to dread pink slips," the Mayor said. It hardly seemed coincidental that his financial plan was printed in buff binders, but an accompanying booklet about proposed relief from Albany was bound in pink.
Mr. Dinkins's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, acknowledged that the vagaries of the Persian Gulf conflict, of state aid and of the local economy had made projecting deficits even harder for an administration that has often appeared to be weeks or more behind in responding to crises.
This time, Mr. Michael said, "I think we've gotten a little bit ahead," but he prudently declined to speculate for how long.

HEADLINE: THE DINKINS BUDGET;
Falling Short of Dinkins's 'Smaller Government' Goal

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
"In the future, ours will be a smaller government," Mayor David N. Dinkins said last week in his State of the City message. "One able to cope with the rapid changes, but a stronger one, more creative, more productive and more responsive."
 Measured against this standard, his $29.3 billion preliminary budget, released yesterday amid a recession and a state budget crisis, appears to fall short. 
 After weeks of worry over a $2 billion budget gap in the fiscal year that begins on July 1, the administration has produced a budget that fails to halt the seemingly inexorable growth of government. It would actually increase spending by 5.6 percent, surpassing the rate of inflation.
And while the plan calls for thousands of layoffs in some agencies and hundreds of service cuts, large and small, most of these would be offset by increased hiring in other agencies, particularly police and social services.
 
Small Cut in Work Force
 The number of city employees in the new fiscal year would be only 3,000 less than when the current fiscal year began, a decrease of about 1.3 percent. Most of the layoffs are scheduled for the Board of Education, an agency beyond the Mayor's direct control.
While some agencies, like the Parks Department, would face devastating cuts, others, like the Police and Fire Departments and the Human Resources Administration, have successfully resisted them.
"Given the current economic recession and severe fiscal pressures at all levels of government, we question whether this reduction is sufficient," State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said in a statement yesterday.
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a research group financed by businesses, said of Mayor Dinkins, "You have to give him good marks for being serious about balancing the budget, but it should be balanced at a lower level while the economy is declining."
 
Opportunity in Crisis
 For reorganizing government, the worst of times is often the best of times. A budget crisis may be an opportunity to parry the power of bureaucratic and political interest groups and achieve long-sought gains.
Some experts say New York's government has been due for large reductions and reorganization for years. The city, they say, has been spending far beyond its means at least since the stock market crash in 1987 while balancing the budget through such one-time measures as raiding the cash hoards of city agencies.
"There is a structural imbalance of about $1 billion which has persisted for the last several years," said Allen Proctor, director of the state Financial Control Board. "The solution to that requires permanent changes in the level of services the city provides and which the local economy can't sustain."
But in practice the administration has found such reorganization difficult to achieve. Rather than rethinking the delivery of services -- how many fire houses the city needs, for example -- most of the cuts in Mr. Dinkins's budget plan would be made on the edges of existing services.
While hundreds of duplicative and otherwise unnecessary administrative jobs have been cut from the Board of Education and the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, other agencies have successfully resisted such cuts.
In the preliminary budget, many cuts would be in the delivery of services -- the cleaning of parks, for example -- that would almost certainly be restored when city revenues pick up at the end of the recession.
After Mayor Dinkins spent weeks reviewing budget cuts for city agencies, the administration decided it could cut no further, at least for now, without hurting too many New Yorkers.
Instead, the administration wants to close gaps through tax increases -- $580 million in proposed taxes on top of an additional $1.3 billion in taxes either pending or already adopted.
In the footsteps of previous administrations, the city is trying other means to close budget gaps. A public corporation, the United Nations Development Corporation, will refinance bonds and turn over the proceeds to the city. Surplus cash at two other city corporations will be turned over to the city as well.
In addition, for the first time, the city would sell bonds to cover the interest costs incurred while city projects are under construction.
 
Savings Noted
 Administration officials say they did achieve some administrative savings. For example, they would consolidate in one agency the management of senior-citizens centers. And more of these savings are to come, they say. Mr. Dinkins noted that he had set up a business-labor panel to study productivity and management.
Perhaps the clearest indication of the administration's failure to make inroads on the bureaucracy was Mr. Dinkins's decision to list "possibilities for streamlining operations" in his statement at yesterday's budget briefing.
They include breaking up the Human Resources Administration, transferring some emergency services from the police to the Fire Department, establishing a "super commuter" agency and transferring maintenance of East River bridges to the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
But all these, Mayor Dinkins said, remain to be considered.

HEADLINE: Brisk Trading Worldwide, but No Panic;
Yen Soars And Tokyo Stocks Rise

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Early reports of American success in attacking Iraqi military positions sent Japanese stock prices and the yen sharply higher, while oil prices in Asia tumbled. The financial markets appeared to express relief at the early signs that the world economy would not suffer major damage from a war in the Persian Gulf.
Anticipating a brief war that would rout the Iraqis, and with no reports of Iraqi counterattacks or defensive operations, traders reversed themselves after an initial burst of nervousness and moved ahead with optimism and unusual energy. 
 The dollar is regarded as a safe holding in times of international stress, and it had risen strongly against the yen in recent days with the approach of the Tuesday deadline the United Nations had set for Iraq's withdrawl from Kuwait. But once the United States finally ended the long waiting game and its forces were reported to have had dramatic successes, traders dumped the dollars they had accumulated, taking profits.
 
A Volatile Currency
 The dollar shot up to 138 yen after the first news reports of the attack flashed through Tokyo trading rooms. But it then fell back steadily, hitting 133.65 yen in mid-afternoon here.
On the Tokyo stock market, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks rose 1,004.11 points, or 4.47 percent, closing at 23,446.81. The rise, on volume of 450 million shares, was the 10th-largest ever for the Nikkei. The surge in stock prices reversed a decline of more than 300 points in early trading when it was unclear what was taking place in the Persian Gulf. On Wednesday, the Nikkei had lost 770.53 points, or 3.3 percent.
"There's still a lot of volatility out there, but people are generally pleased that the world economy seems unlikely to suffer major external shocks from the situation in the gulf," said Kermit Schoenholtz, an economist here with Salomon Brothers Asia.
The oil market in Singapore, the main base for crude oil dealings in Asia, also reacted nervously to the first reports of air raids on Baghdad. Prices shot up to $34 a barrel, traders said, then reversed around the same time the dollar began to decline. By mid-afternoon, crude oil was quoted as low as $27.50 a barrel in Singapore, with many traders in Europe waking up early to sell barrels.
At midmorning in Tokyo, news agencies reported that President Bush had authorized selling crude oil from the United States Strategic Petroleum Reserve, and that also put downward pressure on oil prices.
 
The Dollar's Decline
 The dollar's decline began when reports spread through bank dealing rooms that the Federal Reserve was selling dollars in Singapore to limit the dollar's gains. Once the pullback began, the tumble gathered steam, as news reports of American military successes in the gulf circulated.
The Bank of Japan went out of its way to calm markets by injecting about $4.5 billion into the banking sector. The move was seen as an attempt to make clear that the central bank would act to avert any disruptions in normal trading. The central bank governor, Yasushi Mieno, issued a statement that the bank would intervene if necessary.
In addition, the Finance Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, was quoted as saying that the central banks of the major industrial nations were prepared to intervene if necessary to ease volatility. There was no evidence, by midafternoon, however, that that had been necessary.
 
Traders React Warily
 
By The Associated Press
Stock trading around the world was cautious today as the markets reacted to the American-led attack against Iraq. Market professionals said traders were wary because of uncertainty over the extent of the fighting.
The Hong Kong stock market was steady at the opening. The Australian stock exchange suspended trading for 10 minutes to allow the market to adjust. After trading resumed, the market's principal index fell to levels not seen since the 1987 stock market crash.
"It's not panicky yet but it's a fast market," said Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management in Princeton, N.J.
"The belief of many traders is that it has been a one-sided battle," he said. "We have not heard of any damage to the American side or the allied side."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: THE DIPLOMACY;
Excerpts From U.S. Report Of Its Attempts to Avoid War

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a letter sent by President Bush today to notify Congressional leaders that he had exhausted all diplomatic means to persuade Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. The letter was required under the resolutions approving the use of force that were passed on Saturday by both houses of Congress.
 From the beginning of the gulf crisis, the United States has consistently pursued four basic objectives: (1) the immediate, complete, and unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait; (2) the restoration of the legitimate Government of Kuwait; (3) the protection of U.S. citizens abroad; and (4) the security and stability of a region vital to U.S. national security. In pursuit of these objectives, we have sought and obtained action by the U.N. Security Council, resulting in 12 separate resolutions that have been fully consistent with U.S. objectives. 
 The last of these 12 resolutions, U.N. Security Council Resolution 678 of 29 November 1990, authorizes U.N. member states to use "all necessary means" to implement Resolution 660 and all subsequent relevant resolutions of the Security Council, and to restore international peace and security in the area, unless Iraq fully implements those resolutions on or before Jan. 15, 1991.
. . . Iraq has taken no steps whatever to fulfill these requirements. Iraq has forcefully stated that it considers the Security Council's resolutions invalid and has no intention of complying with them at any time. . . . Iraq has strongly and repeatedly reiterated its annexation of Kuwait and stated its determination that will remain permamently a part of Iraq. . . .
In short, the Government of Iraq remains completely intransigent in rejecting the U.N. Security Council's demands -- despite the exhaustive use by the United States and the United Nations of all appropriate diplomatic, political and economic measures to persuade or compel Iraq to comply.
. . .
The President, the Secretary of State and other U.S. officials have engaged in an exhaustive process of consultation with other governments and international organizations. The Secretary of State alone has, since Aug. 2 of last year, held more than 250 meetings with foreign heads of state, foreign ministers and other high foreign officials.
Most recently, on Jan. 9, the Secretary of State met at length in Geneva with the Iraqi Foreign Minister, who in six and one-half hours of talks demonstrated no readiness whatever to implement the U.N. Security Council resolutions. The Iraqi Foreign Minister even refused to receive a diplomatic communication from the President intended for Saddam Hussein. On Jan. 13, the U.N. Secretary General was rebuffed by Iraq for a second time, in this case in a direct attempt to persuade Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait peacefully. Many other heads of state, foreign ministers and private persons have made similar attempts.

HEADLINE: Brisk Trading Worldwide, but No Panic;
Companies Set Gasoline Price Curbs

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The news of military action drove oil prices wild last night, first up by 20 percent in a few minutes, and then down below their starting point, as it appeared that the American air strike met almost no resistance from the Iraqis.
Meanwhile, some large United States oil companies quickly announced that at least for now, they would not change retail gasoline prices at their company-owned service stations. They also said they would freeze the prices they charge independent distributors and urge them to hold the line, too. 
 Most companies acted as the prices were rising, reaching a peak of about $39 in the thinly traded cash market, $7 higher than the close on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday afternoon for light, sweet crude.
 
Companies' Reactions
 Conoco, Unocal, Mobil and Chevron were among oil companies making announcements shortly after the bombing began.
Noting that petroleum supplies were adequate, the companies said they were holding the line on prices to try to calm customers and prevent panic buying or fuel hoarding. Some companies also attempted to combat hoarding by limiting deliveries to wholesale customers to the amounts of their existing contracts.
But the meaning of the freeze was not clear last night, because of an unexpected turn in the oil market. By midnight New York time, prices had fallen to below their starting point. North Sea Brent, which has been trading for about $2.20 under the price of oil on the New York Merc, was reported at $28, implying that the exchange would open this morning below where it closed last night, despite the start of fighting in the Middle East.
 
Price Spike Expected
 Traders had long expected a price spike, because of the uncertainty created by war, but most had thought it would last a few days, or a week or two. "The entire spike has occurred while the future market in New York was asleep," said Thomas Blakeslee, an analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group, of Hoboken, N.J., at midnight last night.
The cash market is harder to monitor than prices on the exchanges, however, and the jump oil markets could still take sharp swings in either direction.
The news that bombing of Iraq had begun came hours after the close of the two big markets, the New York Mercantile Exchange and the International Petroleum Exchange in London, so that the price change was evident only in cash trades between oil companies.
Under rules recently adopted by the New York Merc, prices for delivery in the first two months -- currently February and March -- are limited to a movement of $7.50. At that point, trading would halt for an hour. When it resumed, if the price moved another $7.50 in the same direction, further price changes that day would be barred.
The oil company announcements come less than a week before many large oil companies are expected to announce stunning profit increases for the fourth quarter.
"The outbreak of war in the Middle East could cause a run-up in world oil prices," said Richard J. Stegemeier, Unocal's chairman. "We urge our customers to avoid any panic buying or fuel hoarding here at home that could create a supply-demand imbalance in the market."
 
Strategic Reserves
 Late last night, President Bush authorized Energy Secretary James D. Watkins to make available 1.12 million barrels of oil a day for the next 30 days from the strategic petroleum reserve. In normal times, the United States imports about seven million barrels a day.
Speaking in a telephone interview last evening as prices were near their peak, Theodore Eck, chief economist of the Amoco Corporation, said that any price increase reflected fear, and not reaction to events in the oilfields. "There's no news at all of anything hitting anything in Saudi Arabia, and it's irrelevant, in a technical sense, what happens to oilfields in Iraq or Kuwait," he said. "They're not producing anyway."
At Cambridge Energy Research Associates, W. Dennis Eklof, a senior consultant, pointed out that apart from the war threat, "The fundamentals of the market are still that there's an excess of supply, but we have seen continuously since last August that there is a war premium in the price."
William Randol, an oil industry expert at First Boston, said that the price freezes by the oil companies were not surprising, and that other companies were likely to freeze wholesale prices or announce that they were going slow on raising fuel prices to match crude rises.
"They're worried that someone would propose a windfall profits tax," he said. "They're looking for brownie points; they're looking to be good corporate citizens."
He added that crude prices are likely to rise only for a few days, so the sacrifice by the oil companies might not be that large.
 
Price Increases in the Future
 "If crude oil prices don't come down -- and I would be surprised if they don't -- over the next two or three months, the companies can raise gas prices to compensate," Mr. Randol said.
Several companies with large refining operations, including Chevron, Exxon and Mobil, are among those expected to post sharp gains in profits. Their operations improved in the quarter because crude costs fell in the quarter far more rapidly than retail and wholesale prices for refined products like gasoline, heating oil and jet fuel.
Some members of Congress already have introduced bills to enact a windfall profits tax that would limit oil-industry profits, with earnings above a certain percentage being paid back to the Government.
In a statement issued shortly before 8 P.M. yesterday, Lawrence J. Rawl, chairman and chief executive of the Exxon Corporation, said oil supplies in the United States and around the world appeared to be "sufficient to meet demand."
 
Prices at the Pump
 Mr. Rawl did not address the question of gasoline pump prices, but said, "Exxon pledges that it will do everything within the capability of its supply system to insure continued supplies for its customers."
Conoco, which is based in Houston, said its decision to hold retail gasoline prices was meant to insulate customers from possible price surges at the pump that could follow "the outbreak of hostilities." It said the freeze would continue "for the time being."
Average prices for unleaded regular gasoline across the United States had fallen approximately 14 cents since peaking at $1.37 a gallon late last year. For instance, the average price in Texas this week was $1.23 a gallon, according industry officials.
On energy markets before last night's attack, product prices rose. Heating oil closed at 91.6 cents a gallon, up 6.9 cents, and gasoline was at 82.19 cents, up 5.15 cents.
 
Instances of Extra Demand
 At Sun Refining and Marketing, which does business in 28 states east of the Rockies under the Sunoco and Atlantic names, Paul J. Durkin, a spokesman, said the company's product terminals had seen "spotty" instances of extra demand. The company is now limiting its customers to 100 percent of the volume on contracts they have signed. Since demand recently has been down slightly, the 100 percent figure is likely to satisfy most retailers.
Sun does not have its own wells, having spun off its exploration and production division into a new company more than a year ago. But Mr. Durkin said, "Everything I've seen says we're not going to have a problem getting our hands on supply."
Marathon Oil is limiting the gas stations that sell under its brand name to 300 percent of their contract amounts a day for the remainder of January; others can buy up to 200 percent a day, with lower limits for a 10-day period. "I hope people will be calm," said William Ryder, a company spokesman. "We've been telling people, there's plenty of supply out there, and I hope the message has gotten through. But when the first shot is fired, Lord knows what people are going do."
Mobil is also limiting sales, and Phillips Petroleum is charging a 10-cent-a-gallon surcharge on purchases above contract specifications.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: EGYPT;
Exiles From Kuwait Rejoice in Cairo

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Thursday, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Hundreds of Kuwaitis drove their cars around the corniche and over briges crossing the Nile River in downtown Cairo, honking and waving flags at around 2 A.M., after news of the American attack against Iraq and Kuwait began to spread here.
Egyptian television suspended regular programming in the early morning to announce that "the Persian Gulf battle has started." 
 Egyptian national radio, which broadcasts around the Arab world, transmitted President Bush's formal announcement of the start of the war at 4 A.M. Cairo time.
"Thank God! Thank God!" was a cry heard over and over again in the lobby of the Intercontinental Hotel, where some Kuwaitis are staying, as many of them began to drift into the lobby, into the streets and eventually into cars in which they joined others.
 
30,000 Egyptians Deployed
 In the early morning, most of this city's 13 million people was asleep, unware that a battle in which some 30,000 to 40,000 Egyptian soldiers may take part had just begun.
An Egyptian taxi driver who toured the city, watching the Kuwaitis demonstrating their enthusiasm, said: "We are worried about our people who are there. I hope the Americans have a good map. They should stay away from the areas where Egyptians live."
It is estimated that 750,000 Egyptians are still living in Iraq. A senior Egyptian Foreign Ministry official said on Wednesday that efforts were under way to evacuate them via Jordan at a pace that may rise to 50,000 a day.
But as early reports filtered to Egypt, it appeared that the initial attack against Iraq had largely avoided residential areas, at least in Baghdad, where many of the Egyptians live.
 
Effect on Economy Feared
 Over the last two days, Egyptian newspapers have been filled with commentary warning of the devastating effect that a war will have on the economy of the region.
Egypt has already suffered the impact of about one million expatriate Egyptians who have returned from Kuwait and Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Most have come back destitute, and are unable to find employment in an economy that cannot employ much of the work force.
In addition to the new burden they represent, Egypt has been deprived of the remittances they used to send, a loss that has amounted to hundreds of millions of dollars since August.
Tourism and the Suez Canal, two other major sources of income for Egypt, have been badly affected. The number of tourists in Egypt now is barely a 10th of the normal figure for this time of year, and fewer ships are traversing the canal.
 
Calm Is Seen in Cairo
 The early morning edition of Al Ahram, the semi-official newspaper, declared that war had started in a banner headline that proclaimed the destruction of all missile bases, Iraqi communications centers, the Baghdad airport and the Iraqi broadcast station.
"The Iraqi Air Force was nowhere in the battle of sky," Al Ahram said, adding that "the bombing aims at the total paralysis of Iraq."
Cairo seemed calm and authorities said the airport would function normally today and that Government-owned television would continue to broadcast news in a nonstop fashion to cover the gulf war.
It even seemed that the apparent success of the first strike against Iraq hads motivated some writers to speak of the beginning of a new erar for the Arab world.
"The tragedy of a large number of the population in the Arab world is that it is living in a fog in which its rulers have been turned to gods who demand thatey their subjects kneel and worships them," wrote Said Senbel, editor in chief of Al Akbar, the largest Egyptian daily, in a front-page editorial today.
Mr. Senbel went on to say that the era of empty sloaganeering in praise of Arab dictators hads come to end, "and it is its a sorry thing that some people never learn."
 
Castro Criticizes U.N.
 HAVANA, Jan. 16 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Cuban President, Fidel Castro, criticized the United Nations tonight for the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf.
In remarks to foreign journalists moments after he was told of the outbreak of fighting in the gulf, Mr. Castro said:
"The Security Council had a great arsenal of measures at its disposal, even economic measures, medical measures without embargoing food measures. There could have been other economic measures. There could have been isolation. There could have been more political condemnation. There were a broad range of measures that they could have taken without resorting to weapons. From the beginning to the end, they had only a declaration to war, not to peace."
He also said the war could have its most severe consequences for third world nations like Cuba. He feared that an increase in oil prices would drastically hurt his economy, which is already operating under austerity measures imposed five months ago.
 
Japan Considers More Aid
 TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 17 (Special to The New York Times) -- Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu summoned his senior national security advisers into an emergency session this morning amid signs that Japan would make some sort of announcement about providing additional financial assistance to the war against Iraq.
Japanese officials said they would try to prepare a quick announcement of assistance to try to mute possible worldwide criticism over Japan's decision to help pay for the war but not to go into combat itself.
The officials said Tokyo also wanted to avoid the delays in announcing aid that led to criticism last summer.
"The most important message we have right now is that we stand firmly by the United States," Taizo Watanabe, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, said on Wednesday. "We won't have to ask America if they need a contribution. We take it for granted they will need it, and we have got to pay."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1671 words

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: AMERICA'S REACTION - U.S. AND ALLIES OPEN AIR WAR ON IRAQ; BOMB BAGHDAD AND KUWAITI TARGETS; 'NO CHOICE' BUT FORCE, BUSH DECLARES;
A TENSE WAIT ENDS

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
In one long moment yesterday, word that the United States had attacked Baghdad swept the country.
In split-level suburban homes on the East Coast where dinner was in the oven, in big-city restaurants in the Midwest where bars were jammed with the happy-hour crowd and in skyscraper offices on the West Coast where people were still at work, there was an odd mixture of apprehension, sadness and relief. 
 In malls, shoppers emptied out of stores and cried. In supermarkets, cashiers rushed to call relatives and share the news that after five months of waiting and wondering America was at war. In department stores, people crowded in front of television sets, with some saying they were stunned that President Bush had decided to act so soon after the United Nations deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait.
 
A Scene Out of World War II
 Suddenly, in public places where cacophony is the norm, there was an unusual silence, eerie rather than giddy. Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan -- where even whispers can take on an echoing, high-decibel intensity -- was quiet. On trains to Connecticut, passengers gathered around people who had radios with headsets. "The people with the radios would listen to the news and then relay it to the other passengers," said Dan Brucker, a spokesman for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, "kind of like World War II radio dispatchers delivering the news."
The word that waves of air attacks were striking Iraq silenced black-tie galas in Manhattan. And in a Houston hotel, the chatter around the bar stopped when the President began his speech from the Oval Office. Only the machine making frozen margaritas kept whirring.
Some people applauded Mr. Bush's decision to order the attack. "It was direct and to the point," Lester Alexander, a New Orleans real-estate investor, said of Mr. Bush's speech. "He did not try to sell me on his reasons, but he explained to me why he took the action. For a politician, that's good. I had a feeling I was hearing truth."
For other people, it was a long night of ambivalence and complicated, conflicting emotions. "I support what Bush is doing," said Scott Mosenson, the manager of a Los Angeles restaurant. "But there's definitely dissonance inside of me. The taking of lives, any lives, is hard to deal with.
"But I'm not a moral absolutist, and I try to envision the highest good possible, so I pray the highest good comes out of the this. I believe Bush is acting in good conscience."
 
Taking to the Streets
 But others questioned Mr. Bush's motivation. And some took their objections to the streets.
Protesters chanting "no blood for oil" assembled in Times Square about an hour after the announcement of the attack. Their target was the military recriting office at 43rd Street and Broadway, some sitting in the street and delaying traffic.
Later the demonstrators walked east toward the United Nations, delaying traffic on Second Avenue and setting police barricades on fire. Two demonstrators were arrested, one for assaulting a police officer by kicking him in the throat.
Although the protesters, then about 2,500 strong, slowed traffic, some motorists honked their horns in support.
Shortly after midnight, the protesters marched back to Times Square, where some burned an American flag.
Two anti-war demonstrators fell from the Brooklyn Bridge early this morning when a car struck a group of protesters marching across the bridge, the police said.
One demonstrator fell 40 feet to a parking lot beneath the western end of the bridge, and the other apparently fell into the East River, said Sgt. Tina S. Mohrmann, a police spokeswoman. The condition of the two demonstrators was not immediately known, the police said.
 
Airport Security Tight
 Airports around the country, where fears of terrorist attacks had been rising all week, went on highest alert shortly before midnight. This means, among other things, that passengers will not be able check luggage at the curbside and that airport roadways will be monitored.
A Federal Aviation Administration official said many airports had taken these steps on their own before the agency's order. Passengers were told to allow more time than usual for checking in.
 Telephone callers may not have it so easy. U S Sprint said its international switching center had been swamped. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked customers not to call the Middle East, saying its international lines had also been overloaded with Americans phoning business associates, friends and loved ones.
Other rhythms of daily life skipped a beat as soon as the allied fighter planes began crisscrossing the Iraqi sky. The President's speech interrupted music videos on the MTV cable-television network, which played peace songs from the 1960's afterwards. In Times Square, even the strippers at the all-nude Paris Theater clustered inside the red-curtained lobby, watching television news. And some Americans worried how close to home the conflict might come.
"You don't know what to expect and then you think, 'Am I really going to be affected by this?' " said Carla Houston of Cupertino, Calif. "Physically, I probably won't be. Mentally, I know I will be. I mean, I was only 6 years old during Vietnam."
On college campuses, on sidewalks and in city parks, people who had not heard the news said they realized something had happened just by the way friends said hello on the telephone. "I called home and my boyfriend was in tears," said Robin Cheevers, a 27-year-old legal secretary in San Francisco.
 In bars and restaurants, managers made somber announcements. At Joe's Stone Crab, a restaurant in Miami Beach, George Silas punched the button on the public address system.
"Ladies and gentlemen," he said, "I've just received word that the United States has started to bombard Iraq. The war is on." There was no cheering and no clapping among the 50 or so customers.
The excitement level was higher in a crowded pub near Dupont Circle in Washington. Robert Parkes Jr. motioned to a bartender and said: "The war's on. Have a drink!"
 But, with two televisions blaring the news at both ends of the bar, Mr. Parkes said: "I have mixed emotions. I don't want lives wasted. That's why I'm kind of happy to hear that the bombs are flying. I know I sound like I have veins in my teeth, but if we do it, we should make it mean something. Let's not make this into another Vietnam."
At the Mirage Hotel in Las Vegas, executives huddled around television sets. "We seem now to really have crossed the line," said one, Alan Feldman. "It's no longer hyperbole and politicians' statements."
It was a moment many had not expected, at least not so soon after the United Nations deadline. "It's scary," said Cindy Winterhalter, a textile designer in Manhattan. "I guess, like a lot of people, even though the deadline had passed, I was hoping there would still be some negotiations or something. But when you make a commitment and a statement like that, I guess you have to follow through with it."
After all the failed diplomacy and conflicting expectations, Mr. Bush's decision brought relief for some. At dusk in the Pike Place Market, Seattle's most popular open-air market, a passer-by announced the start of war. "Finally," said Gary Levy, a vendor there. "Finally."
Some who had been worrying about the outbreak of war talked about where they were when they heard the news, wondering if the conflict would take on the personal historical significance that older generations assign to crackly radio broadcasts of Pearl Harbor or bulletins on black-and-white television about the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
Rosemary Scanlon, an economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, had just arrived at her Brooklyn apartment. She turned on the television in her living room, and while it was warming up, she walked to the bedroom to turn on the radio. As she was walking back to the living room, she heard a reporter in Baghdad saying the bombing had begun.
"I said, 'Oh, God, here we go,' " she said. "I'd worried about it for days. I've had to give two speeches in the last three days about the economic outlook for New York City and New Jersey and I've been thinking about what could be this terrible blow to us all: war. I've been thinking, all of our economic problems are manageable in the context of this war. Just let this pass by and I'll happily solve the savings and loan crisis, the city's fiscal problems, just go down the list of all the problems and I'll solve them."
 
Critical Words From Ellsberg
 In Washington, Daniel J. Ellsberg, the Defense Department analyst in the 1960's who became a prominent opponent of the Vietnam War, was critical of Mr. Bush's decision. He said the President appeared to be ordering the type of massive air strike that the Joint Chiefs of Staff and hawks like Barry Goldwater had advocated, unsuccessfully, against North Vietnam in 1965.
"If the bombing fails in Iraq, I'm afraid the President will compound the error by the worst possible gamble, a ground assault," Mr. Ellsberg said, "with the net result that we will destroy Kuwait in order to liberate it."
That fear was echoed in Detroit , which has the largest concentration of Arab-Americans in this country. Clutching rosaries and lighting candles in their living rooms, some Iraqi Christians voiced despair and resignation as they watched Mr. Bush announce the attack on their homeland.
"I'm visualizing Baghdad at this moment," said Josie Sarafa, a teacher who lives in the Detroit suburb of Birmingham. "The work of centuries will go down the drain."
The concern at a Jewish Community Center in San Francisco, where parents picking up their children from an after-school program stopped to watch Mr. Bush's speech, was more immediate. "I think he tried to justify something nobody yet understands," said Jackie Lewis, 36. "I don't see the reason for the war."
Then the parents prayed.

HEADLINE: Art Deco Lovers Gather in Miami

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Admirers of the pastels and streamlined forms of the Art Deco hotels and apartment houses in Miami Beach came here from around the world last weekend to learn from preservationists who helped establish the nation's first historic Art Deco district. The event was the World Congress of Art Deco.
Delegates from Argentina and Australia, among other places, discussed preservation tactics and Art Deco sites around the world. They hope to establish an international plan to conserve the architectural style. 
 Art Deco, the sleek, elegant style associated with glamour and sophistication, takes its name from the Exposition des Arts Decoratifs et Industriels Modernes, a design fair held in Paris in 1925. The style took hold as the United States entered the Depression. In the 1980's, the blue and pink concrete "painted ladies" of Miami Beach provided the backdrop for the television show "Miami Vice" and helped popularize Art Deco again.
In 1979, a square-mile district of 800 Art Deco and Mediterranean Revival buildings in Miami Beach was put on the National Register of Historic Places. The founder of the Miami Design Preservation League, Barbara Baer Capitman, who led the four-year effort to designate the area a landmark, died last March.
"I think that for many years Art Deco was underestimated," said Luis Rivas, an architect who teaches at the national university in Buenos Aires. "It was considered a poor cousin of the International Style of modern architecture."
Leaders of the Art Deco Society of Western Australia told of demonstrations in Perth to protect Art Deco buildings. "It's been a battlefield of preservation," said Vyonne Geneve, the society's president.
The unsuccessful efforts to save a 1936 Art Deco chapel of a crematorium in Perth included vigils at dawn in the chapel's sanctuary and rallies on the steps of Parliament.
Groans were heard as Ms. Geneve showed a videotape of an official saying he wanted to demolish the chapel because "it's become outdated."
"So has the Parthenon," Ms. Geneve pointed out.
Mr. Rivas said the weak economy in Argentina has blocked developers from tearing down many of the Art Deco buildings in Buenos Aires. Yet the lack of Argentine Government financing has left many of the Art Deco theaters, office buildings and homes of the 1920's and 1930's in ruins.

HEADLINE: Mr. Dinkins Does His Painful Duty

 BODY:
The preliminary budget Mayor David Dinkins released yesterday offers a plausible start at getting ahead of the continuing plunge in New York City's revenues. His plan confronts an anticipated budget gap of nearly $2 billion mainly by cutting some spending and seeking an unusually large package of new taxes. It is not yet as rigorous as it may have to become, but it's a conscientious start.
The plan does not yet take adequate advantage of the recession to make government more efficient through fundamental reorganization; a new mayoral committee of business and labor experts may find ways to do that. Nor, despite threats of huge layoffs, does the plan reduce the city's work force by more than 8,500 employees by June. 
 What Mr. Dinkins does in this plan, as he must by law, is balance the budget, and he has done so reasonably and responsibly. He does not resort to wholesale fiscal gimmicks or borrowing, and even increases the general reserve against emergencies.
The preliminary budget also shows he has made some difficult choices. They are more difficult than they might have been had City Hall negotiated less costly labor contracts, but they are tough nonetheless, reflecting Mr. Dinkins's sober conclusion that, "In this environment, we must measure our priorities by what we cut the least."
Sanitation, parks, bridge maintenance and hospitals are hit hard, while the Police Department and spending for some social services grow. The largest cut -- $321 million -- is imposed on the Board of Education. A cut that deep would be devastating, but may not be real. The city is clearly trying to put pressure on the State Legislature for higher education aid. Moreover, the city is now negotiating a wage deferral with the teachers' union and that would restore some of the cut.
The fate of the education budget is one of many unknowns. If the city has guessed wrong, it will probably have to cut much more. For instance, the plan calls for $580 million in new or higher taxes, on top of the $181 million earmarked for the city's new police program.
Much of the tax package needs state legislative approval, highly unlikely in a year when the state faces a huge deficit of its own. The plan also relies on saving $100 million by getting out from under some state requirements; but those requirements haven't been lifted yet and the Legislature has been resistant in the past.
It's another five months before the new budget has to be adopted, and the Mayor won't have to present his plan in final form until April. That leaves Mr. Dinkins and his administration the time and opportunity to finish the job now so conscientiously begun.

HEADLINE: Supply and Demand Govern Ship Charter

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Pentagon Paying High Prices for Shipping Supplies to Gulf" (front page, Dec. 24) does not describe the operation of the ship charter market very well. The ship charter market is one of the few areas of economic activity truly governed by supply and demand. When ships are in short supply or when the demand for ships increases sharply, as now, charter rates escalate. And when the high rates bring more ships into the market, or when demand slackens, the rates plummet.
Owning ships and trading them in the charter market is a very risky business. While it has made a few noted billionaires, it has made many more bankrupts. So to quote a shipping analyst describing the charter rates as "ludicrous" misses the point. The rates have certainly been high, but also appropriate to a particular situation at a particular time.
While there is no ceiling to charter rates, there is also no floor, and the same economic forces that boosted the rates can ratchet them down to losing levels very quickly. Adam Smith would be right at home in this market.
 
SYDNEY P. LEVINE
President, Shipping Intelligence
New York, Jan. 2, 1991

HEADLINE: PUBLIC & PRIVATE;
Personally

BYLINE: By Anna Quindlen

 BODY:
Woman walks into a bakery, where there's a sign announcing that the price of bagels will go up a nickel on Jan. 15. "War and an increase in the price of bagels on the same day," she says.
"I hope he backs down," says the baker. 
 "Who?" says the woman. "Saddam Hussein or George Bush?"
"Either one," the baker says.
Bagels were more expensive yesterday, and war broke out. Real life was peculiar, with an edge of sadness and of slow motion, and a sense of New Year's Eve gone nuclear: only one shopping day till Armageddon. "Now it is our job to shift without too much awkwardness . . ." Bob Costas said Saturday on NBC Sports, segueing from reports on war to a football post-mortem. That is what it is like. Dinner and war. Homework and war. The mundane and the horrible.
There's a moment in one of the Godfather movies when a capo is being executed for disloyalty. "It was business," he says of his traitorous behavior.
This is personal.
It's personal for Saddam Hussein. This war is a career move. His psyche has been dissected like a biology class frog, but it seems to me that he suffers from a lethal dose of that craziness that afflicts anyone audacious enough to lead a nation, egomania. The Secretary General of the United Nations came to call, hoping to avert the deaths of thousands upon thousands of people, and when he left Saddam Hussein delivered this non sequitur: "He met the American President four times before coming to us."
This brings to mind the moment in Woody Allen's "Bananas" when the new dictator of a Central American country belittles the danish Mr. Allen has brought him. "He brings cake for a group of people," complains one of the dictator's aides, "he doesn't even bring an assortment." Saddam Hussein's comment might be humorous in its egocentricity if it were not so ominous, such a clear indication of how he has intertwined this conflict with those two little words: Big Man.
For George Bush this is personal, too. I don't think the wimp factor is the only thing at work here. But I think that the sled of public positioning always stands at the top of a slippery slope, and when it begins to move, it is difficult to stop it or slow it down, even when half the electorate are yelling, "Wait a minute!" Sanctions needed more time to work, more time than the sled allowed. But that, alas, is yesterday's story.
This is personal. Most people agree that Saddam Hussein is pond scum and that he can't be permitted to take Kuwait as though it were the lunch money of the littlest kid in class. But then they ask themselves this question: Would I sacrifice my child for this?
And the answer is often no.
I only hope that we will continue, when this is done, to take these issues personally. We should take personally the fact that we habitually give aid to the kind of men we can easily and accurately describe as monsters.
We should take personally the fact that few politicians have had the guts or the vision to shape a coherent energy policy that would lessen our dependence on foreign oil. And we should take personal responsibility for the fact that we have not had the will to conserve or change.
We should take personally the idea that if there is to be a new world order, it must include a new answer to the question: Why us? It is time for our messiah complex to get a good overhaul. We can no longer afford economically, psychologically or politically to be the policeman of the world, even if we are the first one called when someone needs a cop.
That will be then. This is now. Time has stopped. So do our hearts, each time a clinch on "One Life to Live" is punctuated by the words "We interrupt this program to bring you a special report. . . ." In Des Moines, a teen-ager demonstrating against the war said he did not want a big black wall in Washington with his name on it. In the desert, a soldier wrote to his wife saying that he would understand if she remarried. It came to me that, no matter how swift the conflict, we will someday soon be reading about the design for the memorial to its dead.
"When do they decide to call it World War III?" a friend asked the other day.
I don't know. There's so much we don't know today. I only know that everyone seems sad and afraid, that the loss and mourning had begun even before the fighting. We are taking this very personally indeed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
