HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals Prices Fall; Gold Loss Biggest Since '83

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Belief that the war with Iraq would be short and successful sent precious metals prices plunging yesterday, with gold registering its biggest one-day loss since early 1983.
While silver and platinum prices spiraled downward with gold, their losses were limited by the thinking that a quick end to the Persian Gulf war would revive the economy and thus create demand for what are basically industrial metals. But yesterday's optimism could be tempered in today's trading, following reports of explosions in Tel Aviv, signaling that the scope of the war may change. 
 At the close of the Commodity Exchange in New York, the spot January gold delivery, in which only two contracts traded, settled at $373.40 an ounce, down $29.80 on the day. But the more active February contract tumbled $30.10, to $374.40.
In either case, the drop in the price of bullion was the biggest since Feb. 28, 1983, when gold plunged $42.50 an ounce, to $400.50. On that Monday, falling oil prices combined with President Ronald Reagan's strong anti-inflation measures to send gold prices plummeting.
Except for an occasionally brief upward move, gold has been trading around $400 since 1983, after hitting a record high of $850 on Jan. 21, 1980, when silver peaked at $50.35 an ounce. Platinum's record price of just over $1,000 an ounce was reached a month later.
"What we had today in the gold market was an almost unanimous belief that the war with Iraq would be over quickly and end victoriously, and this caused selling from all quarters," said Bette Raptopoulos, metals specialist at Prudential-Bache Securities. "Producers sold to get quick profits after the outbreak of the war caused an initial jump in prices in the Far East. There was also selling by commodity funds and from the Mideast, where the initial success of the attacks against Iraq have calmed nerves."
 
Commodity Funds Buying
 Scott W. Mondry and Steven J. Pepper, senior vice presidents at the Republic National Bank of New York, leading dealers in bullion, noted that the commodity funds had been accumulating gold since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, and were also buyers of silver and platinum because of what they perceived were cheap prices and limited downside risk.
The two bullion dealers noted that while silver and platinum were pulled down with gold, their declines were limited by the belief that a quick end to the gulf war would stimulate the economy and create much greater demand for what are basically industrial metls.
On the Comex, the spot Janaury silver delivery lost 18.9 cents an ounce, at $4.005, while the far more active March contract fell 19.5 cents, to $4.013. At the New York Mercantile Exchange, spot January platinum closed down $10.60 an ounce, at $407.20, with the active April delivery also off $10.60, at $411.20.

HEADLINE: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Washington;
BALTIC CRACKDOWN ANGERS CONGRESS

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Voicing anger at repressive measures taken by the Soviet authorities against pro-independence forces in the Baltic republics, members of Congress called on the Bush Administration today to impose sanctions on Moscow and take other retaliatory steps.
The legislators, speaking at a session of the United States Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, pointed repeatedly to what they perceived as a link between the moves of Soviet military units in Lithuania and Latvia at the very time the United States had mounted air strikes against Iraq. 
 Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, said he believed that the Soviet authorities were using the gulf fighting as a pretext for "continuing to heighten" their pressure on the democratically elected governments in the Baltic republics.
Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, asserted that Moscow was also "flouting the embargo" by continuing to send military supplies to Iraq. "Gorbachev has shown he is no longer to be trusted," he said. Representative Don Ritter, Republican of Pennsylvania, proposed "a strategy to hold Mr. Gorbachev's feet to the fire," with a goal of stripping him of his Nobel Peace Prize.
 
Delay in Summit Meeting
 The legislators' recommendations included postponing a Bush-Gorbachev summit meeting scheduled for next month and taking up diplomatic relations with the three Baltic governments. The United States refused to acknowledge the Soviet Union's annexation of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in 1940 and continues to maintain ties with the vestigial diplomatic missions of those countries in Washington. But it has not accorded full recognition to the newly elected governments of the Baltic republics.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, declared: "Only by granting diplomatic recognition to the embattled Baltic republics can we send the message that must be sent."
Both Democratic and Republican legislators said they felt the Administration was treading too lightly on the Baltics issue. "I think the Administration and the State Department will have to do better," said Representative Frank R. Wolf, Republican of Virginia. Representative Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico, said, "I would have wished a stronger response from the State Department."
 
Measures 'Under Review'
 Addressing the Congressional members of the panel, which also includes representatives from the executive branch, Assistant Secretary of State Raymond G. H. Seitz said the Administration had a number of punitive measures "more or less under review."
Mr. Seitz, who is responsible for European and Canadian affairs at the department, said the Administration was considering a proposal to elevate the Baltic states to the status of observers at sessions of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. That conference is the permanent forum that grew out of the 35-government Helsinki agreement of 1975.
Asked whether the United States might send a special high-level delegation to the Baltics to show solidarity with the independence movements, Mr. Seitz said that, too, was under consideration.
Representative Steny H. Hoyer, the Maryland Democrat who as co-chairman convened today's session of the commission on one day's notice, said such a delegation to the Baltics should be headed by former Presidents Carter and Reagan.
In a statement, Mr. Seitz said that the Administration, viewing the military actions in the Baltics 'with abhorrence," had repeatedly sent protests to Moscow. "We ask the Soviet authorities to undo what has been done," he said.
He also noted that Dainis Ivans, deputy prime minister of Latvia, and Bronius Kuzmickas, one of the vice presidents of Lithuania, were arriving in Washington this evening and would "be received here at a high level." Several of the commission members urged that President Bush receive the Baltic leaders as a means of sending the proper signal to Moscow.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Security Prices Stage Rally

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The stunning successes scored by the United States and allied aircraft on the first day of the attack on Iraqt generated a powerful rally in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of some Treasury securities rose by as much as 2 3/8 points and interest rates fell sharply.
The markets' reaction, and huge rise in prices, took place before Iraq lobbed a number of missles into Israel. 
 As participants had predicted, the onset of hostilities led to a sharp sell-off during overnight trading in Tokyo.
The decline was quickly reversed, however, when initial reports showed that the air battle was going entirely as American military leaders had planned.
"The pure gut reaction initially was to sell," said John P. Costas, director of the taxable fixed-income department at the First Boston Corporation. "But as it became evident how successful the event was, it began to look like this obstacle was being overcome in a much easier fashion than anyone had anticipated."
 
Bonds Post Biggest Gains
 Bond prices posted the biggest gains, as traders, analysts and at least some investors determined that the increased likelihood of a speedy resolution to the war would allow the Fed as well as market participants to refocus their attention on the weak economy.
In addition, yesterday's enormous $10.56 drop in oil prices suggested that inflation, which has been moderating lately, would fall further.
"Right now it looks like it will be a quick war, and that is a positive for the economy," said Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers. "But a major reason that is so is that a quick end to the fighting will allow interest rates to come down a lot. When we get the war behind us, it will free up the Federal Reserve to do whatever they need to alleviate the credit crunch."
Other analysts took issue with that view, and said the Fed might well choose to delay any further reduction in short-term rates.
"The Fed will have to determine whether the reduction of tensions in the Middle East and the drop in oil prices will cause a rebound in consumer spending, and whether that will lead to a rebound in the economy," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago.
"Barring any banking crisis, the Fed will probably keep monetary policy steady for awhile."
After rising to a high of 8.48 percent during trading in Tokyo, bond yields plummeted as results of the first day's fighting became known.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 106 7/32, up 2 3/8 points, or $23.75 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.18 percent. Late Wednesday, before shooting started in the Middle East, the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 8.39 percent.
 
Treasury Note Issues
 Among Treasury note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 103 3/32 late yesterday, up 1 7/32 point, to yield 8.03 percent. The 7 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 23/32, up 1/2 point, to yield 7.68 percent. And the 7 1/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 6/ 32, up 2/32, to yield 7.14 percent.
As bond yields fell, interest rates on Treasury bills rose. In the run-up to war, investors had sought a safe haven in highly liquid, short-term securities like Treasury bills.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.09 percent late yesterday, up six basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose 12 basis points, to a late offered rate of 6.25 percent.
The elation that permeated the market produced fairly active trading, participants said, but at least some investors decided to remain on the sidelines.
"We don't see any real reason to jump on right now," said Roger A. Craig, manager of about $650 million in fixed-income investments at the Banc One Ohio Trust Company in Columbus.
"The war news is great right now, but it might not be over the next couple of days. And if we are wrong, there is still plenty of time to jump on board. If everything goes right, bond yields will be well below 8 percent in the near future."
Corporate and tax-exempt municipal bond prices also posted strong gains on the positive developments in the Persian Gulf.
By late in the day, traders in the secondary market for investment-grade bonds said that prices of most intermediate to long-term issues rose as much as 1 1/4 points. Prices of shorter maturities were basically unchanged, the traders said.
In the secondary market for municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues rose by 3/4 point to a full point, market participants said.
Elsewhere, the Public Securities Association, a trade group, said yesterday that because of the war it was recommending that the Government securities market remain open on Monday, the holiday observance of the the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday.
"Given the state of global tensions, many government dealers wish to be in a position to provide the maximum amount of market liquidity to investors around the world," the association said in a statement.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell sharply in the week ended Jan. 7.
With the Fed reportedly paying more attention to the monetary aggregates, yesterday's figures might have been expected to elicit some reaction from credit market participants. However, the war news dominated trading activity yesterday, and the money report had no impact on prices.

HEADLINE: A Sharp Drop in Dollar Counters Expectations

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply yesterday, confounding the expectations of many analysts who thought the United States currency would be a safe harbor in a time of war.
Traders said that the market would continue to be volatile and move with the headlines. Because of the uncertainties -- and the ability of the dollar to turn on a dime -- many are leery of trying to make money now on the currency's movements. 
 In early trading in Tokyo today, the news that Iraqi missiles had been fired on Israel pushed the dollar a little higher.
In one foreign exchange room in New York yesterday morning, some traders could be heard cautioning customers against taking positions at this time. "The market continues to be confusing," said Robert A. White, a vice president of First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles. "The risk-reward ratio is just not there."
 
Brief Rally in Tokyo
 After just a brief rally in Tokyo, which elevated the dollar to more than 136 yen and 1.55 marks, the dollar fell sharply against all currencies. It held at the lower levels as trading opened in Europe, but began to slip some more as trading moved into the afternoon in New York and news from the Persian Gulf continued to indicate that the United States and its allies were having success in their assault on Iraq.
By the close of trading in New York, the dollar was at 1.5080 marks, down 2.4 percent from the Wednesday close of 1.5450 marks, and at 132.35 yen, off 3.3 percent from 136.83 yen at the Wednesday close.
The dollar also fell against other currencies, including the British pound. Sterling cost $1.9312 in New York, 1.4 percent more than Wednesday's close of $1.9050.
Some traders said they thought people who expected the dollar to rise on news of war were wrong all along, because the crisis had already given the currency a boost.
"It is just a typical, typical foreign-exchange move," said Liliana Nealon, vice president of foreign exchange at Union Bank of Switzerland. "It's a textbook case. Buy on the rumors and sell when it actually happens."
 
Central Bank Rumors
 Other traders said the dollar was hurt in Asia on Wednesday night by reports that the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan were intervening in the market to sell dollars in an effort to keep the currency from lurching wildly on war news.
The intervention to sell dollars could not be confirmed, but traders said the rumors had almost the same effect and forced many dollar holders to sell in a hurry.
During trading in the United States yesterday, some traders said that the Fed had entered the market to buy dollars with yen for customer accounts, including other central banks. This is not considered normal intervention, and it did not have much impact. But one trader said Fed traders were expressing some concern about the dollar's decline.
 
Underlying Weakness
 The fall of the dollar shows its long-term underlying weakness, the fickleness of the markets and the quickness with which a trend can be turned around when any event seems to signal that it has run its course.
The factors that have weakened the dollar in the last seven months, bringing it to record lows against the mark and the Swiss franc last year, are still in play. They are declining interest rates in the United States; the possibility of rising interest rates in Germany; an American recession at a time of growth in most of Europe and Japan, and concern about the American banking systems and the budget deficit.

HEADLINE: Gulf Oil Flows as Usual Despite Damage to Storage Tank

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
The Government said today that Persian Gulf oil flowed as usual after war broke out with Iraq, the only damage coming when Iraq destroyed a Japanese-owned storage tank in northern Saudi Arabia that held 200,000 barrels.
Production of 300,000 barrels a day from the Neutral Zone between Saudi Arabia and Iraq was halted as planned in the event of war. 
 "It is quiet," Energy Secretary James D. Watkins told reporters. "The situation is normal."
Mr. Watkins contended that world commercial and strategic supplies were more than adequate to meet demand, now suppressed by recession in the United States and some other countries, and that the Bush Administration had no intention of imposing any controls.
The Government should avoid "trying to interfere in any way with what goes on in the private sector," the Secretary said. "We don't believe there will be any allocation, price control, anything like that."
He said he had discussed with various oil companies the issue of possible windfall profits arising from the war and said they were highly sensitive to political and consumer repercussions if they were seen as gouging.
But Mr. Watkins said he had not requested the price freeze announced late Wednesday by four companies, Mobil, Chevron, Conoco and Unocal.
When asked this afternoon, after the oil price had collapsed, whether he thought the freeze might remain in place to the benefit of the companies, Mr. Watkins said, "I don't think the oil industry is going to play games on that."
Secretary Watkins, a retired admiral, said security measures had been considerably enhanced at the Trans-Alaska oil pipeline and at the nation's utility plants. Moving swiftly to carry out President Bush's decision Wednesday to release 1.12 million barrels a day from the nation's 586-million-barrel Strategic Petroleum Reserve, the department said in putting out bidding notices this morning that the oil would be drawn from four of the six Gulf Coast storage sites and that the bulk of it would be delivered in late February or March.

HEADLINE: So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual: Aerospace;
No Rush Soon To Reorder Arms

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson

 BODY:
A short war with Iraq would not have any direct mpact on aerospace companies and other military contractors, analysts and industry executives said. The war is being fought with existing inventories of weapons systems and other hardware, and contractors generally do not expect immediate new orders to replace arms expended or lost in the conflict.
Missile manufacturers, like the Raytheon Corporation and the Hughes Aircraft Company, could eventually receive replacement orders if the military decides to rebuild its supplies of tactical weapons. 
 The effects on the industry of a long war are more difficult to gauge. If many front-line fighters, bombers, tanks and other equipment were lost, the Pentagon might want to replace some with new orders. But contractors are increasingly concerned that the cost of a long war -- and perhaps even a short one -- would come at least partly out of the Pentagon's procurement budgets. Rather than improving the military-supply companies' prospects for new business, a war in that way could mean further reductions in orders for existing weapons and a slowing of plans for new systems.
In any case, industry executives do not expect the war to reverse or substantially slow the decline in Pentagon spending.
Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf nations have made it clear that they would like to make additional major arms purchases from the United States when the war is over. But sales to Arab nations are always politically complicated because of objections from supporters of Israel. The biggest likely winners if a sale to Saudi Arabia goes through would be the General Dyanamics Corporation, which makes the M-1 tank.

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Surprises Wall Street With Strong Quarterly Net

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
I.B.M. surprised Wall Street analysts yesterday by reporting an usually strong fourth quarter. The hefty increase in earnings and sales for the world's largest computer maker was taken as evidence that the industry was set for a significant shakeout.
Apple Computer also reported sizable gains yesterday, and the improved performance of the two big companies is expected to put increasing pressure on weaker competitors. 
 The International Business Machines Corporation said its income on an operating basis was up 16.1 percent in the quarter, aided by strong sales of new products. Net income was more than four times greater than a year ago, but that increase was magnified by a large charge to earnings taken in the fourth quarter of 1989. Revenues rose 12.7 percent.
The report, capping a year of financial improvement for I.B.M., came in the face of growing concerns about the international economy and continuing doubts about I.B.M.'s success in controlling expenses.
"This is an upside surprise," said Ulric Weil, a computer industry analyst at Weil & Associates in Washington. "This is a very clean report; there are no gimmicks."
Driven by the unexpectedly strong fourth-quarter figures and by positive market reaction to the initial fighting in the Persian Gulf, I.B.M.'s stock jumped $6.625 a share yesterday, closing at $115.75 on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume was 4.3 million shares, making I.B.M. the sixth most-active Big Board stock.
Wall Street analysts had generally cut their earnings estimates for I.B.M. in recent weeks, concerned that the United States economy was rapidly deteriorating and that European growth, which had buoyed American computer makers in recent years, had stalled. Most analysts had expected I.B.M.'s fourth-quarter earnings to be less than $4 a share, but the number came in significantly higher than that.
Fourth-quarter net income rose to $2.46 billion, or $4.30 a share, up from $591 million, or $1.04 a share, for the 1989 quarter. The results in the 1989 quarter were depressed by the effect of a special $2.4 billion charge taken to cover the cost of eliminating a number of jobs, shutting some operations and other changes.
I.B.M.'s fourth-quarter revenues were $23.06 billion, up from $20.46 bil- lion in 1989.
For the year ended Dec. 31, 1990, net earnings were up 57.9 percent, to $6 billion, or $10.51 a share, compared with $3.76 billion, or $6.47 a share, in 1989. Revenue for the year was $69 billion, up 10 percent from 1989's revenue of $62.7 billion.
Part of the quarter's success was attributed to I.B.M.'s product cycle. Such cycles, based on the introduction of new computers and new technologies, have long been thought to offset the effects of recession by increasing customer purchases. I.B.M. recently brought out a new family of its most powerful mainframe computers, and many industry executives and analysts have said the company has done an exceptional job of managing the transition between the two generations.
"The simple story is the product cycle," said Sanjiv Hingorani, an analyst for Salomon Brothers. "The company product position is better than it's been at any time in the past five years, from personal computers to mainframes."
The Digital Equipment Corporation on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter results that were better than expected, and that, combined with I.B.M.'s showing, caused a number of analysts to say the industry's long-expected shake-out may be under way.
 
Haves and Have-Nots
 "There are going to be a few large successful players, a few boutiques and a lot of pressure in between," said Daniel Mandresh, a computer industry analyst at Merrill Lynch.
Mr. Weil said: " We're seeing a gulf developing between the haves and have-nots. The good companies are coming through with better-than-expected results."
Because of the war with Iraq, I.B.M.'s chairman, John F. Akers, decided not to comment on the financial results. Instead, Mr. Akers issued a statement that said in part: "With the outbreak of hostilities, our first thoughts are for the men and women serving there. We pray for their safety and well-being."
He did say I.B.M. was faced with uncertain conditions affecting markets and economies worldwide.
 
Strong Sales in Some Lines
 In a conference call with industry analysts yesterday, company executives said I.B.M. had shown particular strength in its RS/6000 work stations, AS/400 minicomputers and high-end data storage products. They said I.B.M. had sold all of the new air-cooled ES/9000 mainframe computers, the first members of its newest top-of-the-line family, it had been able to manufacture.
I.B.M. said it had benefited from the impact of currency exchange rates because the dollar had weakened since the end of September. It also said sales continued to grow in Europe although at a slower rate.
The company, based in Armonk, N.Y., said it had met its goal of reducing the number of its employees by 10,000 worldwide in 1990. The departures were voluntary.

HEADLINE: Cheap Oil May Not Be Enough to Cure Recession

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
A free fall in the price of crude oil for February delivery, which plunged more than $10, to $21.44 a barrel yesterday, may have raised hopes for a rapid recovery in the nation's slumping economy. But even if a quick, successful end to the military campaign against Iraq pushes oil prices well below $15 a barrel by midsummer, as some oil analysts predict, daunting obstacles to economic growth will remain.
Although lower oil prices would help the economy, a number of underlying problems would remain. These include growing unemployment in military-supply and manufacturing industries, declining incomes, falling home prices, rising taxes and a credit crunch. Combined with the surge in oil prices after Iraq invaded Kuwait last August, these developments sharply depressed the confidence of consumers.
 
Oil's Impact on the Recession
 Many economists agree that if oil prices average $20 a barrel this year, instead of $30, economic output would rise by half a percentage point. That would lighten the blow of the recession, but not enough to alter significantly the forces that shaped the downturn. 
 "A short, successful military conflict was widely expected by consumers," said Richard Curtin, director of consumer surveys at the University of Michigan. A longer conflict with heavy American casualties would be a staggering blow to consumers, who finished 1990 with their optimism about the economy near the lowest level since a deep recession in 1981-82.
Indeed, it is unclear what effect the missile attacks on Israel early this morning would have on short- or long-term oil prices. Other negative developments in the Persian Gulf could send prices soaring anew.
So far, oil traders have focused on a global market that is bulging with crude oil supplies. Many oil analysts said prices could tumble below $15 a barrel this spring. Demand for oil from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is averaging 21 million barrels a day, while OPEC is producing 23.5 million barrels a day.
If that imbalance continued, it would "provide a tremendous boost" to the economy, said Gordon Richards, economist at the National Association of Manufacturers in Washington. Lower gasoline prices, a lower inflation rate and falling interest rates should stimulate the economy into a rebound by midsummer, he said.
 
$20 Billion for the Economy
 Prof. Benjamin M. Friedman, an economist at Harvard University, said an average oil price of $20 a barrel would add $20 billion to the economy this year. If the Federal Reserve also eased credit by lowering interest rates, he said, the recession would be less severe.
But Rimmer de Vries, managing director at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Corporation, said Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, would be less willing to push interest rates lower if oil prices fell below $20. He said Mr. Greenspan had noted repeatedly that if the Persian Gulf crisis were to end by March or April, lower gasoline prices and inflation rates would by themselves improve consumer confidence. Further easing of credit by the Fed would thus be unlikely, Mr. de Vries said, because it could overstimulate the economy and raise the inflation rate.
Profits at most big oil companies would be little changed in the first half of the year, because oil prices fell gradually through the spring of 1990 to less than $15 a barrel by mid-June. Most oil companies based their 1991 drilling plans on oil prices averaging in the low-$20's.
Dozens of industries get a boost from tumbling oil prices, including airlines, chemicals, retailers, consumer goods and automobiles. Shares of those companies soared yesterday on the world's stock markets.
Some analysts think that once victory over Iraq is assured, Saudi Arabia would reward President Bush with oil prices low enough to insure a strong economy -- and his re-election -- in 1992. The Saudis increased their daily oil output to more than eight million barrels after the Kuwait invasion, from their OPEC quota of five million barrels.
"Oil prices in the low teens would give us at least $60 billion a year that would add a point to growth" of the gross national product, said Philip K. Verleger, an expert on oil markets and visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics, in Washington.
"The United States has no way out of this recession in terms of fiscal policy," he said. "What we need is a 'petro' push. If I were a Saudi, I'd consider George Bush the best President they've ever had."

HEADLINE: Surge in World Markets Takes Many by Surprise

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
After days of worry about how far the world's stock markets might drop at the start of a war, markets rose strongly yesterday around the world, beginning in Tokyo and continuing through Asia to Europe and the United States.
But the firing of Iraqi missiles into Israel last night is certain to dampen some of the optimism that pervaded markets after the first 24 hours of military action. 
 In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 issues rose yesterday to 1,004.11 points, or 4.47 percent, to 23,446.81.
The confirmation that several Iraqi missiles exploded in Israel came after the Tokyo market opened this morning. The Nikkei 225 had jumped more than 400 points, but fell on news of the missile attack before rallying again later.
When the European markets opened yesterday, all news from the war zone had been positive for the forces arrayed against Iraq -- there had been no counterattack by Iraq and no offensive had begun against Israel. And trading in Europe opened with a rush.
In Germany, the DAX index of 30 shares surged to a one-day record rise of 99.99 points, or 7.6 percent,, closing at 1,422.67.
 
Big Run-Up in Paris
 The French market's main index jumped to 1,560.47, a surge of 102.70 points or 7.4 percent, the largest one-day rise since the CAC-40 index was introduced in 1988. In London, where stocks had declined less since the Kuwait invasion than in many other markets, The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index rose 2.4 percent, or 49.8 points, closing at 2,104.6. Volume was 564 million shares, double the recent volume.
The global surge in stocks, which was also reflected in exchanges in Norway, Australia, Hong Kong, Italy, Spain, the Netherlands and Canada, left some fund managers and analysts scrambling to supply explanations. One was that stock markets often move against the consensus view, because bad news has already been incorporated into the prices of stocks -- demonstrated in this case by the sharp declines since the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
Another explanation was that expectations had been fooled, so far, by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. Some traders said that they had expected a strong counterattack and an assault on Israel -- a rocky start to the war for the United Nations alliance. But with early reports showing little trouble for the alliance forces, a wave of investor optimism was unleashed, sending markets soaring.
"The word is relief," said Alistair Ross Goobey, chief investment strategist at James Capel Ltd. in London.
 
Effect on Small Markets
 In addition, analysts said many of the markets that rose most sharply, like those in Germany and France, are small and relatively illiquid, which means a little new money can push an index a long way.
Some think the rally can continue if the war news remains positive for the coalition led by the United States.
"It is highly likely that you will get disappointments ahead," said Roger Palmer, chief strategist at Kleinwort Benson Securities in London. "The question then will be how far markets come back. Well, based on the performance today, I think the downside risk is limited."
But some said the markets would remain volatile, trading on headlines from the Persian Gulf, and vulnerable to sharp declines. These analysts also think underlying economic conditions -- recessions in the United States, Britain, Canada and Australia, and slowing growth elsewhere -- would limit any gains even when the uncertainties of the war are resolved.
David Roche, international strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company in London, added that the deteriorating situation in the Soviet Union was a potential crisis that could sharply undermine European markets.

HEADLINE: A $150 Million Loan Buys Philadelphia Some Time

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17

 BODY:
City officials have finally obtained a $150 million loan, or enough currency to relieve a sort of Russian winter that has settled over city government, complete with lines of creditors, a weekly specter of payless paydays for municipal employees and erratic shortages of everything from fax paper to pants for new police recruits.
The loan, to be completed on Friday, does not resolve the city's political stalemate or its fiscal crisis, but it gives the city breathing room until spring when most property and business taxes are paid. At the same time, certain provisions of the loan are intended to put pressure on city and state officials to develop a long-term solution to Philadelphia's chronic inability to pay its bills. 
 "It's a critical first step," said Benjamin Blakney, the City Treasurer. "It's one small step on our road back to recovery," said Jonathan A. Saidel, the City Controller.
A potential snag in the agreement developed late today when State Attorney General Ernie Preate Jr. said he would not approve the loan until he had resolved his concerns, which included the cost of the loan to the city and the risk being incurred by the state teachers' pension fund. The pension fund is part of a coalition that would lend the money to the city, and the Attorney General is required by law to review and approve contracts by state agencies, which include the pension fund.
 
A State Authority Called For
 Also in the lending coalition are local banks and the pension fund of city employees. Under terms of the loan, the city will obtain $100 million on Friday. The rest will become available later this month, but only if city officials start working with state legislators to create a state authority that would help rebuild the city's credit. The authority is only vaguely defined at this point. The loan agreement calls for the introduction of legislation to create it but does not require that the authority actually be created.
It remains to be seen whether city and state officials can overcome sharp differences on the scope and power of such a state authority. Legislators, particularly Republicans who control the State Senate, insist that any state aid to Philadelphia be linked to state supervision of the city's finances. Many city officials reject any such comprehensive state supervision, saying they would only accept it in the future if the city got into trouble again. City officials want a state agency that would primarily guarantee future city borrowing.
City and state officials are also at odds over many other critical issues, including the city's demands for more state aid and state permission to enact a new sales tax. "Perception is reality, and the perception is that Philadelphia is frankly irresponsible in its spending practices," said State Senator Robert C. Jubelirer, a Republican from western Pennsylvania and president pro tempore of the Senate.
As much as anything else, the loan is a monument to the dire financial condition of the city, which faces a $230 million deficit on this year's $2.1 billion budget and a projected deficit of at least $170 million in the fiscal year beginning July 1.
Philadelphia had to approach local banks and the pension funds because it had been shut out of the markets where municipalities usually obtain capital. Last year, after the city was unable to head off its fourth consecutive deficit, Wall Street credit services downgraded Philadelphia's credit rating. The rating eventually reached a level generally reserved for speculative investments that are likely to go into default.
 
High Cost to the City
 The city had initially sought more than $350 million on Wall Street. But the financing from local lenders, culminating six weeks of negotiations, will be only $150 million for 8 to 12 weeks. Moreover, the city had to agree to pay more than $5 million to obtain the loan, or the equivalent of an annual interest rate of more than 24 percent. As another part of the agreement, the city must provide an unusual level of security to investors by earmarking some payments it is scheduled to get from the state for use in repaying the loan.
Saying that the cost of the loan was "absolutely unconscionable," State Treasurer Catherine Baker Knoll, a member of the state pension fund board, cast the board's lone vote on Sunday against the agreement. She said the loan was too risky for the pension fund of the Pennsylvania Public School Employees' Retirement System.
Officials of banks in the lending coalition, lead by the Corestates Financial Corporation, would not discuss the loan.
The Philadelphia police and firefighters unions, which also oppose the loan as too risky for their pension funds, were unable to persuade the Court of Common Pleas on Wednesday to stop the loan. The unions said they would appeal a judge's refusal to block the agreement.
The city's pension board, which handles the pensions of all municipal employees, is normally barred from investing in anything with as poor a credit rating as Philadelphia's, but the City Council amended the law last year in a way that allows the board could lend money to the city.
On Wall Street, reaction to the loan was muted. "This is a short-term infusion of cash for short-term problems," said Hyman C. Grossman, managing director of Standard and Poor's, the credit rating service. "But the long-term problem remains." He said the city needed outside monitoring in some form, more state aid, more taxing authority and more authority to obtain long-term financing to defray its accumulating deficit.
Philadelphia has been operating on a shoestring since September. It has delayed payments to more than 1,000 creditors, dipped into cash reserves held for other purposes, like airport construction projects, and even set rigid controls on petty cash expenditures by city agencies.
As a result, social service agencies have furloughed workers, companies have stopped shipping office supplies to city agencies, street contractors have left some streets partly repaved, and one creditor even repossessed a mobile police station.
The loan will not provide enough money to pay off all of the creditors.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia;
Riyadh Prepares for New Dangers After Iraqi Attack on Israel

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Friday, Jan. 18

 BODY:
The kingdom braced today for growing internal and external threats in the wake of Iraq's missile attacks on Israel and the Saudi city of Dhahran.
The savoring of the coalition's early air successes over Iraq was dramatically cut short in the early hours of the morning by news of the Iraqi attack on Dhahran. The Iraqi missile was intercepted and destroyed by an American-launched Patriot missile, but the attack alarmed Saudis throughout the oil-laden Eastern Province and in the capital. 
 Saudi officials had no immediate reaction to the attacks on Dhahran or on Israel. But several had previously expressed concern about the impact that an attack on Israel -- and possible Israeli retaliation -- would have on the cohesion of the American-led coalition. Meanwhile, Riyadh moved quickly to prevent what Saudi officials described as an increased threat of terrorism.
"The external threat from Iraq seems much less," the official said, "but the internal threat of terrorism is very real."
Before Iraq's latest attacks against Saudi Arabia and Israel, the kingdom had greeted what appeared to be its dramatic air victory over Baghdad with a mixture of astonishment, relief and euphoria. Jubiliation was particularly strong among Kuwaitis, whose Government in exile is based in Taif, on the Saudi Red Sea coast.
 
'Thank You, Bush!'
 "This is a masterpiece! Thanks to Bush! Thank you, Bush!" exclaimed Suleiman Majid al-Shaheen, Undersecretary for Foreign Affairs in Kuwait's Ministry of Foreign Affairs. "We will be for generations and generations grateful to you for what you have done. As a mighty power, you didn't forget the small nation that needed your help. You reaffirmed the principles of your founding fathers. And you will remain part of us."
Abdullah Bishara, a Kuwaiti who heads the Gulf Cooperation Council, the Saudi-dominated economic and military coordinating group based here, said that because of Saddam Hussein's "bluster," no one had anticipated the one-sidedness of the fight so far.
"It's too good to be believed," Mr. Bishara said. Noting that there were no demonstrations Thursday in Arab capitals, where there was considerable sympathy for the Iraqi leader and opposition to the deployment of Western forces here, Mr. Bishara gloated: "Where were the so-called Arab 'masses'? They are here, in the gulf countries."
There was no reaction from the Saudi ruler, King Fahd, who was reported to have spent much of Wednesday night and almost all of Thursday closeted with his brothers in the Defense Department's Operations Room. One Saudi close to the royal family said that President Bush and the King had closely coordinated plans for the attack, and that King Fahd had spoken by phone to Mr. Bush shortly after the first wave of air attacks began.
The official described the King as "delighted" with the outcome so far of the coalition's assault, but also "saddened that Saddam Hussein had subjected the Iraqi people to this painful experience."
The Government made an unusual concesssion to Saudis, many of whom are extremely skeptical of what they see and hear on state-controlled Saudi broadcasts and newspapers. The English-language television channel carried mostly unedited and uncensored reports from the Atlanta-based Cable News Network throughout the day, including a report that Saudi civil defense forces and even soldiers had fled their posts at the border town of Khafji after Iraqi missiles hit an oil facility. Even the Arabic channel used some translated CNN material in its gulf broadcasts.
Other members of the ruling family and prominent Saudi officials expressed relief that Mr. Hussein had been able to do so little damage to the Saudis so far.
 
Prince Lauds U.S. Ties
 "While it is always sad to see any military response to international disputes," said Prince Abdullah, "I'm relieved that there may now be some relief for the whole world, and that Jubail has not been hit." The Prince is head of the Royal Commission of Jubail and Yanbu, which oversees development in these two industrial cities.
Prince Abdullah said that the alliance's joint assault on Iraq would undoubtedly enhance relations between the United States and the Saudis. "It's wonderful," he said. "Even the Israelis may be jealous."
Saudis seemed proud that some of their own pilots had flown with the Americans on initial sorties. Among them was Prince Sultan bin Salman bin Abdulaziz, a former astronaut.
Many Saudis stayed home Thursday, sleeping late after an anxious night that included two air raid alerts. Asian and other foreign workers continued to scramble for gas masks today. Many left the 70 official distribution points disappointed.
Many business owners kept their stores closed, though traffic increased considerably as the day wore on. In the city's main market, only half the stalls were open. "Most Saudis were simply content to savor their relief at home with their families," one Saudi said.
Security was tightened throughout the capital. Policemen with machine guns were posted in front of most ministries; armed police and security men patrolled streets, questioning loiterers and checking foreigners' identity cards.
An announcer on official Saudi television said that the Ministry of Interior was warning against threats to stability. "Harsh punishment will be brought against any effort to destabilize or sabotage the country," the announcer said, quoting a ministry official.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

REACTING TO WAR
The price of crude oil dropped by a third, falling by $10.56, to $21.44, by far the biggest single-day drop in history. After word of the attack on Israel, oil sold for about $2 more in cash trading. [Page D1.] New York Merc officials sighed with relief after a hectic day. [D4.]
After a moment of prayer, stocks took off, with the Dow posting its second-biggest point gain ever on the heaviest volume since October 1989. The Dow soared 114.60, to 2,623.51. [D1.] Markets rose strongly around the world yesterday, although stocks fluctuated in Tokyo early today after the bombing of Israel. [D5.]
For American industry, it was mainly business as usual, with hopes that the war would end quickly. But that was before the attacks on Israel. [D1.]
Daunting obstacles to economic growth will remain even if there is a quick, successful end to the campaign against Iraq. [D5.]
Persian Gulf oil flowed as usual after war broke out, the Government said, the only damage coming when Iraq destroyed a storage tank in Saudi Arabia. [D6.]
The dollar fell sharply, confounding expectations of analysts who thought it would be a safe harbor in wartime. [D6.]
The credit markets staged a powerful rally, with prices of some Treasury securities rising by as much as 2 3/8 points and interest rates falling sharply. [D12.]
Precious metals prices plunged, with gold registering its biggest one-day loss since early 1983. [D13.]
President Bush's address to the nation on the air strike Wednesday night apparently attracted the largest audience in the history of American television. CNN was the center of much of the viewing, and almost all of the attention. [A14.]
 
COMPANIES
I.B.M. surprised Wall Street by reporting an usually strong fourth quarter, while Apple Computer posted a sizable profit increase. The gains were seen as evidence that the industry is set for a shake-out that will put more pressure on competitors. [D1.]
BankAmerica reported a 6.3 percent earnings increase and reiterated its interest in buying the Bank of New England. [D2.]
The Daily News's publisher denied a report that the Tribune Company's board had scuttled an impending negotiating breakthrough between The News and its striking drivers' union. [B1.]
Bookstores were besieged by customers wanting anything about the Middle East they could get their hands on. [D16.]
The high-profile Hollywood producing team that achieved great success with "Top Gun" but recently stumbled with "Days of Thunder" has signed to make films for Disney. [D3.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
The White House has approved a Japanese company's purchase of 40 percent of the only U.S. company that builds precision machine tools for making atomic weapons. [D1.]
 
THE ECONOMY
Construction of homes and apartments plunged last month and for all of 1990, to levels not seen since the recession eight years ago, the Commerce Department reported. [D2.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
War could give Alan Greenspan a chance to redeem his reputation. Economic Scene. [D2.]
Many expected a war to bring panic. Instead, the reaction verged on euphoria. Whether that reaction lasts is likely to depend on the course of war news. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]
Even though war coverage will limit advertising on television, especially in the early days, many agency executives say the situation for advertisers will probably return to normal rapidly. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D16.]

HEADLINE: STOCKS SOAR AND OIL DROPS ON WAR NEWS;
Dow Jumps 114.60 Points; Tokyo Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
After a moment of silent prayer for the troops in the Persian Gulf and a short clang of the opening bell on the New York and the American Stock Exchanges, trading got off to a flying start yesterday.
The waves of buying carried the Dow Jones industrial average up 114.60 points, or more than 4.5 percent, to end the day at 2,623.51. The Dow's point gain was second only to a jump of 186.84 just after the market crash in October 1987. 
 By the 4 P.M. close, exhausted traders had shoveled 318.9 million shares through the highly automated Big Board system -- the heaviest since the Monday after the plunge in October 1989 and the eighth-largest volume on record.
 
Amex Was Busy, Too
 The American Stock Exchange, which deals in smaller stocks, had its own headaches but at a much lower level, handling 19.6 million shares, the highest in six months.
The United States markets were taking part in a worldwide rally in stocks yesterday in reaction to reports that the United Nations military forces had dominated the opening stages of the war against Iraq.
In Tokyo today, after reports of an Iraqi missile attack on Israel, stocks fell at first, then headed up again. At the close, the Nikkei 225-stock average was up 361.49 points, to 23,808.30.
 
Reaction to Attack on Israel
 Shortly after the attack on Israel, a trading executive for Instinet, which provides off-hours trading, said people were "starting to trade actively again, with many orders to sell." He said that among them were orders to sell Intel, I.B.M. and Apple Computer.
At 9 P.M., he said that activity had "calmed down." He said a number of people had entered orders in the system to sell at prices below yesterday's close but that trading on the system was light.
Both stock exchanges in New York were so alert to the possibility of terrorism that neither allowed visitors on its trading floor yesterday. The Big Board was ringed with police barricades.
The gains were striking. Minnesota Mining rose 4 1/8, International Paper 3 1/4, General Electric 3 3/8, Merck 3 1/8, Alcoa 2 5/8 and I.B.M. 6 5/8.
In one of the few disappointments, Motorola slid 3 3/4, to 45 7/8, after reporting a drop in profits.
A drop of $29.80 in the gold price toppled gold shares, with Newmont Gold and ASA each down 4.
And despite a decline of $10.56 in oil prices, to $21.44, oil and oil-service stocks generally held their gains.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, also loaded with blue chips, climbed almost 4 percent, meaning that the gains were widespread.
The composite index of the over-the-counter market advanced almost 3 percent and the Amex market-value index was up more than 1 percent.
 
Tied to Their Desks
 "We traded three days' volume in one day," said David S. Chao, head trader in New York for County NatWest Securities. "There wasn't much time to leave your desk or you could miss a chance to buy at good prices because the prices were so volatile."
William S. Stack, chief investment officer for the Lexington Management Corporation, with $2.5 billion in investments, said the firm, known for its Minute Man symbol, put about $50 million into the market yesterday.
He said the money went into retailing, airline, restaurant and paper issues and, to a lesser extent, high-technology stocks.
He said he had $80 million more to go into "the kind of stocks that benefit from an economic recovery stimulated by falling interest rates, like retailers, airlines and newspapers."
Everybody seemingly lined up to buy: banks, insurance companies, pension funds and all stripes of money manager and individual investor -- all flush with cash and eager to put money to work. Many bought 25,000 to 50,000 shares at a clip -- and often considerably more.
"The advance today is for real," said David B. Bostian Jr., chief economist and strategist for Jesup, Josephthal & Company. "We've seen the lows in the stock market. We could have some interim setbacks, depending on events in the Middle East and the Soviet Union, but I believe the risk-reward is very favorable."
Even so, today is both the start of an uncertain weekend in the gulf and a market "witching hour," when options and index futures expire. Traders said prices today could be volatile for both reasons. "Now we're coming into a weekend, Mr. Chao of NatWest said, "and people will be a little more cautious because of the uncertainty. The Dow is coming into a resistance level, near 2,610 at the start of the year, and it should have some difficulty getting through."
 
Looking Toward Recovery
 Birinyi Associates said program buying added less than 9 points to the Dow yesterday. Big Board officials intervened 14 minutes after the market opened, because the Dow had already soared 50 points. At that point, the exchange imposes limits on program trading.
At the opening of trading, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index contract rose the 5-point limit imposed by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which halted trading briefly then set a 20-point limit. Prices quickly rose to within 3.15 points of the new limit.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview;
IRAQIS FIRE MISSILES AT ISRAELI CITIES AFTER SECOND DAY OF ALLIED BOMBING; U.S. DISCOURAGES AN ISRAELI RESPONSE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
After a day of allied successes in the war against Iraq, Baghdad struck back today with missile attacks on Israel and Saudi Arabia.
Preliminary reports indicated that seven Iraqi missiles hit Israel, and there were reports of injuries but no deaths. The missiles did not appear to be armed with chemical warheads. 
 The attack on Saudi Arabia was less severe. The Pentagon said one Iraqi missile was fired at Saudi Arabia and was intercepted by a Patriot anti-missile rocket just before striking the Dhahran area in the Eastern Province of Saudi Arabia.
 
Right to Respond
 Tonight, the Israeli Ambassador to the United States, Zalman Shoval, said that Israel had refrained, at Washington's behest, from launching a pre-emptive strike at Iraq's missile batteries before the Iraqi attack but that his nation "reserved the right" to respond.
The United States has strongly warned against any Israeli military action against Iraq for fear that it might threaten Arab support for the international alliance against Baghdad.
The Iraqi counterattacks were the first reversal in a war that had gone completely the allies' way. United States officials said 159 Iraqi targets were hit in the first day of intense air attacks against Iraqi and Kuwaiti targets.
 
Testing Ground for Weapons
 The gulf war involved all four branches of the American military and has become in effect a testing ground for the expensive, high-technology weapons it developed for use against the Soviet Union.
American officials said that in the early going Stealth fighters, electronic jamming equipment and devastatingly accurate cruise missiles had paid for themselves in saved lives and powerful blows to a technologically outmatched adversary.
In initial reports on the results of the constant strikes against Iraq, American officials said the Iraqi Defense Ministry and the presidential palace had been struck by Navy Tomahawk cruise missiles fired from offshore in the first use of these weapons in combat.
 
Restrictions on Reporting
 It was difficult to fully analyze the Pentagon assessments, because of the extraordinarily strict information policy imposed by the Bush Administration. The Pentagon offered only sketchy details, including the death of one American pilot, in today's lone official briefing at 9 A.M. Eastern standard time. That briefing took place before the launching of most of the air sorties against Iraq in the second night of bombing, and before the Iraqi missile strikes.
American officials said they were confident that they had inflicted significant damage on their first-priority targets, including command centers, the Scud missile launchers, antiaircraft batteries and Iraqi warplanes. But they acknowledged that they had not destroyed all their targets.
Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, fended off questions about the combat situation this morning by saying full disclosures might endanger American lives.
Speaking away from television cameras on the understanding that they not be quoted by name, other American officials acknowledged that the early air strikes had not entirely achieved their mission of severing President Saddam Hussein's command and communications networks. A Pentagon official said today that some of Iraq's most advanced combat planes had escaped the initial wave of attacks by flying north to other bases.
That report, plus the success in destroying many of the airfields and planes, seemed to explain the remarkably low level of resistance in the first evening of the assault and promised tougher fighting ahead with the Iraqi military, which has been hardened by eight years of war with Iran but has never experienced the scope and intensity of the assault that began about 2:30 A.M. Baghdad time on Thursday.
 
Unremitting Wave of Sorties
 Since then American, French, British, Saudi and Kuwaiti warplanes kept up a virtually unremitting wave of aerial sorties that totaled well over 1,300 through the first day and another night in the Persian Gulf.
The initial assault also included Army AH-64A Apache helicopters that a Pentagon official said crossed into Iraq on a special-operations mission to disable an Iraqi air defense radar.
Officials said the air assault was just beginning and was merely the first phase of the assault against Iraq that was likely to include far more difficult and potentially more bloody ground battles with Iraqi soldiers and tank crews who have dug into southern Iraq and Kuwait.
 
Sense of Euphoria in Washington
 The reports of initial allied victories lent a sense of euphoria to a capital that had been mired in talk of recession, Federal budget deficits and open partisan warfare between the White House and Congress.
Administration officials tried to chasten this mood by playing down the importance of first-day successes and warning of more battles to come and with them the likelihood of American casualties. But President Bush and his advisers warned that there would be no "pause for peace" to give President Hussein time to rethink his defiance of the United Nations demand that he withdraw.
"We're using force and we're not going to stop until he pulls out of Kuwait," Mr. Bush said at the White House.
 
Hussein Is Defiant
 But in Baghdad, a defiant Mr. Hussein vowed to fight on as his Government said it would defeat the American-led coalition. Iraq released its first casualty reports, saying that 23 civilians had been killed and 66 wounded in allied bombing attacks.
Reports of damage and casualties were impossible to confirm independently. Iraq said its forces shot down 55 attacking warplanes, while the United States and Kuwait's Government-in-exile each reported one plane lost and Britain reported two downed aircraft through the first day and night of fighting. The American plane, an F/A-18 off the carrier Saratoga, was shot down by an Iraqi surface-to-air missile and its pilot was killed, American officials said. He was identified tonight as Lieut. Comdr. Michael S. Speicher, 33 years old.casualty in the war.
Officials here stressed that the combat had just started and that more casualties were inevitable.
 
Oil Flow Normal, U.S. Says
 The United States Government said Persian Gulf oil flowed as usual. The only reported damage to fields or facilities came when Iraqi artillery fire hit a Japanese-owned storage tank in Khafji in northern Saudi Arabia that had held 200,000 barrels, American officials said.
Allied F-15's and radar-evading F-117 Stealth fighters kicked off the war with the first blows against air-defense batteries near Baghdad. Two battleships and a cruiser in the Persian Gulf and Los Angeles class submarines in the Red Sea fired Tomahawk cruise missiles at communications sites, power plants and other fixed targets.
Attacking behind the wave of high-technology weapons, aging B-52 bombers pounded Iraq's Republican Guard, the elite of Bahgdad's 545,000-strong army in southern Iraq and Kuwait.
Although Iraq had responded to the allied air attacks on Thursday night primarily with antiaircraft fire, American pilots engaged Iraqi warplanes in their first aerial duels today.
 
Protected Weapons a Concern
 American officials said Mr. Hussein, whose personal behavior and military plans remained an enigma, may have enough missiles and planes in hardened bunkers to mount resistance in the days ahead. The point was driven home hours later with news of the Scud attacks.
"The Department of Defense has confirmed the firing of missiles from Iraq into Israel and Saudi Arabia," the White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said tonight. "Damage assessments are being made."
"The President is outraged at, and condemns, this further aggression by Iraq," said the Mr. Fitzwater. "Coalition forces in the gulf are attacking missile sites and targets in Iraq."
An American official said the United States had sent two flights of F-15's from Turkey to destroy the missile launchers that had delivered the blows.
 
Agreement to Consult
 The United States and Israel had previously agreed to consult if Iraq launched an attack on Israel. The Israelis had told the United States last week that their response to an Iraqi missile attack would depend primarily on the extent of damage done and the ability of the allied air force to prevent a second strike.
American officials said earlier in the day that the fact that Iraq launched no Scud missiles in the first day of fighting suggested that efforts to destroy the weapons or sever command links to them had been largely successful.
But General Powell cautioned that some of the Iraqi missiles, Soviet-designed surface-to-surface rockets known by their NATO code name, are on mobile launchers that are hard to find. American military planners were said to be concerned that about 30 to 35 mobile Scud launchers may still be operable.
It also was too early to tell how long the war would be confined to the air before American and allied ground forces are used. American military officials said the bombing could be expected to continue for days at least, in hopes of avoiding a more costly conflict on the ground by destroying as much of Iraq's command structure, missile sites, air force and ground forces as possible.
 
'It Will Be Awesome'
 After talking with Defense Secretary Cheney, Senator Alan K. Simpson, the Republican Whip and a close ally of Mr. Bush, said: "My sense is that it will be continuous, it will be all out, it will be awesome. We'll continue to pound and pound and pack him down in the sand with bombardment day and night."
The Bush Administration had to put out a small political brushfire this afternoon after Mr. Fitzwater said of Mr. Hussein: "All he has to do is surrender and comply with all the U.N. resolutions. The situation to Saddam is the same now as it's been for five and a half months, and all he has to do is lay down his arms."
The White House later explained that the United States was not calling for the total surrender of Iraq, but was sticking to its initial purpose of driving Iraq's army out of Kuwait. If Mr. Hussein leaves Kuwait, Administration officials reiterated today, they will stop the war.
But they said there would be no "pause" in the fighting to permit him to fully absorb what has happened and to reconsider his position. Doing that, some officials argued, would allow him to regroup militarily and increase the casualties if he then decided to keep fighting.
Mr. Bush later said he did "not want to get into semantics" and repeated his insistence that Iraq leave Kuwait.
At the briefing in the Pentagon today, Mr. Cheney and General Powell gave reporters the first bare outlines of what American and other allied forces had been able to achieve in their air raids and what remained to be done.
 
Attacks on Communications
 General Powell said the first day's bombing had done considerable damage to "the means by which the leadership of Iraq talks to its soldiers and communicates and maintains control." But he said Iraq's command system had not collapsed.
A Pentagon official said the Air Force had failed to knock out Iraq's television station in its first raid and that planes had been sent back today to attempt another mission to destroy it. Meanwhile, Mr. Hussein used the television station to make a speech exhorting his countrymen to fight and to show that he himself was still alive and unhurt.
Reports on damage to Iraq's air force were mixed. In Paris, Gen. Maurice Schmitt, head of the French armed forces, said that allied air raids had destroyed "on the order of 50 percent" of Iraq's warplanes. Pentagon officials said that B-52's and other attack planes had pounded Iraqi airfields but that it would take some time before they were entirely disabled.
"We have command of the skies, although we will have to pay attention to keeping it," said Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee and a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee.
 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Two buildings and several vehicles that were damaged or destoyed last night by one of the Iraqi missile attacks against Israel. (Agence France- Presse) (pg. A8)
 
Chart/Map: "After the First Wave, Iraq Lashes Back"
 
Allied Forces
 
The attack began Thursday morning local time.
 
Tomahawk cruise missiles carrying conventional warheads were launched from U.S. Navy battleships, cruisers and destroyers in the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf.
 
Land- and ship-based fighter aircraft massed at bases in northern Saudi Arabia, then flew north over Iraq and Kuwait, jamming radar and knocking out antiaircraft weapons.
 
B-52 bombers aimed at Iraq's elite infantry, the Republican Guard, in northwest Kuwait and southern Iraq. B-52's made runs against military centers and chemical and nuclear weapons plants throughout Iraq.
 
Iraqi Forces
 
In the initial attack, Iraqi planes were prevented from scrambling. The only retaliation was artillery fire at Khafji, where oil tanks burned but no injuries were reported.
 
Early Friday local time, Iraqi Scud surface-to-surface missiles struck Israel, causing undetermined damage and at least some minor injuries. Early reports said missiles exploded in Tel Aviv, Haifa and in unpopulated areas of the country.
 
An Iraqi missile was intercepted before it struck Dhahran. The Pentagon said American aerial bombardments of Scud sites were continuing.
 
Map shows locations of air bases in Saudi Arabia, and where Allied and Iraqi forces attacked. (pg. A1)

HEADLINE: Of the Palate, From the Palette

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
"ART WHAT THOU EAT," a display of 19th- and 20th-century American paintings and sculpture at the New-York Historical Society through March 22, makes a good case for developing an eating disorder. Eating too much -- or not eating at all -- is one of the few ways that individuals can still exert some control over the corporate takeover of American food supplies that is depicted here.
The connection to food production is, after all, an Everyman sort of link to nature. Without it, people are as vulnerable as unfettered skiffs in a squall. When appetite is no longer a response to choosing among foods of one's own making, it becomes an amorphous urge easily co-opted by industry. TV dinners, junk food, liquid diets, microwave ovens and McDonald's are the beachheads in corporate America's assault on idiosyncratic taste.
I 
 t's scary. The stylistic changes in the painting of food in the last 200 years are a graphic witness to what has been lost. The sensuous, intimate pastoral scenes and still lifes from the 19th century seem quaint and fumbling next to the inviolable, stern lines of contemporary Pop and Minimalist food art.
Bye-bye personal taste. Now you will have it their way.
The 16 groupings of paintings are arranged by concept, from food and economics to food and sexuality. The first, "Rituals for Victuals," sets the show's sociohistoric scheme. "The Dinner Party," by Henry Sargent in the 1820's, is the interior of a Boston Brahmin dining room where the mood is sheltered, mellow and perfectly ordered. By 1950, "Oyster Party" by Lucille Corcos is still a celebration of the convivial powers of food, but the tone has changed. It's chaotic. The helpful servants are gone, and so is the sedate decorum. People are cooking and crouching and singing and eating and everybody is having one heck of a time. Yet they are naive, folkloric figures, vulnerable to the world outside (where it is snowing). By the mid-20th century, food has lost its communal magic.
In "Football" (1986) by Janet Fish, the dinner companion is a hard-edged television set. Dinner is a bag of potato chips, a jar of pickles, a loaf of sliced bread, a plastic container of fruit with a plastic fork. Isolation is the entree. Even the diner is missing.
According to Linda Weintraub, director of the Edith C. Blum Art Institute at Bard College and one of the show's four curators, the stylistic move from mutable lines, mellow moods and a manageable scale to food rendered in stern strokes, unwieldy planes and scenes that seem reduced to their bottom line, parallels the nation's changing attitude toward its daily bread. "Style is never arbitrary," she said. "It always changes in tandem with society."
At the beginning of the 19th century, America was a family-oriented, farm-centered society: the food eaten was the food grown. Dinner was a direct result of effort and was therefore imbued with thankful wonder (in our Puritan soul, we could only enjoy the pleasures of food as just rewards for honest labor). By the mid-19th century, railroads and steam ships had widened the distance between the field and the table, and the span was chock full of new, exotic choices like citrus fruits and pineapples, bananas and lobsters. Inundated with choice, people began controlling food through processing. Canned and preserved foods zoomed to the front of grocery shelves in the late 19th century. Industrialization started to displace the family farm. Mass marketing started to ring the dinner bell. Instead of being judged by its inherent quality, food was increasingly appraised for the quality of its packaging.
Eventually, this led to what Harvey Levenstein, a historian and author of "Revolution at the Table" (Oxford, 1988), calls "an abundance of choice and no variety." Consumers can choose between containers, but the contents are about the same. Well, breaking up is hard to do. And by the mid-20th century, fewer than 10 percent of Americans had a hands-on connection to getting their food to the table. Instead of eating three planned (and generally communal) meals, most had 17 random encounters with food a day, Miss Weintraub said. In other words, we had turned into a nation of lonely nibblers.
 
Industrial Bread
 The effect of this shift on the individual rises like a strong yeast from the progressions of paintings in the section called "Wonder Bread." John Francis's "Still Life" from 1866 is a warm tableau of homely, handmade biscuits. Jasper Johns's "Bread" (1969), on the other hand, is a perfect slice of something white and industrial that is resolutely mounted on a void-like lead ground. The word "unappetizing" comes to mind. But a few years later, "EST Graduate," Peter Nagy's depiction of Pepperidge Farm's high-rise corporate headquarters, doesn't even "un" the appetite. It does nothing to the senses at all.
The shift from the sensuous to the systematic is even more vivid in the section called "Technology of Fruit." The first painting, Levi Wells Prentice's "Apples in a Basket" (1890), is a ruby cascade; each fruit is different, none are perfect, all inspire a rhapsody: apple pie, applesauce, stewed apples with boudin, baked apples, apple butter. But oh no! The paintings progress to "Fruit Bowl," in which Hans Hofmann's abstract lines are resolutely removed from nature and the colorless bowl of fruit is a small corner in colliding planes of reality. Next is Roy Lichtenstein's "Bananas and Grapefruit," a flat, cold-blooded cartoon of perfect, unapproachable, genetically engineered fruit.
It's enough to unsettle a gal's "appetistat." Paintings arranged around concepts like "From Market to Merchandising," "Men and Meat: Hunter, Butcher, Carver," and "Apples and Eve" provide further insight into the country's current existential crisis of consumption. Chronic obesity, diet-related health problems and runaway eating disorders seem the logical outcome to the progression of alienation from appetite that is depicted in "Art What Thou Eat."
 
A Horror of Brutality
 Estranged from the pleasure of idiosyncratic appetite, the Puritan in us has also developed a sense of horror with the brutality of food production. In only two centuries, we've moved from the philosophy that good food is just reward for hard labor to a nonspecific anxiety over what we eat. America's vulnerability to every burp and gurgle of diet-related "findings" from the health profession today is just one painful attempt to find a new justification for eating with pleasure -- or at least with purpose. And the gag response that many viewers had as they stood in front of Abraham Rattner's portrait "The Meat Cutter" (1964) is another.
Unlike the cool, Minimalist paintings that precede it, "The Meat Cutter" is painted in bold strokes and vivid colors. It is a portrait of a butcher whose bloody victim is virtually indistinguishable from his own blood-spattered arm, a revolting emblem of the blurring of lines between human and animal and the growing apprehension about people's proper position in the food chain. The painting is a sad little pat on the back to a culture estranged from its own appetite.
"Of course, you can't decide what to have for dinner; food is gross and messy and inhuman and unhealthy," says the painting. And in the 25 years since, food advertisers and marketers have tirelessly said: "Let corporate America find something tidy and healthy and convenient for you, dear!"
 
Where and When
"Art What Thou Eat" will be on view through March 22 at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street, in Manhattan. Hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday to Sunday. Admission is $4.50 ($3 for the elderly; $1 for those under 12). Information: (212) 873-3400.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Apples in a Basket," top, by Levi Wells Prentice, and "Bananas and Grapefruit," by Roy Lichtenstein, at the New-York Historical Society. (The New York Historical Society)
