HEADLINE: So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual

BYLINE: By Agis Salpukas

 BODY:
Some executives canceled flights, fearful of terrorism. American flags sold briskly at Woolworth's. And advertising agencies scanned commercials for messages that might seem offensive to a nation at war.
But for the most part, American industry went on with business as usual yesterday, hopeful that the war would end quickly. That was before Iraqi missiles struck Israel last night, complicating the political and military situation and bringing a great deal more uncertainty to the scene. 
 Representatives of the steel and airline industries expressed hopes yesterday afternoon that the drop in oil prices that followed the first huge air raids on Iraq would ease cost pressures. In real estate and retailing, executives hoped an improvement in the public's morale would help slumping sales.
"If it continues this way, I think it removes an enormous amount of uncertainty from the consumer," said Barbara Allen, a real estate analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company, after the initial optimistic reports of heavy damage in Iraq and few American casualties. "I would not be surprised to see an upsurge in home buying because the affordability trend is so favorable."
Following are accounts of how the fighting in the Persian Gulf region is affecting various segements of American industry:
 
Mixed News for Airlines
Most major international airlines, including British Airways, KLM and Pan Am, said cancellations had increased on most international flights. Domestic flights in the United States showed little effects of the war.
At the same time, the airlines were optimistic that the steep slide in oil prices, if sustained, will drive down the cost of jet fuel.
"This could provide major cost relief for the industry and start to limit the losses," said Paul Karos, an analyst with the First Boston Corporation. He said a doubling of fuel prices for most of the fourth quarter had damaged the industry.
Jeffrey Kriendler, a senior vice president for corporate relations at Pan American, said the spot price for aviation fuel dropped to 77 cents a gallon yesterday from 97 cents the day before. Before Iraq invaded Ku- wait on Aug. 2, the spot price was 61 cents a gallon.
In the aftermath of the opening round of air raids on Iraq, many international airlines said they had been flooded with calls.
Sandy Gardiner, the senior vice president of public relations in North America for British Airways, said the airline had 10,500 calls at its offices at Heathrow Airport yesterday morning. But only 84 callers canceled flights, he said.
Odette Fodor Gernaert, manager of public relations at KLM in the United States, said, "We have increased cancellations, but we have also seen an increase in the number of bookings."
She said some people might be switching to KLM, hoping that the airline was less of a target for terrorists than an airline of a nation whose foces were involved in the military strike against Iraq.
Airlines have made it easier to cancel; most are allowing people holding tickets with cancellation penalties to change their travel plans or turn their tickets in for vouchers good for one year. John Hotard, a spokesman for American Airlines, said only a small number of passengers had canceled trips and asked for vouchers.
At the Marriott Corporation, whose 639 hotels make it one of the largest chains in the world, Rodger Conner, the senior vice president of communications, said there had been no noticeable increase in cancellations or drop in reservations.
The sharpest drops in occupancy have come at the company's International hotels in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and Amman, Jordan. But the International Hotel in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, is 98 percent full, he said, because many Saudi families had moved there from more exposed places.
Terry Denny, the manger of public relations for the International Air Transport Association, the industry trade group, said airlines had been notified to get in touch with their insurance brokers in London to find out what new rates would be for their flights.
Lloyd's of London and other insurers increased rates more than tenfold on some flights to the Middle East before war broke out. Some airlines responded by canceling flights.

HEADLINE: So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual: Real Estate;
A Way to Cure Buyer Paralysis

BYLINE: By Richard D. Hylton

 BODY:
Real estate executives, analysts and builders were relieved but cautious yesterday about what theinitial phase of the Persian Gulf conflict meant for their troubled industry.
"It's certainly positive to the extent -- and presuming -- it clears up the uncertainty on the part of consumers and commercial tenants to make long-term commitments to purchase a home or lease space," said David Shulman, a managing director and head of Salomon Brothers' real estate research department. 
 And Barbara Allen of Kidder, Peabody & Company commented, "If it continues this way, I think it removes an enormous amount of uncertainty from the consumer and I would not be surprised to see an upsurge in home buying because the affordability trend is so favorable."
Like Mr. Shulman, many industry experts said it was far too soon to judge fully the effects of the conflict.
"I hope now, with the early signs of what is going on, that some of the paralysis might be eliminated and people can bring more buyers and sellers together," said James W. Allwin, Morgan Stanley & Company's managing director in charge of real estate investment banking.
Nearly all real estate experts said that if the likelihood of a protracted conflict faded quickly, consumers would begin to focus more on domestic economic issues like the recession, falling real estate values and the banking crisis.
"The issue here is whether the problems in the economy are more fundamental than the rise in oil prices caused by the invasion of Kuwait and its affect on consumer confidence," said Mr. Shulman. "In my view, the problems are more fundamental."

HEADLINE: So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual: Retailing;
A Run on Flags, But No Trends

BYLINE: By Isadore Barmash

 BODY:
There was no obvious slowdown in retailing yesterday and few industry executives were willing to quantify what the effect of the war could be.
Many retail companies, including Sears, Roebuck & Company, the largest, said they felt the Mideast conflict -- along with the recession -- had weakenened consumer confidence and hurt business. "But it's impossible at this time to say what the effect of a short- or long-term war could be on our business or that of the industry," said a Sears spokesman in Chicago. 
 At the K Mart Corporation, the second-largest retailer, a spokesman said, "Our January sales pattern has been nicely up so far and we have not heard of any interruptions in it."
The Woolworth Corporation said many of its stores reported a run on American flags. "We can't quantify how many, but lots were sold," a company spokesman said.
If the war lasts at least several days, Woolworth expects flatter or reduced sales, the spokesman said, primarily because many consumers would probably stay home to watch the developing news on television. If the war ends fairly soon, he predicted, "it will have a significant, uplifting effect on sales."
Woolworth and other major retailers said they had increased security at their headquarters buildings.

HEADLINE: So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual: Steel;
Looking for Help In Durable Goods

BYLINE: By Jonathan P. Hicks

 BODY:
Steel industry executives said the war in the Middle East would not affect their business prospects in the near term.
"Very little of what we produce goes into war materials," said Robert Lefley, a spokesman with Inland Steel Industries. "The biggest impact will be what it does to the overall economy and consumer confidence, which will enable consumers to buy durable goods." 
 Other steel executives and analysts said a disruption in crude oil supplies, or higher prices, would have a damaging effect in the long term. Energy costs for steelmakers and other manufacturers have climbed by as much as 50 percent since the Persian Gulf crisis began last summer.
"When the problem is resolved and tension eases, we can expect investment in plant and equipment to accelerate and the industrial expansion phase of the business cycle to continue," said Frank W. Luersson, chairman and chief executive of Inland Steel and chairman of the American Iron and Steel Institute, a trade group.
A long war would be disastrous for the steel industry, analysts said, because interest rates and inflation would likely remain high.
"The steel industry needs lower interest rates to help stimulate capital spending," said Christopher Plummer, a steel industry analyst with the WEFA Group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., a research concern. "The construction industry and capital spending in manufacturing accounts for 60 percent of the demand for steel."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: AROUND THE WORLD - JAPAN;
Financial Aid Is Pledged

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Japan responded today to the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf with a new pledge of financial aid to the United States and allied troops in the region and a reiteration of its determination to avoid direct combat itself.
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, emerging from a round of hurried meetings with his Cabinet, said, however, that Japan might use some of its military aircraft to evacuate civilians or refugees from the region but that such a decision was still being debated. 
 Mr. Kaifu said Japan would extend "maximum possible support" to military actions taken by the anti-Iraq allies in what officials said was an effort to avoid the delays that led to criticism of Japan last summer, especially in the United States Congress.
The debate on the symbolic but direct role of using a military transport plane illustrated the continuing concern that Japan not take any steps that might conceivably be interpreted as a violation of its ban on the use of force that was written into the Constitution after World War II.
Japan's avoidance of a direct role stems from deep-seated pacifist feelings, a popular distrust of the military and an equally widespread feeling, especially in business circles, that the gulf crisis generally should be resolved by negotiations rather than fighting.
 
$4 Billion Promised Earlier
 Japanese officials said they have become increasingly concerned that Tokyo react quickly with a pledge of financial aid to avoid criticism, such as was expressed in August, that it was late in coming up with its package of $4 billion in aid for the military buildup and for economic relief in the gulf.
"The most important message we have right now is that we stand firmly by the United States," Taizo Watanabe, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, said in an interview.
But Mr. Watanabe and other officials said that because of Japan's procedures, specific needs would have to be identified for Mr. Kaifu's Government to come up with precise sums in addition to the $4 billion, less than half of which has actually been disbursed.
"Please don't expect that right after the shooting starts, we come up with a figure right away," Mr. Watanabe said.
Since the beginning of the crisis in August, Japan has gone through an agonizing debate over the gulf, culminating in an extraordinary setback for Prime Minister Kaifu when his bill to send unarmed military personnel to the region died in Parliament.

HEADLINE: More Cells for More Prisoners, but to What End?

SERIES: First of two articles about the future of American prisons.

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VACAVILLE, Calif.

 BODY:
At a time when the hard-pressed Federal and state governments are desperately trying to reduce most of the services they provide, they continue to build prisons as fast as possible. America's taxpayers are financing several billion dollars in new prisons every year -- and still there are not enough cells for the flood of prisoners, many of them with special mental, medical and educational problems.
By the middle of 1990 there were 695,000 inmates in state prisons and 60,000 in Federal penitentiaries, an overall increase of 80,000 in one year. That is the largest growth in 65 years of record-keeping. 
 Yet even as frightened voters elect politicians who promise to be tough on crime and authorize more and more walled compounds surrounded by razor wire, motion detectors and heavily armed guards, there seems to be little discussion about what these troubled institutions are supposed to do.
Are they simply to remove a wrongdoer from society for a while, preferably a long while, and then release him little different than he was on entry? Are they supposed to punish a prisoner somehow beyond just the simple loss of freedom? Or should they also seek to rehabilitate the prisoner to avoid future crimes?
 
Imbalance in Purpose?
 "The four classical purposes of imprisonment are incapacitation, deterrence, punishment and rehabilitation," said Frank Hartmann, executive director of the criminal justice program at Harvard University. "Right now, the balance has gone. You'd have to say rehabilitation is out and incapacitation and punishment are in."
But a growing number of prison administrators now say that locking up inmates for a while does little to make the public safer. So many criminals are being ordered to do time that the system, no matter how fast it builds prisons, cannot keep up. Corrections officials say a state could go broke trying to construct and run enough prisons to guarantee that each inmate serves a full sentence. And so, many of these convicts are released after barely a third of their sentences, having learned nothing -- except, perhaps, some crime tips from fellow inmates.
"There is no relationship between the incarceration rate and violent crime," said Daniel P. O'Brien, assistant to Minnesota's commissioner of corrections. "We're in the business of tricking people into thinking that spending hundreds of millions for new prisons will make them safer."
Anthony Travisono, executive director of the American Correctional Association, a group of prison professionals, agreed. "It is a kind of a fraud, no doubt," he said.
 
No Cure in Buildings
 Mr. Travisono said society is failing to follow through after conviction. "The problem is," he said, "we have bond issues for new buildings. But buildings, new or old, have never cured anyone of anything."
He added: "If they want corrections to lock people up just to vegetate and fester, then we don't want to take the rap when these folks come out the same as they went in, or worse. There has got to be much greater public discourse on the problems."
Kenneth McGinnis, director of Illinois's Department of Corrections, said: "Economic pressures are overwhelming most states and governments. Prisons will simply bankrupt the states unless we find cheaper ways to punish and figure out how to keep all these people from returning."
 
A 'City' of Sorts
 The state prison complex here in Vacaville, some 40 miles northeast of San Francisco, is the largest in California, probably in the world: 8,000 inmates, four times the prison's 1980 population, housed in cells and dorms sprawling over 1.5 square miles of arid land.
California's prison system is the largest in the country. It has 97,000 inmates, or 29,000 more people than live in the state capital near here. There are 32,000 employees at 20 facilities and an annual operating budget exceeding $2.3 billion.
It's still growing rapidly. Ten years ago, the system had 22,000 prisoners at 12 facilities. The Corrections Department's planning and construction division has been told to plan for 173,000 inmates by 1996, meaning 20 more prisons at a cost of at least $2 billion. When the next three prisons with 8,000 beds are completed, the state system will still be operating at 185 percent of design capacity.
Nearly 40 states are operating under court orders concerning overcrowding. Corrections, an industry of some $25 billion a year, spent $3 billion on new construction in 1990.
"We're spending billions on bricks and mortar and security staff," said Alvin Bronstein, executive director of the National Prison Project of the American Civil Liberties Union, a prisoner-rights group. "But we're not spending on maintenance and programs because people believe, 'Nothing works, so why bother?' "
 
'Life' Can Mean Life
 The reasons for the record increases are clear. Reflecting public anger, more felonies now draw longer terms. So do new classes of felonies; in many states, repeated drunken-driving convictions now require prison time, while three-time violent offenders can draw true life terms. In 1975, 15 percent of all California's felony convictions led to prison terms. Today, 35 percent do.
Determinate or fixed sentences have eliminated much judicial discretion in assessing prison terms. Rigid formulas cross-reference a criminal's record, tendency to violence, use of weapons and other criteria to compute a precise term without flexibility -- not, for instance, five to 10 years. Use of probation is way down and violators are rejailed more quickly; 35 percent of California's inmates are violators of probation from old crimes.
Finally, the drug epidemics of the 1980's have swelled inmate populations. California officials estimate that 85 percent of convicts enter prison with a substance abuse problem, often creating greater problems of control and counseling.
"In the 1970's, we had a lot going on in counseling, treatment, education," said Mr. McGinnis of Illinois, whose prison system grew 20 percent last year, the largest increase of any state. "Then we're overwhelmed with these numbers, so we end up just scratching the surface."
 
Don't Dare 'Coddle'
 No corrections official would argue that sure-fire strategies have been developed for turning criminals away from crime. But most corrections officials maintain that it is sensible and cost-effective to try counseling, education and drug treatment. Even if only a few inmates respond, they say, the public is that much safer and will be spared future expenses for years of warehousing them.
But in the get-tough political climate, virtually any such programs smack of coddling criminals, and most politicians want no part of them.
Years ago, in fact, California's legislators wrote rehabilitation out of the state code. "Our mission," said Michael Van Winkle, a corrections spokesman, "does not include rehabilitation."
But if sheer punishment, not rehabilitation, is now the aim of incarceration, are the prisons doing even that job adequately?
Centuries ago, no criminal was sentenced to prison as punishment. Prisons were merely storage sites where prisoners were housed temporarily, at their own expense, to await trial or imposition of their punishment, which typically was exile, flogging or execution. As an alternative to, for instance, cutting off the hands of thieves, a reform movement of the late 18th century led by Pennsylvania Quakers invented the penitentiary: humane housing where convicted wrongdoers would go for a term to reflect on their sins and be penitent.
 
Starting at the Bottom
 Since then, the slow but steady increases in prison populations combined with declining public enthusiasm for rehabilitation efforts among more violent criminals. Prison terms, though varying widely in length for the same crimes even in adjoining counties, did remove the criminal from society. But in many cases the prisons became mere schools for crime.
And all this was complicated by the emergence of a substantial urban underclass, usually uneducated and often involved with drugs. For many of these convicts, who have rarely had stable families, steady employment or even basic reading skills, any prison programs are aimed more at providing basic habilitation than rehabilitation, Mr. Hartmann said. "If you're an illiterate drug addict who can't fill out a basic job application," he added, "it would seem very likely we would see you back in prison someday."
James Waite of Oklahoma's penal system stresses the expense of the current system. "Ninety-eight percent of all prisoners will be back on the street someday," he said. "If they don't go out any better prepared to face life, then we've just warehoused them for a time. And at our cost of about $15,000 a year per inmate, it would be cheaper to send them to college than keep them in here."
 
A Place to Sweat
 Most citizens would find even the nicest prison a discouraging place, an where everyone awakens, eats, works and sleeps at set times. Well-behaved inmates can earn better accommodations, moving from solitary cells to 100-man open dorm rooms, and jobs, from washing floors to filing papers.
But here at Vacaville, a combination of units built in the 60's and 80's, everyone swelters through the heat; when it's 90 outdoors, it's 110 degrees in the rooms. Bathrooms are open to full view. Prisoners can be stripped and searched before and after each visit, as can visitors who wait behind a steel barrier that warns: "Do Not Kiss Thru Bars."
Good inmates may receive four packages per year. Television is offered in day rooms, corrections officials say, primarily as an institutional tool to soak up inmates' idle time. Twice each night every room and cell is checked; if the guard can't see skin through the door, the inmate is awakened to prove his presence. There are gangs and violence, though less at newer institutions, where large groups cannot mingle.
 
Safer Than the Street?
 Then why isn't the threat of a prison sentence more of a deterrence to crime? "I think the average American would find such a life quite a deterrence," said Mr. Travisono, "But for many of these guys, prison is safer than the street. They get three square meals a day, a bed and free health care because that's what the laws set as humane."
Reuben Greenberg, chief of police in Charleston, S.C., suggested that there would be greater deterrence if first offenders were punished more certainly, though not necessarily more harshly. As he put it, "How fast would you learn to get your hand off a hot burner if it took a year to feel the pain?"
Many experts say that what's necessary is a range of sanctions. "Right now," says Barry Krisberg of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency, "we can give criminals an aspirin or a lobotomy." What's most important, he says, is more certainty of some other punishments, from community service and house arrest to intensive probation with daily check-ins.
Mr. Travisono said governors, not corrections officials, would have to lead the search for new methods of punishment. "They are the leaders of a state," he said. "They must involve prosecutors, judges, community groups. It's a bureaucratic reality that corrections works for the governor. When he or she says this is the budget, you don't try to outbudget your boss in public. Or you're not around anymore either."

HEADLINE: N.F.L. PLAYOFFS: The Conference Championships;
Lofton Brings Healing Touch

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., Jan. 17

 BODY:
As the events in the Persian Gulf developed Wednesday night, and Carlton Bailey, a linebacker for the Buffalo Bills, became concerned about his father, a chief warrant officer in the naval reserve stationed there, one of the two telephone calls Bailey received from a teammate came from James Lofton.
When Marv Levy, the coach of the Bills, was asked again this week to explain the influences that helped reduce the internal problems that characterized Buffalo's 1989 season and could have threatened the team's future, the first player he mentioned was James Lofton. 
 Less than a year and a half after he was released by the Los Angeles Raiders, Lofton, a wide receiver, will present his former team with a significant problem in the American Football Conference championship game this Sunday.
Although the 34-year-old Lofton's success in the Bills' playoff victory over Miami last Saturday provided the latest evidence that his skills have not eroded, his contributions have extended beyond statistical achievements since he joined Buffalo early in the 1989 season.
 
In His 13th Season
 And the numbers, by themselves, have already given him Hall of Fame-caliber credentials. Lofton is at the end of his 13th professional season, his second with the Bills after two with the Raiders and nine in Green Bay, seven of which were Pro Bowl seasons.
Lofton's 642 career receptions rank sixth in pro football history and third among active players, behind Art Monk of Washington and Ozzie Newsome of Cleveland. Lofton's 7 receptions in the playoff victory over the Dolphins last Saturday, for 149 yards, were the most in each category for a playoff game in his career.
His 174 yards in Buffalo's victory over Philadelphia on Dec. 2 was the fourth-highest total in his career, the most in six years, and increased his career total, now 11,963, beyond that of Don Maynard and into third place for career receiving yards. His 63-yard touchdown catch, 45 seconds into that game, was the 60th touchdown reception of his career and started the Bills toward a 24-0 first-quarter lead. The 71-yard catch that day was Lofton's longest in six years.
Less than 18 months ago, Lofton was considered an expendable part of a Raider offense that had grown to include Willie Gault, acquired in a trade with the Chicago Bears, and Mervyn Fernandez, a former most valuable player in the Canadian Football League. "I wasn't looked at as a backup," Lofton said. "I was either a starting receiver or nothing."
 
New Role for a Veteran
 Soon he was unemployed, considering a number of options that included the Bills and the Philadelphia Eagles. Nick Nicolau, a receivers coach who joined the Bills for the 1989 season, had held a similar job during Lofton's second season with the Raiders.
"Nick Nicolau knew him and liked him," Levy remembered. "We brought James in with a bunch of 22-, 23- and 24-year-olds. He outran all of them. We just wanted to see if he lost speed or lost movement, and he hadn't."
Once the Bills had their answer, Lofton had to accept a new role. His first game with Buffalo was the first of his professional career in which he was not a starter. He started just 2 of 11 games in 1989, and caught just eight passes. But his contribution to a tense atmosphere in the dressing room went beyond those statistics.
"I've been around worse, when it's physical, between players and player and coach," Lofton said. "It was settled before the season was over, but the articles hadn't finished coming out."
"I watched James when I was younger and he was with Green Bay," said Andre Reed, the wide receiver. "He was always, 'This guy is amazing.' You never thought he would lose a step.
"I worked out with him during the off-season," Reed said. "And the way he works out makes you want to be a better player."
 
Tight Security
 Bill Polian, the general manager and vice president of the Bills, said that the security force for the game had been doubled from 250 people to 500. Polian confirmed that the Federal Aviation Administration would not allow airplanes that carry advertisements to fly over the stadium. He said the Bills organization had asked for a ban on such flights long before the current global situation. The Bills increased security and banned the sale of beer for the playoff game against Miami as a result of a raucous celebration that followed the regular-season victory over the Dolphins on Dec. 23.

HEADLINE: Rhode Island Bank Inquiry

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 18

 BODY:
Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun urged on Thursday that an independent prosecutor be appointed to investigate Rhode Island's banking crisis.
"I feel it is dead wrong," he said, "to have multiple investigations." 
 The Governor did not disclose how the special prosecutor would be picked but said his decision was not an attempt to put pressure on the State Attorney General, James O'Neil, and legislative leaders to abandon their investigations.
There have been widespread reports that insiders at credit unions withdrew thousands of dollars from their institutions just before Mr. Sundlun closed 45 of them on Jan. 1 after the collapse of the state's private bank insurance system.
Fifteen institutions, with about $1 billion in deposits, remain closed because they cannot obtain Federal deposit insurance.
Under the Governor's bailout plan, closed banks and credit unions will be merged into a new state agency, the Depositors Economic Protection Corporation, which would make payouts to depositors. Depositors would receive up to $12,500 in cash immediately but would have to wait as long as four years for the rest of their money, up to $100,000.

HEADLINE: About New York;
In a Dark World, A Diverse Few Pray for Peace

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
At 3:30 A.M. yesterday, a cool breeze caressed a nearly empty Amsterdam Avenue in front of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. A newspaper truck rumbled past. A man carrying a mountain of plastic bags stumbled toward tomorrow.
The neo-Gothic towers of one of the world's largest churches loomed against wispy white clouds high in the violet sky. It was 11:30 A.M. in Iraq. Inside the vast and nearly dark cathedral, two women sat alone holding candles. They have been staying here in the deadest part of the night since Sunday, praying for peace. Since early evening Wednesday, they and half a hundred other vigilants could no longer pray that there would be no war. 
 "Peace be with you," Kristin Bergfeld, owner of a cleaning services company, said by way of greeting.
Ms. Bergfeld recalled Wednesday evening. She held up the tiny, tiny remnant of a candle that she had been burning when war exploded. "I will always have this," she said with palpable intensity. "I will always, always have this."
The vigil is held around the "Peace Altar" made by the late woodworking genius George Nakashima. It is carved from a 125-foot English walnut tree, perhaps 300 years old. A small bouquet of white carnations and a red table rested on the huge altar.
New York in times of national crisis is very much like New York at any other time. People walk straight ahead through difficult lives, trying not to catch the eye of strangers. They look for something interesting but are sure they have seen it all before. A demonstration in Times Square, no matter the purpose, is but another inconvenience.
 But judging by call-in shows, talk in cafes and barbershops, the unexpected smiles, there is some pleasure even in this hopelessly blase metropolis that Uncle Sam is standing tall in a strange and dangerous conflict. Or at least that, so far, few Americans have been casualties.
But in the liberal churches grave doubts persist. At the Episcopal cathedral, Islamic religious leaders have been invited to pray for peace. At the Community Church of New York, a Unitarian Universalist congregation, body bags were placed on the front steps in dramatic protest. The impressive thing about the prayer vigil is that it is so unimpressive. Individuals come quietly as pilgrims seeking some measure of peace.
Over the course of the vigil at St. John the Divine, there was a Vietnam veteran in a three-piece suit whose son is somewhere in the Persian Gulf. There at the same time was a woman who had been thrilled to get a picture in the mail of her best friend's fiance. He too is in the Gulf. The two held hands, sobbing inconsolably.
Pilgrims have included an executive who had been in Baghdad two days before. A Nicaraguan who had lived through that nation's bloodbath. A little boy who said God lived in the green balloon he carried. A group of young women formed a circle and danced.
There have been a 30-year-old investment banker and an unemployed man dying of AIDS who lives in a single-room-occupancy hotel. On Wednesday night, there were people who had wandered the city looking for an open church.
"You can bring horrible dreams here and be comforted," said a poet, writer and actor ("what New Yorkers do"), Seanan Forbes, the other woman praying.
Around 4 A.M., Lewis S. Payne, a social worker, padded in. As much as he disagreed with Washington's attack, he was now enraged at Iraq for hitting Israel. "I found myself really angry last night," he said. "I actually felt a rage." He stepped into a corner and put on Zen Buddhist robes. He joined with the women to sing hymns, then settled onto the prayer mat and pillow that he had brought. He crossed his legs. He expressed despair at the seemingly inexorable pace of events.
"It's as though we're playing out a dream and everybody knows the scenario," Mr. Payne said. "The whole thing is an absurdity."
Time passed. Every so often, security men would saunter past. A woman who had brought her cat in a box slept in the choir seats. A drunk staggered here and there. The vigilants talked and prayed and made paper cranes, a symbol of peace. They recited a G. K. Chesterton poem in unison, "Our earthly rulers falter, our people drift and die."
Ms. Forbes left after finishing her second consoling letter to "Any Service Member." Outside, birds began to chirp and dawn teased the stained glass. Mr. Payne suggested that he and Ms. Bergfeld pray.
"Forgive us, forgive us for this madness we bring on ourselves," he said through tears. Then they hugged, two human beings alone with their hopes, fears and conceptions of God.
Morning traffic drowned out New York's birds. It was 3:05 P.M. in Iraq.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Public Opinion;
Approval of Bush Soars

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. KAGAY

 BODY:
President Bush's job approval rating has sharply increased in the past week, reaching the highest level measured for an American President in the last 30 years, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
Eighty-six percent of 544 adults interviewed Thursday evening -- one day after the war against Iraq began and primarily after it was reported that Iraq had attacked Israel -- said they approved of the way Mr. Bush was handling his job as President, while 10 percent disapproved and 4 percent had no opinion. 
 The approval rating was 20 percentage points higher than in a Times/CBS News Poll taken Jan. 11-13, before the hostilities. In the past such striking shifts have occurred at the outset of other international conflicts, as Americans rallied in support of flag and country, their armed forces overseas and their Commander in Chief.
Mr. Bush's rating was the highest recorded for any President since John F. Kennedy received 83 percent approval in a Gallup Poll in May 1961 after another military operation, the unsuccessful attempt to liberate Cuba in the Bay of Pigs invasion.
The new nationwide telephone poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points, and polls completed in just one day can be subject to additional error.
Over the past week, an even greater movement occurred in public opinion about the desirability of starting military action against Iraq. In the latest poll, 79 percent of the respondents said the United States "did the right thing in starting military actions against Iraq," while last weekend, before the war, only 47 percent said the United States "should start military actions against Iraq" if it did not withdraw its troops from Kuwait by Jan. 15.
Only 16 percent now say the United States should "have waited longer to see if the trade embargo and other economic sanctions worked," whereas last weekend, before the war, 46 percent expressed a preference for giving sanctions more time to produce results.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Off Despite Crisis; Technical Factors Aid Slide

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar closed mostly lower yesterday although war raged in the Middle East, a crisis that would normally draw investors to the safety of the United States currency.
Reports of early successes by the United States-led forces fighting to oust Iraq from Kuwait had already pushed the dollar down, and technical factors accelerated the slide yesterday, traders said. 
 "The market was acting as though the war had ended, not that it started," said Rayelle Weber Tyler of International Treasury Consulting.
The dollar closed yesterday at 1.4985 German marks, down from 1.5080 marks Thursday. It finished slightly higher, however, against the Japanese currency, at 132.50 Japanese yen, up from 132.35 yen.
 
Feeble Midday Rally
 The dollar managed a feeble rally around midday when Defense Minister Moshe Arens of Israel spoke of retaliating for Iraq's missile attack on Israel. Even reports of new missile attacks, which were later proved false, failed to help the dollar.
Ms. Tyler said dollar sentiment has been bearish since last year because of the weak United States economy. The prospect of war changed the mood, but the buying evaporated when fighting actually broke out. Others traders called it a classic case of "buy on the rumor, sell on the news."
The British pound rose yesterday to $1.9490 from $1.9330 Thursday. The dollar closed at 1.2565 Swiss francs, down from 1.2690 in the previous session.
Against the Canadian currency, the dollar closed at $1.1585 (Canadian), down from $1.1590 (Canadian) Thursday. Against the French franc, the dollar closed at 5.0945 francs, down from Thursday's 5.1190 francs.

HEADLINE: Modest Late Rally Lifts Treasuries

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
A modest late rally lifted prices of long-term Treasury securities yesterday. The market had marked time earlier waiting for bond traders to convert some of their huge gains of the previous session into cash. But dealers said no significant profit taking materialized.
One reason, dealers said, was the sharp drop in crude oil prices to below the level that prevailed before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. This diminished fears of inflation, the bane of the fixed-income market. 
 Another big reason for the lack of selling in the Treasury debt market was the plunge in the key interbank lending rate after the Federal Reserve had moved to drain reserves from the banking system.
 
 Heavy Selling in Tokyo
 "What contributed heavily to the market's firmness was its failure to emulate the sharp losses in our Treasury bonds overnight in Tokyo," said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. "News that Iraqi missiles had hit Israel came after our market closed, but caused heavy selling of our Treasury bonds in Tokyo. The selling there erased half the two-point gain in the long bond earlier in New York."
But the loss in Tokyo was quickly recouped at the opening in New York. In late trading, the Treasury benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in August 2020, were offered at 106 13/32, up 6/32 on the day, as the yield dipped to 8.17 percent, from 8.18 percent the day before.
Thursday, widespread belief that the war would end quickly and successfully sent the price of the long bond soaring over two points, or $20 for each $1,000 of face value, and its yield tumbling to 8.18 percent from 8.39 percent. A week ago the long bond's yield was 8.35 percent.
 
Auctions Next Week

On Wednesday, the Treasury plans to auction $12.5 billion of new two-year notes, and on Thursday $9 billion of new five-year notes. The two-year notes traded on a when-issued basis to yield 7.11 percent, down from 7.15 percent the day before, while the yield on the five-year notes slipped to 7.35 percent from 7.68 percent on the same basis.
The credit market was fascinated by the odd behavior of the market in Federal funds. The funds rate is considered the basic cost of credit because that is what banks charge each other for temporary loans.
According to dealers, the funds began trading at 6.5 percent, or a quarter-point below what is now perceived as the Federal Reserve's target for this interest cost. Just before noon, Eastern time, the Fed moved to drain reserves from the banking system over the weekend.
Instead of bolstering the funds rate, the draining of reserves was quickly followed by a drop in the rate to as low as 4.5 percent. The funds rate then snapped back to 5 percent and traded at 6 percent just before the close.
 
Linked to Holiday
 Some dealers said the odd moves in the funds rate reflected the ample reserves in the banking system that resulted from the Fed's cut in reserve requirements last month, as well as the fact that banks were still reluctant lenders.
Other dealers linked the Fed's action to the observance of the holiday for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on Monday. While the Federal Reserve will be closed Monday, primary dealers in Treasury securities and many banks will be open, along with most brokerage houses.
In any event, the gyrations in the funds rate had no impact on bill rates, which are normally the debt issues most sensitive to changes in the funds rate. The discount rate on 90-day Treasury bills dipped two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.08 percent; six-month bills dropped nine basis points, to 6.18 percent, and the one-year bills lost four basis points, at 6.22 percent.

HEADLINE: Teacher Corps May Feel Weight Of New York City Budget Crisis

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
The first teacher-recruits in a new national program to help troubled schools have come to New York City and met the enemy, but it's not truancy, or poverty, or drugs or violence. It's a budget crisis.
And unless the Board of Education and the teachers' union can come up with a foolproof fiscal strategy to avoid as many as 4,000 layoffs, these recruits, with the least seniority, will be among the first to go at the end of the month. 
 "It's very disheartening and ironic," said Jessica Larntz, who joined the Teach for America program out of Stanford University. "I saw Teach for America as very idealistic, a way to give something back to society."
"We knew we'd be assigned to districts with high teacher turnover because of poverty, crime, drugs and single-parent families," added the 23-year-old native of St. Paul. "It's been a tough experience, and thekids have sometimes been difficult to control, but in mid-October, I made my decision to stick this out. Now, it's sad to have it taken away after so many people put so much time into it. But I guess nobody could do anything about the money."
 
Welcome to New York
 Ms. Larntz is one of about 155 recent graduates from some of America's best colleges who came here in September, one of nearly 500 young people nationwide who volunteered for the Peace Corps-like program. Energetic and idealistic, their goal was to spend two years in the country's toughest urban or rural districts.
But their arrival here coincided with a worsening of the city's financial problems and a nationwide recession, and now hope has given way to disillusionment.
Jennifer Copaken, a 22-year-old Harvard University graduate who moved from her home in Potomac, Md., to teach in Queens, said: "The hardest thing is how it vacillates from day to day. It's very difficult to stay motivated."
"One day, people say the wage deferrals or furloughs could go through and our jobs could be saved," she added. "Other days, we're told we might be transferred to Oakland."
 
When Does the Ax Fall?
 Principals at schools throughout the city know that they may have to dismiss hundreds of teachers with the least seniority to help reduce New York's budget deficit by slashing $90 million from this year's schools allocation. Most or all of the dismissals could be rescinded within the next two weeks, if an agreement is reached between the board and unions representing teachers and other school workers to achieve the cuts by deferring school employees' pay, rather than laying off workers.
But, if layoffs are required, the vast majority of these young teachers will be out of a job on Feb. 1. And, because of their junior status as Board of Education employees and the molasses-like progress of the budget negotiations, they may only learn their fate a few days before that deadline.
 
'A Pretty Bad Blow'
 And even if the board resolves its immediate crisis without layoffs, these young teachers' jobs are still vulnerable because of job cutbacks that are likely to result from state budget cuts and about $400 million in proposed reductions in Board of Education financing included in the city's fiscal 1992 budget plan presented Wednesday by Mayor David N. Dinkins.
"It's a pretty bad blow," said Jackie Graves, a Williams College graduate who is teaching at Public School 65 in the Bronx. "If it happened, I don't think I could move. I've got an apartment with a lease that I probably couldn't get out of."
Suzanne Muchin, a teacher at Intermediate School 139 in the South Bronx, added: "We all chose New York City because of the teacher shortage here. We thought we were doing New York a favor."
Most teachers in the program are paid $26,500 a year.
Curtis Etherly and Timothy Knowles, the program's regional directors, said at two emergency meetings for local corps members in the last two weeks that they were trying to line up replacement jobs in Los Angeles, New Orleans and Oakland, and subsidized training for members who wanted to stay in New York.
But Mr. Etherly acknowledged that many would be "fending for themselves," and that the threat of layoffs in many cities "could not have come at a worse time, in the middle of a school year, and when financial problems are affecting New York and other cities."
Many corps teachers say that it would be extremely disruptive to have to move next month, and that their experience has soured them on the idea of remaining with the program, even though Mr. Etherly said that they would have "guaranteed placements" next fall at the location of their choice.
"If any of our members are cut, it would be a real shame and very shortsighted," said Wendy Kopp, the 23-year-old founder of Teach for America.
The program was started last year, and its first recruits were dispersed to classrooms around the country in September. Ms. Kopp's idea was that intelligent, dedicated college graduates who were not education majors would take a crash teacher-training course and spend two years teaching as a form of public service.
Ms. Kopp and her assistants recruited prospective teachers at more than 100 colleges, raised more than $2 million from corporations and foundations and convinced school systems to hire corps members even though they lack education degrees or teacher certification.
"Our corps is exactly what New York City needs -- young, energetic teachers," she added at a meeting last week to prepare New York corps members for the possibility of layoffs.
Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez seemed to concur, at least last year, when he said: "Without programs like this, we are never going to resolve pipeline issues related to attracting the very best and brightest to our profession."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Participants placed in New York City by Teach for America, a program to help recruit teachers for troubled schools, at a group meeting led by Curtis Etherly, right, regional director. Ms. Larntz is a native of St. Paul. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times) (pg. 35)

HEADLINE: Alcoa Posts $140.4 Million Quarterly Loss

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The Aluminum Company of America, stung by lower aluminum prices and $275 million in reductions to after-tax income, yesterday reported a $140.4 million loss for the fourth quarter. The company had net income of $164.7 million, or $1.88 a share, in the quarter in 1989.
The company said that excluding the charges, fourth-quarter earnings were $134.6 million. Revenues fell slightly, to $2.75 billion, from $2.76 billion in the quarter in 1989. 
 Alcoa, the nation's largest aluminum producer, said the reductions to income included a $142 million write-off of mostly non-aluminum businesses, but the company did not specify the operations involved.
 
 Environmental Costs
 An additional $90 million charge was related to the costs of cleaning up environmental problems at United States plants. The company said that nearly all of its domestic plant sites would be affected.
Also, there was a $43 million charge for an expected loss from the sale of the Astech division of Alcoa Composites Inc., a subsidiary. Astech, formerly a part of TRW Inc., was acquired by Alcoa in 1986 and was put up for sale a year ago.
For the year, Alcoa earned $295.2 million, or $3.40 a share, compared with record earnings in 1989 of $944.9 million, or $10.67 a share. Total revenue for the year slipped to $10.87 billion from $11.16 billion in 1989.
The Pittsburgh-based company has de-emphasizsed its non-aluminum operations in recent years under its chairman, Paul H. O'Neill. It sold several businesses in plastics and in composite materials, choosing instead to focus on aluminum. Aerospace and industrial products now account for 28 percent of revenue.
 
Falling Prices
 But aluminum ingot prices have fallen in the last year, hurting earnings. The price of aluminum averaged about 75 cents a pound in 1990, compared with about 89 cents in 1989. Also, results of Brazilian operations plunged because of actions by the Government there to curb inflation. Earnings from Brazil dropped to less than $1 million in 1990 from $104 million in 1989, the company said.
Despite the fourth-quarter loss, analysts said that Alcoa's alumunim business remained firm regardless of a downturn in the economy. Analysts also said that the supply and demand patterns in the industry were in balance and that Alcoa would likely fare well, unless the price of aluminum eroded further.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Alcoa shares rose $1.25 each, to $59.75.

HEADLINE: Nissan Plans New Factory For Engines in Tennessee

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 18

 BODY:
The Nissan Motor Company said today that it planned to build a second plant in the United States that would make automobile engines, enabling the company to increase the domestic content of its American-assembled cars.
Nissan, Japan's second-largest auto maker, plans to spend more than $500 million on the new plant, which will be in Decherd, Tenn. Decherd is about 60 miles from Smyrna, Tenn., where Nissan makes subcompact cars and small pickup trucks.
With tensions rising again between Washington and Tokyo over Japan's huge trade surplus, Nissan's move may help blunt criticism that the company has been slow to increase the domestic content of the vehicles it assembles in this country. Domestic content covers not only components like engines and transmissions, but also all other aspects of a manufacturing operation from the labor force to the source of the food served in the employee cafeteria.
 
 Company's View of U.S. Role

The announcement also strengthens Nissan's argument that the company is adding jobs and increasing the technical sophistication of its American operations. 
 Nissan's Smyrna plant is not unionized. A spokesman for the United Automobile Workers said the union "consistently has welcomed the creation of jobs in the U.S. by those who sell extensively in the U.S. market."
While there are clear political advantages to adding American plants, such moves can end up hurting Japanese car makers financially, because of Federal rules on calculating the corporate average fuel economy for a company's output of vehicles.
The rules classify vehicles with less than 75 percent domestic content as imports. Separate calculations are made for an auto maker's domestically made and foreign-made fleets, but each category must meet the standard of a fleet average of at least 27.5 miles a gallon. Using more American-made components could shift some of Nissan's output from the import to the domestic category, altering the mix of higher-mileage and lower-mileage vehicles in each category and possibly subjecting the company to stiff Federal penalties for not meeting the mileage standard.
 
Part of Long-Range Plan
 "This new plant is part of our long-range plan to increase the localization of parts in the United States and reduce imports from Japan," said Jerry L. Benefield, president and chief executive officer of Nissan's American manufacturing arm.
People familiar with Nissan's operations said executives had not intended to announce plans for the new plant for several weeks. But the news began to leak out in Japan, possibly in connection with trade talks going on in Tokyo between the American and Japanese Governments.
The new plant will be highly automated, Nissan executives said, employing 500 workers who will produce 300,000 engines a year. Production is scheduled to begin in early 1996.
"Engines are one of the heaviest components, so they are very costly to bring over from Japan," said Ron Harbour, an automotive manufacturing consultant in Troy, Mich. "But they are also the most critical component, so control of quality is very critical. That may have been one reason Nissan waited this long to set up engine production in U.S."
 
Possible Link to Other Plant
 Nissan executives would not say whether the plant's engines would go into vehicles made in Smyrna, where the company built about 96,000 Sentra subcompact cars and 139,000 light trucks last year.
Nissan now imports the engines in many of those vehicles from Japan and Mexico. But four-cylinder engines for the Sentra are assembled in the Smyrna plant from parts imported from Mexico and Japan.
Nissan's announcement, which caught some industry analysts and rival automobile executives by surprise, comes seven weeks after the Toyota Motor Corporation said it would double the capacity of its assembly plant in Georgetown, Ky.

HEADLINE: Japan's Homeless: Seen Yet Ignored

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YOKOHAMA, Japan

 BODY:
In a silent, dark alley near piers that bustle during the day, a few small piles of cardboard and blankets are all that keep the late-night chill from 10 sleeping men, a handful of the scores of homeless vagrants of this otherwise prosperous port.
"I chose this way of life myself, no one chose it for me," said Yuji Inoue, a grizzled 64-year-old unemployed construction worker, stirring momentarily for a cigarette and some conversation. "The people who come by and see me, well, no one is hostile. But nobody's giving me money either." 
 Like the United States and Europe, Japan is scarred by homelessness created by the stresses of advanced development. But the phenomenon is little discussed in a society that emphasizes its economic triumphs rather than those the miracle has trampled or left behind.
Census takers leave it up to local officials to give out the numbers of the homeless, and most decline to do so. The National Police Agency also refuses to divulge its estimates.
 
Becoming Ordinary
 Yet Japanese have become accustomed to the sight of derelicts camped in tunnels, under highways and inside train stations in Tokyo, Yokohama and Osaka. No one knows how many there are, but perhaps thousands of people may live that way part of the time.
Like their American counterparts, many suffer from alcoholism and mental illness, raising questions about how to help them while respecting their civil rights. As in the United States, the police here say they cannot sweep them from the streets unless they disrupt traffic or are disorderly.
But in contrast with the United States and some European countries, Japan has not been emptying its mental institutions into the streets. Last June, 336,271 patients were counted in mental hospitals, nearly twice as many as 25 years ago.
Some experts say more Japanese homeless are from ethnic minorities than the population at large. The minorities here include Koreans and other foreign nationalities and the descendants of the Burakumin, an ancient Untouchable-like lower class, but there are no statistics.
And unlike the United States, Japan is not faced with large numbers of entire families without homes, or people with jobs who cannot find housing. Drugs are not a major problem, but drinking and gambling are epidemic.
 
Lining Up for Jobs
 Generally, the homeless in Japan's major cities live in and near the areas where large populations of laborers reside in flophouses and line up in the morning for part-time construction jobs, usually at shape-ups run by organized crime. One such neighborhood in Yokohama is Kotobukicho, which means, roughly, town of congratulations for a long life.
"This area is a showcase of Japan's problems," said the Rev. Hidetoshi Watanabe, a local pastor. "There's worker exploitation, old men isolated from their families, discrimination against foreigners, minorities, the mentally and physically disabled -- and of course alcoholism."
Several local groups in Yokohama seek to help the homeless as well as the larger group of perhaps 7,000, most of them men, who live in squalid Kotobukicho, a trash-strewn corner of the downtown area where the streets are often filled with drunken and gambling vagrants.
Before it was razed in the American bombings of World War II, the neighborhood of Kotobukicho was a prosperous place of shops and homes. When it was rebuilt, the city chose it for dozens of cheap hotels to house laborers doing construction at the harbor and nearby American navy base.
 
Many Refuse Aid
 Today the people who work with the residents here estimate that half the derelict population spends part of the year in the streets, often when they are out of work or want to sleep off drinking bouts. Many are eligible for welfare or disability payments but choose not to accept.
"It may be an oversimplification, but I think most of the homeless are there because they want to enjoy their freedom," said Yoshinori Shibuya, a senior official in the Yokohama social welfare bureau. "We urge them to accept welfare payments or to go the hospital, but 80 percent refuse."
Census takers found 191 homeless people in Yokohama last October, but social workers think the number at its peak in the summer is twice that. That is a small number, perhaps, for a city of three million but startling because of the concentration of the homeless at downtown parks and public buildings.
Another peak time for the homeless is the New Year's period, when construction work is generally shut down for the holiday, cutting off the income for workers. At this time, Yokohama, like Tokyo and Osaka, puts up a temporary shelter -- in this case, for 200 people, in a small city park.
"If I earned a little more, I could move to a high-class hotel," said Masateru Nakano, a longtime resident, shrugging his shoulders. "But when I get money, I spend it on my women and on drinking, so there are a lot of times when I have to sleep on the street. Life isn't so easy for me."
 
No-Win Situation
 City officials say they are criticized by groups seeking to help the homeless for not doing enough and by other Yokohama residents for doing too much, thereby supposedly making it too easy to be homeless.
Yokohama spends $2 million a year for services in Kotobukicho, including running two large centers with indoor lounges, television rooms, health clinics, bathing facilities and eating areas. The city also pays welfare or disability grants to more than 2,200 residents of the area.
On a recent afternoon at one shelter, 40 men in tattered clothing were slouching in chairs, watching spangle-clad iceskaters on television. Elsewhere, men were using the laundry rooms and bathing areas, and some were just sleeping in corners.
Outside, knots of men stood at illegal gambling dens, drinking, stamping their feet in the cold and scanning pages of listings of boat races, horse races and other events. Residents say Kotobukicho has several offices of yakuza, or organized crime syndicates, that run gambling or labor operations.
The urgency of city efforts to get people off the streets deepened in 1983, when some junior high school students threw rocks and assaulted and beat some homeless people, killing three. In Kotobukicho, volunteers now patrol the homeless areas twice a week in the winter and once a month at other times.
 
'A Shameful Thing'
 Their aim is simply to make sure they are all right, offering blankets and encouraging them to sign up for welfare, unemployment or disability grants.
"We are careful not to become too familiar with the people we help because it's a shameful thing for them," said Yoh Nonomura, a volunteer. "They get annoyed even if we ask them their names. They generally want to be left alone."
Last week, dozens of residents lined up at the city-sponsored temporary shelters for free steaming bowls of rice and vegetables distributed by the Kabukicho Day Laborers Union. That evening, volunteers spread out with food and blankets in the streets and parks.
One volunteer was Masaaki Kagoshima, a bearded and ponytailed organizer specializing in helping the conditions of Koreans, Filipinos, Bangladeshis and other foreign laborers who make up a part of the homeless.
"The problems in this area are the inevitable product of a huge and highly developed consumer society," Mr. Kagosima said. "Kotobukicho is really a kind of third world society concentrated within Japan."
Late at night, Mr. Kagoshima drove alone in his van with two visitors to the first building near the docks, where Mr. Inoue was sleeping with 10 friends. He said he and the others usually gathered up their blankets at the end of each night and hid them safely out of sight during the day.
 
'I Didn't Want to Beg'
 "If I went to the shelter at night, my things would be stolen," he said, gesturing to the bedding, clothes and pillow piled in a corner. "When I started this way of life seven years ago, I didn't want to beg for help from the government. I just don't like to beg for help."
The next stop was a park at City Hall, where Mr. Kagoshima said hello to a man and a woman underneath blankets with their dog. "Some people can't stay in the hotels because they don't allow dogs," Mr. Kagoshima said. He asked the couple whether they needed blankets, and they said no.
At the Kannae train station, 20 men were lying in blankets along an indoor tunnel as Mr. Kagoshima and other volunteers handed out plastic bowls of hot soup and small Japanese oranges. He placed a flier about a meeting the next day on a sleeping man's back, using an orange as a paperweight.
Nearby, Yoshiaki Nakamura, a 55-year-old tunnel resident with wavy gray hair, was gulping onion soup. "I'm satisfied with my way of life," he said, "and I don't think of myself as an unlucky person.," He said he earned about $12 a day from picking up cardboard from trash cans and selling it to recyclers.
Among Yokohama welfare officials, homelessness is one of many problems faced by Japan today, particularly the problems of old people and handicapped generally. "Of course, homelessness is a vital issue," Mr. Shibuya said. "But I wouldn't give it more priority than other problems we face."
But for Mr. Kagoshima, the issue of homelessness symbolizes the need for Japanese to face up to the indifference, if not antagonism, toward people with physical and mental handicaps. "If we don't overcome this hostility," he said, "Japan will become two worlds talking past each other."

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Narrowed in November

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit fell 12 percent in November, to $9.7 billion, the Commerce Department reported today, as the weakening economy dampened demand for oil and other imports.
Even though oil prices were still rising during the month, the nation's petroleum bill fell by 13 percent, the largest drop in at least three years, as volume fell by 14 percent. Industry, motorists and other users cut back their purchases as the higher prices ate into their buying power. 
 "With a slowing economy, this shows that we've adjusted to higher prices," said Stephen Cooney, the director of international investment at the National Association of Manufacturers.
A United States success in the war in the Persian Gulf that started two days ago, he added, "should mean no long-term effect on oil prices."
 
A Widespread Decline

Virtually all other major categories of imports declined as well, including automobiles, which had risen nearly 40 percent in October.
The November trade shortfall -- the excess of imports over exports -- was below a revised deficit of $10.99 billion for October, originally reported at $11.61 billion.
The report showed that total merchandise imports fell 6 percent, to $43.32 billion. Exports were also off, but by a lesser amount, 4 percent, to $33.62 billion.
"The big import decline confirms a recession," said David Rolley, a senior economist at DRI/MCGraw Hill. He predicted a "further substantial decline" in imports in coming months as the economy continues to fall.
Next Friday, when the Government issues its first report on output in the fourth quarter of 1990, many economists expect it to show an annual rate of decline of around 3 to 3.5 percent. Such a drop would follow nearly eight years of steady growth, a period of expansion second only to the record 106 months of growth during the Vietnam War buildup of the 1960's.
Although exports slackened during November, foreign sales -- now serving as one of the main economic props -- were at their third-highest level on record. Many economists described the decline in exports as a normal monthly fluctuation.
Still, just about every major category of exports fell, with declines of around $200 million each in computers, chemicals and electrical and specialized machinery. Food was among the few buoyant export sectors.
 
Decline in Growth

Michael R. Darby, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, pointed out that export growth has actually been falling during the last three years, but stressed that exports still remain an important source of general economic growth, helped by the dollar's decline during 1990.
The dollar's exchange rate -- near postwar lows against other major currencies -- makes United States products more competitive by lowering their prices in other currencies.
According to Mr. Darby's calculations, exports were rising at a rate of 30 percent in 1988, 13 percent in 1989 and 8 percent in the first 10 months of 1990.
Ian A. MacKinnon, senior vice president for the Vanguard Group of Investment Companies in Valley Forge, Pa., said the deterioration in the deficit since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq was almost entirely attributable to the jump in oil prices after the invasion.
He predicted that if the dollar continues about where it is now, "We believe the country will be in a position of trade surplus in two years."
 
 Record Set in 1987
 The trade deficit has been narrowing since 1987, when it rose to a record $152 billion. In 1989 the gap declined to $109.40 billion, from $118.53 billion in 1988. The annual rate for the first 11 months of 1990 was $103.58 billion.
Two-thirds of the November drop in imports was accounted for by petroleum. The volume of oil imports was off 14 percent, to 214 million barrels, from 249 million in Octoer. Volume had declined 2 percent in October after rising sharply in September.
The average price for a barrel of oil imported in November was $29.44, or 40 cents more than in October and $10.30 a barrel more than the average price in the first 10 months of 1990.
The price of oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange closed today at $19.25.
The bilateral deficits with most trading partners declined in November. The gap with Japan narrowed to $3.79 billion, from $4.45 billion in October.
The second-highest deficit in November was with China, which has sharply expanded its exports of textiles, toys and other products in recent years. The deficit with China eased to $1.078 billion, from $1.175 billion in October, and it just nosed out Canada. The deficit with Canada stood at $1.070 billion, compared with $1.354 billion in October.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq;
RAIDS SAID TO CUT POWER IN BAGHDAD

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Sketchy reports from Western news agencies and television correspondents suggest that the Iraqi capital has lost its electricity and telephone service and is suffering a severe shortage of water.
A third day of bombardment and the wail of air raid sirens have reportedly sent thousands more civilians fleeing for the countryside and other Iraqi cities. 
Most Baghdad residents have stayed indoors, using candles for light, since the United States began its military campaign Wednesday night. Food in freezers and refrigerators has spoiled, according to Reuters news agency reports, and residents are described as worried about food shortages.
In one of the few news dispatches from Baghdad, Maamoun Youssef, an Iraqi who has reported for over a decade for Reuters, painted a bleak picture of a ghost town of closed markets, shops and restaurants, with only a few militiamen and civilians on the streets. Most filling stations are closed but drivers have flocked to those with hand-operated pumps, he said. Mr. Youssef, operating under restrictions placed on journalists by the Iraqi authorities, described civilians praying "for the safety of their families as bombs shake homes and rattle windows."
 
Damage Hard to Assess
 Since the attacks began, President Bush and his military advisers have said key strategic and military sites in Baghdad are being bombed with pinpoint accuracy, maintaining that civilian targets have been scrupulously avoided. But neither official American statements nor sketchy information from Iraq provide a detailed picture of the damage or the impact on Iraq's civilian population.
Normal communication to the Iraqi capital has been cut; the authorities imposed censorship rules today on the few remaining foreign correspondents and on foreign news agencies. Monitoring of official statements on Baghdad Radio and from the Iraqi News Agency were left as the the main source of news.
According to the agencies involved, 10 foreign journalists from Cable News Network, the Associated Press and the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation left Baghdad today in a four-car convoy to Jordan. Three CNN correspondents stayed despite the impossiblity of communication. During the war with Iran, Iraq resricted reporting of sensitive strategic and military data, particularly reports of attacks on Baghdad.
The Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, made no public statements today, and there was no report on Iraq's state-controlled media of his activities. But at a briefing at the Pentagon, Rear Adm. John McConnell, director of intelligence for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said that the United States believed that Mr. Hussein "is maintaining control over all elements of his armed forces."
 
Futility of Assessment
 Arab diplomats in contact with the Baghdad Government believe that Mr. Hussein will keep a low profile during the air attacks and wait to fight back from a position of strength if the war shifts to the ground.
Senior Administration officials say they are baffled by Mr. Hussein's intentions. "We've stopped trying to figure out his thinking," one senior official said.
Part of the difficulty for these officials is that there are few people who know him well, and those who do are reluctant to speak. Even Iraqi exiles who have long known Mr. Hussein acknowledge that they cannot predict his next move.
"Maybe he is out of his mind or crazy or maybe he'd like to die as a hero," said Hani al-Fekaiki, who served as a member of Iraq's ruling Revolutionary Command Council in the brief Baath Party rule in 1963. He said he first met Mr. Hussein in prison in 1958. "I'm beginning to think he will keep fighting no matter what the result will be," Mr. al-Fekaiki said. "Anyone in his place should have withdrawn two weeks ago. I just don't know. What I do know is that we, the Iraqi people, will never forgive the United States for bombing Iraq. You supported Saddam and now when you get cross with him you are asking our people to pay the price."
 
Echoes of Enemy Heard
 In recent weeks Mr. Hussein, a secularist, has increasingly borrowed the messianic language of his late enemy, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran. Mr. Hussein's speech on Thursday, his only public comment since the assault, was filled with religious imagery, portraying Mr. Bush as Satan and the Iraqi people as "the descendants of prophets and believers." In place of hailing Iraq's military might and denouncing Americans as lacking the will to fight, he presented himself as a victim of external treachery and fatalistically called on God to bring him victory.
One indication of Mr. Hussein's disdain for surrender came today from the Baghdad Radio, which said that attacking forces would face a long, bloody war. Another came from Saadi Mehdi Saleh, the Speaker of Iraq's Parliament, who described steps to defend Baghdad. In remarks quoted by the Baghdad Radio, he said that hundreds of thousands of weapons had been distributed to the people of Baghdad, turning the capital into "a jungle of fighters and trenches."
The Baghdad Radio also broadcast military reports that, like its communiques in the war with Iran, included claims of Iraqi successes.
In one communique, Iraq asserted that it shot down 22 allied aircraft Friday afternoon, saying this brought to 94 the number shot down since the war began. The allied command said seven aircraft had been shot down: three American, two British and one each from Italy and Kuwait.
 
'Wailing of Its Daughter'
 Iraq's confirmation of its missile strike on Israel came from over the official radio about eight hours after the attack. Iraq struck "political, economic and scientific targets" in "the criminal Zionist entity with long-range missiles to avenge the suffering of the Arab and Muslim people," the radio said. "Let the United States hear the wailing of its daughter implanted in the heart of the Arab homeland," the radio dispatch said.
Iraq also asserted on its radio today that Israel sent 64 planes to join the multinational force in Saudi Arabia, the home of Islam's holiest shrines, a claim that Saudi authorities swiftly denied. Shortly after the first American troops landed in Saudi Arabia last August, Iraq charged that Israeli pilots had painted their planes like American aircraft.
The Iraqi Information Minister, Latif Nassif al-Jassem, a close associate of Mr. Hussein, told foreign journalists in Baghdad on Friday that Iraq had captured American pilots shot down in air raids. When he was asked by Peter Arnett of CNN, who remains in Baghdad, the Minister said that the pilots would be shown to journalists.
In a briefing at the Pentagon today, Lieut. Gen. Thomas Kelly, the director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said that seven American pilots are listed as missing but "We know of no American prisoners of war at all."

PUB-DATE: January 19, 1991

SECTION: Section 1; Page 6; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Turkey;
U.S. IS SAID TO USE TURKISH AIR BASES

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Using Turkish bases to open a second front in the air war against Iraq, United States planes began bombing runs on Iraqi military targets today, foreign diplomats here said.
The American raids on northwestern Iraq were said to have come with the Turkish Government's blessing, a decision of supreme delicacy for this Muslim country where opposition leaders, news commentators and many ordinary Turks warned that they were being dragged unwisely into a war against an Arab neighbor. 
 So sensitive was Turkey's reported approval of air strikes that both the Government and the United States Embassy refused to acknowledge that they had occurred. Foreign Ministry spokesmen issued a statement confirming that 27 warplanes had taken off this morning in the early hours, but added that the flight was "purely for night training."
Non-American diplomats said, however, that the planes, an assortment of fighters and bombers, had struck at targets in northwestern Iraq, some after refueling at the eastern Turkish city of Batman. They then returned three hours later the Incirlik Air Base near the southern city of Adana, 430 miles from the Iraqi border.
 
Turks All but Confirm It
 News reports from Washington quoted unidentified Bush Administration officials as saying much the same as the Ankara diplomats. Moreover, Turkey's President, Turgut Ozal, all but agreed tonight that the raids had taken place, although he stopped short of a full confirmation.
"The flights started as training," he told a Turkish television interviewer. "But they had permission beforehand, and afterwards they may have gone somewhere else."
On Thursday, at Mr. Ozal's behest, Parliament authorized United States air strikes from Turkish soil, and the Government gave its formal, and fully expected, approval today.
The Americans are in the process of doubling their number of war planes at Incirlik to 96, and they are also bringing in Patriot air-defense missiles. Being able to strike at Iraq from Turkey gives the United States more flexibility and more firepower from the north in the air war.
In return for their help, the Turks have won pledges from Washington of more military equipment, new economic assistance and trade concessions and promises from the Administration to seek a sharp increase in military aid next year.
